Authors: Oliveira P., McKee S., Coles C.
Title: Optimal scheduling of a hydro thermal power generation system
Affiliations: Department of Mathematics, University of Strathclyde, Glasgow, Scotland, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Oliveira, P., Department of Mathematics, University of Strathclyde, Glasgow, Scotland, United Kingdom; McKee, S., Department of Mathematics, University of Strathclyde, Glasgow, Scotland, United Kingdom; Coles, C., Department of Mathematics, University of Strathclyde, Glasgow, Scotland, United Kingdom
Abstract: In this study we present the weekly optimization of a power system consisting of hydro and thermal units. The mathematical model, a mixed integer (linear) programming problem, is discussed and the solution of the unit commitment and economic dispatch problem is determined over a period of a week on an hourly basis. The system contains 840 integer variables and 1344 continuous variables, with sparsity of 0.11%. This work allows both the water in the hydro unit and in the pump-storage unit to be costed. © 1993.
Author Keywords: Branch and bound; Energy; Optimization; Scheduling
Index Keywords: Costs; Economics; Electric power generation; Electric power systems; Hydroelectric power; Linear programming; Mathematical models; Optimization; Water; Branch and bound; Economic dispatch; Hydro thermal power generation system; Optimal scheduling; Thermal units; Unit commitment; Scheduling

Authors: Fontenla J.M.
Title: Generation of electric currents in two-dimensional magnetic nulls
Affiliations: University of Alabama in Huntsville, EB-136M, Huntsville, AL 35899, United States
Authors with affiliations: Fontenla, J.M., University of Alabama in Huntsville, EB-136M, Huntsville, AL 35899, United States
Abstract: We present detailed calculations and results for a model case of two-dimensional small distortions of static, current-free equilibrium around a null-line magnetic configuration. This setup has been studied for fast energy release in flares, but has not been studied before in the context of the magnetic energy buildup that precedes the flare. Our analytical results are new because they include gas pressure and provide explicit formulae for the expressions of all quantities (and especially the electric current) and energy storage as functions of the values of boundary conditions. A general solution is shown as a combination of eigenfunctions, with coefficients resulting from the boundary conditions. These boundary conditions are given in terms of any arbitrary plasma acceleration at a boundary enclosing the domain we study. The approach used here studies the MHD evolution of the electric current and plasma density variations driven by external forces. We find that both pressure and Lorentz forces are important, and that their boundary values select between a wide range of solutions, many of which have been found previously in numerical simulations. Most of the modes we find display strong current sheets, velocities, and pressure variations at the separatrices. Also we find that Joule and other dissipative terms are not important for typical cases, except at an extremely narrow inner core, and near the separatrices. We discuss our results and their relationship to numerical MHD simulations.
Author Keywords: MHD; Sun: magnetic fields

Authors: Xie T., Liu J., Fischbeck H.J.
Title: Further investigation of proton elastic scattering cross-section on carbon and silicon
Affiliations: Linfield Research Institute, McMinnville, OR 97128, United States; Department of Medical Physics, Rush Presbyterian-St. Luke's Medical Center, 1653 W. Congress Pkwy, Chicago, IL 60612, United States; Department of Physics, University of Oklahoma, Norman, OK 73019, United States
Authors with affiliations: Xie, T., Linfield Research Institute, McMinnville, OR 97128, United States; Liu, J., Department of Medical Physics, Rush Presbyterian-St. Luke's Medical Center, 1653 W. Congress Pkwy, Chicago, IL 60612, United States; Fischbeck, H.J., Department of Physics, University of Oklahoma, Norman, OK 73019, United States
Abstract: Elastic scattering cross-sections of protons on carbon and silicon in the energy region of 450 to 2200 kev have been measured at a laboratory scattering angle of 155°. digitized data of proton elastic scattering on carbon and silicon at different laboratory angles transferred mathematically from the previous graphic data were also listed. The present measured data have been tested on proton elastic scattering spectra of several samples with the aid of computer simulation. The results showed that these data worked reasonably well. Comparison between the measured data and the previous data showed good agreement. This fact indicates that the method used to transfer the previous graphic data to digitized data is reliable and useful. © 1993.
Index Keywords: Backscattering; Carbon; Computer simulation; Data transfer; Digital storage; Elasticity; Protons; Resonance; Silicon; Surface phenomena; Digitized data; Graphic data; Proton elastic scattering cross section; Scattering

Abstract: The FENICE detector, installed at the Frascati e+ e- storage ring ADONE, for measuring the neutron e.m. form factors in the timelike region, is described. FENICE is a nonmagnetic detector and consists of a complex array of scintillators, limited streamer tubes and iron converters for detecting mainly the process e+ e- → nn. Antineutrons are identified by the charged prongs produced in their annihilation and the antineutron velocity is measured by the retrieved annihilation time with respect to the beam crossing time. Neutrons are detected in plastic scintillator layers. To reduce the cosmic rays background a concrete shield, covered by an active veto system, is added. © 1993.
Index Keywords: Accelerator shielding; Colliding beam accelerators; Electron beams; High energy physics; Interference suppression; Neutrons; Scintillation counters; Storage rings; Velocity measurement; Antineutrons; Electron positron collider ADONE; FENICE detector; Neutron electromagnetic form factors; Particle annihilation; Particle detectors

Authors: McGahan W.A., Makovicka T., Hale J., Woolam J.A.
Title: Carbon overcoats with controlled properties: non-destructive ellipsometry evaluation
Affiliations: Center for Microelectronic and Optical Materials Research, Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Nebraska-Lincoln, Lincoln, NE 68588-0511, United States; J.A. Woollam Company, 650 J Street, Lincoln, NE 68508, United States
Authors with affiliations: McGahan, W.A., Center for Microelectronic and Optical Materials Research, Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Nebraska-Lincoln, Lincoln, NE 68588-0511, United States, J.A. Woollam Company, 650 J Street, Lincoln, NE 68508, United States; Woolam, J.A., Center for Microelectronic and Optical Materials Research, Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Nebraska-Lincoln, Lincoln, NE 68588-0511, United States, J.A. Woollam Company, 650 J Street, Lincoln, NE 68508, United States
Abstract: Hard carbon thin films have been prepared on fused silica substrates by r.f. plasma deposition and magnetron sputtering using mixtures of argon and methane gases. By controlling the deposition power and gas pressure amorphous carbon films with optical energy gaps ranging from zero to above 2.0 eV were prepared and characterized by variable-angle-of-incidence spectroscopic ellipsometry (VASE). A parametric model was developed based on the measured optical constants as function of optical energy gap which allows the measurement of the thickness and optical constants of thin carbon films on opaque substrates with the VASE technique only. Applications of this model to the characterization of carbon overcoats on magnetic disk structures are presented as well. © 1993.
Index Keywords: Carbon; Ellipsometry; Films; Magnetic disk storage; Nondestructive examination; Plasma devices; Sputtering; Carbon overcoats; Optical energy gaps; Coatings

Authors: Schipper W.J., Hoogendorp M.F., Blasse G.
Title: The luminescence and X-ray storage properties of Pr3+ and Ce3+ in YNbO4 and M′-YTaO4
Affiliations: Debye Research Institute, University of Utrecht, P.O. Box 80, 000, 3508 TA Utrecht, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Schipper, W.J., Debye Research Institute, University of Utrecht, P.O. Box 80, 000, 3508 TA Utrecht, Netherlands; Hoogendorp, M.F., Debye Research Institute, University of Utrecht, P.O. Box 80, 000, 3508 TA Utrecht, Netherlands; Blasse, G., Debye Research Institute, University of Utrecht, P.O. Box 80, 000, 3508 TA Utrecht, Netherlands
Abstract: The luminescence of Pr3+ in YNbO4 and YTaO4 is described. Emissions from both the 3P0 and the 1D2 levels are observed, the latter of which is dominant. The Ce3+ ion does not luminesce in these hosts; its presence quenches the host lattice emission as well. This is ascribed to a metal-to-metal charge transfer state at low energy. A comparison to other cases of quenched Ce3+ luminescence is made. YTaO4:Pr acts as a photostimulable X-ray storage phosphor, which may also be filled by UV irradiation. © 1993.
Index Keywords: Crystal lattices; Energy storage; Ions; Light emission; Luminescence of solids; Phosphors; Ultraviolet radiation; X rays; Yttrium compounds; Host lattice emission; Metal to metal charge transfer state; X ray storage; Yttrium niobate; Yttrium tantalate; Rare earth compounds

Authors: Meli F., Züttel A., Schlapbach L.
Title: Electrochemical and surface properties of low cost, cobalt-free LaNi5-type hydrogen storage alloys
Affiliations: Institut de Physique, Université, 1700 Fribourg, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Meli, F., Institut de Physique, Université, 1700 Fribourg, Switzerland; Züttel, A., Institut de Physique, Université, 1700 Fribourg, Switzerland; Schlapbach, L., Institut de Physique, Université, 1700 Fribourg, Switzerland
Abstract: For many applications AB5 type hydrogen storage alloys are still too expensive. We report on the results of studies aimed at lowering the alloy costs by partial substitutions of A and B elements respectively. We have improved the capacity of silicon-containing cobalt-free AB5-type alloys by optimization of the La:Ce ratio in the A component and by the substitution of aluminium by manganese in the B component. The alloy Lm0.5Mm0.5Ni4.2Mn0.2Al0.3Si0.3 (Mm, rare earth mischmetal; Lm, lanthanum-rich mischmetal) showed a maximum capacity of 270 mA h g-1 and good cycling stability, i.e. the optimum in price/performance ratio. Substitution of larger amounts of nickel with copper could further lower the price of such alloys; however, these copper-containing alloys showed low kinetics and a slow activation. Electrochemical measurements were carried out on ten different single-phase AB5 alloys and on a two-phase AB5.36-type alloy. Up to 500 charge-discharge cycles were performed. Samples were characterized using X-ray diffraction, scanning electron microscopy, energy-dispersive X-ray analysis and photoelectron spectroscopy. Photoelectron spectroscopic analysis of Lm0.5Mm0.5Ni2.4Cu2Mn0.25Si0.35 after 30 electrochemical charge-discharge cycles points to a thick nickel oxide top surface layer, no enrichment of metallic nickel in near surface layers and to a slightly enhanced metallic copper subsurface layer. No passivating silicon surface oxide film could be found. We attribute the low electrochemical kinetics of this alloy to the absence of metallic nickel at the electrode-electrolyte interface. © 1993.
Index Keywords: Chemical activation; Electrochemistry; Lanthanum alloys; Photoelectron spectroscopy; Rare earth elements; Reaction kinetics; Scanning electron microscopy; Secondary batteries; Substitution reactions; Surface properties; X ray analysis; Electrochemical cycling stability; Hydrogen storage alloys; Lanthanum rich mischmetal; Rare earth mischmetal; Intermetallics

Authors: Ruggiero A.G.
Title: Nuclear fusion of protons with ions of boron
Affiliations: Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, Long Island, 11973, NY, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ruggiero, A.G., Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, Long Island, 11973, NY, United States
Abstract: This paper describes a method of extracting energy from the fusion events occurring between the collision of a beam of protons with a beam of ions of11B. The two beams are circulating in separated and intersecting storage rings where they collide head-on in a common long-straight section. Requirements on the beam parameters in the collider are presented. Limitations due to space-charge forces are discussed; it is found necessary to provide beam-charge neutralization with electrons. The paper discusses also the effects of Coulomb scattering between particles of the same beam and in the opposing beams. Methods are proposed for controlling the electromagnetic interaction. © 1993 Società Italiana di Fisica.
Author Keywords: Fusion reactors and thermonuclear power studies

Authors: Meier W.R., Waganer L.M.
Title: Recent heavy-ion fusion power plant studies in the US
Affiliations: W. J. Schafer Associates, Inc., 303 Lindbergh Avenue, Livermore, 94550, CA, United States; McDonnell Douglas Aerospace, St. Louis, P.O. Box 516, MO, United States
Authors with affiliations: Meier, W.R., W. J. Schafer Associates, Inc., 303 Lindbergh Avenue, Livermore, 94550, CA, United States; Waganer, L.M., McDonnell Douglas Aerospace, St. Louis, P.O. Box 516, MO, United States
Abstract: The United States Department of Energy (DOE) sponsored two studies of inertial fusion energy (IFE) electric power plants, one led by McDonnell Douglas Aerospace (MDA) and the other led by W. J. Schafer Associates (WJSA). These studies, which were completed in March of 1992, included the conceptual design and analysis of two KrF-laser and two heavy-ion-driven power plants. The reactor and driver designs for the heavy-ion power plants are described in this paper. The MDA team design, Prometheus-H, features a wetted-wall chamber, a compact induction linac driver, and channel propagation for beam delivery. The single-beam driver uses storage rings to accumulate a series of pulses before delivery to the target. The use of storage rings and a folded linear section results in a compact footprint and significant cost savings compared to a straight multiple-beam linac. Fourteen beams of doubly-charged, 4 GeV Pb ions are used to deliver 7 MJ on the target at a pulse repetition rate of 3.5 Hz with an overall driver efficiency of 21%. The channel propagation mode requires only two small, diametrically opposed holes through the blanket and first wall; this approach maximizes the wall coverage and minimizes radiation leakage and contamination of the beamlines. Th resulting target gain is 103 for a yield of 719 MJ per pulse. The Prometheus chamber has a Pb-cooled, porous SiC first wall and a He-cooled Li2O breeding blanket. The blanket structural material is low-activation SiC. The thermal conversion efficiency is 43%, and the net electric power is 1000 MWe. The WJSA team design, Osiris, uses a wetted-wall chamber, a multiple-beam induction linac driver, and ballistic focus with auto-neutralization. The driver design is conservative in that it uses singly charged ions and does not use beam combination or splitting. Twelve beams are close-packed in order to use common cores and focusing magnets. The accelerator costs were reduced by operating at spacecharge-limited current density and standardizing the quadrupole and inductor designs. In this case, twelve beams of 3.8 GeV Xe ions provide a total of 5 MJ at a pulse repetition rate of 4.6 Hz. The overall driver efficiency is 28%, the target gain is 87, and the yield is 432 MJ per pulse. The Osiris chamber uses a flexible, porous carbon/carbon fabric to contain the flow of the molten salt Flibe, which serves as the primary coolant and breeding material. The vacuum vessel structure is a carbon/carbon composite. The thermal conversion efficiency is 45%, and the net electric power is 1000 MWe. © 1993 Società Italiana di Fisica.
Author Keywords: Fusion reactors and thermonuclear ppwer studies

Authors: Raasch D., Reck J.
Title: Anisotropy, wall energy density, and exchange stiffness of amorphous (Gd,Dy)-(Fe,Co) films
Affiliations: Philips GmbH Forschungslaboratorium Aachen, Weisshausstrasse 2, D-5100 Aachen, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Raasch, D., Philips GmbH Forschungslaboratorium Aachen, Weisshausstrasse 2, D-5100 Aachen, Germany; Reck, J., Philips GmbH Forschungslaboratorium Aachen, Weisshausstrasse 2, D-5100 Aachen, Germany
Abstract: The uniaxial anisotropy Ku and the magnetic domain wall energy density σw are important quantities for the thermomagnetically information storage process and its modeling. Ku was measured on (Gd,Dy)-(Fe,Co) films in dependence on temperature and Dy content. It increased linearly with increasing Dy content. Ku and the coercive field H c are related by the equation Hc=αKu n/μ0Ms with the fitting parameters α and n. At room temperature σw was determined from the difference of the switching fields for expanding and collapsing of thermomagnetically written circular domains on magneto-optical disks. The disks were prepared by electron beam evaporation with Dy contents between 5 and 35 at. %; the composition was adjusted to yield samples with a Curie temperature TC close to 500 K. The wall energy density increased with the Dy content. The exchange stiffness A was derived from measured σw and Ku data using the simple Bloch wall equation A= σw2/16Ku. The exchange stiffness was found independent on the Dy content to be 3.1×10-12±0. 8×10-12 J/m. The resulting A was in agreement to literature data for amorphous Gd33Fe67 alloys.

Authors: Schneider H., Tobehn I., Rückert M., Brinkmann U., Hippler R.
Title: Experiments at the Giessen source TEPOS with low energy positrons
Affiliations: Strahlenzentrum der Universität Giessen, Leihgesterner Weg 217, Giessen, D-6300, Germany; Fakultät für Physik, Universität Bielefeld, Universitätsstrasse 25, Bielefeld 1, D-4800, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Schneider, H., Strahlenzentrum der Universität Giessen, Leihgesterner Weg 217, Giessen, D-6300, Germany; Tobehn, I., Strahlenzentrum der Universität Giessen, Leihgesterner Weg 217, Giessen, D-6300, Germany; Rückert, M., Strahlenzentrum der Universität Giessen, Leihgesterner Weg 217, Giessen, D-6300, Germany; Brinkmann, U., Fakultät für Physik, Universität Bielefeld, Universitätsstrasse 25, Bielefeld 1, D-4800, Germany; Hippler, R., Fakultät für Physik, Universität Bielefeld, Universitätsstrasse 25, Bielefeld 1, D-4800, Germany
Abstract: The TEPOS facility at the Giessen LINAC delivers intense positron beams in the energy range between some eV and 6 keV; with postacceleration up to 80 keV. Results for remoderation and positron storage will be discussed. Further the energy-loss of positrons in thin aluminium foils at incident energies of 6-20 keV was measured. Cross sections for K- and L-shell ionization of thin silver and gold targets by positron and electron impact were determined at projectile energies of 30-70 keV. The experimental results are presented in detail; they are confirmed by calculations in plane wave Born approximation (PWBA) which include an electron exchange term and take into account the deceleration or acceleration of the incident projectile in the nuclear field of the target atom. © 1993 J.C. Baltzer AG, Science Publishers.

Authors: Gabrielse G., Jhe W., Phillips D., Quint W., Tseng C., Haarsma L., Abdullah K., Gröbner J., Kalinowsky H.
Title: Extremely cold antiprotons for antihydrogen production
Affiliations: Department of Physics, Harvard University, Cambridge, 02138, MA, United States; Institut für Physik, Universität Mainz, Mainz, 6500, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Gabrielse, G., Department of Physics, Harvard University, Cambridge, 02138, MA, United States; Jhe, W., Department of Physics, Harvard University, Cambridge, 02138, MA, United States; Phillips, D., Department of Physics, Harvard University, Cambridge, 02138, MA, United States; Quint, W., Department of Physics, Harvard University, Cambridge, 02138, MA, United States; Tseng, C., Department of Physics, Harvard University, Cambridge, 02138, MA, United States; Haarsma, L., Department of Physics, Harvard University, Cambridge, 02138, MA, United States; Abdullah, K., Department of Physics, Harvard University, Cambridge, 02138, MA, United States; Gröbner, J., Institut für Physik, Universität Mainz, Mainz, 6500, Germany; Kalinowsky, H., Institut für Physik, Universität Mainz, Mainz, 6500, Germany
Abstract: The possibility to produce, trap and study antihydrogen atoms rests upon the recent availability of extremely cold antiprotons in a Penning trap. Over the last five years, our TRAP Collaboration has slowed, cooled and stored antiprotons at energies 1010 lower than was previously possible. The storage time exceeds 3.4 months despite the extremely low energy, which corresponds to 4.2 K in temperature units. The first example of measurements which become possible with extremely cold antiprotons is a comparison of the antiproton inertial masses which shows they are the same to a fractional accuracy of 4×10-8. (This is 1000 times more accurate than previous comparisons and large additional increases in accuracy are anticipated.) To increase the number of trapped antiprotons available for antihydrogen production, we have demonstrated that we can accumulate or "stack" antiprotons cooled from successive pulsed injections into our trap. © 1993 J.C. Baltzer AG, Science Publishers.

Authors: Burke T., Podlesak T.F., Carter J., Feltz R.
Title: Investigation of novel capacitors for pulse power applications
Source title: IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference - Digest of Technical Papers
Affiliations: Army Research Lab, Fort Monmouth, United States
Authors with affiliations: Burke, T., Army Research Lab, Fort Monmouth, United States; Podlesak, T.F., Army Research Lab, Fort Monmouth, United States; Carter, J., Army Research Lab, Fort Monmouth, United States; Feltz, R., Army Research Lab, Fort Monmouth, United States
Abstract: Two types of high energy density, double layer capacitors of bipolar construction were evaluated under pulse conditions. One capacitor is a commercial component for use in computer power backup circuits. It was found that allowing interpulse timings of hundreds of milliseconds allowed the battery action of such components to restore to nearly full charging voltage. Operating the components under single charge, multiple discharge pulse conditions was very successful. High equivalent series resistances (ESR) were observed, however, suggesting future problems in applying such components to highly underdamped, ringing circuits or circuits where efficient energy transfer from storage to load is necessary.
Index Keywords: Electric discharges; Electric loads; Electric power supplies to apparatus; High energy density double layer capacitors; Capacitor storage

Abstract: This paper presents the description of the developing powerful experimental complex EMG-PIRIT to study high energy plasma formations at 10-100 MA currents powered by MKG and with a two-cascade current pulse formation by an explosive plasma and plasma erosion switch. The VNIIEF designed technological and experimental base allows to carry out the experiments with 10-100 MJ magnetocumulative generators with explosive plasma switches and to transfer the generated high-voltage pulse to the shielded building where the most expensive components of the installation are located - a vacuum inductive storage, a plasma switch, a load and diagnostics system.
Index Keywords: Capacitor storage; Electric currents; Electric loads; Electric switches; Plasma diagnostics; Plasma sources; Vacuum applications; Explosive magnetic generators (EMG); High energy plasma formations; Magnetocumulative generators; Plasma switch; Vacuum inductive storage; Electric generators

Authors: Ihara S., Kohno S., Katsuki S., Akiyama H., Maeda S.
Title: Plasma opening switch using laser-produced plasma
Source title: IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference - Digest of Technical Papers
Affiliations: Kumamoto Univ, Kumamoto, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Ihara, S., Kumamoto Univ, Kumamoto, Japan; Kohno, S., Kumamoto Univ, Kumamoto, Japan; Katsuki, S., Kumamoto Univ, Kumamoto, Japan; Akiyama, H., Kumamoto Univ, Kumamoto, Japan; Maeda, S., Kumamoto Univ, Kumamoto, Japan
Abstract: In order to construct a practical inductive energy storage pulsed power generator, the development of the opening switch which can repeatedly conduct a large current and then rapidly interrupt this current is necessary. Though the plasma opening switch (POS) can interrupt a large current rapidly, the effective number of switch operations is limited because of the decrease of the carbon sprayed on the insulator with each shot. We proposed a plasma opening switch using laser-produced plasma as one of opening switches which can be repeatedly used. The another advantage of the POS with the laser produced plasma is that it becomes possible to select more suitable plasma species for the operation of POS by changing the target materials. Here, the target materials are changed.
Index Keywords: Ablation; Aluminum; Asynchronous generators; Capacitors; Copper; Electric currents; Electric discharges; Electric energy storage; Ionization; Laser accessories; Laser produced plasmas; Plasma sources; Plasma opening switch; Target materials; Electric switches

Authors: Podlesak T.F., Fonda K., Creedon J., Ulrich R.
Title: Comparative experimental study of capacitor dielectrics under ringing conditions
Source title: IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference - Digest of Technical Papers
Affiliations: Army Research Lab, Fort Monmouth, United States
Authors with affiliations: Podlesak, T.F., Army Research Lab, Fort Monmouth, United States; Fonda, K., Army Research Lab, Fort Monmouth, United States; Creedon, J., Army Research Lab, Fort Monmouth, United States; Ulrich, R., Army Research Lab, Fort Monmouth, United States
Abstract: Five different types of pulse power capacitors, each with a different dielectric material, were evaluated in an underdamped circuit. The purpose of these measurements was to determine the applicability of the various capacitor technologies for use in circuits where severe ringing will be required. Such circuits could include induction type electromagnetic launchers. It was found that severe losses, due to the effective series resistance (ESR) of the capacitors, manifested themselves. This places severe restrictions on the application of such components to circuits that require highly efficient transfer of energy from energy storage to the load. The degree of the loss varies considerably from capacitor dielectric to dielectric and from electrode construction to electrode construction.
Index Keywords: Capacitor storage; Dielectric materials; Electric loads; Electric network analysis; Electrodes; Electromagnetic launchers; Equipment testing; Effective series resistance (ESR); Energy transfer; Pulsed power capacitors; Capacitors

Authors: Bowles E.E., Heyse M.W., Kolawole J., Taconi Jr. N.E.
Title: 100 kA, 5000 V solid state opening switch for railgun applications
Source title: IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference - Digest of Technical Papers
Affiliations: General Atomics, San Diego, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bowles, E.E., General Atomics, San Diego, United States; Heyse, M.W., General Atomics, San Diego, United States; Kolawole, J., General Atomics, San Diego, United States; Taconi Jr., N.E., General Atomics, San Diego, United States
Abstract: Inductive energy stores have demonstrated higher energy storage densities than capacitive energy stores. A limitation in the use of inductive energy stores has been the availability of adequately rated opening switches. A self commutated solid state switch has been developed for use as an opening device for an inductive energy store. The switch is rated at 100 kA and 5000 V and is composed of four identical 25 kA switch modules. The opening repetition rate for the intended application varies from single pulse to 10 Hz. Efficiency and volumetric power density are optimized. The switch topology is a two stage hybrid consisting of an SCR-FET/SCR-IGBT combination. The switch is designed to charge an inductive energy store and repetitively commutate the current into a railgun load. A 100 kA switch module has been built and successfully tested. The theory of operation, circuit topology and test results are given in this paper.
Index Keywords: Efficiency; Electric commutation; Electric currents; Electric energy storage; Electric loads; Electric network topology; Electric switches; Equipment testing; Solid state devices; Switching circuits; Inductive energy storage; Solid state opening switch; Rail guns

Authors: Morozov E.A., Komin S.N., Sokolova T.G., Tzelisheva V.I., Fedorova V.S.
Title: Capacitors - Forming line
Source title: IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference - Digest of Technical Papers
Affiliations: St. Petersburg State Technical Univ, St. Petersburg, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Morozov, E.A., St. Petersburg State Technical Univ, St. Petersburg, Russian Federation; Komin, S.N., St. Petersburg State Technical Univ, St. Petersburg, Russian Federation; Sokolova, T.G., St. Petersburg State Technical Univ, St. Petersburg, Russian Federation; Tzelisheva, V.I., St. Petersburg State Technical Univ, St. Petersburg, Russian Federation; Fedorova, V.S., St. Petersburg State Technical Univ, St. Petersburg, Russian Federation
Abstract: A technology for the production of capacitors with forming line properties is developed. With this technology, the effectiveness of energy transmission from the storing device into the load is increased, the use of intermediate storage devices is avoided, and the charge period of lines is increased. These capacitors are useful in power supply systems of lasers and high-current accelerators with pulse repetition frequency of up to 100 Hz.
Index Keywords: Capacitor storage; Electric loads; Electric power supplies to apparatus; High power lasers; Particle accelerators; Pulse generators; Forming line; Capacitors

Authors: Murthy S.K., Weldon W.F., Pratap S.B., Gagnon W.
Title: Power supplies for airborne laser systems
Source title: IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference - Digest of Technical Papers
Affiliations: Univ of Texas at Austin, Austin, United States
Authors with affiliations: Murthy, S.K., Univ of Texas at Austin, Austin, United States; Weldon, W.F., Univ of Texas at Austin, Austin, United States; Pratap, S.B., Univ of Texas at Austin, Austin, United States; Gagnon, W., Univ of Texas at Austin, Austin, United States
Abstract: The power supply options for an airborne laser system (solid state laser diodes) is investigated. The application demands a power supply capable of a high repetition rate and delivering a total energy of 20 MJ. The compensated pulsed alternator (compulsator) invented by the Center for Electromechanics at the University of Texas is examined as a possible power supply option. The lower limits of the compulsator size and weight for the different configurations is explored.
Index Keywords: Capacitors; Electric energy storage; Electric loads; Electric power supplies to apparatus; Rail guns; Airborne laser systems; Compensated pulsed alternator (Compulsator); Inductive loads; Semiconductor lasers

Authors: Han Kwang S., Lee Ja H.
Title: INPIStron switched pulsed power for dense plasma pinches
Source title: IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference - Digest of Technical Papers
Affiliations: Hampton Univ, Hampton, United States
Authors with affiliations: Han, Kwang S., Hampton Univ, Hampton, United States; Lee, Ja H., Hampton Univ, Hampton, United States
Abstract: The inverse plasma switch INPIStron was employed for high energy capacitor bank discharge systems to produce focused dense plasmas in hypocycloidal-pinch (HCP) devices. A single unit and an array of multiple HCPs were coupled as the load of the pulsed power circuit. The geometry and switching plasma dynamics were found advantageous and convenient for commutating the large current pulse from the low impedance transmission line to the low impedance plasma load. The pulsed power system with a single unit HCP, the system A, was used for production of high temperature plasma focus and its diagnostics. The radially running down plasmadynamics, revealed in image converter photographs, could be simulated by a simple snow-plow model with a correction for plasma resistivity. The system B with an array of 8-HCP units which forms a long coaxial discharge chamber was used for pumping a Ti-sapphire laser. The intense uv emission from the plasma was frequency shifted with dye-solution jacket to match the absorption band of the Ti crystal laser near 500 nm. An untuned laser pulse energy of 0.6 J/pulse was obtained for 6.4 kJ/40 kV discharge, or near 102 times of the explosion limit of conventional flashlamps. FOr both system the advantages of the INPIStron were well demonstrated: (a) a single unit is sufficient for a large current (greater than 50 kA) without increasing the system impedance, (b) highly reliable and long life operation and (c) implied scalability for the high power ranges above Ipeak = 1 MA and Vhold = 100 kV.
Index Keywords: Capacitor storage; Electric commutation; Electric conductivity; Electric currents; Electric impedance; Electric loads; Electric switches; Laser tuning; Mathematical models; Plasma density; Plasma devices; Ultraviolet radiation; Hypocycloidal pinch (HCP) devices; Inverse plasma switch INPIStron; Plasma sources

Authors: Emelin P.Yu., Fridman B.E., Rutberg Ph.G.
Title: Capacity energy storage unit of E7-25 type
Source title: IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference - Digest of Technical Papers
Affiliations: Russian Acad of Sciences, Saunt-Petersburg, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Emelin, P.Yu., Russian Acad of Sciences, Saunt-Petersburg, Russian Federation; Fridman, B.E., Russian Acad of Sciences, Saunt-Petersburg, Russian Federation; Rutberg, Ph.G., Russian Acad of Sciences, Saunt-Petersburg, Russian Federation
Abstract: Capacity energy storage is intended for supplying electrothermal and rail gun launchers. Projectical stored energy is 17.2 MJ, maximum voltage is 25 kV, discharge current range is 10 MA, frequency discharge current oscillations in short circuit is 8 kHz. The storage was built on the module principle. It contains 23 modules, all modules consist of 8 cells. Every cell has capacitors on 94 kJ stored energy and vacuum triggered switch. Control and nisation systems of the storage provide distant controlling by every module and operation of nonsimultaneous programmed discharge, where triggered switches in cells are switched-on in definite time.
Index Keywords: Circuit oscillations; Control systems; Electric currents; Electric discharges; Electric power supplies to apparatus; Electric switches; Overvoltage protection; Rail guns; Electrothermal launchers; Capacitor storage

Authors: Fridman B.E.
Title: Application of the non-linear silicon-carbide resistors in the capacitive energy storage
Source title: IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference - Digest of Technical Papers
Affiliations: Russian Acad of Sciences, St. Petersburg, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Fridman, B.E., Russian Acad of Sciences, St. Petersburg, Russian Federation
Abstract: Non-linear silicon-carbide resistors of tervit type posses high heat capacity and permit high temperature up to 600 °C. This allows using these resistors for capacitors' energy absorption of discharge neutralization and for separation of capacitors cells at the stage of charging. Tervit type resistors are distinctive of their volt-ampere characteristic, where voltage is proportional to current taken to the power of 1/3. According to this the tervit resistance at low voltage is too high and it is necessary to connect wire resistor in parallel. The analysis of transients during in non-linear electric circuits with tervit is performed at capacitors' charge neutralization and at emergency when Insulation broken-down in any of capacitor cell. Conditions providing silicon-carbide resistors effective operation are defind. In this paper we list the results of experiments reproducing the tervit operating conditions in the capacity energy storage E7-25.
Index Keywords: Electric currents; Electric discharges; Energy absorption; Resistors; Silicon carbide; Specific heat of solids; Nonlinear silicon carbide resistors; Tervit type resistors; Capacitor storage

Authors: Driga M.D.
Title: Asynchronous generators for fast, high-energy pulsed discharge as power supplies for electromagnetic launchers
Source title: IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference - Digest of Technical Papers
Affiliations: Univ of Texas at Austin, Austin, United States
Authors with affiliations: Driga, M.D., Univ of Texas at Austin, Austin, United States
Abstract: A new type of pulsed asynchronous generator producing the reactive power necessary for self-excitation - possible only in a short transient regime, time sufficient for powering an electromagnetic launcher is presented. The gradual increase in amplitude during the pulse time followed by the collapse of the excitation and of the output voltages and currents permits the projectile to be under constant acceleration during the large part of the transit through the barrel and to exit the accelerator under zero current, representing an almost ideal condition for an electromagnetic launch.
Index Keywords: Electric currents; Electric discharges; Electric energy storage; Electric excitation; Electric power supplies to apparatus; Electromagnetic launchers; Reactive power; Transients; Electric energy; Energy density; Kinetic energy; Magnetic energy; Pulse time; Pulsed discharge; Pulsed power supplies; Self excitation; Asynchronous generators

Authors: Thornton E., Spikings C.R.
Title: 500 kJ capacitor bank for electrothermal gun research
Source title: IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference - Digest of Technical Papers
Affiliations: British Aerospace, Bristol, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Thornton, E., British Aerospace, Bristol, United Kingdom; Spikings, C.R., British Aerospace, Bristol, United Kingdom
Abstract: The design, construction and performance of a 500 kJ capacitor bank is described. It was funded by Royal Ordinance and is intended for use as a power supply for electrothermal gun research, working into a load of nominally 30 mΩ. Operating at 20 kV, the bank has 10 individually triggerable stages so that the shape of the current waveform can be varied according to the trigger timing. The stage inductors are 40 μH and the peak current exceeds 200 kA, with a pulse length of approximately 500 μs when the stages are triggered simultaneously. When triggered in sequence the peak current is typically 70 kA for a pulse duration of 2 ms. `D' size ignitrons are used as stage switches and also as crowbars to limit voltage reversal on the capacitors. Care was taken to reduce problems of electrical interference by elimination of ground loops. Current waveforms are predicted for simultaneous and sequenced trigger timing with a dummy load, and agree well with measured waveforms. In addition the energy transfer efficiency is derived for both the dummy load and for a plasma source and variations in energy loss in the circuit considered.
Index Keywords: Electric currents; Electric loads; Electric losses; Electric switches; Electromagnetic launchers; Plasma sources; Trigger circuits; Voltage control; Waveform analysis; Electrothermal gun research; Capacitor storage

Authors: Sincerny P., Ashby S., Childers K., Deeney C., Drury D., Goyer J., Kortbawi D., Roth I., Stallings C., Schlitt L.
Title: DECADE high power generator
Source title: IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference - Digest of Technical Papers
Affiliations: Physics Int Co, San Leandro, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sincerny, P., Physics Int Co, San Leandro, United States; Ashby, S., Physics Int Co, San Leandro, United States; Childers, K., Physics Int Co, San Leandro, United States; Deeney, C., Physics Int Co, San Leandro, United States; Drury, D., Physics Int Co, San Leandro, United States; Goyer, J., Physics Int Co, San Leandro, United States; Kortbawi, D., Physics Int Co, San Leandro, United States; Roth, I., Physics Int Co, San Leandro, United States; Stallings, C., Physics Int Co, San Leandro, United States; Schlitt, L., Physics Int Co, San Leandro, United States
Abstract: DECADE is a very high peak power generator designed to drive both large area bremsstrahlung diode arrays and imploding plasma loads. For a one square meter array of bremsstrahlung diodes, the machine will deliver up to 2.5 MJ of electrical energy at a peak voltage of 1.8 MV. DECADE will drive up to 25 MA into a plasma radiation source load. The DECADE generator consists of sixteen independent pulsed power modules. Each module consists of a 500 kJ Marx that pulse charges a water transfer capacitor. The transfer capacitor discharges into a water output line through an array of triggered gas switches. The water output line then pulse charges the final inductive store/opening switch pulse compression stage. When the opening switch opens, the inductive store discharges into either an independent diode load or into a vacuum convolute that connects all sixteen modules to single imploding plasma load. Extensive testing has been completed on a half energy prototype module. The first of sixteen full power modules has been constructed and initial testing is in progress. The full DECADE facility will begin testing in mid 1995.
Index Keywords: Capacitor storage; Diodes; Electric switches; Equipment testing; Plasma sources; Pulse generators; Bremsstrahlung diodes; DECADE high power generator; Imploding plasma loads; Electric generators

Authors: Funk E.E., Lee Chi H., Jasper Jr. L.
Title: Photoconductivity quenching in a GaAs opening switch pulsed power system
Source title: IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference - Digest of Technical Papers
Affiliations: Univ of Maryland, College Park, United States
Authors with affiliations: Funk, E.E., Univ of Maryland, College Park, United States; Lee, Chi H., Univ of Maryland, College Park, United States; Jasper Jr., L., Univ of Maryland, College Park, United States
Abstract: The use of a GaAs photoconductive closing and opening switch in an inductive energy storage system has, in the past, required a custom built laser with optical pulse shaping. We now describe a system which may be operated by a simple, Q-switched laser pulse. We have designed a high impedance (500-Ω) system which provides a switch conduction time which is sustained longer than the laser pulse. Furthermore we have demonstrated that at high voltages the switch exhibits fast quenching of conductivity resulting in opening times of less than 20-ns after sustained conduction. This fast opening action has allowed us to achieve a power gain of up to 8.9 and switched out voltages as high as 7-kV.
Index Keywords: Electric currents; Electric energy storage; Electric impedance; Electric power transmission networks; Laser pulses; Photoconducting devices; Photoconductivity; Q switched lasers; Semiconducting gallium arsenide; Gallium arsenide opening switch pulsed power system; Photoconductivity quenching; Semiconductor switches

Authors: Thomas B.L., Pronko S., Ness R.M., Auyeung A., Cooper J.R.
Title: Thyratron modulators for the superconducting supercollider drift tube and coupled cavity linacs
Source title: IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference - Digest of Technical Papers
Affiliations: Maxwell Lab, Inc, San Diego, United States
Authors with affiliations: Thomas, B.L., Maxwell Lab, Inc, San Diego, United States; Pronko, S., Maxwell Lab, Inc, San Diego, United States; Ness, R.M., Maxwell Lab, Inc, San Diego, United States; Auyeung, A., Maxwell Lab, Inc, San Diego, United States; Cooper, J.R., Maxwell Lab, Inc, San Diego, United States
Abstract: Maxwell Laboratories has designed and is building two different types of modulators for the Superconducting Supercollider (SSC) in Waxahachie, Texas. The modulators will drive the klystrons for the Drift Tube Linac (DTL) and the Coupled Cavity Linac (CCL). A total of 11 CCL modulators will be built and 5 DTL modulators will be built. Several interesting features have been incorporated into the design of the modulator. One of these features is the use of a bank of off-the-shelf switching power supplies to charge the PFN. The pulse width for both modulators is greater than 70 μs which translates into a long pulse mode of operation for the thyratrons. The modulators were designed with an extensive computer control system which allows the modulators to be remotely controlled from the computer which controls the entire supercollider facility.
Index Keywords: Colliding beam accelerators; Computer applications; Control systems; Electric energy storage; Electric power supplies to apparatus; Klystrons; Linear accelerators; Pulse generators; Remote control; Superconducting devices; Thyratrons; Coupled cavity linac; Drift tube linac; Pulse forming networks; Superconducting supercollider; Thyratron modulators; Modulators

Abstract: Currently, studies are focused on electron accelerators powered by the systems comprising the inductive storages and switches for power sharpening. In the course of such system studies, there was revealed a negative effect of plasma extraction from the switch region to the diode on possible variation in time, energy and space characteristics of the electron beam. In line with this problem, experiments were performed on an electron accelerator powered by inductive storage based on induction plasma injectors.
Index Keywords: Capacitor storage; Electric currents; Electric fields; Electric switches; Electron beams; Plasma diodes; Plasmas; Induction plasma injectors; Inductive storage; Particle accelerators

Authors: Emelin P.Yu., Fridman B.E., Rutberg Ph.G.
Title: Programmed discharge of the capacity energy storage
Source title: IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference - Digest of Technical Papers
Affiliations: Russian Acad of Sciences, Sant-Petersburg, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Emelin, P.Yu., Russian Acad of Sciences, Sant-Petersburg, Russian Federation; Fridman, B.E., Russian Acad of Sciences, Sant-Petersburg, Russian Federation; Rutberg, Ph.G., Russian Acad of Sciences, Sant-Petersburg, Russian Federation
Abstract: The programmed discharge regime can be realized in large energy storages through the non-simultaneous initiating of the storage sections' discharging. The paper analyses the transients during in discharge circuits of the capacity energy storage, operating conditions of the it's elements and energy losses at programmed discharge. An equivalent scheme of the tuned circuit with current source and alternating capacitance is suggested for approximately defining of the current in the load. Examine a problem of synthesis of the spark-gap switch-on programs, which provides the optimal regimes of different load's operation. Consider the programmed discharge of the capacity energy storage E7-25 for constant L-R load, railgun and arc load.
Index Keywords: Electric arcs; Electric currents; Electric discharges; Electric loads; Electric spark gaps; Equivalent circuits; Mathematical models; Rail guns; Transients; Programmed discharge; Spark gap switch on programs; Capacitor storage

Authors: Larson D.W., MacDougall F.W., Yang X.H., Hardy P.E.
Title: Impact of high energy density capacitors with metallized electrode in large capacitor banks for nuclear fusion applications
Source title: IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference - Digest of Technical Papers
Affiliations: Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab, Livermore, United States
Authors with affiliations: Larson, D.W., Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab, Livermore, United States; MacDougall, F.W., Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab, Livermore, United States; Yang, X.H., Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab, Livermore, United States; Hardy, P.E., Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab, Livermore, United States
Abstract: Power supplies for Inertial Confinement Fusion (ICF) lasers require large capacitor banks. As capacitor bank size increases, reliability, expressed as Mean-Time-Between-Failures (MTBF) is reduced, for a given capacitor design. Metallized electrode capacitors exhibit more predictable failure characteristics than traditional foil designs, thus increasing MTBF for some applications. In addition, their `soft' failure mode gives facility operators flexibility to schedule capacitor bank maintenance. Experience with the design and testing of a metallized electrode capacitor for a 13 MJ bank is presented. Weibull statistics are used to predict performance on the 13 MJ bank, and on a proposed 250 MJ facility. While the Beamlet capacitor data is specific to Aerovox capacitor part number KM223YW215D01, much of the information is applicable to high voltage metallized electrode capacitors in general.
Index Keywords: Electric power supplies to apparatus; Electrodes; Equipment testing; Failure analysis; High energy lasers; Inertial confinement fusion; Maintenance; Metallizing; Reliability; Aerovox capacitor; Beamlet capacitor; Mean time between failures (MTBF); Metallized electrode capacitor; Capacitor storage

Authors: Nesterov V.V., Cassel R.L.
Title: Energy efficient deQing for SLAC Klystron Modulators
Source title: IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference - Digest of Technical Papers
Affiliations: Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States
Authors with affiliations: Nesterov, V.V., Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States; Cassel, R.L., Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States
Abstract: Two hundred and forty Klystron Modulator Stations at SLAC were converted to a new deQing circuit configuration. With the help of the new deQing circuit, the energy stored in a charging choke at the moment of deQing is no longer dissipated in a resistor but is being constantly returned to the power line. The design considerations and a circuit layout will be presented.
Index Keywords: Electric energy storage; Electric inductors; Integrated circuit layout; Klystrons; Linear accelerators; DeQing circuit; Klystron Modulator Stations; Stanford Linear Accelerator Center (SLAC); Modulators

Authors: Korzekwa R., Ingram M., Hutcherson K., Bernardes J., Ball E., Gehman V., Gripshover R., Berger T.
Title: High-energy high-Q capacitor banks driving high-current long-duration arc discharges
Source title: IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference - Digest of Technical Papers
Affiliations: Naval Surface Warfare Cent, Dahlgren, United States
Authors with affiliations: Korzekwa, R., Naval Surface Warfare Cent, Dahlgren, United States; Ingram, M., Naval Surface Warfare Cent, Dahlgren, United States; Hutcherson, K., Naval Surface Warfare Cent, Dahlgren, United States; Bernardes, J., Naval Surface Warfare Cent, Dahlgren, United States; Ball, E., Naval Surface Warfare Cent, Dahlgren, United States; Gehman, V., Naval Surface Warfare Cent, Dahlgren, United States; Gripshover, R., Naval Surface Warfare Cent, Dahlgren, United States; Berger, T., Naval Surface Warfare Cent, Dahlgren, United States
Abstract: High-energy capacitor banks have been constructed to investigate long-duration (100 μs to >10 ms) high-current wire-initiated arc discharges. In particular a megajoule bank which produces large currents with high voltage-reversal has been constructed. This capacitor bank is used in a high-Q circuit with a specially constructed low-loss, 1.7 mH inductor. The effects of low frequency and high-voltage reversal on these capacitors are described. Also, the effects of high-coulomb transfer on a high-action spark gap are presented. A spectroscopic observation system capable of measuring visible emission from these discharges has been constructed and is used to obtain electron number density and temperature measurements versus the discharge radius, as well as provide information on the time evolution of the discharge composition.
Index Keywords: Electric arcs; Electric currents; Electric discharges; Electric spark gaps; Electric wire; Electron density measurement; Electron emission; Spectroscopy; Temperature measurement; High current long duration arc discharges; High energy high Q capacitor banks; Capacitor storage

Authors: Bossamykin V.S., Gordeev V.S.
Title: Stepped line conversion of pulsed voltage, current and electric power
Source title: IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference - Digest of Technical Papers
Affiliations: Scientific Research Inst of, Experimental Physics, Nizhni Novgorod, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Bossamykin, V.S., Scientific Research Inst of, Experimental Physics, Nizhni Novgorod, Russian Federation; Gordeev, V.S., Scientific Research Inst of, Experimental Physics, Nizhni Novgorod, Russian Federation
Abstract: Pulsed facilities that provide additional increase in voltage amplitude or pulse current delivered from an external generator along a constant impedance transmission line are of great practical interest. The schemes are suggested for such stepped line - based facilities to operate jointly with generators producing a single rectangular pulse or a bipolar meander - pulse. The versions both with closing and opening switches are found. In the passive operating regime, only the delivered from the external generator energy is employed. In the active operating regime before the pulse arrival from the generator, the facility stores additional energy in the form of electric or magnetic field depending on the version. In the ideal case, the energy supplied from the external generator, and the one stored in the facility itself are efficiently delivered to the resistive lead in the form of a single rectangular pulse. With a definite ratio of the stepped line impedances these facilities are capable to provide 5-10 fold increase in voltage or current only due to the wave processes. In all the cases the electric power grows. High efficiency can be achieved at the scheme parameters optimization and with the input pulse form being different from rectangular.
Index Keywords: Electric currents; Electric fields; Electric impedance; Electric loads; Electric switches; Energy storage; Magnetic fields; Mathematical models; Optimization; Power converters; Stepped line conversion; Pulse generators

Title: Review of the Procyon explosive pulsed power system
