Abstract: The Procyon system and its performance is presented and the amount of increased energy to be obtained either by optimizing the current design or scaling the device is discussed. Procyon is the name for an explosive pulsed power (EPP) system designed to drive 1-MJ plasma z-pinch experiments. The design features, goals and preliminary data are summarized.
Index Keywords: Capacitor storage; Capacitors; Electric currents; Electric generators; Electric inductors; Electric power supplies to apparatus; Electric switches; Optimization; Systems analysis; Capacitor bank; Explosively formed fuse (EFF) opening switch; Magnetic flux compression generator (MCG); Procyon explosive pulsed power (EPP) system; Storage inductor; Plasma applications

Authors: Wisken Holger G., Braunsberger Ulrich E., Salge Jurgen G.H.
Title: Electrothermal generation of pressure pulses for mass acceleration
Source title: IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference - Digest of Technical Papers
Affiliations: Technische Universitaet Braunschweig, Salzgitter, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Wisken, Holger G., Technische Universitaet Braunschweig, Salzgitter, Germany; Braunsberger, Ulrich E., Technische Universitaet Braunschweig, Salzgitter, Germany; Salge, Jurgen G.H., Technische Universitaet Braunschweig, Salzgitter, Germany
Abstract: Electrothermally generated pressure pulses are very effective to accelerate masses to high velocities. The intermediate storage of energy in the pressure chamber offers the possibility to reduce the electrical power needed for the acceleration process. This can be done by pressurizing the chamber with gas prior to the final shock-heating via an electric arc from a capacitor bank. Another possibility is to evaporate a liquid in the chamber by a relatively long lasting arc prior to the release of the projectile. In the latter case the current needed can be kept comparatively small. After some fundamental considerations this paper gives results of experiments conducted so far. The experimental set-up and the power supply allow to generate the pressure during time periods of up to 20 ms, during this time the current is sustained. The energy is taken from an inductive store.
Index Keywords: Capacitor storage; Electric arcs; Electric currents; Electric power supplies to apparatus; Evaporation; Pressure; Projectiles; Electrothermal mass accelerators; Pressure pulses; Electromagnetic launchers

Authors: Katulka G.L., DelGuercio M., Khong T.
Title: Applications of digital and optoelectronic circuits to electrothermal-chemical gun system facilities
Source title: IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference - Digest of Technical Papers
Affiliations: U.S. Army Research Lab, Aberdeen Proving Ground, United States
Authors with affiliations: Katulka, G.L., U.S. Army Research Lab, Aberdeen Proving Ground, United States; DelGuercio, M., U.S. Army Research Lab, Aberdeen Proving Ground, United States; Khong, T., U.S. Army Research Lab, Aberdeen Proving Ground, United States
Abstract: The use of digital electronic and optical electronic circuits for controlling various aspects of pulse-forming networks (PFNs) in electrothermal-chemical (ETC) gun facilities at the U.S. Army Research Laboratory (ARL) is described. A design of a digital sample and hold circuit used to retain, in digital memory, the initial voltage (and energy) of PFNs is considered. In addition, various uses of optical electronic circuits to control PFN safety network function, amplifier operations, and power supply switching are described.
Index Keywords: Amplifiers (electronic); Control systems; Digital circuits; Digital storage; Electric switches; Optoelectronic devices; Plasma flow; Power supply circuits; Electrothermal chemical (ETC) gun facilities; Optoelectronic circuits; Power supply switching; Pulse forming networks (PFNs); Safety network function; U.S. Army Research Laboratory (ARL); Electromagnetic launchers

Authors: Bossamykin V.S., Gerasimov A.I., Klement'ev A.P., Pavlovskii A.I., Fedotkin A.S., Morunov K.A., Slyusarenko S.Ja., Zenkov D.I., Nazarenko S.T.
Title: System of 500 kV Marx generator for LIA-10 radial lines charging
Source title: IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference - Digest of Technical Papers
Affiliations: All-Russian Inst of Experimental, Physics, Nizhni Novgorod, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Bossamykin, V.S., All-Russian Inst of Experimental, Physics, Nizhni Novgorod, Russian Federation; Gerasimov, A.I., All-Russian Inst of Experimental, Physics, Nizhni Novgorod, Russian Federation; Klement'ev, A.P., All-Russian Inst of Experimental, Physics, Nizhni Novgorod, Russian Federation; Pavlovskii, A.I., All-Russian Inst of Experimental, Physics, Nizhni Novgorod, Russian Federation; Fedotkin, A.S., All-Russian Inst of Experimental, Physics, Nizhni Novgorod, Russian Federation; Morunov, K.A., All-Russian Inst of Experimental, Physics, Nizhni Novgorod, Russian Federation; Slyusarenko, S.Ja., All-Russian Inst of Experimental, Physics, Nizhni Novgorod, Russian Federation; Zenkov, D.I., All-Russian Inst of Experimental, Physics, Nizhni Novgorod, Russian Federation; Nazarenko, S.T., All-Russian Inst of Experimental, Physics, Nizhni Novgorod, Russian Federation
Abstract: In -0.8 μs time the radial lines of 48 cavities in the linear induction accelerator LIA-10 are charged up to 400-500 kV with 16 five-stage one-circuit Marx generator. The generator electric scheme is presented as well as same of its design peculiarities, the arrangement and characteristics of gas-filled trigatrons in the stages. Stored energy is 6.25 kJ, equivalent capacitance is 0.05 μF, output voltage is -500 kV, circuit inductance is -2.5 μH. At -100% electrical strength reserve for the switches and with synchronized triggering of all generators the maximum jitter is ±15 ns for -104 shots. During 15 years the generators set has operated successfully in LIA-10.
Index Keywords: Capacitance; Electric energy storage; Electric switches; Pulse generators; Synchronization; Trigger circuits; Five stage one circuit Marx generator; Gas filled trigatron; Linear induction accelerator LIA-10; Linear accelerators

Authors: Cochrane J.C., Bartsch R.R., Benage J.R., Forman P.R., Gribble R.F., Ladish J.S., Oona H., Parker J.V., Scudder D.W., Shlachter J.S., Wysocki F.J.
Title: Plasma flow switch and foil implosion experiments on Pegasus II
Source title: IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference - Digest of Technical Papers
Affiliations: Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States
Authors with affiliations: Cochrane, J.C., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Bartsch, R.R., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Benage, J.R., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Forman, P.R., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Gribble, R.F., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Ladish, J.S., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Oona, H., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Parker, J.V., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Scudder, D.W., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Shlachter, J.S., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Wysocki, F.J., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States
Abstract: Pegasus II is the upgraded version of Pegasus, a pulsed power machine used in the Los Alamos AGEX (Above Ground EXperiments) program. A goal of the program is to produce an intense source of soft X rays from the thermalization of the kinetic energy of a plasma implosion provided by the implosion of a cylindrical thin metallic foil. Experiments were performed on a capacitor bank to develop a plasma flow switch to switch the bank current into the load at peak current. This allows efficient coupling of bank energy into foil kinetic energy.
Index Keywords: Capacitor storage; Electric currents; Electric switches; Metallic films; Plasma flow; Plasma sources; Pulse generators; Foil implosion; Pegasus II; Plasma flow switch; Plasma devices

Authors: Carlier E., Ducimetiere L., Jansson U., Mayer M., Schroder G.H., Vossenberg E.B.
Title: High power pulse generator for the beam dumping kicker system of CERN's Large Electron Positron Collider LEP
Source title: IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference - Digest of Technical Papers
Affiliations: CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Carlier, E., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Ducimetiere, L., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Jansson, U., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Mayer, M., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Schroder, G.H., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Vossenberg, E.B., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Abstract: CERN is upgrading its 55 GeV Large Electron Positron storage ring (LEP) to an energy of up to 100 GeV per beam and to higher intensities. Adequate equipment for rapid dumping of the counter-rotating beam bunches at the end of the storage period or in an emergency situation is therefore required. A fast kicker magnet system has been built for this purpose. The magnet is energized by the discharge of a storage capacitor, located close to the magnet in the LEP tunnel. The charging voltage of the capacitor is proportional to the beam momentum which is 20 GeV/c at injection and will be 100 GeV/c at top energy. The current pulse has a maximum amplitude of 9.5 kA with a rise time of 9.2 μs and a fall time constant of 285 μs. The generator consists of a pulse capacitor discharged by a gas switch in series with a stack of blocking diodes, specially selected for very low reverse recovery energy. A free-wheel diode stack, in series with a small series resistor for slope control, bypasses the generator output. These free-wheel diodes have a very low dynamic forward resistance. After a short presentation of the layout of the dumping system and its kicker magnet this paper discusses in more detail the pulse generator with emphasis on the performances of the fast diode stacks. Results of measurements on the operational generator at design voltage will also be discussed.
Index Keywords: Accelerator magnets; Capacitor storage; Diodes; Particle beams; Performance; Pulse generators; Storage rings; Beam dumping kicker system; Free wheel diode stack; Large Electron Positron Collider; Colliding beam accelerators

Authors: Liu Shengyi, Dougal Roger.A.
Title: Observation of intense electron beam generation from plasma closing/opening switches
Source title: IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference - Digest of Technical Papers
Affiliations: Univ of South Carolina, Columbia, United States
Authors with affiliations: Liu, Shengyi, Univ of South Carolina, Columbia, United States; Dougal, Roger.A., Univ of South Carolina, Columbia, United States
Abstract: Operation of a magnetically delayed vacuum switch (MDVS) in a closing then opening sequence produces an intense electron beam during the opening phase. Experimental demonstration of electron beam extraction and measurement of the beam parameters was accomplished on two different switch devices. The measurements show that the beam brightness exceeds 2×109 A/m2-radian2, comparable to that from other technologically important sources. The kinetic energy of the beam is determined by the voltage generated across the storage inductor during the opening phase, and can be much higher than the capacitor bank voltage. The beam pulse duration is 20 to approximately 40 ns FWHM.
Index Keywords: Capacitor storage; Electric currents; Electron beams; Plasma devices; Pulse generators; Intense electron beam generation; Magnetically delayed vacuum switch; Plasma closing/opening switches; Electric switches

Authors: Bartsch R.R., Gribble R.F., Greene A.E., Cochrane J.C.
Title: Protection fuse for a 4.5 MJ capacitor bank
Source title: IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference - Digest of Technical Papers
Affiliations: Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bartsch, R.R., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Gribble, R.F., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Greene, A.E., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Cochrane, J.C., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States
Abstract: Protection fuses were developed for the 4.5 MJ Pegasus-II capacitor bank. These fuses were designed to prevent voltage swings of greater than 120% of the maximum capacitor charge voltage - maximum permitted reversal is the actual charge voltage minus 1.20 times the maximum allowed charge voltage. This is accomplished without significantly degrading the current wave form. A major portion of the capacitor bank stored energy is dissipated in the protection elements, and the voltage during the interruption process is kept as low as possible. The parameters of test circuits and fuses are presented, and test data are analyzed and discussed.
Index Keywords: Electric currents; Electric equipment protection; Electric fuses; Electric losses; Equipment testing; Mathematical models; Voltage control; Pegasus II capacitor bank; Capacitor storage

Authors: Ollis C.W., Cravey W.R., Hawkins S.A., Kirbie H.C., Newton M.A.
Title: Spice modeling of a FET-switched induction accelerator cell
Source title: IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference - Digest of Technical Papers
Affiliations: Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab, Livermore, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ollis, C.W., Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab, Livermore, United States; Cravey, W.R., Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab, Livermore, United States; Hawkins, S.A., Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab, Livermore, United States; Kirbie, H.C., Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab, Livermore, United States; Newton, M.A., Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab, Livermore, United States
Abstract: A PSpice model of an induction accelerator cell switched by field-effect transistors (FETs) has been developed to simulate the modulator's circuit performance and induction core flux behavior. A FET switched induction cell has been built that generate 4-kV, 1 μs pulses at pulse rates exceeding 100 kHz. The circuit architecture provides for core reset between pulses and produces bursts of pulses that are variable in amplitude, pulse width and prf. The transistor switching array, energy storage capacitors, reset circuit, and cell core are all combined into a compact, low-impedance package. This high-prf induction cell is being developed as the accelerating element for a proposed heavy-ion recirculator, which is an arrangement of many small induction cells in a 30-m diameter circle. The recirculator will accept 10-MeV ions from a linear ion accelerator, under development at the Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, and continue their acceleration to 60-MeV by repeatedly passing the ion beam through the many 5-kV cells. As the ions gain speed, the cell prf must also keep pace by increasing from 70 kHz to 200 kHz. Simple PSpice models have been used to predict B-H loop behavior in the magnetic core and to analyze circuit performance. Simulations of the induction cell will be presented and compared with experimental data.
Index Keywords: Arrays; Capacitor storage; Electric impedance; Electronics packaging; Field effect transistors; Ions; Magnetic materials; Mathematical models; Modulators; Particle accelerators; Performance; Semiconductor switches; Field effect transistor switched induction accelerator cell; Induction core flux; PSpice model; Pulse generators

Authors: Weise Th.H.G.G., Loeffler M.J.
Title: Experimental investigations on rock fractioning by replacing explosives with electrically generated pressure pulses
Source title: IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference - Digest of Technical Papers
Affiliations: TZN Forschungs- und, Entwicklungszentrum Unterluss GmbH, Unterluss, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Weise, Th.H.G.G., TZN Forschungs- und, Entwicklungszentrum Unterluss GmbH, Unterluss, Germany; Loeffler, M.J., TZN Forschungs- und, Entwicklungszentrum Unterluss GmbH, Unterluss, Germany
Abstract: Experimental results obtained from fundamental investigations on rock fractioning with electrically generated pressure pulses are presented. After discussing the basic considerations the principle of the introduced technology is presented and discussed. In order to demonstrate the performance of electrically generated detonations experimental investigations are conducted. By using a 100 kJ capacitor bank aluminum wires are exploded which are embedded in waterfilled tubes. These tubes are arranged within the devices to be detonated. Parameter studies have been performed which led to the detailed knowledge of the processes taking place during the energy transfer into the device to be detonated. The results are discussed and an overview about different kinds of applications closes the paper.
Index Keywords: Aluminum compounds; Blasting; Detonation; Electric arcs; Electric energy storage; Electric wire; Electricity; Explosives; Plasma applications; Capacitor bank aluminum wires; Electrically generated pressure pulses; Energy transfer; Rock fractioning; Rock mechanics

Authors: Luu K., Chang D., Coradeschi T., Hildenbrand D., Rapka J.
Title: Design and test results of a thermally fused explosive switch
Source title: IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference - Digest of Technical Papers
Affiliations: US Army Armament Research, Development and Engineering Cent, Picatinny Arsenal, United States
Authors with affiliations: Luu, K., US Army Armament Research, Development and Engineering Cent, Picatinny Arsenal, United States; Chang, D., US Army Armament Research, Development and Engineering Cent, Picatinny Arsenal, United States; Coradeschi, T., US Army Armament Research, Development and Engineering Cent, Picatinny Arsenal, United States; Hildenbrand, D., US Army Armament Research, Development and Engineering Cent, Picatinny Arsenal, United States; Rapka, J., US Army Armament Research, Development and Engineering Cent, Picatinny Arsenal, United States
Abstract: The need to reduce solid armature and launch package start-up acceleration for an inductively driven railgun necessitates an increase in the storage inductor to gun commutation time. For this purpose, a `fused,' high current, explosively actuated opening switch has been designed and tested at the Electric Armaments Division, ARDEC, Picatinny Arsenal, New Jersey. The switch has been operated in the 600 kA to 1300 kA current range and has repeatedly demonstrated opening times from 720 μs at 600 kA to 840 μs at 1000 kA. Armature jerk for an 615 gram solid armature has been reduced from 350 Megagees (MG)/sec to 38 MG/sec at the 600 kA operating point. The design premise for the thermal fusing section, operating experience and test results are presented.
Index Keywords: Electric commutation; Electric energy storage; Equipment testing; Mathematical models; Product design; Rail guns; Thermal effects; Thermally fused explosive switch; Electric switches

Authors: Strachan D., Ford R., Hammon J., da Silva T., MacDougal F., Weise T.
Title: Design and performance of a transportable 1 MJ pulsed power source for electric gun investigation
Source title: IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference - Digest of Technical Papers
Affiliations: Physics Intl Co, San Leandro, United States
Authors with affiliations: Strachan, D., Physics Intl Co, San Leandro, United States; Ford, R., Physics Intl Co, San Leandro, United States; Hammon, J., Physics Intl Co, San Leandro, United States; da Silva, T., Physics Intl Co, San Leandro, United States; MacDougal, F., Physics Intl Co, San Leandro, United States; Weise, T., Physics Intl Co, San Leandro, United States
Abstract: In this paper, we describe a transportable 1.0 MJ energy storage bank designed for use as a electrothermal gun driver. The bank is installed in a standard transport container, to allow its use at various proving grounds in Europe. At the full 44 kV charging voltage, the bank provides short circuit currents to 180 kA. In normal operation, the bank produces over-damped discharges with 1 GW peak power in pulse duration of 1 ms. The energy storage capacitors are designed to be `self clearing' in the event of an internal dielectric breakdown. The design of the bank also eliminates individual capacitor fuses, employing compact ceramic resistors to limit fault currents and voltage reversals. All control and diagnostic functions are controlled via fiberoptics for safety, as well as interference considerations. In the following paragraphs, we describe the layout and operational parameters of the system and strategies implemented for fault mitigation. Performance data into a dummy load and a short circuit are also presented.
Index Keywords: Capacitor storage; Electric breakdown of solids; Electric discharges; Electric equipment protection; Electric loads; Electric power supplies to apparatus; Fiber optics; Pulse generators; Short circuit currents; Electrothermal gun; Transportable pulsed power source; Electromagnetic launchers

Authors: Pratap S.B., Kitzmiller J.R., Aanstoos T.A., Cook K.G., Headifen R.N., Kuenast R.A., Lee R.A., Liu H.-P., Wehrlen D.J.
Title: Optimization and design of the air core compulsator for the cannon caliber electromagnetic launcher system (CCEML)
Source title: IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference - Digest of Technical Papers
Affiliations: Univ of Texas at Austin, Austin, United States
Authors with affiliations: Pratap, S.B., Univ of Texas at Austin, Austin, United States; Kitzmiller, J.R., Univ of Texas at Austin, Austin, United States; Aanstoos, T.A., Univ of Texas at Austin, Austin, United States; Cook, K.G., Univ of Texas at Austin, Austin, United States; Headifen, R.N., Univ of Texas at Austin, Austin, United States; Kuenast, R.A., Univ of Texas at Austin, Austin, United States; Lee, R.A., Univ of Texas at Austin, Austin, United States; Liu, H.-P., Univ of Texas at Austin, Austin, United States; Wehrlen, D.J., Univ of Texas at Austin, Austin, United States
Abstract: The Center for Electromechanics at The University of Texas at Austin (CEM-UT) is currently in the manufacturing phase of a skid mounted, compulsator driven 30 mm (round-bore equivalent), rapid fire railgun system. The objective of the 30-month program is to develop a compact, lightweight test bed capable of launching three, five-round salvos of 185-g payloads to 1.85 km/s at a firing rate of 5 Hz. Per contractual requirement, the system is also fully compatible with the Amphibious Assault Vehicle (AAV). This paper describes the results of the optimization process used in determining the power supply requirements for the CCEML. The paper presents the performance specifications and design of the compulsator and critical power electronics resulting from the optimization process. The compulsator (CPA) is a four-pole, self-excited, air-core design which stores the energy for all three salvos inertially.
Index Keywords: Electric energy storage; Electric power supplies to apparatus; Electronic equipment; Optimization; Parameter estimation; Rail guns; Air core compulsator; Cannon caliber electromagnetic launcher system (CCEML); Critical power electronics; Fire railgun system; Four pole self excited air core design; Electromagnetic launchers

Authors: Kotov Yu.A., Mesyats G.A., Rukin S.N., Filatov A.L., Lyubutin S.K.
Title: Novel nanosecond semiconductor opening switch for megavolt repetitive pulsed power technology: Experiment and applications
Source title: IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference - Digest of Technical Papers
Affiliations: Russian Acad of Sciences, Ekaterinburg, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Kotov, Yu.A., Russian Acad of Sciences, Ekaterinburg, Russian Federation; Mesyats, G.A., Russian Acad of Sciences, Ekaterinburg, Russian Federation; Rukin, S.N., Russian Acad of Sciences, Ekaterinburg, Russian Federation; Filatov, A.L., Russian Acad of Sciences, Ekaterinburg, Russian Federation; Lyubutin, S.K., Russian Acad of Sciences, Ekaterinburg, Russian Federation
Abstract: A novel nanosecond semiconductor opening switch (SOS) has been developed which has a pulsed power of the GW range and voltage levels of up to a few 100's of kV. The SOS is based on high-voltage solid state rectifiers and is designed for pulsed power generators with inductive energy storage. A 30 ns opening phase duration, a 45 kA interrupted current, and a 450 kV opened SOS voltage have been attained with the use of a three-stage, 2 kJ. 150 kV open circuit Marx generator as the SOS driver. On the basis of the experimental results obtained, we have developed and tested repetitive high-current generators and accelerators with a 0.5 MV output voltage and a 15 to 100 ns pulse width. The ideology is presented of constructing high-power megavolt pulsed generators with an all-solid-state switching system. A description is provided of the setups developed on this principle. We discuss features peculiar to the setups developed and prospects of developing these further.
Index Keywords: Electric currents; Electric energy storage; Electric generators; Electric power utilization; Solid state rectifiers; Inductive energy storage; Marx generator; Nanosecond semiconductor opening switch (SOS); Pulsed power generators; Semiconductor switches

Authors: Sayeh M.R., Athinarayanan R.
Title: Extrema of R-energy function in LYAM system
Source title: Intelligent Engineering Systems Through Artificial Neural Networks
Affiliations: Southern Illinois Univ at Carbondale, Carbondale, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sayeh, M.R., Southern Illinois Univ at Carbondale, Carbondale, United States; Athinarayanan, R., Southern Illinois Univ at Carbondale, Carbondale, United States
Abstract: In this paper, a study of the R-energy function of the Lyapunov associative memory (LYAM) system is given. This system operates as an unsupervised classifier, vector quantizer, or content-addressable memory. The R-energy function stores each pattern cluster by creating a local minimum. Therefore, it is crucial to know where these minima are and how close they can be. In general, a closed-form solution is difficult to find due to the transcendental nature of R function. However, we found the maximum in closed form and the two minima in approximation for the two-class system in one dimensional space.

Authors: Fujita S., Hamamoto I., Nakamura K., Tanaka K., Ozawa K.
Title: Evaluation of oxygen necessity during hypothermic liver perfusion
Affiliations: Second Department of Surgery, Faculty of Medicine, Kyoto University, 54 Shogoin-Kawara-cho, Sakyo-ku, Kyoto 606, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Fujita, S., Second Department of Surgery, Faculty of Medicine, Kyoto University, 54 Shogoin-Kawara-cho, Sakyo-ku, Kyoto 606, Japan; Hamamoto, I., Second Department of Surgery, Faculty of Medicine, Kyoto University, 54 Shogoin-Kawara-cho, Sakyo-ku, Kyoto 606, Japan; Nakamura, K., Second Department of Surgery, Faculty of Medicine, Kyoto University, 54 Shogoin-Kawara-cho, Sakyo-ku, Kyoto 606, Japan; Tanaka, K., Second Department of Surgery, Faculty of Medicine, Kyoto University, 54 Shogoin-Kawara-cho, Sakyo-ku, Kyoto 606, Japan; Ozawa, K., Second Department of Surgery, Faculty of Medicine, Kyoto University, 54 Shogoin-Kawara-cho, Sakyo-ku, Kyoto 606, Japan
Abstract: Need of oxygen by the liver during hypothermic perfusion was evaluated using isolated perfusion model. Livers were perfused by a continuous perfusion system with oxygen saturated perfusate or nitrogen saturated perfusate, or simply stored for 12 hours at 5°C. Quality of individual liver was assessed at one hour after normothermic reperfusion. Tissue edema was significant in all experimental groups, but the extent of which was much higher in nitrogen and simple cold storage groups. AST, ATL, LDH and PNP in the perfusate at the end of normothermic reperfusion were significantly higher in nitrogen and simple storage groups and those of oxygen group were similar to the control. Tissue adenine nucleotide and purine catabolite concentration in oxygen group was almost identical to the control at the end of hypothermic preservation, while ATP and energy charge in nitrogen and simple cold storage groups were significantly low. Conjugated dienes before and after reperfusion showed no difference in any groups, indicating no involvement of free radical injury on reperfusion in this asanguineous perfusion model. These results suggest that continuous supply of oxygen is necessary for liver preservation even though the temperature is lowered to inhibit cellular metabolism.
Author Keywords: free radical; liver; oxygen; perfusion; preservation

Authors: Fujita S., Hamamoto I., Nakamura K., Tanaka K., Ozawa K.
Title: Effect of nutritional status on hypothermic liver perfusion
Affiliations: Second Department of Surgery, Faculty of Medicine, Kyoto University, 54 Shogoin-Kawara-cho, Sakyo-ku, Kyoto 606, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Fujita, S., Second Department of Surgery, Faculty of Medicine, Kyoto University, 54 Shogoin-Kawara-cho, Sakyo-ku, Kyoto 606, Japan; Hamamoto, I., Second Department of Surgery, Faculty of Medicine, Kyoto University, 54 Shogoin-Kawara-cho, Sakyo-ku, Kyoto 606, Japan; Nakamura, K., Second Department of Surgery, Faculty of Medicine, Kyoto University, 54 Shogoin-Kawara-cho, Sakyo-ku, Kyoto 606, Japan; Tanaka, K., Second Department of Surgery, Faculty of Medicine, Kyoto University, 54 Shogoin-Kawara-cho, Sakyo-ku, Kyoto 606, Japan; Ozawa, K., Second Department of Surgery, Faculty of Medicine, Kyoto University, 54 Shogoin-Kawara-cho, Sakyo-ku, Kyoto 606, Japan
Abstract: The effect of nutritional status on livers preserved either by simple cold storage or by hypothermic perfusion was studied using isolated rat liver perfusion model. Livers either form fed or fasted rats were preserved for 18 hours by simple cold storage procedure with UW solution, or continuously perfused for 12 hours at 5 or 20°C. Each liver was assessed by one hour normothermic reperfusion following preservation period. Fasted livers in each preservation procedure demonstrated deterioration of hepatocytes more than fed livers assessed by AST, ALT and LDH liberation into perfusate. PNP in the perfusion procedures showed no difference between fasted and fed livers. Slight sinusoidal lining cells changes and vacuolization in hepatocytes were preferential in all groups. Patchy areas of hepatocytic discoloration were often seen in fasted group in each preservation procedure. The nutritional status of hepatic graft is important in both simple storage and continuous perfusion preservation method.
Author Keywords: liver; nutrition; perfusion; preservation; transplantation

Title: Enhancement of transient stability using superconducting magnetic energy storage
Source title: Proceedings of the 10th IEEE Region Conference on Computer, Communication, Control and Power Engineering
Affiliations: North China Electric Power Research, Inst, Beijing, China
Authors with affiliations: Xiaokui, Li, North China Electric Power Research, Inst, Beijing, China; Fan, Jiang, North China Electric Power Research, Inst, Beijing, China
Abstract: The Superconducting Magnet Energy Storage (SMES) system is a special and advanced technique studied for FACTS, Flexible AC Transmission Systems. This paper provides an application of the SMES for solving the transient stability problem of a generator connected to a infinite power system. The controller of SMES is demanded to have the stability ability by controlling SMES to provide appropriate energy in certain time. ANN, which has received more and more attention recently, is a better choice as the controller. A special controller is designed for modulating the SMES input signal. The structure and parameters of proposed ANN controller are determined from the PID controller whose parameters are acquired by pole assignment method. The computer simulations on the nonlinear power system model demonstrate the control effort of the proposed controller under disturbing condition. The result is promising.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Control systems; Energy storage; Superconducting magnets; System stability; Artificial neural networks; Superconducting magnetic energy storage; Electric power systems

Authors: Schainker Robert B., Mehta Ben, Pollak Robert
Title: Overview of CAES technology
Source title: Proceedings of the American Power Conference
Affiliations: Electric Power Research Inst EPRI, Palo Alto, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schainker, Robert B., Electric Power Research Inst EPRI, Palo Alto, United States; Mehta, Ben, Electric Power Research Inst EPRI, Palo Alto, United States; Pollak, Robert, Electric Power Research Inst EPRI, Palo Alto, United States
Abstract: CAES plants are attractive alternatives to other storage options, and can save utilities and their customers money due to their load-levelling, dynamic and strategic benefits. It is preferred storage option when daily storage time periods of 3 to 12 hours are required. CAES sites are available in about 85% of the area of the continental USA, and every utility who considered CAES has found at least one suitable site. The first plant, built in Germany, has been operating reliably since 1978. The first USA plant has been in operation since 1991. Future CAES plants, which take advantage of other CAES plant configurations (eg using saturators) and present combustion turbine technology, will be capable of lower NOx, lower operating costs, and lower capital costs.
Index Keywords: Combustion; Compressed air motors; Electric power plants; Energy storage; Compressed Air Energy Storage (CAES); Electric utility industry; Load factors; Compressed air

Authors: Bolduc Phil, Lehmicke David, Smith Joseph
Title: Performance of a grid-connected PV system with energy storage
Source title: Conference Record of the IEEE Photovoltaic Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Ascension Technology, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bolduc, Phil, Ascension Technology, United States; Lehmicke, David, Ascension Technology, United States; Smith, Joseph, Ascension Technology, United States
Abstract: With sponsorship from the Pennsylvania Energy Office and Philadelphia Electric Company (PECO), a one kilowatt amorphous photovoltaic system has been operated in a grid-connected mode with energy storage. The purpose of the system development and performance experiment is to investigate the additional value a grid-connected system garners with dispatchable battery energy storage. From the start of the project the first goal of the systems operation was to provide a given rated power supply to the grid during a pre-set dispatch interval everyday. As such the ability to maximize total energy output was compromised in order to meet this goal. Meeting the reliability goal while minimizing energy loss provided the stimulus for much of the stimulation analysis performed early in the project.
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Computer simulation; Electric batteries; Energy storage; Performance; Grid connected PV systems; Philadelphia Electric Company; Photovoltaic cells

Abstract: The Magnet Power Supply System is described by specification design, hardware, and operating experience. A unique system for the one Hz, 1.5 GeV Booster, where the wideband QF and QD power supplies track the dipole current to within 0.1% at injection will be detailed. AC distribution system considerations related to inverting the stored energy of the booster magnet back into power grid will be discussed. The rational for linear correctors and individual quad supplies (225 total units) will be placed within the context of the storage-ring requirements.

Abstract: We designed a compact electron storage ring system which gives a X-ray photons density of 1010 photons/mm2/sec at 33 keV for the K-edge subtraction method using a two-dimensional imaging system. We adopted a beam energy of 1.75GeV, the maximum field of superconducting wigglers of 8.3 Tesla, a stored current higher than 800mA and a low energy injection system. The ring system with a circumference of about 60m is feasible.

Authors: Goetzberger A., Bopp G., GrieBhaber W., Stahl W.
Title: PV/Hydrogen/Oxygen-System of the self-sufficient solar house Freiburg
Source title: Conference Record of the IEEE Photovoltaic Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Fraunhofer-Inst fur Solare, Energiesysteme, Freiburg, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Goetzberger, A., Fraunhofer-Inst fur Solare, Energiesysteme, Freiburg, Germany; Bopp, G., Fraunhofer-Inst fur Solare, Energiesysteme, Freiburg, Germany; GrieBhaber, W., Fraunhofer-Inst fur Solare, Energiesysteme, Freiburg, Germany; Stahl, W., Fraunhofer-Inst fur Solare, Energiesysteme, Freiburg, Germany
Abstract: Solar radiation is the only energy source to supply the inhabitants of the Self-Sufficient Solar House (SSSH) with heat and electricity. The house had no grid connection, no auxillary fossil fuels are used. The transparent insulation of the southern building walls is the solar space heating system. A bifacially illuminated flat plate collector provides the domestic hot water. A PV-generator of 4.2 kW provides all the electrical power for appliances and the control system and indirectly hydrogen gas for cooking. For short term energy storage there is a lead-acid battery. For long-term storage (summer to winter), an electrolyser is used, which produces hydrogen and oxygen. In winter the gases are either transformed into electricity for electrical appliances by a fuel cell or used directly for cooking. The household is equipped with commercially available energy-efficient electrical appliances for 230 V AC. The construction of the house was completed in October 1992 after 3 years of research, planning and design. The first results show a good agreement with the simulation results.
Index Keywords: Electric batteries; Electric power systems; Energy storage; Houses; Hydrogen; Oxygen; Space heating; Self sufficient solar houses; Photovoltaic cells

Authors: Byrne John, Wang Young Doo, Nigro Ralph, Bottenberg William
Title: Commercial building demand-side management tools: requirements for dispatchable photovoltaic systems
Source title: Conference Record of the IEEE Photovoltaic Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Univ of Delaware, Newark, United States
Authors with affiliations: Byrne, John, Univ of Delaware, Newark, United States; Wang, Young Doo, Univ of Delaware, Newark, United States; Nigro, Ralph, Univ of Delaware, Newark, United States; Bottenberg, William, Univ of Delaware, Newark, United States
Abstract: We examine the potential for dispatchable, peak shaving PV arrays using storage, in terms of economic benefit, system requirements and potential for success. We conclude that the use of the system as a dispatchable peak shaving tool provides much more value than PV systems built to maximize energy output only. Reductions of 30% in major systems components will enable the introduction of dispatchable peak shaving PV systems as a cost effective option for commercial buildings. Finally, the eventual inclusion of tax effects and environmental and fuel risk factors in the analysis will make these applications more cost effective for a wider range of applications
Index Keywords: Buildings; Cost accounting; Electric utilities; Management; Demand side management; Dispatchable photovoltaic systems; Photovoltaic cells

Abstract: A new technology has been developed in the field of photosynthesis to study energy storage in different organelles and leaves. The methodology is based on the ″mirage effect″, in which a refractive index gradient is induced in a fluid in contact with the sample. The sample (leaf, algae...) is irradiated with an intensity-modulated light, producing the periodic deflection of a laser beam parallel to the surface.

Abstract: Signals of high-energy bremsstrahlung in the TRISTAN accumulation ring was observed with lead-glass counters, accompanied by a sudden decrease in the electron beam lifetime which occurred due to microparticle trapping in the electron beam. The observation showed a trapped microparticle made a periodic oscillation; the period was 1s. The observation coincides with the result based on our newly developed theory for vertical oscillation of a trapped microparticle. Furthermore, the calculated variation in the beam lifetime also coincides with the actual variation in the beam lifetime.

Abstract: The MIT-Bates Linear Accelerator Center is now in the commissioning stage for the new South Hall Ring (SHR). The SHR is a 1 GeV electron storage/stretcher ring with a 190 meter circumference and is designed for circulating beams of 80 mA. This paper describes the design of the vacuum system, hardware developed and operational performance during commissioning.

Authors: Early R.A., Raubenheimer T.O.
Title: Computer studies of a combined-function bend magnet for a proposed redesign of the SLAC SLC damping rings
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Stanford Univ, Stanford, United States
Authors with affiliations: Early, R.A., Stanford Univ, Stanford, United States; Raubenheimer, T.O., Stanford Univ, Stanford, United States
Abstract: A proposed redesign of the SLAC SLC Damping Ring requires a combined-function bending magnet. The magnet will operate with a main field of 1.8338 T, and quadrupole and sextupole gradients dBy/dx, d2By/dx2 of -14.1 T/m and -477 T/m2, respectively. Because the orbit sagitta in the magnet is in excess of 2 cm, the pole will be curved with a 2 m radius of curvature. Furthermore, since the current must be variable over a range of ±2 percent, we have considered using vanadium permendur poles to avoid adverse saturation effects. Studies were done using POISSON in 2-D and TOSCA for 3-D end effects.

Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: W.J. Schafer Associates, Inc, Livermore, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bieri, Robert L., W.J. Schafer Associates, Inc, Livermore, United States
Abstract: A computer model for the cost and performance of a recirculating induction heavy-ion accelerator for driving inertial fusion reactions has been developed. This code has been used to examine the driver design space in an effort to reduce driver costs while maintaining high driver efficiency and target gain. The driver model is described, and the results of parametric studies are reported. The design parameters examined include driver energy, maximum magnetic field allowed at the superconducting windings, maximum bending field in each ring, axial quadrupole field packing fraction for the focusing magnets in each ring, and ion mass.

Authors: Caspers F., Chanel M., Oeftiger U.
Title: Novel method of noise suppression in beam transfer function measurements
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Caspers, F., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Chanel, M., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Oeftiger, U., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Abstract: Beam transfer function (BTF), giving the frequency domain response of the beam to an external excitation, are widely used to measure the impedance of the beam environment, to analyze stability conditions and to determine the true momentum distribution in spite of strong signal shielding in dense, cooled beams. A problem encountered in low intensity (antiproton and rare ion) storage rings is the unwanted noise on the BTF signal. We have developed a method of noise suppression which may be viewed as gating in time domain. Transforming (by software) the BTF into the time domain, cutting off the tail after the response decayed and going back into frequency space we obtain a significantly clearer signal. The tail of the time response contains information on beam and system noise which can be treated separately. Results obtained on the low energy antiproton ring LEAR are discussed.
Index Keywords: Control systems; Mathematical models; Measurements; Particle beams; Signal processing; Transfer functions; Beam transfer functions; Low energy antiproton ring; Noise suppression; Time gating technique; Spurious signal noise

Authors: Salyer Ival O., Sircar Anil K.
Title: Development of phase change technology for heating and cooling of residential buildings and other applications
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Univ of Dayton Research Inst, Dayton, United States
Authors with affiliations: Salyer, Ival O., Univ of Dayton Research Inst, Dayton, United States; Sircar, Anil K., Univ of Dayton Research Inst, Dayton, United States
Abstract: The research reported herein is a continuation of work sponsored by the Department of Energy's Solar Passive Division (1982-1988) and the Office of Energy Storage and Distribution at Oak Ridge National Laboratory (ORNL) (1988-1993). The program objectives were: (1) to define a cost-effective, environmentally safe, solid-to-liquid, phase change material (PCM) that would melt and freeze sharply and concurrently at about 25°C, and have a heat of fusion +30 cal/g and (2) develop methods by which the PCM could be incorporated into building materials (specifically plasterboard) to accomplish energy conservation and electric peak-load shifting in residential and commercial buildings. These DOE PCM-plasterboard research goals have been achieved. A suitable low-cost linear alkyl hydrocarbon PCM from petroleum refining has been defined, and methods of containing the PCM to eliminate leakage and problems of expansion in melting and freezing have been developed. Processes whereby this PCM could be incorporated into plasterboard either by post-manufacturing imbibing of liquid PCM into the pore space of the plasterboard or by an additive that could be incorporated into the wet stage of plasterboard manufacture have been developed and tested in detail. Both of these processes have been successfully demonstrated in the laboratories of the University of Dayton Research Institute, National Gypsum Company (NGC) and United States Gypsum Company (USG). Large-scale plant production and testing of storage effectiveness and comfort factor in residential buildings remains to be performed.
Index Keywords: Building materials; Buildings; Cooling; Energy conservation; Freezing; Heating; Hydrocarbons; Manufacture; Materials testing; Melting; Petroleum refining; Alkyl hydrocarbon; Commercial buildings; Electric peak load shifting; Heat of fusion; Phase change material; Plasterboard; Residential buildings; Thermal energy storage materials; Energy storage

Authors: Song J.J., Kustom R.L.
Title: RF characteristics of the APS storage ring isolation valve
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States
Authors with affiliations: Song, J.J., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States; Kustom, R.L., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States
Abstract: The RF impedance of the isolation valve of the APS storage ring system was measured by the wire method with a synthetic pulse technique. The coupling impedance as well as the energy loss of the sector valve with and without an RF liner or screen, and the flange gap of the various sizes was measured. There appear to be resonances at certain frequencies without an RF liner that might cause an unacceptably large coupling impedance. Data with various sizes of the flange gap show that good RF contact around any flange is necessary. The impedance due to intrusions into the beam chamber was also measured. The results are compared with the computer simulation from MAFIA.

Title: Performance of upgraded SORTEC 1-GeV 500 mA SR source facility
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: SORTEC Corp, Tsukuba, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kishimoto, T., SORTEC Corp, Tsukuba, Japan; Kodaira, M., SORTEC Corp, Tsukuba, Japan; Awaji, N., SORTEC Corp, Tsukuba, Japan; Mukugl, K., SORTEC Corp, Tsukuba, Japan; Araki, M., SORTEC Corp, Tsukuba, Japan; Kijima, Y., SORTEC Corp, Tsukuba, Japan; Haraguchi, M., SORTEC Corp, Tsukuba, Japan
Abstract: At SORTEC, the 1GeV SR source facility has been successfully upgraded. The ultrahigh vacuum of the storage ring was completely recovered. At present, the maximum beam lifetime reached 25 at 500mA and 80 h at 200 mA. Machine studies are continuing for investigation of the beam behavior at various stored beam currents of up to 500mA, by using the merit of the full energy injection scheme. In this paper, the performance of RF accelerating system, ion clearing effects and vacuum characteristics are described. As a result, it is shown that the lifetime predicted from the theoretical considerations has been almost attained.

Authors: Rudd A.F.
Title: Phase-change material wallboard for distributed thermal storage in buildings
Affiliations: Florida Solar Energy Cent, Cape Canaveral, United States
Authors with affiliations: Rudd, A.F., Florida Solar Energy Cent, Cape Canaveral, United States
Abstract: Development and testing were conducted for a prototype phase-change material (PCM) wallboard to enhance the thermal energy storage capacity of buildings with particular interest in peak load shifting. Most important, it was determined that small-scale differential scanning calorimetry can adequately predict (within 9%) the performance of PCM wallboard when installed in full-scale applications. Initial PCM wallboard developmental tests were conducted on a small scale using a differential scanning calorimeter (DSC). The DSC measured the melting point and latent heat of selected phase-change materials and some prototype PCM wallboard. Based on these initial DSC tests, coconut fatty acid was selected for the room-scale PCM wallboard tests due to its favorable melting and freezing temperature range. At a loading of 25% by weight, the DSC measured an average latent heat of 9.57 Btu/lb (22.26 J/g) for the PCM wallboard. The average melting point was 76.8 °F (24.9 °C). Additional tests were conducted to ascertain DSC measurement reproducibility, spatial uniformity of PCM loading, and PCM high-temperature stability. Room-scale tests showed that the PCM wallboard had an average thermal storage capacity of 10.4 Btu/lb (24.2 J/g). This varied by only 8.7% compared to the latent heat recorded by the DSC. Thus expensive, large-scale testing may not be required until a PCM wallboard product is well along in development. Thus far, the PCM wallboard development work has experimentally shown that the concept is workable on a large scale and that phase-change material can be successfully integrated and distributed within a building with a significant thermal storage effect. However, to obtain the magnitude of storage required, more work is needed to identify or develop new materials with greater latent heat capacity while keeping the melting/freezing range between 72 °F (22.2 °C) and 79 °F (26.1 °C).
Index Keywords: Building materials; Calorimetry; Fatty acids; Materials testing; Thermal effects; Walls (structural partitions); Coconut fatty acid; Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC); Melting point; Phase change material (PCM) wallboard; Thermal energy storage capacity; Heat storage

Authors: Muljadi Eduard, Lipo Thomas A.
Title: Series compensated PWM inverter with battery supply applied to an isolated induction generator
Source title: Conference Record - IAS Annual Meeting (IEEE Industry Applications Society)
Affiliations: Univ of Wisconsin Madison, Madison, United States
Authors with affiliations: Muljadi, Eduard, Univ of Wisconsin Madison, Madison, United States; Lipo, Thomas A., Univ of Wisconsin Madison, Madison, United States
Abstract: This paper proposes a new series compensated induction generator/battery supply topology which provides a constant voltage and frequency at the terminals, allowing minimum current harmonic distortion while at the same time providing a source and sink of real and reactive power. With appropriate control of the reactive power, the speed of the generator is allowed to vary within a relatively wide range. This technique can be further expanded by applying AC capacitors in parallel with the load to lessen the burden of the PWM inverter. Both simulation and experimental results are in agreement with the theory which leads to the conclusion that the system could be feasible for isolated power generation systems (wind, hydro, diesel or hybrid generation).

Authors: Jonscher Andrew K.
Title: Energy criterion in the interpretation of the universal dielectric response
Source title: Annual Report - Conference on Electrical Insulation and Dielectric Phenomena
Affiliations: Univ of London, Surrey, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Jonscher, Andrew K., Univ of London, Surrey, United Kingdom
Abstract: The 'universal' dielectric response follows a frequency dependence of the complex susceptibility given by a fractional power law in which the ratio of energy lost per radian to energy stored at the peak is independent of frequency. It is shown that this 'energy criterion' can be satisfied in any solid state system in which the energy lost in every microscopic reversal of polarisation is independent of the rate of reversals. Specific models are discussed, such as dipolar and charge carrier polarisations in solids, and it is shown that the exponent n is related to the density of the polarising species and also to the dipole 'length' which in the case of hopping charge carriers means the hopping distance. The limiting forms of dielectric response corresponding to the 'flat' low-loss behaviour characteristic of good insulators, with n → 1 is obtained with low density systems, while in high-density systems the highly lossy Debye-like dipolar or 'Low-Frequency Dispersion' (LFD) charge carrier response is found in good agreement with experimental observations. The concept of constant microscopic loss per reversal is remarkably simple physically and constitutes an excellent basis for the interpretation of a wide range of dielectric behaviours.
Index Keywords: Charge carriers; Electric energy storage; Electric insulators; Energy dissipation; Fourier transforms; Mathematical models; Polarization; Solid state devices; Debye-like dipolar; Energy criterion; Fractional power law; Low frequency dispersion; Universal dielectric response; Dielectric properties

Authors: Jason A.J., Hardekopf R.A., Macek R.W., Schriber S.O., Thiessen H.A., Woods R.

Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference

Abstract: A design study for an accelerator-driven spallation-neutron source is underway at Los Alamos. The driver, based on the LAMPF facility, produces a 1-MW proton beam and is upgradable to 5 MW. After linear acceleration to full energy, an H- beam is accumulated for approximately 1.2 ms in an accumulator ring and then extracted to produce an intense proton burst, less than 1 μs long, onto a spallation-target system with a 60-Hz pulse rate. The design uses existing infrastructure insofar as possible while maintaining project goals. This paper summarizes the system specifications and design status.

Authors: Chubar O.V., Smolyakov N.V.
Title: Generation of intensive long-wavelength edge radiation in high-energy electron storage rings
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Kurchato Inst, Moscow, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Chubar, O.V., Kurchato Inst, Moscow, Russian Federation; Smolyakov, N.V., Kurchato Inst, Moscow, Russian Federation
Abstract: Computation results on bending magnet edge radiation (ER) in 2.5 GeV electron storage ring Siberia-2 are reported. Special features of the ER in high-energy electron storage rings are discussed. This radiation differs from standard synchrotron radiation as well as from short-wavelength ER in proton storage rings. Emission peculiarities of the long-wavelength ER in high-energy electron storage rings are considered. The ER is shown to possess certain features of long-wavelength bremsstrahlung.

Authors: Namkung W., Ko I., Cho M., Ryu C., Bak J., Nam S., Lee H.

Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: POSTECH, Pohang, South Korea

Abstract: Pohang Accelerator Laboratory (PAL) is constructing the 2-GeV Pohang Light Source (PLS). The 2-GeV electron linear accelerator will be used as a full energy injector to the storage ring. There are 42 accelerating columns in the 150-m long linac. The linac is powered by 11 klystrons of 80-MW maximum output power, which are driven by 200-MW modulators. Two 200-MW modulators connected to the klystrons are already under normal operation, and assembly work for the nine remaining modulators is in progress. In the tunnel, about half of the linac has been installed. The cooling system is completed along with the precision temperature controllers. The installation work will be completed by the end of 1993. We present the updated construction progress of the PLS 2-GeV linac.

Abstract: An intensive and systematic lattice design study for the 2 TeV injection lines from the High Energy Booster (HEB) to the Collider rings has led to a compact resistive magnet solution which is a one piece achromat having beta function transitions on both ends and a pseudo-periodic structure in between. A comparison between several possible solutions concentrated on the desired optical flexibility and major technical problems associated with the huge amount of beam energy (6.55 MJ) in the HEB and mechanical interferences. Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Univ of Aarhus, Arhus, Denmark
Authors with affiliations: Moller, Solen Pape, Univ of Aarhus, Arhus, Denmark
Abstract: ASTRID is a storage ring/synchrotron for ions and electrons. Results from the first three years of commissioning and running will be presented. A wide range of both positive and negative ions (both atomic and molecular) varying in mass from 3He to C70 (Buckministerfullerene) have been stored in the ring. The physics has been centered around laser-cooling, lifetime measurements of measurable ions and electron recombination. The ring is 2×34 months a year operational as a 580 MeV synchrotron radiation source. (λc = 35 A), with stored currents (presently) around 150 mA. Initially, beam-loading problems in the rf-cavity hindered large currents, but a fast feedback loop has circumvented this problem. Presently the current is limited by the injection rate at 100 MeV and the lifetime of the beam, at high currents influenced by ions trapped in the beam.

Authors: Hutson R., Macek R.
Title: First-turn losses in the LAMPF proton storage ring (PSR)
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hutson, R., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Macek, R., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States
Abstract: Beam-loss measurements indicate that 0.2-0.3% of the protons injected into the PSR are lost during the first turn. We describe a plausible mechanism, involving field stripping of excited hydrogen atoms, for these losses. Protons are injected into the PSR by transporting a neutral hydrogen beam through a hole in the yoke of one ring bender and then through a carbon foil on the ring axis. The foil strips roughly 93% of the beam atoms to protons. Although the original PSR design assumed that all unstripped atoms would pass through a hole in the yoke of the next downstream bender and on to a beam stop, recent calculations indicate that about 6% of these unstripped atoms will emerge from the foil in an excited state with principle quantum number n≥3. These calculations also indicate that atoms in excited states with n≥3 will be stripped quickly to protons in the 1.2-Tesla field of the downstream bender. The trajectories of these protons will be outside the phase-space acceptance of the ring and will be quickly lost by collision with the beam pipe, thereby giving rise to first-turn losses. The estimated numbers of protons that would be lost by this mechanism are consistent with the observed first-turn loss rates. This mechanism has important consequences for the design of future storage rings that use neutral atom or negative ion stripping for injection.
Index Keywords: Colliding beam accelerators; Electron energy levels; Particle beam injection; Phase space methods; Protons; Storage rings; Beam loss measurements; First turn losses; Proton storage ring (PSR); Particle beam dynamics

Authors: Krakow K.I., Lin S., Yan L.

Authors with affiliations: Krakow, K.I., Concordia Univ, Montreal, Canada; Lin, S., Concordia Univ, Montreal, Canada; Yan, L., Concordia Univ, Montreal, Canada
Abstract: An idealized model of reversed-cycle hot gas defrosting is developed. The model is developed for systems that have receivers and that are reversed while the compressor is running. An idealized model is necessitated by the complexity of the reversed cycle. The variation with time of the condensation pressure (which is essentially the compressor discharge pressure) is shown to be due, primarily, to the mass and internal energy stored in the pressure side of the system. The model is intended to provide for simulation of the performance characteristics of defrosting cycles and to provide a means of quantitative analysis.

Authors with affiliations: Ball, Newton E., Univ of California, Pleasant Hill, United States
Abstract: A progression through reasoned steps is presented, leading to the centerless flywheel, suspended and positioned by the motor/generator of which it is the rotor. A new electrical machine form is introduced, made possible by the absence of web, hub, and axle. An example small flywheel, suitable for use as an UPS or as a weak single phase to strong three phase converter, is described and tentative specifications are given.

Abstract: DC breakdown of polyvinylidene fluoride films was studied. It was found that the interface between the metal electrode and the polymer film is very important in determining the breakdown voltage. When the positive electrode was blocked by inserting a thin layer of insulating polymer between the polyvinylidene fluoride film and the metal electrode, the breakdown voltage decreased drastically. The breakdown behavior was also studied as a function of the thickness of polymers used to block the electrode.

Authors: Donald M., Helm R., Irwin J., Moshammer H., Forest E., Robin D., Zholents A., Sullivan M.
Title: Localized chromaticity correction of low-beta insertions in storage rings
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States
Authors with affiliations: Donald, M., Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States; Helm, R., Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States; Irwin, J., Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States; Moshammer, H., Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States; Forest, E., Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States; Robin, D., Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States; Zholents, A., Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States; Sullivan, M., Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States
Abstract: The correction of the chromaticity of low-beta insertions in the storage rings is usually made with sextupole lenses in the ring's arcs. When decreasing the beta functions at the insertion point (IP), this technique becomes fairly ineffective, since it fails to properly correct the higher order chromatic aberrations. Here we consider the approach where the chromatic effects of the quadrupole lenses generating low beta functions at the IP are corrected locally with two families of sextupoles, one family for each plane. Each family has two pairs of sextupoles which are located symmetrically on both sides of the IP. The sextupole-like aberrations of individual sextupoles are eliminated by utilizing optics forming a -I transformation between sextupoles in the pair. The optics also includes bending magnets which preserve equal dispersion functions at the two sextupoles in each pair. At sextupoles in one family, the vertical beta function is made large and the horizontal is made small. The situation is reversed in the sextupoles of the other family. The betatron phase advances from the IP to the sextupoles are chosen to eliminate a second order chromatic aberration. The application of the localized chromatic correction is demonstrated using as an example the lattice design for the Low Energy Ring of the SLAC/LBL/LLNL PEP-II B Factory.
Index Keywords: Aberrations; Accelerator magnets; Betatrons; Error compensation; Error correction; Function evaluation; Lenses; Particle beam dynamics; Particle optics; Localized chromaticity correction; Low beta insertions; Storage rings

Abstract: A new beam line, expected to be built by September 1993, will transport the 50 MeV electron beam from the ALS LINAC into an experimental area to support various R&D activities in the Center for Beam Physics at LBL. A variety of experiments are planned involving the interaction of such a relativistic electron beam with plasmas (plasma focusing), laser beams (generation of femtosecond X-ray pulses) and electromagnetic cavities (Crab cavities etc....). The beam line is designed using the measured emittance and Twiss parameters of the ALS linac. It accommodates the different requirements of the various experiments on the electron beam properties (charge, energy, pulse length) and on the handling of the beam before and after the interaction point. Special attention has also been given to incorporate diagnostics for measuring the beam properties (such as the electron energy, bunch length and charge) needed in the interpretation of the experiments.

Abstract: Pulsed radar modulators employ specialized power conversion techniques to satisfy the high voltage requirements of the RF devices utilized. Well established approaches include several modulating techniques with classical and switching power supplies. More recently, so called 'hardfet' and 'modified hardfet' pulse modulating schemes have been introduced, wherein high voltage is generated with parallel-to-serial switching of arrayed energy storage modules.

Authors: Ruzhnikov V.A., Vizgalov A.V., Yarygin V.I., Wolff L.R.
Title: System analysis of a domestic central heating facility: the TECTEM
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: ECS-Russia, Obninsk, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Ruzhnikov, V.A., ECS-Russia, Obninsk, Russian Federation; Vizgalov, A.V., ECS-Russia, Obninsk, Russian Federation; Yarygin, V.I., ECS-Russia, Obninsk, Russian Federation; Wolff, L.R., ECS-Russia, Obninsk, Russian Federation
Abstract: A TECTEM is a domestic central heating facility equipped with Thermionic Energy Convertors (TECs). The TECs are combustion heated and thus produce low voltage DC electricity. An invertor converts this electricity into 110V 60Hz or 220V50Hz AC power. This power either is fed back into the grit or used at the site. In the latter case batteries are used for intermediate storage of the DC power. The TECTEM will ultimately replace the conventional central heating facilities and thus become one of the smallest possible cogeneration units. Because of the tremendous size of the world market for domestic central heating facilities, its penetration of this market may have a substantial impact on the efficiency of worldwide power production.
Index Keywords: Cogeneration plants; Systems analysis; Thermoelectric energy conversion; Conventional central heating facilities; Domestic central heating facilities; Heat supply systems; Netherlands heat supply system; Thermionic energy convertors (TEC); Heating

Authors: Kopainsky J.
Title: Co-generation power plants in MV and LV networks
Affiliations: Elektra Birseck Muenchenstein, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Kopainsky, J., Elektra Birseck Muenchenstein, Switzerland
Abstract: A co-generation power plant simultaneously converts fossil energy into heat and electricity. Its efficiency is comparable to that of a boiler. However, this conversion is more economical, since part of the output energy represents high-valued electricity. Elektra Birseck has developed the following concept in order to optimize the use of fossil energy while minimizing the emission of pollutants: The co-generation power plant is equipped with a heat buffer. During the daily electrical load peak it is electrically, else thermally controlled. Thus, energy storage and transport are performed in the physically most adequate form, viz. in the heat buffer and in the electrical power system respectively. The power system transports the energy to two types of consumers whose peak loads appear at different times of the day: First to thermal consumers with electrical heat pumps equipped with short term buffer which make use of the environmental heat. Second to electrical consumers for whom it acts as peak power plant. The stability criterion for connecting a plant to the power system is derived. The results of the operation of 25 plants during several years are presented. The costs exceed the average electrical acquisition costs by appr. 0.02 US $/KWh. In return, the emission of pollutants is reduced by appr. 40% as compared with boilers, and the electrical peak load is lowered by appr. 2%.
Index Keywords: Air pollution; Cost accounting; Electric loads; Low voltage networks; Medium voltage networks; Cogeneration plants

Authors: Chang Meng-Yueh, Ou Rong-Shyang, Tzou Ying-Yu

Affiliations: Natl Chiao Tung Univ, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Chang, Meng-Yueh, Natl Chiao Tung Univ, Taiwan; Ou, Rong-Shyang, Natl Chiao Tung Univ, Taiwan; Tzou, Ying-Yu, Natl Chiao Tung Univ, Taiwan
Abstract: This paper presents the fully digital control of a bilateral pulsewidth modulated (PWM) dc/ac and dc/dc converter for battery energy storage system (BESS) using digital signal processor (DSP). The concerned BESS consists of a switched-mode current-controlled rectifier (SCR) for power flow control and a bilateral buck/boost converter (BBC) for battery charging control. The gating signals for SCR and BBC are determined at every sampling instant by a DSP-based fuzzy controller using a set of instantaneous feedback signals. The experimental results of a 0.75 kW prototype system are shown to verify the proposed control scheme.

Source title: Proceedings of the American Power Conference
Affiliations: Savannah River Technology Center, Aiken, United States
Authors with affiliations: Buckner, M.R., Savannah River Technology Center, Aiken, United States; Inhaber, H., Savannah River Technology Center, Aiken, United States; Radder, J.A., Savannah River Technology Center, Aiken, United States; Angelos, J.G., Savannah River Technology Center, Aiken, United States
Abstract: In August 1992, the Nuclear Energy Office of the Department of Energy chartered the Plutonium Disposition Task Force to assess the disposition of excess weapons-grade plutonium. Task force workings groups considered storage, disposal, and fission options for this disposition, and a separate working group evaluated nonproliferation concerns of each alternative. As part of the Fission Working Group, the Savannah River Technology Center sponsored light-water reactor (LWR) technology. This report details the technical assessment of LWR technology for plutonium disposition. The aspects the working group considered are proliferation issues, technical feasibility, technical availability, economics, regulatory issues, and political acceptance.

Authors: Ronkowski M., Iwan K., Szczesny R.
Title: Simulation of converter - synchronous machine drives in normal and fault operation
Affiliations: Technical Univ of Gdansk, Gdansk, Poland
Authors with affiliations: Ronkowski, M., Technical Univ of Gdansk, Gdansk, Poland; Iwan, K., Technical Univ of Gdansk, Gdansk, Poland; Szczesny, R., Technical Univ of Gdansk, Gdansk, Poland
Abstract: A multiport transient equivalent circuit models of synchronous motors, applicable in simulation of converter drive systems, are presented. The proposed circuits exhibit networks with the same number of external terminals as the motor and model the machine behaviour directly in terms of the stator and/or rotor and mechanical variables as well. The main advantage of the approach is the ease of describing the system in terms of its topology. Thus, different control strategies for normal and fault operation of any converter - synchronous machine drives can be investigated. To determine the transient stator current, torque and rotor velocity for any desired supply voltage, frequency and load, the global converter-synchronous motor circuit is transformed into a sequence of dc analyses of resistive networks upon replacing each energy storage elements (inductances, rotor inertia) by a preselected implicit numerical-integration algorithm. The approach is demonstrated using a 3-phase synchronous machine supplied by a voltage source inverter. The simulation results prove that the proposed approach can be recommended for CAD programs.
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Circuit theory; Computer aided design; Computer simulation; Electric drives; Electric inverters; Electric network parameters; Equivalent circuits; Integration; Mathematical models; Time varying networks; Transients; Converter synchronous machine drives; Multiport transient equivalent circuit models; Synchronous motors

Authors: Chakravorti Ashim K., Emanuel Alexander E.
Title: Design, analysis and limitations of a Dc-to-Ac converter usable for interfacing alternative energy sources and energy storage systems with the utility grid
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Superconductivity, Inc, Middleton, United States
Authors with affiliations: Chakravorti, Ashim K., Superconductivity, Inc, Middleton, United States; Emanuel, Alexander E., Superconductivity, Inc, Middleton, United States
Abstract: This paper presents a dc-to-ac converter design that can be used to interface any type of alternative energy source or energy storage system with the utility grid. The converter is capable of real and reactive power exchanges between the utility grid and the alternative energy source(s). The control philosophy, also presented here, is very simple and allows for the synthesis of useful harmonics. Experimental results are provided to demonstrate the versatility of the converter circuit as: a reacitve power exchanger at the fundamental frequency; an Active Power Line Conditioner; and an active filter. Various design constraints are discussed and the limitations of the converter circuit are analyzed in this paper.
Index Keywords: Analysis; Design; Electric energy storage; Electric power distribution; Electric power systems; Alternative energy sources; Converter limitations; DC to AC converters; Energy storage systems; Reactive power exchanger; Utility power grid; Power converters

Authors: Brinkmann R., Willeke F.
Title: First experience with colliding electron-proton beams in HERA
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Deutsches Elektronen Synchrotron, Hamburg, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Brinkmann, R., Deutsches Elektronen Synchrotron, Hamburg, Germany; Willeke, F., Deutsches Elektronen Synchrotron, Hamburg, Germany
Abstract: We report on first experience with colliding electron and proton beams in HERA (see also [2]). In 1992, the first year of operation, HERA has delivered some 60(nb)-1 of e-p Luminosity to the experiments H1 and ZEUS. The beam energies amounted to 26GeV and 820GeV. A maximum luminosity of 2.2 · 1029cm-2s-1 has been achieved by colliding a train of nine electron bunches against nine proton bunches. A complete collection of data is contained in reference[1]. The beams could be brought into and held in collision without problems. The lifetime of the proton beam in collision is as long as 50h. This requires both careful matching of the electron and proton beam cross sections and also that the two orbits coincide within ≈ 0.2σ beam size at the interaction point. The proton beam suffered a beam-beam tune shift of up to ΔQx ≈ 0.0018. This is close to the limit which was assumed in the design of HERA. Nonetheless, there is only little degradation in the proton beam quality in collision. Under these conditions, the proton beam fills could be stored and be made available for collision for some 24h in HERA.
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Electron beams; Particle beam dynamics; Particle beams; Protons; Stability; Storage rings; Beam finding algorithm; Beam lifetime; Beam-beam tune shift; Colliding electron-proton beams; Double ring electron-proton collider; Electron bunch; Luminosity; Proton beams; Proton bunch; Colliding beam accelerators

Authors: Bloom E., Bulos F., Fieguth T., Godfrey G., Loew G., Miller R.

Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States

Abstract: The R&D program described focuses on an improvement of the SLAC linac designed to extract and study a 9 GeV electron beam under stringent control of energy, energy spread, emittance, optical parameters and timing. The extraction system starts with an on-axis pulsed magnet, followed by a magnetic lattice and diagnostic equipment required for the measurement and optimization of the above beam qualities. This system is required to fill 1658 bunches of 9 GeV electrons (0.99A stored) and 3.1 GeV positrons (2.14A stored) in two separate rings in a total of about 6 min from zero ring current or in about 3 min from 80% ring current. This electron extraction system will be capable of measuring all beam parameters important to the development of an injection system for the PEP-II asymmetric collider.

Authors: Sheng I.C., Sharma S., Rotela E., Howell J.

Abstract: A high heat load crotch absorber has been designed for the Advanced Photon Source (APS) storage ring curved chambers. The absorber, which uses a beryllium diffuser brazed to oxygen free high-conductivity copper (OFHC) plates, has been optimized to spread the beam power in order to reduce its temperature rise and thermal stresses. Circular copper tubes are brazed to the absorber for water cooling. The absorber design and analytical results from a three-dimensional finite element model are presented in this paper.

Affiliations: Univ of Lancaster, Lancaster, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Lazarus, M.J., Univ of Lancaster, Lancaster, United Kingdom; Richardson, J., Univ of Lancaster, Lancaster, United Kingdom
Abstract: Saturated bipolar transistors can have a very low collector 'on'-state voltage if the base is over-driven, making these components potential replacements for thyristor devices. However, the associated charge storage results in pulse stretching. Fortunately, pulse-length control can be achieved without the use of energy-dissipating base-discharger circuitry or semiconductor doping.
