Authors: Xi Boling, Botman J.I.M., Laar J.van, Timmermans C.J., Hagedoorn H.L.
Title: Estimation of collective effects for the EUTERPE ring
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Eindhoven Univ of Technology, Eindhoven, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Xi, Boling, Eindhoven Univ of Technology, Eindhoven, Netherlands; Botman, J.I.M., Eindhoven Univ of Technology, Eindhoven, Netherlands; Laar, J.van, Eindhoven Univ of Technology, Eindhoven, Netherlands; Timmermans, C.J., Eindhoven Univ of Technology, Eindhoven, Netherlands; Hagedoorn, H.L., Eindhoven Univ of Technology, Eindhoven, Netherlands
Abstract: In low energy storage rings with a high current, collective effects can make the real bunch length, transverse emittances and beam lifetime notably different from the ones designed on the basis of single particle dynamics. The storage ring EUTERPE is a low energy ring with a nominal beam energy of 400 MeV and with an injection energy of 75 MeV. The estimation of collective effects in this ring is reported in this paper. The dependence of several collective effects on various machine parameters, limiting effects on the bunch size and current for several optical options and possible improving measures are discussed. The results indicate that an equilibrium transverse emittance of 8.5 nm.rad with a beam current of 100 mA in a high brilliance mode is achievable, which is near the natural emittance. Collective effects have no obvious adverse effects on low energy injection in the EUTERPE ring.
Index Keywords: Accelerator magnets; Electric currents; Electric impedance; Energy storage; Estimation; Particle beam injection; Storage rings; Synchrotron radiation; Background gas scattering; Beam current; Beam lifetime; Collective effects; EUTERPE ring; Intra-beam scattering; Single bunch instability effects; Transverse emittance; Turbulent bunch lengthening; Particle beam dynamics

Abstract: Cold-end sulfuric-acid corrosion is a phenomenon common in boilers and heat recovery steam generators. Usually, operating conditions can be changed to reduce or eliminate corrosion. The operation of an on-line continuous corrosion probe in a test-rig and correlation with physical corrosion measurements is reported. Description of the development of a full-scale recuperator corrosion probe is presented as well as preliminary results.

Title: Conceptual design for one megawatt spallation neutron source at Argonne
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States
Authors with affiliations: Cho, Y., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States; Bailey, J., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States; Brown, B., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States; Brumwell, F., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States; Carpenter, J., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States; Crawford, K., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States; Horan, D., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States; Jerng, D., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States; Kelb, R., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States; Knox, A., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States; Kustom, R., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States; Lessner, E., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States; McGhee, D., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States; Mills, F., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States; Moe, H., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States; et. al., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States
Abstract: A feasibility study of a spallation neutron source based on a rapid cycling synchrotron which delivers a proton beam of 2 GeV in energy and 0.5 mA time-averaged current at a 30-Hz repetition rate is presented. The lattice consists of 90-degree phase advance FODO cells with dispersion-free straight sections, and has a three-fold symmetry. The ring magnet system will be energized by 20-Hz and 60-Hz resonant circuits to decrease the dB/dt during the acceleration cycle. This lowers the peak acceleration voltage requirement to 130 kV. The single turn extraction system will be used to extract the beam alternatively to two target stations. The first station will operate at 10 Hz for research using long wavelength neutrons, and the second station will use the remaining pulses, collectively, providing 36 neutron beams. The 400-MeV negative-hydrogen-ion injector linac consists of an ion source, rf quadrupole, matching section, 100-MeV drift-tube linac, and a 300-MeV coupled-cavity linac.
Index Keywords: Accelerator magnets; Ion sources; Linear accelerators; Particle beam extraction; Particle beams; Particle injectors; Protons; Resonant circuits; Storage rings; Synchrotrons; FODO cells; Negative hydrogen ion injector; Neutron beams; Peak acceleration voltage; Proton beams; Radiofrequency quadrupole; Rapid cycling synchrotron; Ring magnet system; Single turn extraction system; Spallation neutron source; Neutron sources

Authors: Shintake Tsumoru
Title: Suppression of longitudinal coupled-bunch instability using energy storage cavity in B-factory RF system
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: KEK: National Lab for High Energy, Physics, Tsukuba, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Shintake, Tsumoru, KEK: National Lab for High Energy, Physics, Tsukuba, Japan
Abstract: The longitudinal coupled bunch instability due to the fundamental accelerating mode can to be suppressed by attaching an energy storage cavity to a normal conducting accelerating cavity. Since the stored EM-energy in this system is very large, a small frequency detuning is sufficient to compensate reactive part of the beam loading voltage induce by extreme high beam current in B-factory storage rings. In KEK B-factory case, it is possible to use a normal conducting single cell accelerating cavity connected to an energy storage cavity of 1.2 m diameter by 1.9 m length. The stored energy in this system is 8.3 Joul, and the loaded Q is 7.2×104. The effective impedance for the coupled bunch mode (m=-1) is reduced to as low as 18 kΩ/ring. Since the growth time of the instability is 22 msec, which is comparable to the radiation damping time, this type of instability will not occur.
Index Keywords: Damping; Electric impedance; Electromagnetic fields; Storage rings; Energy storage cavity; Higher order modes (HOM); Longitudinal coupled bench instability; Cavity resonators

Authors: Yung Edward K.N., Lee Wislon W.S., Luk K.M.
Title: Dielectric resonator on a microstrip antenna

Authors with affiliations: Yung, Edward K.N., City Polytechnic of Hong Kong; Lee, Wislon W.S., City Polytechnic of Hong Kong; Luk, K.M., City Polytechnic of Hong Kong
Abstract: Microstrip antennas and dielectric resonators are extensively studied recently. Dielectric resonators are broadly used in the design of filters and other microwave devices, but they are seldom applied for radiation of energy. Studies of a coaxial line fed monopole in a dielectric resonator of cylindrical or spherical shape are found in recent literature. Dielectric radiators excited by a simpler method such as a microstrip line or coplanar waveguide are reported. A resonator by definition is a device for storage of energy, not precipitator of energy. Thus, it is not surprised to find ta all of the aforementioned dielectric radiators are inefficient antennas and their bandwidths are extremely narrow. The paper discusses an antenna comprising of a circular microstrip antenna of radius R and a circular dielectric disk of radius r of height h.

Authors with affiliations: Miyahara, Yoshikazu, JAERI-RIKEN, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: Design of a positron accumulation ring (PAR) for the SPring-8 project has been considered as an option to increase the injection rate into the storage ring via a synchrotron. The beam energy and the circumference of the PAR are 500 MeV and 28.294 m, respectively. The injection rate can be increased by about 10 times. Reduced bunch length in the PAR and RF synchronism between the PAR and the synchrotron are favorable to produce a pure single bunched beam in the storage ring.
Index Keywords: Accelerator magnets; Electron absorption; Focusing; Linear accelerators; Particle accelerator accessories; Particle beam injection; Particle optics; Synchrotron radiation; Synchrotrons; Positron beams; Storage rings

Authors: Koenig A.A.

Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Silent power Inc, Wayne, United States
Authors with affiliations: Koenig, A.A., Silent power Inc, Wayne, United States
Abstract: The principal advantage of using advantage of using advanced batteries lay in their inherent high specific energy density. In the case of sodium sulfur, this is typically 100 Wh/kg and 135 Wh/liter. For applications, such as electric vehicles, this translates to 3-fold increase in driving range over lead-acid batteries between charges. In addition to the EV market, sodium sulfur batteries also offer advantages in a utility power setting, such as supplementing power to burgeoning communities during peak demand periods and providing storage for distributed energy sources.

Abstract: The dielectric properties of LDPE filled with aluminum silicate clay fillers have been studied by thermally stimulated currents and time domain dielectric spectroscopy. The change of the charge storage behavior and related dielectric responses due to the polymer-filler interactions was investigated by analyzing the effect of the particle sizes of the fillers and that of surface modification of the fillers.

Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference

Abstract: This paper summarizes the current status of the solution to High Level Waste (HLW) management in U.S. It addresses all aspects of handling and disposal of HLW from reactor pool storage to final permanent disposal. Each problem area is discussed under the headings of issues, recommended solutions, and current status. Among the issues discussed, the public acceptance and siting obviously are the overriding issues to be solved. After much delay, the site characterization work at the Yucca Mountain potential site are now in progress.

Authors: Temnykh Alexander B., Welch James J., Rice David H.
Title: Long range beam-beam interaction at CESR. Experiments, simulation and phenomenology
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Cornell Univ, Ithaca, United States
Authors with affiliations: Temnykh, Alexander B., Cornell Univ, Ithaca, United States; Welch, James J., Cornell Univ, Ithaca, United States; Rice, David H., Cornell Univ, Ithaca, United States
Abstract: We have conducted fairly extensive experiments at CESR to measure the minimum separation using a variety of different optics, crossing points , beam currents, and energies. In all cases we have found that if the opposing beam current is large enough, we can adequately fit the minimum separation to the function proportional to the square root of the opposing beam current. However, if the opposing beam current is instead quite small, reasonable lifetime may be obtained with no separation at all. Tracking simulations give similar results. We also found that the minimum required separation depends significantly on the beta functions at the crossing points. A number of phenomenological models/criteria suitable for use in designing optics have been evaluated against the experimental data and the results are reported here. Some traditional models did not fare well in this evaluation.
Index Keywords: Colliding beam accelerators; Electron ring accelerators; Evaluation; High energy physics; Mathematical models; Particle optics; Simulation; Storage rings; BEAMBEAM experiments; Crossing points; Minimum separation; Opposing beam current; Particle beams

Authors: Chung Y., Emery L., Kirchman J.
Title: Compensation for the effect of vacuum chamber eddy current by digital signal processing for closed orbit feedback
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States
Authors with affiliations: Chung, Y., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States; Emery, L., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States; Kirchman, J., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States
Abstract: The Advanced Photon Source (APS) will implement both global and local beam position feedback systems to stabilize the particle and X-ray beams. The relatively thick (1/2″) aluminum storage ring vacuum chamber at corrector magnet locations for the local feedback systems will induce significant eddy current. This will reduce the correction bandwidth and could potentially destabilize the feedback systems. This paper describes measurements of the effect of the eddy current induced in the APS storage ring vacuum chamber by a horizontal/vertical corrector magnet and its compensation using digital signal processing at 4 kHz sampling frequency with proportional, integral, and derivative (PID) control algorithm for closed orbit feedback. A theory of digital feedback to obtain the linear system responses and the conditions for optimal control will also be presented. The magnet field in the vacuum chamber shows strong quadrupole and sextupole components varying with frequency, in addition to significant attenuation and phase shift with bandwidth (-3 dB) of 20 Hz for horizontal and 4 Hz for vertical fields relative to the magnet current. Large changes in the magnet resistance and inductance were also observed, as a result of reduced total magnetic energy and increased Ohmic heat loss.
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Digital signal processing; Eddy currents; Electric variables measurement; Magnetic variables measurement; Mathematical models; Particle accelerators; Particle beams; Advanced Photon Source accelerator; Closed orbit feedback; Correction bandwidth; Magnetic resistance; Vacuum chamber eddy current; Control systems

Authors: Bogner R.S.
Title: Super nickel cadmium cell life and test data
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Hughes Aircraft Co, Torrance, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bogner, R.S., Hughes Aircraft Co, Torrance, United States
Abstract: Hughes has developed an advanced nickel-cadmium battery cell which the authors have called the Super nickel-cadmium (Ni/Cd) cell. The Hughes Super Ni/CDTM cell incorporates design changes to negate the problems encountered in the present aerospace Ni/Cd cell. In the former, both positive and negative electrodes are impregnated by electrochemical deposition technique. This reduces the corrosion of nickel sinter and positive electrodes do not expand as rapidly as CD electrodes. The nylon separator used in the standard cell was replaced by an inert polymer impregnated zirconia cloth separator. These cells have undergone extensive life testing in both GEO and LEO regimes. Capacity loss problems were encountered during instead flight battery assembly since batteries are assembled with shorted cells. Results show that seven capacity loss are due to shorted storage & positive electrodes. Cells stored on trickle charge for up to nine months with no apparent loss. With the implementation of this procedure no losses were reported.

Authors: Tully N.
Title: Influence of installation parameters on the performance of a solar thermosyphon DHW system
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Univ of the Witwatersrand, Johannesburg, South Africa
Authors with affiliations: Tully, N., Univ of the Witwatersrand, Johannesburg, South Africa
Abstract: South Africa has an excellent solar energy resource, particularly in the main island conurbation where the annual overall energy incident on an inclined surface is typically around 20 MJ/M2/day. A simulation model for a thermosyphon domestic hot water system with in-tank electrical element back up is developed. The effects of using a vertical or a horizontal storage tank configuration and various system installation and operating parameters is considered. Results show that in terms of solar fraction, vertical tanks provide 20% and 40% better performance than horizontal tanks. Apart from solar panel area and panel less coefficient, vertical tank installations are relatively insensitive to installation parameters, whilst horizontal tanks should be more carefully optimized. It was found that a 1kW electrical backup element provides an adequate user fraction whilst minimizing electricity consumption and that using small diameter interconnecting pipes can, by limiting flowrates, be beneficial.

Authors: Somasundaram Sriram, Drost M.Kevin, Brown Daryl R., Antoniak Zenen A.
Title: Coadunation of technologies: cogeneration and thermal energy storage
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, International Gas Turbine Institute (Publication) IGTI
Affiliations: Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, United States
Authors with affiliations: Somasundaram, Sriram, Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, United States; Drost, M.Kevin, Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, United States; Brown, Daryl R., Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, United States; Antoniak, Zenen A., Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, United States
Abstract: Cogeneration is playing an increasingly important role in providing an independent and on-site high-efficiency source of power generation and thermal energy for space heating and cooling, as well as industrial process heat applications. This paper addresses some of the thermal energy storage (TES) systems that are readily applicable to be combined with cogeneration systems, and provides an update on the current status of these TES systems. TES allows a cogeneration facility to provide dispatchable electric power while providing a constant thermal load, and increase peak capacity by providing economical cooling of the combustion inlet air. The particular systems addressed are high-temperature diurnal TES, and TES for cooling the combustion turbine inlet air.

Authors: Li Hsien-Yuan, Liang Feng, Zhao Yifan, Lipo Thomas A.
Title: Doubly salient doubly excited variable reluctance motor
Source title: Conference Record - IAS Annual Meeting (IEEE Industry Applications Society)
Affiliations: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, United States
Authors with affiliations: Li, Hsien-Yuan, Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, United States; Liang, Feng, Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, United States; Zhao, Yifan, Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, United States; Lipo, Thomas A., Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, United States
Abstract: A new variable reluctance motor is introduced to help solve the energy circulation problems which exist during commutation in conventional variable motors (VRMs). The motor enables the energy stored in the magnetic field to be retained and utilized within the motor instead of being returned back to the source. The operating principles of the motor and associated converters are presented. The analysis shows that by employing both short pitch and full pitch windings, this new motor can eliminate the two problems without extra conductors in the slots. As a result the new motor has the following important performance advantages over conventional VRMs: (1) it allows a significant improvement in the turn-off process and therefore allows higher speed capacity; (2) it has higher output with the same or higher efficiency with the same output because of the improvement on the turn-off performance and due to the utilization of the trapped energy, (3) the machine can have a higher output with the same power converter because of the improvement of the energy conversion ratio.
Index Keywords: Electric commutation; Electric converters; Electric currents; Electric excitation; Electric network analysis; Electric windings; Energy storage; Magnetic fields; Thermal effects; Doubly salient doubly excited variable reluctance motor; Energy circulation; Reluctance motors

Authors: Nawrocky R.J., Bergmann U., Siddons D.P.
Title: Bunch killer for the NSLS X-ray electron storage ring
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States
Authors with affiliations: Nawrocky, R.J., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States; Bergmann, U., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States; Siddons, D.P., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States
Abstract: In the NSLS x-ray electron storage ring, which operates at a harmonic number of 30, the beam may be stored in many different bunch patterns. The minimum spacing between bunches is approximately 19 nsec. While most of the experimenters are primarily interested in photon flux, some experimenters are sensitive to bunch spacing. Time resolved nuclear resonance scattering experiments, for example, need pulses of x-rays spaced at the order of 100 nsec apart and a very low noise floor (10-6) between pulses. Perhaps even more important than the level of the background is that it be reproducible and homogeneous in time. It has been found in practice that a small number of electrons always get trapped in the `empty' rf buckets during injection into the storage ring and remain as low level stray bunches. These extra bunches produce an unacceptable temporarily localized, non-reproducible background which is difficult if not impossible to correct for. A `bunch killer' system based on the rf knock-out technique has been developed and installed on the ring to remove the unwanted bunches. We describe the operation of this system and present experimental results to illustrate its effectiveness.
Index Keywords: Electron ring accelerators; High energy physics; Mathematical models; Particle accelerator accessories; Bunch killer; RF buckets; X ray electron storage ring; Storage rings

Authors: McKee J.W., Stone K.W., Sirko R.J., Blackmon J.B.
Title: Lunar base power options and evaluation
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Douglas Aerospace, Huntington Beach, United States
Authors with affiliations: McKee, J.W., Douglas Aerospace, Huntington Beach, United States; Stone, K.W., Douglas Aerospace, Huntington Beach, United States; Sirko, R.J., Douglas Aerospace, Huntington Beach, United States; Blackmon, J.B., Douglas Aerospace, Huntington Beach, United States
Abstract: Issues that must be considered in selecting the electrical and thermal power system are reviewed including the goals and objectives of the lunar base. For a reference base with primary objectives of manned exploration with a ten person crew, indigenous resource recovery, and geoscience data collection, six power systems are compared using thirteen selection criteria. The systems are configured, basic characteristics are given, and the main features of each are described. The systems are ranked using the selection criteria to provide insight into the most likely power systems for the reference base.

Authors: Takashashi A., Hartwig K.T.

Affiliations: Sumitomo Chemical Company, Ltd, Tsukuba, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Takashashi, A., Sumitomo Chemical Company, Ltd, Tsukuba, Japan; Hartwig, K.T., Sumitomo Chemical Company, Ltd, Tsukuba, Japan
Abstract: Electrical resistivity, yield stress and changes in these properties caused by cyclic strain at 4.2K are reported for (100), (110) and (111) oriented single crystal specimens of 99.9998% aluminum. Specimens oriented with (100) and (111) along the tension-compression axis are found to exhibit significantly higher rates of work hardening and dramatically lower levels of cyclic strain resistivity degradation than (110) oriented specimens. The behavior is explained after consideration of operating slip system present for each orientation and dislocation interactions. Our results suggest the use of single crystal of strongly textured high purity aluminum stabilizer material for large scale superconductive magnetic energy storage (SMES) conductors. Methods of preparing and characterizing the centimeter diameter by 15 cm long specimens used in the study are described.

Abstract: Real-time recording of mid-infrared laser radiation in photochromic spiropyran-MMA copolymer materials is investigated. The laser radiation, derived from a CO2 laser, bleached pre-colored merocyanine, thereby converting it back to spiropyran. The exposure sensitivity at 50 percent of the initial merocyanine optical density was about 0.1 J/mm2 at 10.6 μm laser wavelength and 0.2 J/mm2 at 10.5 μm. The difference of sensitivity at the two laser wavelengths points to differences in thermal energy dissipation mechanisms. The characteristics and examples of imagery, recorded in these photochromics, are presented. A resolution equal or better than 40 lines/mm was achieved.

Abstract: We report the first observation of bistable polarization switching in a vertical-cavity surface-emitting laser (VCSEL) under optical injection. Input wavelength dependence of the switching is studied. Polarization switching at frequencies up to 6 GHz is obtained. We believe this polarization switching is achieved through injection locking where both the wavelength and the polarization of the VCSEL are locked by the injected optical signal. Because of the high switching speed and the low switching energy, the polarization bistable switching in VCSELs opens new possibilities in optical storage and the area of smart pixels for optical processing and interconnects.

Abstract: In the present work we have studied in detail the lithiation behavior of reactively sputtered crystalline tungsten oxide (WO3) films. These films, depending on their thickness and other deposition conditions, exhibit a wide range of changes under lithium insertion from deep coloration to no coloration at all. This gives the possibility of using the WO3 films either as electrochromic (EC) layer or as counter electrode (CE) layer for lithium ion storage, respectively. From these results a quasi- symmetric electrochromic system encompassing a-WO3 as EC layer and c-WO3 as the CE layer is fabricated and studied for its electrochromic behavior.

Abstract: The realization of the design energy and luminosity goals of the Superconducting Super Collider (SSC) will require proper resolutions of a number of challenging problems in accelerator physics. Affiliations: Environment Canada, Dartmouth, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Cruickshanks, Frank, Environment Canada, Dartmouth, Canada; Mirza, Cameron, Environment Canada, Dartmouth, Canada; Chant, Verne, Environment Canada, Dartmouth, Canada
Abstract: Under the terms of a water/economy agreement between the Province of New Brunswick and the Government of Canada, a study was commissioned to develop a framework for the economic and environmental assessment of Seasonal Thermal Energy Storage, (STES) technology in Canada. The purpose was to relate existing experience to the current Canadian situation with respect to the opportunity for utilizing aquifer storage for low-temperature heating and cooling applications. Presented are the economic considerations for the application of groundwater source heating and cooling for large commercial buildings. Compared are the quantities of emissions from conventional energy systems (electrical and fossil fuel) and estimates of the reduction in emissions that would occur as a result of using groundwater for heating and cooling. The analyses covered capital and operating costs only, without incorporating the externalities of emissions of CO2, NOx and SO2 which are associated with the use of conventional energy sources. Regardless of externalities, the results showed that STES is definitely economical in larger commercial buildings in the various locations in Canada. As well, potentially significant environmental benefits were identified, especially in Atlantic Canada, where the major source of electricity from fossil fuel power plants.
Index Keywords: Aquifers; Buildings; Cooling; Cost accounting; Economics; Electricity; Energy conservation; Energy resources; Environmental impact; Groundwater; Heating; Particulate emissions; Aquifer thermal energy storage; Commercial buildings; Conventional energy systems; Economic aspects; Environmental assessment; Groundwater source heating; Seasonal thermal energy storage; Energy storage

Authors: Sun Wern-Jieh, Sechen Carl
Title: Efficient and effective placement for very large circuits
Affiliations: Univ of Washington, Seattle, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sun, Wern-Jieh, Univ of Washington, Seattle, United States; Sechen, Carl, Univ of Washington, Seattle, United States
Abstract: We present two major extensions to the implementation of simulated annealing for row-based placement which have enabled it to obtain the best results ever reported for a large set of MCNC benchmark circuits while using the least computation time ever reported for remotely comparable results. Our results indicate that chip area reductions up to 16% can be expected, compared with TimberWolfSC v6.0. Our new hierarchical annealing-based placement program yields total wire length reductions of up to 9% while consuming up to 7.5 times less CPU time in comparison to TimberWolfSC v6.0. In comparison to the Gordian/Domino program, our new program yields total wire lengths which are always lower (up to 9% lower) and our program is always faster for circuits with more than 5000 cells (which represents the range of circuit sizes of interest).
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Computational complexity; Computational methods; Electric energy storage; Error analysis; Hierarchical systems; Integrated circuit layout; Hierarchical annealing based placement program; Row based placement; VLSI circuits

Authors: Nakhamkin M., Swensen E., Abitante P., Schainker R., Pollak R.
Title: Technical and economic characteristics of compressed air energy storage concepts with air humidification
Source title: Proceedings of the American Power Conference
Affiliations: Energy Storage & Power, Consultants, Mountainside, United States
Authors with affiliations: Nakhamkin, M., Energy Storage & Power, Consultants, Mountainside, United States; Swensen, E., Energy Storage & Power, Consultants, Mountainside, United States; Abitante, P., Energy Storage & Power, Consultants, Mountainside, United States; Schainker, R., Energy Storage & Power, Consultants, Mountainside, United States; Pollak, R., Energy Storage & Power, Consultants, Mountainside, United States
Abstract: This paper presents the results of an EPRI-sponsored project whose objective is to develop and thermodynamically analyze several CASH cycle concepts, make parametric cost estimates, and ultimately optimize the overall cycle for a given underground storage geology and set of economic evaluation factors. A thermodynamic and parametric-cost comparison is made with the conventional and steam-inject CAES concepts.
Index Keywords: Compressed air motors; Economics; Thermodynamics; Turbomachinery; Underground structures; Air Humidification; Compressed Air energy Storage (CAES); Recuperator; Compressed air

Authors: Gavrilovic M.MN., Begin G.
Title: SMES systems for transient stability and damping improvement of power systems
Source title: Proceedings of the American Power Conference
Affiliations: Hydro-Quebec, Varennes, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Gavrilovic, M.MN., Hydro-Quebec, Varennes, Canada; Begin, G., Hydro-Quebec, Varennes, Canada
Abstract: Future development of power systems calls for a constant improvement and evaluation of prospective transmission technologies. Superconducting magnetic energy storage systems (SMES) with forced-commutated converters employing GTO thyristors could perform a variety of functions such as automatic generation control, fast spinning reserve, black start, improved transmission efficiency, voltage control, peak generation reduction, off-peak load shifting, and dynamic stability improvement by increased transmission transient stability margin and improved power oscillation damping. The most interesting SMES benefit to long power transmission systems (e.g. Hydro-Quebec's system), is the dynamic stability improvement by increased transient stability, improved oscillation damping and voltgage regulation.
Index Keywords: Energy storage; Thyristors; GTO thyristors; Power system improvement; SMES systems characteristics; Superconducting magnetic energy storage systems (SMES); Electric power systems

Authors: Pereira Jorge G., Malukluta Sarma
Title: Artificial intelligence controller for energy storage in a single phase power system
Authors with affiliations: Pereira, Jorge G.; Malukluta, Sarma
Abstract: Energy storage in utility distribution systems provides dynamic-operating benefits which include spinning reserve, load-following, reduced-minimum loading of power stations, voltage and frequency regulation. These storage systems can take the form of pumped-hydro, compressed, and battery energy storage. The control of interfaces to the PCS and auxiliary equipment is implemented by the facility monitoring and control system (FMCS). According to the preliminary design, the FMCS would contain a centrally-located microcomputer, hardwired logic-control panel, and a data-acquisition system.
Index Keywords: Control systems; Data acquisition; Microcomputers; Battery energy storage; Facility monitoring and control system (FMCS); Power station reduced-minimum loading; Single phase power system; Artificial intelligence

Authors: Dikansky N.S., Pestrikov D.V.
Title: On limitations on low-α rings performance due to ▽Z-Instabilities
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Budker Inst of Nuclear Physics, Novosibirsk, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Dikansky, N.S., Budker Inst of Nuclear Physics, Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Pestrikov, D.V., Budker Inst of Nuclear Physics, Novosibirsk, Russian Federation
Abstract: We analyze collective instabilities of a bunch due to the radial gradient of the longitudinal impedance. One of the specific features of these collective effects is that decrements of collective synchrotron modes do not depend on the value of momentum compaction factor of the ring. This effect can limit the performance of the so-called low-α storage rings. It can be used for the damping of unstable modes of the synchrotron coherent oscillations as well.

Authors: Guignard G.
Title: Lattice scaling and emittance control in the CLIC main linac
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Guignard, G., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Abstract: For the main linac of the CERN linear collider (CLIC), emittance degradation due to wake fields and misalignments was previously investigated at unvarying injection energy and scaling of the betatron function. In particular, to keep a constant stability margin along the linac, the scaling retained was such that β2/γ was constant. Recent developments suggest that the lattice scaling along the linac should be modulated differently in order to better balance the effects of the wake fields with respect to the chromatic dispersion. This may help to reduce the emittance dilution as would also a reasonable increase of the injection energy compatible with a bunch compressor. In the case of 250-GeV CLIC linacs, it was found that independent scaling of the cell length and focusing strength, and scaling laws different from the one mentioned above allow a better control of the growth of the small emittances foreseen, especially in the vertical plane. This approach combined with a simultaneous adjustment of the injection energy and an improvement of the trajectory mastering, has made it possible to relax the alignment tolerances on the quadrupoles and the cavities while keeping the final emittances at their required level.
Index Keywords: Alignment; Betatrons; Cavity resonators; Colliding beam accelerators; Fits and tolerances; Focusing; Mathematical models; Particle beam injection; Stability; Storage rings; Bunch compressors; Cell length; Emittance control; Emittance dilution; Focusing strength; Injection energy; Lattice scaling; Wake fields; Linear accelerators

Title: Study of coupled-bunch collective effects in the PEP-II B-factory
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, United States
Authors with affiliations: Byrd, John, Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, United States
Abstract: We present an overview of the calculated longitudinal and transverse coupled-bunch (CB) growth rates using the measured RF cavity higher order mode impedance and estimated resistive wall (RW) impedance for the proposed PEP-II B-Factory[1], a dual-ring electron-positron collider. We also describe a visual method of representing the effective beam impedance and corresponding growth rates which is especially useful for understanding the dependence of of growth rate on higher order mode frequency and Q, spread of HOM frequencies between cells, and for determining the requirements of the CB feedback systems.

Authors: Jach C., Medveko A., Vinnik V., Fishler Y.
Title: Energy storage inductor for the low energy booster resonant power supply system
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: SSCI, United States
Authors with affiliations: Jach, C., SSCI, United States; Medveko, A., SSCI, United States; Vinnik, V., SSCI, United States; Fishler, Y., SSCI, United States
Abstract: The Energy Storage Inductor (ESI) is an important part of the Low Energy Booster (LEB) Resonant Power Supply System. The ESI is a 40 mH, 3400 A, two-legged, picture frame, ONAN-cooled, linear inductor. The ESI is currently under construction at the UETM plant in Ekaterinburg (Russia) as a part of an inter-laboratory collaborative agreement between BINP (Russia) and SSCL (USA). This paper gives an overview of the ESI requirements and describes the design approach and testing methods.

Authors: Lee Tong-Nyong

Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Pohang Accelerator Lab, Pohang, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Lee, Tong-Nyong, Pohang Accelerator Lab, Pohang, South Korea
Abstract: PLS (Pohang Light Source) is a synchrotron radiation facility currently under construction in Pohang, Korea. It consists of a 2-GeV full energy injector linac, a storage ring, and three initial beam lines. The PLS belongs to a third generation machine with an expected beam emittance of 12 nm rad. The commissioning of the PLS is scheduled to take place toward the late fall of 1994. The facility will be opened to users by mid-1995 and will eventually provide high brightness source of radiation in the wide spectral region from bending magnets and insertion devices.
Index Keywords: Linear accelerators; Magnets; Storage rings; Superconducting devices; Beam emittance; Injector; Pohang Light Source (PLS); Synchrotron radiation

Abstract: The DAW structure linac-the preinjector for the SIBERIA SR complex was commissioned on November 1, 1992 when the 62.5 MeV electron beam is obtained. A 6-m-long high impedance (92 MOhm/m) linac operates at 2.8 GHz. The paper describes the experimental RF characteristics of the linac structure and beam measurements obtained during the commissioning. The results of electron current, energy spectrum, beam profiles and emittance measurements are presented.

Authors: Shaffer G., Coleman P.D., Mustane R.E., Wallace J.D., Wang X.Q., Zhao Y., Rogers J.D.
Title: RF Systems engineering for the SSC collider rings
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: SUperconduting Supercollider Lab, Dallas, United States
Authors with affiliations: Shaffer, G., SUperconduting Supercollider Lab, Dallas, United States; Coleman, P.D., SUperconduting Supercollider Lab, Dallas, United States; Mustane, R.E., SUperconduting Supercollider Lab, Dallas, United States; Wallace, J.D., SUperconduting Supercollider Lab, Dallas, United States; Wang, X.Q., SUperconduting Supercollider Lab, Dallas, United States; Zhao, Y., SUperconduting Supercollider Lab, Dallas, United States; Rogers, J.D., SUperconduting Supercollider Lab, Dallas, United States
Abstract: Acceleration and storage of 70-mA proton beams in the 2 × 20 TeV Supercollider rings can be performed both with normal conducting as well as superconducting 360-MHz rf systems. A normal conducting accelerating structure would use 32 or 24 single-cell cavities per ring, operating with a mean gradient of 2 - 2.6 MV/m to generate the required peak voltage of 20 MV in the beam holding mode. Superconducting cavities would allow operation with mean gradients up to about 5 MV/m, and tolerate higher transient beam loading due to nearly tenfold larger stored energy in the accelerating structure. A superconducting structure could consist of five pairs of single-cell resonators per ring, each pair being fed by a 250-kW cw klystron amplifier. The use of 500-kW or 250-kW klystron amplifiers, six or eight per ring, would seem appropriate for feeding normal conducting structures. Provisions for feedforward and feedback (rf amplitude and phase) are included in the low-level rf system. Furthermore, active damping of undesired modes and corrections of bunch phase deviations are planned by means of auxiliary (broadband) rf systems.
Index Keywords: Cavity resonators; Damping; Particle accelerators; Superconducting materials; Collides rings; Gradient; Normal conducting; Colliding beam accelerators

Authors: Steck M., Beckert K., Eickhoff H., Franzke B., Nolden F., Spadtke P.
Title: Electron cooling of heavy ions at GSI
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: GSI, Darmstadt, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Steck, M., GSI, Darmstadt, Germany; Beckert, K., GSI, Darmstadt, Germany; Eickhoff, H., GSI, Darmstadt, Germany; Franzke, B., GSI, Darmstadt, Germany; Nolden, F., GSI, Darmstadt, Germany; Spadtke, P., GSI, Darmstadt, Germany
Abstract: Electron cooling of heavy ions has been studied at the storage ring ESR over the whole range of ions up to bare uranium. Systematic measurements of the ion beam temperature evidence a dependence on the particle number which proves an equilibrium between cooling and heating by intrabeam scattering. Measurements of the longitudinal intrabeam scattering rate and of the longitudinal cooling force provide with information about the longitudinal cooling times. Small deviations of the longitudinal cooling time from the theoretically predicted A/Z2 dependence are found.
Index Keywords: Cooling; Electrons; Heat transfer; High energy physics; Ions; Mathematical models; Electron cooler; Electron cooling; Heavy ions; Intrabeam scattering; Longitudinal cooling force; Longitudinal cooling time; Storage rings

Authors: Rose J., McKenzie-Wilson R., Pirkl W., Ratti A.
Title: Conceptual design of the 26.7 MHz RF system for RHIC
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Brookhaven National Lab, Upton, United States
Authors with affiliations: Rose, J., Brookhaven National Lab, Upton, United States; McKenzie-Wilson, R., Brookhaven National Lab, Upton, United States; Pirkl, W., Brookhaven National Lab, Upton, United States; Ratti, A., Brookhaven National Lab, Upton, United States
Abstract: The 26.7 MHz (harmonic # h = 342) RF system will be used to capture the injected bunched beam from the AGS and accelerate it to a kinetic energy of up to 250 GeV for protons; 100 GeV/u for gold ions. All ions except protons cross transitions, and are finally transferred to a storage RF system working at 196 MHz. Each RHIC ring will be provided with two single-ended capacitively loaded quarter-wave cavities; each of these can be dynamically tuned by 100 kHz to compensate for the change in speed of the beam,and can deliver at least 200 kV voltage. A 100 kW tetrode amplifier with local RF feedback is directly coupled to the cavity to minimize phase delay. Prototypes of cavity and amplifier have been built and first test results are presented.
Index Keywords: Cavity resonators; Colliding beam accelerators; Power amplifiers; Protons; Tetrodes; Conceptual design; Injected bunched beam; Quarter wave cavities; Storage rings

Authors: Kramer D.
Title: STATUS of BESSY II a high brilliance synchrotron light source in the VUV to XUV range
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: BESSY mbH, Berlin, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Kramer, D., BESSY mbH, Berlin, Germany
Abstract: The approval of the BESSY II project marked the start of the construction of the first third generation synchrotron light source in Germany. BESSY II, designed for low emittance (ε = 6. 10-9 radm) and the incorporation of a large number of insertion devices (IDs) is expected to deliver VUV to XIV radiation with a brilliance in excess of 1018 photons/(sec·mm2·mrad2·0.1%bandwidth), the photon energies ranging from 10 to 2000 eV from undulators and wigglers. Photon spectra with a critical energy of 11.5 keV will be generated in the 6 T field of a superconducting wavelength shifter (WLS) which is planned to be installed in one of the 14 straight sections available for insertion devices. The decision to build BESSY II at a new site at Berlin Adlershof gave the challenge for a complete redesign of the storage ring without the severe boundaries compared to earlier proposals [1], with respect to requirements and practicabilities of constructing an accelerator complex mid in the center of West-Berlin.
Index Keywords: Particle accelerators; Photons; Storage rings; Superconducting devices; Emittance; Insertion devices (IDs); Synchrotron light source; Synchrotron radiation

Title: Progress report on the Laboratorio Nacional de Luz Sincrotron (Brazil)
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Laboratorio Nacional de Luz, Sincrotron, Campinas, Brazil
Authors with affiliations: Rodrigues, A.R.D., Laboratorio Nacional de Luz, Sincrotron, Campinas, Brazil; Goncalves da Silva, C.E.T., Laboratorio Nacional de Luz, Sincrotron, Campinas, Brazil; Wisnivesky, D., Laboratorio Nacional de Luz, Sincrotron, Campinas, Brazil
Abstract: We present a progress report on the design and construction of the Brazilian synchrotron light source facility, which is based on a 1. 15 GeV (nominal energy) electron storage ring. To date, the first part of the LINAC injector (50 MeV) has been completed and is in operation. Prototypes for all the ring main components - magnets, vacuum chambers, kickers and septa, power supplies, control system, beam position monitors, RF cavity - have been developed in-house and characterized. An update of the production of these components, which is already under way, is presented here. A report will be given on the experience acquired with laser cutting technique for the production of laminated magnets, pioneered by LNLS.
Index Keywords: Electron beams; Magnets; Power supply circuits; Storage rings; Injector; Progress report; Septa; Synchrotron light source; Synchrotron radiation

Authors: Akchurin N., Badano L., Bravar A., Conte M., Hall J., Kreiser H., McPherson J., Olchowski F., Onel Y., Penzo A., Pisent A., Pusterla M., Rinckel T., Rossmanith R.
Title: Measurement of spin motions in a storage ring outside the stable polarization direction
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Univ of Iowa, Iowa City, United States
Authors with affiliations: Akchurin, N., Univ of Iowa, Iowa City, United States; Badano, L., Univ of Iowa, Iowa City, United States; Bravar, A., Univ of Iowa, Iowa City, United States; Conte, M., Univ of Iowa, Iowa City, United States; Hall, J., Univ of Iowa, Iowa City, United States; Kreiser, H., Univ of Iowa, Iowa City, United States; McPherson, J., Univ of Iowa, Iowa City, United States; Olchowski, F., Univ of Iowa, Iowa City, United States; Onel, Y., Univ of Iowa, Iowa City, United States; Penzo, A., Univ of Iowa, Iowa City, United States; Pisent, A., Univ of Iowa, Iowa City, United States; Pusterla, M., Univ of Iowa, Iowa City, United States; Rinckel, T., Univ of Iowa, Iowa City, United States; Rossmanith, R., Univ of Iowa, Iowa City, United States
Abstract: Polarized, stored beams are becoming a more and more important tool in nuclear and high energy physics. In order to measure the beam polarization in a storage ring the polarization vector of the stored beam has to aim, revolution for revolution, over a period of seconds to minutes, into the same, so-called `stable', direction. In this paper measurements at the Indiana University Cooler Ring (IUCF) are described in which for the first time in a storage ring oscillations of the polarization vector around this stable direction have been measured. The existence and the dynamics of such oscillations are, for instance, important for a new proposed technique for polarizing stored hadron beams.
Index Keywords: Accelerator magnets; Electron resonance; High energy physics; Mathematical models; Measurements; Nuclear physics; Oscillations; Particle beams; Polarization; System stability; Vectors; Spin motions measurements; Stable polarization direction; Stored hadron beams; Storage rings

Authors: Gaul Gavin
Title: Westinghouse CAES program status report
Source title: Proceedings of the American Power Conference
Affiliations: Westinghouse Electric Corp, Orlando, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gaul, Gavin, Westinghouse Electric Corp, Orlando, United States
Abstract: Westinghouse, in a joint effort with the electric Power Research Institute, recently completed a preliminary investigation to determine the potential for adapting modern combustion and steam turbine technology to the next generation of CAES power plants. The results showed that it is feasible and cost effective to apply existing turbine hardware to CAES technology.

Authors: Kane Thomas J., Kmetec Jeffrey D., Kubo Tracy S., Re Sean, Wallace R.W.
Title: Diode pumped thulium laser research at lightwave electronics
Source title: Conference Proceedings - Lasers and Electro-Optics Society Annual Meeting
Affiliations: Lightwave Electronics Corp, Mountain View, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kane, Thomas J., Lightwave Electronics Corp, Mountain View, United States; Kmetec, Jeffrey D., Lightwave Electronics Corp, Mountain View, United States; Kubo, Tracy S., Lightwave Electronics Corp, Mountain View, United States; Re, Sean, Lightwave Electronics Corp, Mountain View, United States; Wallace, R.W., Lightwave Electronics Corp, Mountain View, United States
Abstract: Lightwave Electronics has been working on eyesafe diode-pumped lasers for over six years. Initially we looked at Tm:Ho;YAG, and were disappointed by its low energy storage and cooling requirements. All recent work has been with Thulium-doped garnets. Much of our work has had as its goal the construction of a wind-sensing laser radar usable at ranges up to a few kilometers. Such a system requires a single-frequency pulsed laser with several millijoules of energy, with pulse duration several hundred nanoseconds long, and with optical frequency precisely related to a cw reference oscillator. The first component development for this system was a cw single-frequency monolithic ring laser. This laser is pumped with a single 250-mW laser diode operating at the Thulium:YAG pump absorption wavelength of 785 nm. Single-frequency output exceeds 10 mW over a range of wavelengths which can be tuned by means of temperature from 2012.77 nm to 2013.54 nm. We have engineered these lasers to the point where they are available as a product with permanent coupling into single-mode fiber. They have ample power for either injection-seeding or for use as a local oscillator for heterodyne detection.
Index Keywords: Crystal oscillators; Optical devices; Optical fiber coupling; Optical pumping; Semiconductor diodes; Diode pumped lasers; Heterodyne detection; Injection seeding; Single frequency monolithic lasers; Thulium lasers; Ring lasers

Authors: Esterowitz R., Stoneman R., Pinto J., Rosenblatt G.
Title: Diode pumped solid state mid-IR lasers for medical applications
Source title: Conference Proceedings - Lasers and Electro-Optics Society Annual Meeting
Affiliations: Naval Research Lab, Washington, United States
Authors with affiliations: Esterowitz, R., Naval Research Lab, Washington, United States; Stoneman, R., Naval Research Lab, Washington, United States; Pinto, J., Naval Research Lab, Washington, United States; Rosenblatt, G., Naval Research Lab, Washington, United States
Abstract: In codoped thulium-holmium system the effective upper laser level lifetime is reduced significantly below its intrinsic lifetime owing to a strong upconversion process. This greatly reduces the energy storage in the material resulting in decreased Q-switched laser performance. To overcome this problem we utilized an intracavity pumping technique for populating the holmium upper laser level. A separate singly-doped low concentration holmium crystal placed within the high concentration thulium laser cavity, thereby allowing absorption of the 2 micron thulium laser emission by the separate holmium crystal. This technique offers the potential for utilizing the long upper-state storage lifetime of the 2.1 micron to be discussed include 1) cascade laser emission producing simultaneous laser operation at 2.08 and 2.31 microns 2) laser emission at the water overtone peak at 1.94 microns in selected hosts and 3) efficient CW operation of the erbium ion at 2.8 microns resonantly pumped at 0.97 microns resulting in a laser slope efficiency of 36%.
Index Keywords: Efficiency; Infrared radiation; Medical applications; Q switching; Semiconductor diodes; Tissue; Optical losses; Solid state lasers

Authors: Maslennikov I., Turner W.
Title: Photodesorption experiments on SSC collider beam tube configurations
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: SSC Lab, Dallas, United States
Authors with affiliations: Maslennikov, I., SSC Lab, Dallas, United States; Turner, W., SSC Lab, Dallas, United States
Abstract: Experimental measurements of photodesorption coefficients of H2, CH4, CO and CO2 are being done to obtain data necessary to predict the vacuum performance of the Collider. Experiments have been done or are planned for warm tubes (i.e. room temperature), cold tubes (i.e. 4.2 K) and liner configurations (i.e. 4.2 K, 20 K and 80 K). Two synchrotron radiation beamlines have been constructed on the VEPP-2M storage ring at BINP, Russia. The photon critical energy is 284 eV, as in the SSC Collider, angle of incidence is 10 mrad. To date approximately fifteen warm beam tubes have been tested, including electrodeposited Cu, high purity bulk Cu and Nitronic 40 SS, several cleaning procedures, with and without in-situ baking and with and without magnetic field. The maximum integrated photon dose was achieved was 2·1022 photons/m on the high intensity beamline. Several experiments have been done on the VUV ring at BNL to check a subset of the BINP data and to extend the integrated photon flux up to 1023 photons/m, or 100 days of SSC operation. The data from the warm experiments will be used to evaluate the best tubes to be used in the more time consuming cold experiments.
Index Keywords: Desorption; Dosimetry; Electron tubes; Magnetic fields; Particle beams; Photons; Storage rings; Synchrotron radiation; Vacuum technology; Beam tube; Cold tube; Liner configuration; Photodesorption; Photon critical energy; Photon simulated desorption; Superconducting super collider; Synchrotron radiation beamline; Warm tube; Colliding beam accelerators

Authors: Suetsugu Yusuke, Kanazawa Ken-ichi
Title: Test fabrication of a copper beam duct for the KEK B-factory
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Natl Lab for High Energy Physics, Ibaraki, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Suetsugu, Yusuke, Natl Lab for High Energy Physics, Ibaraki, Japan; Kanazawa, Ken-ichi, Natl Lab for High Energy Physics, Ibaraki, Japan
Abstract: A trial model of copper beam duct for the KEK B-Factory was fabricated and gas desorption rates were measured. The duct consists of a cooling channel, a beam channel and a pump channel, which were extruded separately and welded each other by the electron beam welding. The duct received only ultrasonic cleaning in a freon bath. The ultimate total pressure was about 4 × 10-10 Torr after a baking at 150°C for 48 hours and the thermal gas desorption rate was calculated as about 1.5 × 10-12 Torr.l/(s. cm2) in N2 equivalent. The measurement of the photon stimulated gas desorption rate was performed using the synchrotron radiation with a critical energy of 26.3 keV from the TRISTAN Accumulation Ring. The photo-desorption coefficients in the order of 10-2 molecules/photon were observed for main gases desorbed at the initial stage. These high gas desorption rates indicate that more careful surface preparation must be necessary.
Index Keywords: Colliding beam accelerators; Copper; Desorption; Ducts; Electron beam welding; Electron beams; Fabrication; Mass spectrometry; Photons; Synchrotron radiation; Vacuum applications; Beam channel; Cooling channel; Copper beam duct; Gas desorption rate; Photo desorption coefficient; Photon stimulated gas desorption; Pump channel; Thermal gas desorption; Storage rings

Authors with affiliations: Balachandran, U., Argonne National Lab, Argonne, United States; Zhong, W., Argonne National Lab, Argonne, United States
Abstract: One of the objectives of the superconductor program at Argonne National Lab is to develop improved processing methods for the production of YBCO superconductors with higher levitation forces suitable for low-friction, superconductor/permanent-magnet bearings and flywheel-energy-storage applications. From the standpoint of these applications, melt-processed bulk YBCO superconductors are of considerable interest. Levitation force and flux-pinning properties depend on microstructural features of the superconductors. We have added several chemical species to YBCO to alter the microstructure and have used a seeding technique to induce crystallization during melt processing. In this paper, we discuss the effects of various process parameters, additives, and a seeding technique on the properties of melt-processed bulk YBCO samples and compare the results with solid-state-sintered superconductors.
Index Keywords: Crystallization; Levitation melting; Microstructure; Processing; Flux pinning properties; Levitation force; Seeding technique; Superconducting materials

Authors: Ethirajan A., Najafi M.
Title: Mathematical modeling and simulation of latent heat cool storage system
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Univ of Southwestern Louisiana, Lafayette, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ethirajan, A., Univ of Southwestern Louisiana, Lafayette, United States; Najafi, M., Univ of Southwestern Louisiana, Lafayette, United States
Abstract: A mathematical model is formulated to predict the temperature field within the storage tank during the charging operation of a cool energy storage system. The closed-loop system operates in a 'direct-charge' mode to form solid Refrigerant 134a clathrate as its storage medium. Enthalpy method is implemented to formulate the storage tank's heat transfer governing equation. The governing equation counts for phase-change, volumetric heat sink and two dimensional conduction modes. The volumetric sink term included in the governing equation represents the heat removal from the storage tank by the compressor. A set of algebraic discretized equations are obtained from the governing equation through the method of control-volume-based finite-difference. The resulting algebraic discretized equations are solved numerically using Gauss-Seidel iteration method to predict the temperature distribution within the storage tank. The results demonstrate the system's feasibility and potential for the experimental set up of the system for the future work.
Index Keywords: Algebra; Finite difference method; Heat sinks; Heat transfer; Hydrates; Iterative methods; Mathematical models; Refrigerants; Temperature distribution; Algebraic discretized equation; Closed loop system; Enthalpy method; Gauss-Seidel iteration method; Latent heat cool storage system; Refrigerant 134a clathrate; Storage tank; Vapor compression cycle; Heat storage

Abstract: A noise tolerant auto-correlation associative memory is proposed. An associated energy function is formed by a multiplication of plural Hopfield's energy functions each of which includes single pattern as its energy minimum. An asynchronous optimizing algorithm of the whole energy function is also presented based on the binary neuron model. The advantages of this new associative memory are that the orthogonality relation among patterns does not need to be satisfied and each stored pattern has a large basin around itself. The numerical simulations show a fairly good performance of associative memory for arbitrary pattern vectors which are not orthogonal to each other.

Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Univ of Genoa, Genoa, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Bisio, G., Univ of Genoa, Genoa, Italy
Abstract: Energy storage is a key technology for many purposes and in particular for air conditioning plants and a successful exploitation of solar energy. Thermal storage devices are usually classified as either variable temperature ('sensible heat') or constant temperature ('latent heat') devices. For both models a basic question is to determine the efficiency suitably: only exergy efficiency appears a proper way. The aim of this paper is to examine exergy efficiency for both variable and constant temperature systems. Two types of definitions of exergy efficiency are proposed, depending on the fact that the exergy of the fluid leaving the thermal storage during the charge phase can be either totally lost or utilized elsewhere.

Authors: Ledjeff K., Gieshoff J., Friedrich K.

Abstract: In this paper, three different concepts of pollution-free utilisation of natural gas have been studied and compared to the state of the art technology available. All systems discussed show better results with respect to emissions like nitrogen oxides and carbon monoxide. The use of hydrogen as energy carrier being produced by methane cracking constitutes the only way to avoid the formation of carbon dioxide. Other options available need the expensive removal of carbon dioxide and capacious storage. Evaluation of these systems gives a preference for concept 3, because the emissions can be reduced to an ultra low level, the efficiency is improved and the cost are lowest. And the introduction of new energy systems for cleaner environment are accompanied by higher cost than the cost of the available technology.

Abstract: A novel damping scheme using superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES) unit is proposed in this paper to damp subsynchronous resonance (SSR) of the IEEE Second Benchmark Model, system-1 which is a widely employed standard model for computer simulation of SSR. The studied system contains a turbine-generator set connected to an infinite bus through two parallel transmission lines, one of which is series-capacitor compensated. In order to stabilize all SSR modes, simultaneous active and reactive power modulation and a proportional-integral-derivative (PID) damping controller designed by modal control theory are proposed for the SMES unit. Frequency-domain approach based on eigenvalue analysis and time-domain approach based on nonlinear-model simulations are performed to validate the effectiveness of the proposed damping method.

The plant was constructed by Harbert International, with the primary equipment being furnished by Dresser Rand and the cavern solution mined in a salt dome by Fenix and Scisson (now PB-KBB). At that time, EPRI was looking for utilities to test a new model, DYNASTORE, that was being developed under EPRI sponsorship. DYNASTORE is a chronological dispatch model, capable of modeling down to ten-minute time intervals, whose goal is to better quantify certain DOBs of energy storage.

An added advantage of this scheme is that a spectrum of synchrotron radiation will be produced that contains a contribution due to the spin, so that the device can be effectively used as spin polarimeter, with advantages compared to Compton backscattering methods. Results are presented for two high energy proton storage rings: RHIC and the SSC.

Abstract: Application of combustion heated thermionic systems for cogeneration purposes involves major modifications to the heating system. The system behaviour of a thermionic domestic heating system has been studied. In a previous study the behaviour of a system with recuperator is assessed. In this study the dimensions of the parts constituting the heating system are evaluated. First the optimum capacity of the converter is determined for a typical Dutch single family house, using a thermal storage and direct dumping of the electricity produced in the grid. Second the dimensions of the converter module are assessed using an analytical method. Last the exploitation of the thermionic cogeneration system is valued.

Abstract: Space charge can be formed by poling, by corona discharge or under electron radiation. Whatever its origin, the space charge can be built up after successive trapping and detrapping. This work shows that sample damages occur during a space charge variation and are not due to hot electron avalanche or to stimulated desorption. Implication in Space Charge Characterization are discussed.

Authors: Zegras C.
Title: Flywheel may clean up battery use, powering electric vehicles for 'greener' transportation
Authors with affiliations: Zegras, C.
Abstract: Kinetic energy storage is not a new idea. However, the necessary masses and rotating speeds required to provide continued functional energy storage for widespread application have evaded scientists. Now advances in materials and computer technology may bring this idea closer to reality in the form of the flywheel battery. One advantage of such innovation would be to make electric vehicles a more viable transport option, something that chemical batteries have not yet made possible.
Index Keywords: Electric vehicles; Energy conservation; Energy storage; Environmental impact; Secondary batteries; Functional energy storage; Kinetic energy storage; Flywheels

Authors: Schoenung Susan M., Bieri Robert L.
Title: Superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES) for electric vehicle recharging

Authors with affiliations: Schoenung, Susan M., W.J. Schafer Associates, Livermore, United States; Bieri, Robert L., W.J. Schafer Associates, Livermore, United States
Abstract: The successful use of electric vehicles in urban areas will depend on having the infrastructure available to charge and service these vehicles. One component of the necessary infrastructure will be charging stations for emergency or daytime recharge away from home. It is desirable to charge from stored energy resources during the day to avoid adding to peak electric load for this energy. Superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES) is an attractive option for such storage because of its high efficiency, low maintenance, and flexibility. The storage unit can also be used for other utility functions when not used for vehicle recharging. This paper presents some of the characteristics of a SMES system at a size of 1 MWh that could be used for electric vehicle recharging.

Authors: Dearien John A., Plum Martin M.
Title: Capital, energy, and time economics of an automated, on-demand transportation system
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Idaho Natl Engineering Lab, Idaho Falls, United States
Authors with affiliations: Dearien, John A., Idaho Natl Engineering Lab, Idaho Falls, United States; Plum, Martin M., Idaho Natl Engineering Lab, Idaho Falls, United States
Abstract: Many transit and rail planners feel that the only way to decrease the capital and operating cost of rail and transit systems is to decrease the size and weight of the vehicles. This paper discusses the requirements of such a downsized transportation system and benefits to be gained by decreasing the size of the operational vehicles. An on-demand transportation system is one that provides transportation to a traveler when the traveler desires it and as directly as possible to the desired destination. A system has been developed and tested at the Idaho National Engineering Laboratory (INEL). The CyberTran (Cybernetic Transportation) system utilizes small, low occupancy, computer controlled electrically powered vehicles in an elevated guideway at speeds up to 150 mph. The low weight of the vehicles coupled with the automated control and electrically powered operation of the vehicles, provides for a significant reduction in the capital and operating cost of the system. This system was designed to be operated in the median of the Interstate Highways.

Authors: Maslovsky Vladimir M., Simanovich Ellen V.
Title: Prolonged storage of electrons in MONOS-structures
Affiliations: Zelenograd Research Inst of Physical, Problems, Moscow, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Maslovsky, Vladimir M., Zelenograd Research Inst of Physical, Problems, Moscow, Russian Federation; Simanovich, Ellen V., Zelenograd Research Inst of Physical, Problems, Moscow, Russian Federation
Abstract: The transient process of the accumulation of charge in the Silicon Nitride by applying a positive voltage pulse to MONOS structure is investigated with the help of the experimental and theoretical methods (monopolar injection of electrons). The mathematical model of charge carriers transport in an amorphous nitride thin films in MONOS structures at the high electric fields has been developed. The essential peculiarity of this model is that the injected carriers from the contact are captured by a quasi-continuous spectrum of states that there are traps, having an exponential distribution of density in the nitride band gap and by the monoenergetic positively charged deep centers. The positive traps are made by the negative correlation energy defects. These defects are formed by the weak quasi-hydrogenous bonds Si -H-Si the changes of ones in consequences of a migration of hydrogen stipulate for the degradation processes in the nitride. It is established that the quasi-distributed traps are answered for the prolonged relaxation of current in the external circuit when t>>Tg in which the exponent α of function J-t-α is detrermined by the parameter of the energy distribution of traps and by the applied voltage on the structure hat is in agreement with experimental results and corresponds to the dispersive transport of carriers.
Index Keywords: Defects; Electrons; Heterojunctions; Mathematical models; Solid state physics; Transport properties; Charge accumulation; Degradation process; Dispersive transport; MONOS structures; Silicon nitride

Authors: Heyes Anthony G.
Title: Global warming and the evaluation of fuel substitution strategies: on why policy should be left to the politicians
Source title: International Journal of Global Energy Issues
Affiliations: McGill Univ, Montreal, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Heyes, Anthony G., McGill Univ, Montreal, Canada
Abstract: It is often taken for granted that substituting natural gas for oil will serve to reduce the greenhouse emissions of the strategy sector, and executing such substitution is thus seen as a coherent policy response to the problem of global warming. In this paper we argue that such a policy is ill-founded because the supposition on which it rests is based on an incomplete consideration of the comparative pollution characteristics of the two fuels. The consideration is incomplete in two senses: (i) authors focus on emissions of carbon dioxide to the virtual exclusion of the secondary greenhouse gases, (ii) attention is paid only to those emissions which result from fuel combustion, rather than to emissions from the entire fuel cycle (including extraction, distribution and storage). In this paper we adopt a simple, empirical 'emission-accounting' framework [28]. Using a range of plausible parameter values it is demonstrated that the 'greenhouse friendliness' ranking of natural gas and oil is highly ambiguous. We cite very recent engineering estimates of methane leakage associated with commercial natural gas distribution and go on to demonstrate that natural gas usage may result in the emission of more greenhouse gases than oil usage. The ambiguity in the ranking is driven by two major uncertainties, one technological and one political. The most significant implication is that the resolution of the technical uncertainty surrounding the greenhouse effect and man's impact upon global climate will not be sufficient to determine what constitutes an effective policy response. The determination of policy will be an essentially political problem. Policy formulation and determination should, as the title suggests, be left to the politicians.
Index Keywords: Air pollution control; Greenhouse effect; Laws and legislation; Fuel substitution; Global warming; Greenhouse gases; Energy policy

Abstract: It was important for us to have accurate inventory records. This was critical if we intended to keep our plant running. It was also important for us to NOT spend an excess amount of time and energy counting parts. By sharing the responsibility of inventory accuracies between materials and production, combined with a handshake agreement between accounting and manufacturing, we met both of these criteria.

Abstract: Superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES) has been proposed for numerous applications which represent a wide range of required stored energy and power ratings. Abstract: Early in 1992 Carolina Power and Light Co. initiated a project to bring superconducting technology out of the laboratory and into practice solving important power system problems. The project is spread over three years and involves three different customer sites. A micro superconducting magnetic energy storage device system called the SSD from Superconductivity, Inc. of Madison, WI. will be employed in the project. Electrotek Concepts of Mountain View, CA has been engaged to do power quality studies at the sites prior to the SSD installation as well as to provide power monitoring, analysis and periodic reporting on the project throughout. The scope of work for the project has been broken into seven tasks. These tasks are: 1) select customers for SSD testing, 2) perform background power monitoring, 3) perform preliminary SSD testing and develop overall test plan, 4) develop analytical models and perform simulations, 5) install SSD and perform SSD tests, 6) perform long-term monitoring of SSD installation, and characterize SSD performance and develop guidelines for SSD applications.

Authors: Decker Franz-Josef
Title: Transverse effects of longitudinal wakefields at high dispersion
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States
Authors with affiliations: Decker, Franz-Josef, Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States
Abstract: In high energy linear colliders the transverse beam emittance has to be preserved in order to achieve small interaction spots. Beams with trajectory offsets in cavities excite transverse wakefields which kick the tail of the beam leading to an undesired emittance growth. Here we will concentrate on the longitudinal wakefield creating an energy deviation ΔEW within the beam. At high dispersion η the beam will be spread out corresponding to its initial (and/or correlated) energy spread ΔEo (or ΔErf) and is therefore very sensitive to energy changes. The energy variation ΔEW will cause a transverse emittance blow up in the high dispersion regions. The effect can be estimated by comparing the betatron size σx = √βε with displacement Δx = ηΔEW/E. Some kicks and displacements will compensate each other along the beam line. Simulation results are presented showing how much is really compensated and the final emittance contribution of this effect for the SLC Ring-To-Linac transport line. To minimize it, any vacuum pipe irregularities, like bellows, diameter steps, collimators, etc. should be smoothed or avoided at higher dispersion areas.
Index Keywords: Betatrons; Correlation methods; Electromagnetic dispersion; Magnetic field effects; Magnetic fields; Mathematical models; Particle beams; Phase space methods; Sensitivity analysis; Storage rings; Transport properties; Damping ring; Emittance growth; Energy deviation; High dispersion; Longitudinal wakefield; Phase space correlation; Transverse effects; Colliding beam accelerators

Authors: Blumberg L.N., Blum E.
Title: Simulation of emittance dilution in electron storage ring from compton backscattering
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States
Authors with affiliations: Blumberg, L.N., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States; Blum, E., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States
Abstract: A Monte-Carlo simulation of Compton backscattered λL=3.2-μm (EL= .38494 eV) photons from an IR-FEL on 75-MeV electrons in a storage ring yields an RMS electron energy spread of ΔE=11.9-keV for a sample of 107 single scattering events. Electrons are sampled from a beam of natural energy spread σE = 5.6-keV and damped transverse angle spreads σx′ = .041-mrad and σy′, = .052-mrad (100%) coupling), scaled from the 200-MeV BNL XLS compact storage ring. The Compton-scattered X-Rays are generated from an integral of the CM Klein-Nishina cross-section transformed to the lab. A tracking calculation has also been performed in 6-dimensional phase space. Initial electron coordinates are selected randomly from a Gaussian distribution of RMS spreads σxo=.102-mm, σx′o=.041-mrad, σyo=.018-mm, σy′o=.052-mrad, σφo=22-mrad and σEo=6-keV. A sample of 10000 electrons were each following for 40000 turns around the ring through an RF cavity of frf=211.54-MHz and peak voltage Vm=300-keV. Preliminary results indicate that the resulting energy distribution is quite broad with an RMS width of ΔE = 124-keV. The transverse widths are only slightly increased from their original values, i.e. Δx = .106-mm and Δx′=.043 mrad. The scaled energy spread of ΔEapprox.360-keV for approx. 350,000 turns desired in a 10-msec X-Ray angiography exposure is well within the RF bucket used here; even Vm<50-kV is adequate. Further, the electron energy spread adds a negligible RMS X-Ray energy spread of ΔEX=.32-keV. The electron energy damping time of τE=379-msec at 75-MeV in an XLS-type ring allows for damping this induced spread and top-off of the ring between heart cycles.
Index Keywords: Electromagnetic wave backscattering; Electron beams; Free electron lasers; Infrared radiation; Integral equations; Mathematical models; Monte Carlo methods; Particle beam dynamics; Particle beam tracking; Phase space methods; Photons; X rays; Collision probability; Compton backscattering; Electron storage ring; Emittance dilution; Gaussian distribution; Infrared free electron laser; Tracking calculation; Storage rings
