Abstract: For a given rf cavity voltage amplitude, Vrf, there is a maximum attainable peak current in an ion storage ring. This occurs when the electric field from the beam space charge balances the rf cavity field. In this limit, the linear charge density distribution, λ(s), is parabolic and incoherent synchrotron motion is suppressed. The beam energy spread cannot be determined from the bunch time spread, TFWHM, which depends only upon the beam current, I, and Vrf. This work has recently been published [1]; no beam time has been available since for further results. This 1 page paper summarizes this work, discusses planned measurements, conjectures about possible results, and does its small part to limit the explosive growth of the PAC proceedings!

Abstract: The Superconducting Super Collider (SSC) is a proton-proton colliding beam accelerator which, when completed, will provide collision energies of 40 TeV in the center-of-mass, at a luminosity of 1033/cm2/sec-1. This paper will describe the current status of the design and construction of the project.
Index Keywords: Accelerator magnets; Betatrons; Energy storage; Particle beam dynamics; Particle detectors; Particle injectors; Protons; Storage rings; Synchrotron radiation; Beam-beam tune shift; Collision energy; Luminosity; Proton-proton collision; Superconducting super collider; Transverse emittance; Colliding beam accelerators

Authors: Calderon M., Holdener F., Barletta W., Petersen D., Foerster C.
Title: Distributed ion pump testing for PEP-II, asymmetric B-factory collider

Abstract: The paper discusses the testing procedures to be used for the PEP-II asymmetric B-factory collider and the design of the ion pumps to be used in the process. Ion pumps using plate type anodes have been chosen to achieve pumping speeds. In the high energy ring, high gas loads deriving from the intense photon radiation are calculated and must maintain an average pressure of 5 n Torr.

Authors: Carwardine John A., Pile Geoff, Zinneman Thomas E.
Title: Management of high current transients in the CWDD injector 200 kV power system
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: AEA Technology, Abingdon, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Carwardine, John A., AEA Technology, Abingdon, United Kingdom; Pile, Geoff, AEA Technology, Abingdon, United Kingdom; Zinneman, Thomas E., AEA Technology, Abingdon, United Kingdom
Abstract: The injector for the Continuous Wave Deuterium Demonstrator is designed to deliver a high current CW negative deuterium ion beam at an energy of 200 keV to a Radio Frequency Quadrupole [1]. The injector comprises a volume ion source, triode accelerator, high-power electron traps and low-energy beam transport with a single focusing solenoid. Some 75 Joules of energy are stored in stray capacitance around the high voltage system and discharged in a few microseconds following an injector breakdown. In order to limit damage to the accelerator grids, a magnetic snubber is incorporated to absorb most of the energy. Nevertheless, large current transients flow around the system as a result of an injector breakdown; these have frequently damaged power components and caused spurious behavior in many of the supporting systems. The analytical and practical approaches taken to minimize the effects of these transients are described. Injector breakdowns were simulated using an air spark gap and measurements made using standard EMC test techniques. The power circuit was modeled using an electrical simulation code; good agreement was reached between the model and measured results.
Index Keywords: Capacitor storage; Circuit theory; Computer simulation; Electric breakdown; Electric current measurement; Electric power systems; Electric spark gaps; Electromagnetic compatibility; Energy management; Equipment testing; Ion beams; Transients; Air spark gap; Continuous wave deuterium demonstrator; Electrical simulation code; EMC test techniques; High current transients; Injector breakdown; Magnetic snubber; Radio frequency quadrupole; Stray capacitance; Particle injectors

Authors: Pourmovahed A.
Title: Sizing energy storage units for hydraulic hybrid vehicle applications
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Dynamic Systems and Control Division (Publication) DSC
Affiliations: GMI Engineering and Management Inst, Flint, United States
Authors with affiliations: Pourmovahed, A., GMI Engineering and Management Inst, Flint, United States
Abstract: The purpose of this study is to determine the upper-bound energy storage capacity of gas-charged hydraulic accumulators and to assess the accumulator size and total mass for use in a hydraulic-hybrid passenger car. At pressures commonly encountered in a hydraulic accumulator (up to 41.48 MPa, absolute (6000 psig)), thermodynamic properties of nitrogen depart significantly from ideal gas behavior. To determine the best equation of state for accumulator calculations, predictions of the ideal gas law, the Beattie-Bridgeman equation, the Benedict-Webb-Rubin (BWR) equation, and Sandri's equation of state were compared with nitrogen data published by the National Bureau of Standards. The BWR equation of state is shown superior to other proposed equations and is, consequently, selected for accumulator analysis. A hydraulic accumulator operating at a constant temperature will have the maximum possible energy storage capacity. A conventional accumulator can be 'isothermalized' by the insertion of an appropriate elastomeric foam into the gas enclosure. This will minimize entropy generation in the accumulator and virtually eliminate the thermal losses. At 300 K (80°F), the upper-bound volumetric energy density for commercially available accumulators rated at 20.79 MPa, absolute (3000 psig), is 7.27 MJ/m3-gas (276.0 hp-s/ft3). The corresponding value for 41.48 MPa, absolute (6000 psig), is 13.19 MJ/m3-gas (500.8 hp-s/ft3). These are theoretical limits and can only be approached by the insertion of an appropriate foam with an 'optimum' mass and construction. By comparing experimental data taken with an 8.185-liter (2.162-gallon), piston-type accumulator with analytical results, it is shown that foam optimization can increase the energy storage capacity of this accumulator by about 10%. The results of this study are applied to a 1361-kg 3000-lb) hybrid passenger car and minimum accumulator volume requirement, and its associated total mass are determined.
Index Keywords: Automobiles; Energy storage; Entropy; Equations of state; Foams; Nitrogen; Optimization; Thermodynamic properties; Beattie-Bridgeman equation; Benedict-Webb-Rubin equation; Elastomeric foam; Energy storage capacity; Gas charged hydraulic accumulator; Hydraulic hybrid passenger car; Hydraulic hybrid vehicle; Ideal gas law; Sandri's equation; Hydraulic accumulators

Authors: Newberger Barry S., Shih H.-J., Ellison J.A.
Title: Effect of betatron motion on the septum flux in superslow extraction at the SSC
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Univ of Texas-Austin, Austin, United States
Authors with affiliations: Newberger, Barry S., Univ of Texas-Austin, Austin, United States; Shih, H.-J., Univ of Texas-Austin, Austin, United States; Ellison, J.A., Univ of Texas-Austin, Austin, United States
Abstract: A scheme for the superslow extraction of protons from the SSC rings for high energy test beam or precision fixed-target B physics is currently being investigated. The flux onto the extraction septum (a curved Si crystal) is to be generated by diffusion produced by noise injected into the RF system. The extraction rate depends on both the diffusion of the closed orbit (due to dispersion at the crystal) and the horizontal betatron amplitude of the diffusing protons. The diffusion of the closed orbit has previously been described by the one-dimension longitudinal diffusion theory of Dome and Krinsky and Wang. In this paper, we extend this theory to include the effect of the betatron motion. Comparisons with Monte Carlo tracking simulations are made.

Authors with affiliations: Steinbruck, M., Kernforschungszentrum Karlsruhe GmbH, Karlsruhe, Germany; Heinzel, V., Kernforschungszentrum Karlsruhe GmbH, Karlsruhe, Germany; Huber, F., Kernforschungszentrum Karlsruhe GmbH, Karlsruhe, Germany; Peppler, W., Kernforschungszentrum Karlsruhe GmbH, Karlsruhe, Germany; Will, H., Kernforschungszentrum Karlsruhe GmbH, Karlsruhe, Germany; Voss, M., Kernforschungszentrum Karlsruhe GmbH, Karlsruhe, Germany
Abstract: The AMTEC (Alkali Metal Thermo-Electric Converter or SHE (Sodium Heat Engine) is a device for direct conversion of heat into electricity without the need of any moving parts. The AMTEC has been considered for applications like remote terrestrial power generation, industrial co-generation, and space nuclear power generation. The beta-alumina solid electrolyte (BASE) is the crucial component in AMTEC systems. Today it is produced in large quantities for the sodium/sulfur battery, other similar energy storage devices, and sensors.
Index Keywords: Ammonia; Energy storage; Power generation; Thermoelectric energy conversion; Alkali metal thermoelectric converter (AMTEC); Ammonia solid electrolytes; Beta-alumina solid electrolyte (BASE); Solid electrolytes

Authors: Geisler Mark S., Jeutter Dean C.
Title: Implantable transcutaneously programmable and rechargeable nerve regenerator with telemetry links
Source title: Proceedings of the Annual Conference on Engineering in Medicine and Biology
Affiliations: Marquette Univ, Milwaukee, United States
Authors with affiliations: Geisler, Mark S., Marquette Univ, Milwaukee, United States; Jeutter, Dean C., Marquette Univ, Milwaukee, United States
Abstract: A transcutaneously programmable microcontroller based neurostimulation system has been developed and implemented. This Regenerative Electrical Stimulation (RES) system consists of an implantable, battery powdered, transcutaneously rechargeable and programmable stimulator (Programmable Rechargeable Stimulator - PRS) and a control device (External Controller Recharger - ECR) external to the patient. The ECR provides the functions of user interface, pulse parameter data storage, patient data storage, of control RF power transfer used to charge the battery and controls the RF circuits to transmit/receive data to/from the PRS. The PRS provides functions of receive/transmit data from/to the ECR, controls stimulus pulse parameter to the electrodes and monitors PRS system functions. The PRS can provide monophasic, bipolar or DC pulses to the electrodes in 1ms on/off to 25min. on/off time intervals in 128 steps. Pulse amplitudes range from 10μA to 1.0mA in 128 steps. Nickel Metal Hydride (NiMH) cells are used as the PRS power source providing an energy density 2 times greater than conventional cells. The PRS uses radio frequency energy (RF) to transmit measured parameters of RF signal sensitivity, battery temperature, cell voltage, internal board temperature, and positive and negative electrode drive voltage to the ECR. The RF subsystems use one coil to charge the batteries and transmit/receive data from the PRS.
Index Keywords: Biomedical engineering; Control equipment; Design; Electric variables control; Neurology; Signal processing; External controller recharger; Regenerative electrical stimulation; Transcutaneously programmable microcontroller; Biomedical equipment

Authors: Stevulova Nadezda, Tkacova Klara
Title: Changes in surface of dry activated quartz and magnesite powders during dynamic and static contacts with liquid environments of various polarity
Affiliations: Slovak Acad of Science, Kosice, Slovakia
Authors with affiliations: Stevulova, Nadezda, Slovak Acad of Science, Kosice, Slovakia; Tkacova, Klara, Slovak Acad of Science, Kosice, Slovakia
Abstract: The influence of liquid environments of various polarity on the metastable states formed during dry grinding of quartz and magnesite have been investigated. The X-ray amorphous phase content and the excess enthalpy accumulated during energy intensive dry grinding remain unaffected during short-termed regrinding as well as during long-termed stirring and static storage of the activated powders in liquid environment. The changes in specific surface area depend upon: the permittivity of liquid environment, crystallochemical properties of the activated powder and conditions of their mutual contact.

Authors: Zhou P., Colestock P.L., Junck K., Crawford C.A.
Title: Measurement of escaping ions in the Fermilab antiproton accumulator
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Fermi Natl Accelerator Lab, Batavia, United States
Authors with affiliations: Zhou, P., Fermi Natl Accelerator Lab, Batavia, United States; Colestock, P.L., Fermi Natl Accelerator Lab, Batavia, United States; Junck, K., Fermi Natl Accelerator Lab, Batavia, United States; Crawford, C.A., Fermi Natl Accelerator Lab, Batavia, United States
Abstract: Positively charged ions trapped in the negatively charged beam of the Fermilab antiproton accumulator pose a limit to beam stability and density. To better understand the dynamics and the consequences of the beam-ion interaction, we have built and installed a low energy ion detector and energy analyzer in the Fermilab accumulator. This analyzer is capable of energy analysis of the escaping ions using a probe with energy retarding grids and may also be scanned in the pitch angle of the escaping ions. Measurements have been made in both longitudinal and transverse planes under a variety of machine operating conditions. The experimental measurement results will be presented together with attempts to model the ion dynamics and explain observations.

Authors: Stoltze S., Mikkelsen J., Lorentzen B., Petersen P.M., Qvale B.
Title: Waste-heat recovery in batch processes using heat storage
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Advanced Energy Systems Division (Publication) AES
Affiliations: Technical Univ of Denmark, Lyngby, Denmark
Authors with affiliations: Stoltze, S., Technical Univ of Denmark, Lyngby, Denmark; Mikkelsen, J., Technical Univ of Denmark, Lyngby, Denmark; Lorentzen, B., Technical Univ of Denmark, Lyngby, Denmark; Petersen, P.M., Technical Univ of Denmark, Lyngby, Denmark; Qvale, B., Technical Univ of Denmark, Lyngby, Denmark
Abstract: The waste-heat recovery in batch processes has been studied using the Pinch-Point Method. The aim of the work has been to investigate theoretical and practical approaches to the design of heat-exchanger networks, including heat storage, for waste-heat recovery in batch processes. The study is limited to the incorporation of energy-storage systems based on fixed-temperature variable-mass stores. The background for preferring this to the alternatives (variable-temperature fixed-mass and constant-mass constant-temperature (latent-heat) stores) is given. It is shown that the maximum energy-saving targets as calculated by the Pinch-Point Method (Time Average Model, TAM) can be achieved by locating energy stores at either end of each process stream. This theoretically large number of heat-storage tanks (twice the number of process streams) can be reduced to just a few tanks. A simple procedure for determining a number of heat-storage tanks sufficient to achieve the maximum energy-saving targets as calculated by the Pinch-Point Method is described. This procedure relies on combinatorial considerations and could therefore be labelled the `Combinatorial Method' for incorporation of heat storage in heat-exchanger networks. Qualitative arguments justifying the procedure are presented. For simple systems, waste-heat recovery systems with only three heat-storage temperatures (a hot storage, a cold storage and a heat store at the Pinch Temperature) often can achieve the maximum energy-saving targets. Through case studies, six of which are presented, it is found that a theoretically large number of heat-storage tanks (twice the number of process streams) can be reduced to just a few tanks. The description of these six cases is intended to be sufficiently detailed to serve as bench-mark cases for development of alternative methods.
Index Keywords: Chemical operations; Energy conservation; Heat exchangers; Heat storage; Mathematical models; Process control; Systems analysis; Tanks (containers); Batch processes; Fixed temperature variable mass storage; Pinch point method; Time average model (TAM); Waste heat utilization

Authors: Mcintosh A.C.
Title: A semenov approach to the modelling of thermal runaway of damp combustible material
Source title: IMA Journal of Applied Mathematics (Institute of Mathematics and Its Applications)
Affiliations: Department of Fuel and Energy, Leeds University, Leeds LS2 9JT, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Mcintosh, A.C., Department of Fuel and Energy, Leeds University, Leeds LS2 9JT, United Kingdom
Abstract: Semenov theory for the self-heating of a reactive slab is extended to take account of the presence of water vapour. In this paper, mass changes due to evaporation/condensation are neglected but heat exchange is retained in the energy equation. By doing this, a simple easily solvable set of equations can be set up to represent the thermal behaviour of the slab. No account is taken of possible wet exothermic reactions in this paper. The aim is simply to understand the effects of evaporation/condensation on the overall thermal history. Using a simple model which treats the mass changes within the material as negligible, the competitive effects of condensation and evaporation are shown to produce a two-time situation which depends crucially on the surface mass transfer/heat transfer ratio hm. Either self-heating occurs at a lower rate than that due to dry oxidation, or else a maximum temperature is reached before a lower equilibrium steady-state temperature is achieved. Thus, compared to the dry case, in general terms, evaporation certainly encourages stability. However, the final strictly subcritical steady state will not always be achieved due to the competitive process between recondensation and evaporation loss at the surface at medium timescales. A set of quasi-steady states is identified which yield plots of a more restrictive critical value of temperature against the Frank-Kamenetskii parameter (proportional to the thickness of the slab and its reactivity). If the value of hm is such that the maximum temperature reaches this critical value, then thermal runaway can still take place even though the starting value of temperature was strictly below the true (damp) final steady-state critical value. © 1993 Oxford Univerity Press.
Index Keywords: Condensation; Evaporation; Heat transfer; Heating; Mass transfer; Materials handling; Mathematical models; Storage (materials); Thermal effects; Thermodynamic stability; Transport properties; Damp combustible materials; Reactive materials; Self heating; Semenov approach; Thermal runways; Flammable materials

Title: Heavy ion beam accumulation, cooling, and experiments at the ESR

Authors with affiliations: Franzke, B., GSI- Gesellschaft fur, Schwerionenforschung mbH, Darmstadt, Germany; Beckert, K., GSI- Gesellschaft fur, Schwerionenforschung mbH, Darmstadt, Germany; Bosch, F., GSI- Gesellschaft fur, Schwerionenforschung mbH, Darmstadt, Germany; Eickhoff, H., GSI- Gesellschaft fur, Schwerionenforschung mbH, Darmstadt, Germany; Franzak, B., GSI- Gesellschaft fur, Schwerionenforschung mbH, Darmstadt, Germany; Gruber, A., GSI- Gesellschaft fur, Schwerionenforschung mbH, Darmstadt, Germany; Klepper, O., GSI- Gesellschaft fur, Schwerionenforschung mbH, Darmstadt, Germany; Nolden, F., GSI- Gesellschaft fur, Schwerionenforschung mbH, Darmstadt, Germany; Raabe, P., GSI- Gesellschaft fur, Schwerionenforschung mbH, Darmstadt, Germany; Reich, H., GSI- Gesellschaft fur, Schwerionenforschung mbH, Darmstadt, Germany; Spadtke, P., GSI- Gesellschaft fur, Schwerionenforschung mbH, Darmstadt, Germany; Steck, M., GSI- Gesellschaft fur, Schwerionenforschung mbH, Darmstadt, Germany; Struckmeter, J., GSI- Gesellschaft fur, Schwerionenforschung mbH, Darmstadt, Germany
Abstract: The Experimental Storage Ring ESR- a part of the heavy ion accelerator facility at GSI- started operation early in 1990. This paper informs about the progress achieved in accumulation, electron cooling and internal experiments with fully stripped heavy ions from O8+ to U92+ at energies between 90 MeV/u and 300 MeV/u. Rf-stacking combined with compression in phase space by electron cooling turned out to be a very effective accumulation technique. Maximum number of stored ions for heaviest ions are determined by the equilibrium between accumulation rate and beam loss rate due to radiative electron capture of cooler electrons. Beam currents for higher ions up to Ar18+ are limited by coherent instabilities. First excellent results of internal experiments with cooled, circulating beams of either primary ions or of secondary nuclear fragments confirm that the combination of the heavy ion facility Unilac-SIS-FRS with the storage ring ESR offers unique possibilities for atomic, nuclear and accelerator physics.
Index Keywords: Cooling; Particle accelerators; Storage rings; Beam loss rate; Electron cooling; Experimental storage ring; Heavy ion accelerator; Heavy ion beam accumulation; Ion beams

Authors: Vaidyanathan
Title: Distinctive features of storage-induced capacity loss in Ni-H2 cells
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: COMSAT Lab, Clarksburg, United States
Authors with affiliations: Vaidyanathan, COMSAT Lab, Clarksburg, United States
Abstract: The nickel-hydrogen (Ni-H2) battery, introduced in 1993 as the energy storage device in INTELSAT V communications satellites, has demonstrated a cycle life unmatched by any other battery. Work performed by several organizations has elaborated on its performance features, and insight has been gained into its failure mechanisms. The technology is considered to have matured and, while nondramatic breakthroughs are expected in its characteristics, a steady improvement in reliability and adaptability is sought.

Authors: Rice David
Title: C E S R luminosity upgrades and experiments
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Cornell Univ, Ithaca, United States
Authors with affiliations: Rice, David, Cornell Univ, Ithaca, United States
Abstract: The Cornell Electron Storage Ring (CESR) has provided over 2.5 fb-1 integrated luminosity on the Y(4S) resonance and nearby continuum. facilitating measurements of B meson decays. In order to seek out rarer events, the luminosity of the storage ring must maintain a geometric growth. The luminosity upgrade program of CESR provides this growth capability while utilizing many of the developments in technology and accelerator physics required for later upgrade to an asymmetric B factory. All upgrades incorporate approximately the same pre-bunch parameters as in CESR's present operation. The next step in the upgrade replaces the individual bunches with `bunch trains', or closely spaced group of bunches treated as a single bunch by the pretzel separation scheme. The higher beam currents will require improvements to the RF, vacuum, feedback, and injector systems. Separation at the parasitic interaction points near the main interaction point is provided by a small horizontal crossing angle. Machine experiments have been conducted to determine criteria for separation at parasitic crossings and measure the effects of small crossing angles on beam-beam dynamics, as well as study other topics related to the upgrade program.
Index Keywords: High energy physics; Luminescence; Storage rings; Bunch trains; Cornell Electron Storage Ring; Interaction points; Luminosity; Parasitic crossings; Upgrade; Electron ring accelerators

Abstract: An RF cavity operating at three times the frequency of the present Main Ring rf system at Fermilab has been installed to minimize the beam loss and longitudinal emittance (εl) growth related to the transition crossing. Tests have been carried out with beam intensities ranging from 3×109 to 2.3×1010 ppb and εl≈.07 eVs. No beam loss conditions have been attained. Attempts have been made to reduce emittance growth after the transition.

Abstract: Acceleration cycle studies of the LNLS 1.15 GeV UVX electron storage ring are described. Since this ring will initially be injected at low energies (100 MeV), questions related to the behavior of beam lifetime during the ramping period (about 10 s), especially at the lowest energies, are crucial for the successful operation of the machine. In this work, we present results of Touschek lifetimes, due to single and multiple scattering effects, compared with damping times at various energies. We show that these effects should not lead to appreciable stored current losses.

Authors: Grieser M., Habs D., Hahn R.V., Hochadel B., Kleffner C.M., Liebmann J., Repnow R., Schwalm D., Bisoth G., Jaeschke E., Papureanu S.

Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: MPI fur Kertnphysik, Heidelberg, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Grieser, M., MPI fur Kertnphysik, Heidelberg, Germany; Habs, D., MPI fur Kertnphysik, Heidelberg, Germany; Hahn, R.V., MPI fur Kertnphysik, Heidelberg, Germany; Hochadel, B., MPI fur Kertnphysik, Heidelberg, Germany; Kleffner, C.M., MPI fur Kertnphysik, Heidelberg, Germany; Liebmann, J., MPI fur Kertnphysik, Heidelberg, Germany; Repnow, R., MPI fur Kertnphysik, Heidelberg, Germany; Schwalm, D., MPI fur Kertnphysik, Heidelberg, Germany; Bisoth, G., MPI fur Kertnphysik, Heidelberg, Germany; Jaeschke, E., MPI fur Kertnphysik, Heidelberg, Germany; Papureanu, S., MPI fur Kertnphysik, Heidelberg, Germany
Abstract: A newly designed radio frequency cavity was used at the storage ring TSR in Heidelberg to accelerate stored 12C6+ (E0 = 73.3 MeV) beams. It was possible to accelerate about 90% of the stored particles by more than a factor of three in kinetic energy (Efin ≈ 240 MeV). A new operating mode of the machine close to the transition energy was also investigated. Up to 10 μA 12 C6+ and protons could be stored, however, the beams were susceptive to longitudinal instabilities. For 21 MeV protons (γ = 1.02) a γtr parameter of 1.04 could be reached. A new method to produce a beam of polarized ions, based on spin selective attenuation by a polarized atomic hydrogen target was successfully proved with 23 MeV protons. To minimize losses of the beam particles the TSR was operated in the low-beta mode. After one hour a beam polarization of 0.014 was achieved.

Title: Commissioning results of the Amsterdam pulse stretcher storage ring AmPS
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: NIKHEF-K, Amsterdam, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Maas, R., NIKHEF-K, Amsterdam, Netherlands; Kroes, F., NIKHEF-K, Amsterdam, Netherlands; van der Lann, J., NIKHEF-K, Amsterdam, Netherlands; Luijckx, G., NIKHEF-K, Amsterdam, Netherlands; Noomen, J., NIKHEF-K, Amsterdam, Netherlands; Wo, Y., NIKHEF-K, Amsterdam, Netherlands
Abstract: AmPS has been built to enhance substantially the main specifications of the 1% duty factor 550 MeV electron accelerator facility MEA. The maximum energy will be raised to 0.9 GeV while the duty factor increases from 1% to approximately 100%. To this purpose the ring AmPS was added to this facility. Simultaneously the linac was upgraded both in current and energy. To modes of operation for the ring are implemented: a Pulse Stretcher mode with 3 turn injection creating an external beam, and a Storage Mode with multi turn injection for internal target physics. The commissioning of the ring started in April 1992. Within 2 months 10% duty factor beams could be delivered for electron scattering experiments. Meanwhile the performance of the machine has been improved dramatically. The actual performance of the ring is presented and is compared with the initial design goals.

Authors: Kerslake Thomas W., Hojnicki Jeffrey S., Green Robert D., Follo Jeffrey C.
Title: System performance predictions for space station freedom's electrical power system
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference

Authors with affiliations: Kerslake, Thomas W., NASA Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, United States; Hojnicki, Jeffrey S., NASA Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, United States; Green, Robert D., NASA Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, United States; Follo, Jeffrey C., NASA Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, United States
Abstract: One of the most important resources of Space Station Freedom is electric power. The Electric Power System (EPS) capability to effectively deliver power to housekeeping and user loads continues to strongly influence Freedom's designed and planned approaches for assembly and operations. The EPS design consists of silicon photovoltaic (PV) arrays, nickel-hydrogen batteries and direct current power management and distribution (PMAD) hardware and cabling. A dedicated active thermal control system maintains batteries and electrical equipment within their prescribed operating temperature limits. In this paper, results from the SPACE analytical cases are presented: (1) an electric load driven case and (2) a maximum EPS capability ease. Using iterative calculations, the maximum continuous day/night EPS capability under nominal orbital conditions after 5 years of station operation is computed.

Authors: Kentfield J.A.C.
Title: Detailed study of the operation of the regenerators of both cold-end and hot-end connected gamma type stirling engines
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Univ of Calgary, Calgary, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Kentfield, J.A.C., Univ of Calgary, Calgary, Canada
Abstract: Two regenerator thermo-fluids analyses were performed for idealised, gamma type, Stirling engines equipped with separate cylinders for the working piston and the displacer. One analysis was for a conventional version of the gamma configuration with the working (power) cylinder connected to the cold end of the displacer cylinder. The other analysis was for a non-conventional version of the engine in which the working cylinder is connected to the hot end of the displacer cylinder. The two configurations are, therefore, identified as cold-end connected and hot-end connected respectively. Whilst the two configurations are not synonymous with respect to specific work output, it is shown that from the viewpoint of regenerator operation both configurations are equivalent for prescribed cycle upper and lower temperatures. The analysis was extended to show that, as a general axiom, the energy stored transiently in the regenerator of any idealised Stirling engine is, for each case, γ times the corresponding cycle internal energy difference.
Index Keywords: Energy storage; Engine cylinders; Engine pistons; Flow of fluids; Gases; Heat transfer; Regenerators; Specific heat of gases; Cold-end connected stirling engines; Gamma type stirling engines; Hot-end connected stirling engines; Internal energy difference; Regenerator operation; Working fluid; Heat engines

Abstract: The results of the research for developing energy storage building materials capable of storing and releasing appropriate amounts of thermal energy within a designated range of temperature are presented. Organic phase change materials (PCM) were evaluated according to their thermal, physical, kinetic and chemical properties, as well as the economic factors involved. These include gypsum wallboard, concrete blocks, bricks and tiles. Particular attention was given to PCM impregnated. wallboards. The set up of the appropriate testing methods are discussed.

Authors: Pinheiro Humberto, Zeferino Cesar Albenes

Affiliations: Universidade Federal de Santa Maria, Brazil
Authors with affiliations: Pinheiro, Humberto, Universidade Federal de Santa Maria, Brazil; Zeferino, Cesar Albenes, Universidade Federal de Santa Maria, Brazil
Abstract: This paper presents a control strategy for shunt power line conditioner with inductive energy storage. The proposed strategy has two decouple AC control loops and one DC control loop. The AC control loops are analyzed under the Variable Structure approach. Equations to obtain the circuit parameters are given as guidelines for the design. Finally, simulation is presented as a means of demonstrating the active conditioner dynamic performance.

Authors: Surjaatmadja Jim B., Stromberg James L.
Title: Modeling forces created by energized fluids emitting from ruptured tubing
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Fluids Engineering Division (Publication) FED
Affiliations: Halliburton Energy Services, Duncan, United States
Authors with affiliations: Surjaatmadja, Jim B., Halliburton Energy Services, Duncan, United States; Stromberg, James L., Halliburton Energy Services, Duncan, United States
Abstract: When an oilwell service pipe containing high-pressure energized fluids ruptures, the resulting effluent generates large reaction forces on the pipe and other equipment. The restraining equipment used must be strong enough to prevent the flowline from exhibiting uncontrolled motion. Therefore, reaction forces must be computed before a service job to ensure that proper restraint systems are used. In practice, most damage occurs within the first few seconds after the equipment ruptures. Therefore, steady-state mathematical models are insufficient and transient models are essential to simulate such ruptures. Moreover, fracturing jobs often use foams, and these foams are often mixed with proppants (such as sand). Transient solutions must allow for the use of these fluids. This paper discusses the development of transient solutions for predicting reaction forces of exploding gases, foams, and propped foams. The solution employs numerical methods using quasisteady-state analysis techniques. It also outlines the effects of energy storage during rupture, allowing for the design of effective restraining equipment for the job. Various models are compared to extensive test results to show their validity.
Index Keywords: Discharge (fluid mechanics); Flow control; Fracturing (oil wells); High pressure effects; Loads (forces); Mathematical models; Numerical analysis; Numerical methods; Pipe; Pipe flow; Rupture disks; Tubing; Energized fluids; Quasisteady state analysis techniques; Reaction forces; Ruptured tubing; Flow of fluids

Abstract: In this paper, a formulation is suggested in order to calculate the scattering matrix of the two port antenna module with a more CAD oriented approach. Correspondingly, a simple equivalent network is obtained, which is useful in synthesis processes. Some lumped element of the equivalent network are evaluated by typical full-wave reaction integrals, making use of some simplifying assumptions for the current distributions on the slot and the microstrip-line. Furthermore, in order to describe the storage of the reactive energy near the coupling slot toward the patch, a parallel plate waveguide model is used.

Authors: Ivanov B., Peneva K., Bancheva N.
Title: Heat integration in batch reactors operating in different time intervals. Part I. A hot-cold reactor system with two storage tanks
Affiliations: Bulgarian Acad of Sciences, Sofia, Bulgaria
Authors with affiliations: Ivanov, B., Bulgarian Acad of Sciences, Sofia, Bulgaria; Peneva, K., Bulgarian Acad of Sciences, Sofia, Bulgaria; Bancheva, N., Bulgarian Acad of Sciences, Sofia, Bulgaria
Abstract: The present study addresses the problem of determining heat integration opportunities in a system of two batch reactors operating in different time intervals. In three successive parts different aspects of the use of heat storage tanks are considered. In the first part of the study cases using two storage tanks are discussed, the second deals with cases using one common heat storage, and the third part is devoted to the problems of synthesis and reconstruction of integrated systems with heat storage tanks. In the present first part of this study three different arrangements of heat integration are proposed, which are suitable for cases of regular performance of batch processing lines where the number of appearances of both hot and cold vessels is equal. Mathematical models describing the heat exchange in such cases are developed. Temperature time-variation relationships as explicit function of the main design and performance parameters are obtained.

Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man and Cybernetics

Abstract: In many bond graph models, it is convenient, for simplicity reasons, to use internal and/or energy-pumping modulations (IM and EPM). However, the result is often physically absurd. Using cardiac models as motivating examples, the author shows that a particular class of IM and EPM, made of internally and externally modulated n-ports energy storing elements, may be modified to restore physical consistency.

Authors: Drozhdin A.I., Baishev I.S., Mokhov N.V., Parker B., Richardson R.D., Zhou J.
Title: Dealing with abort kicker prefire in the superconducting super collider
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Superconducting Super Collider Lab, Dallas, United States
Authors with affiliations: Drozhdin, A.I., Superconducting Super Collider Lab, Dallas, United States; Baishev, I.S., Superconducting Super Collider Lab, Dallas, United States; Mokhov, N.V., Superconducting Super Collider Lab, Dallas, United States; Parker, B., Superconducting Super Collider Lab, Dallas, United States; Richardson, R.D., Superconducting Super Collider Lab, Dallas, United States; Zhou, J., Superconducting Super Collider Lab, Dallas, United States
Abstract: The Superconducting Super Collider uses a single-turn extraction abort system to divert the circulating beam to a massive graphite absorber at normal termination of the operating cycle or in case of any of a number of predefined fault modes. The Collider rings must be designed to be tolerant to abort extraction kicker prefires and misfires because of the large circulating beam energy. We have studied the consequences of beam loss in the accelerator due to such prefires and misfires in terms of material heating and radiation generation using full scale machine simulations and Monte-Carlo energy deposition calculations. Some results from these calculations as well as possible protective measures for minimizing the damaging effects of kicker prefire and misfire are discussed in this paper.

Authors: Bergher M.
Title: New outlooks on bunched beam instabilities in particle accelerators. A proposal for a simple method to release a potential self-consistent high quality beam
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Cent Universitaire Paris-Sud, Orsay, France
Authors with affiliations: Bergher, M., Cent Universitaire Paris-Sud, Orsay, France
Abstract: Several hypotheses have been proposed to explain bunched beam instabilities under increasing intensity. In fact, the cause of these instabilities can be used to generate a very high quality beam. Total coherent synchrotron radiation brings the bunches to plasma density by self-consistent supercooling in the three bunch dimensions i.e. by reduction of energy dispersion. Maximal density and minimal residual instabilities can be controlled by feedback loops. Thus, more efficient machines can be made available, opening new possibilities in many fields.

Authors: Wei Jie, Li Xiao-Ping, Sessler Andrew M.
Title: Crystalline beam ground state
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wei, Jie, Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States; Li, Xiao-Ping, Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States; Sessler, Andrew M., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States
Abstract: In order to employ Molecular Dynamics method, commonly used in condensed matter physics, we have derived the equations of motion for a beam of charged particles in the rotating rest frame of the reference particle. We include in the formalism that the particles are confined by the guiding and focusing magnetic fields, and that they are confined in a conducting vacuum pipe while interacting with each other via a Coulomb force. Numerical simulations has been performed to obtain the equilibrium structure. The effects of the shearing force, centrifugal force, and azimuthal variation of the focusing strength are investigated. It is found that a constant gradient storage ring can not give a crystalline beam, but that an alternating-gradient (AG) structure can. In such a machine the ground state is, except for one-dimensional (1-D) crystals, time-dependent. The ground state is a zero entropy state, despite the time-dependent, periodic variation of the focusing force. The nature of the ground state, similar to that found by Rahman and Schiffer[1], depends upon the density and the relative focusing strengths in the transverse directions. At low density, the crystal is 1-D. As the density increases, it transforms into various kinds of 2-D and 3-D crystals. If the energy of the beam is higher than the transition energy of the machine, the crystalline structure can not be formed for lack of radial focusing.
Index Keywords: Crystal structure; Crystallization; Crystals; Density (specific gravity); Elementary particles; Equations of motion; Focusing; Magnetic fields; Mathematical models; Storage rings; Tensors; Alternating gradient structure; Centrifugal force; Coulomb force; Crystalline beams; Ground state; Molecular dynamics; Radial focusing; Shearing force; Vacuum pipe; Particle beams

Authors: Bane K.L.F., Oide K.
Title: Simulations of the longitudinal instability in the SLC damping rings
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Stanford Univ, Stanford, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bane, K.L.F., Stanford Univ, Stanford, United States; Oide, K., Stanford Univ, Stanford, United States
Abstract: A longitudinal single bunch instability has been observed in the SLC damping rings. Beyond the threshold current, the energy spread of the beam increases and a 'saw-tooth instability' appears. The latter term describes a complicated phenomenon depending on the current and voltage. It can also describe a cycle that includes the quick release in bunch length over a time on the order of synchrotron period. This paper will try to understand the instability through simulations. Bunch lengthening calculations are to obtain the average bunch shape as a function of the current. The investigation of single bunch behavior of the SLC damping rings using the time domain tracking and also the Vlasov equation are presented in this paper, together with their modifications.

Authors: O'Day S., Bieniosek F., Anderson K.
Title: New target results from the FNAL antiproton source
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Farmilab, Batavia, United States
Authors with affiliations: O'Day, S., Farmilab, Batavia, United States; Bieniosek, F., Farmilab, Batavia, United States; Anderson, K., Farmilab, Batavia, United States
Abstract: Nickel and compressed rhenium powder targets have been installed in the FNAL antiproton source target station. Ni was chosen for its high melting point energy and resistance to stress wave fractures. As well, compressed powdered rhenium segments were constrained by a thinwall Ti jacket to insure resistance to stress fractures. The ̄p yield of these new targets is compared with that of copper-the previous standard production target. The target depletion characteristics of nickel and rhenium for a beam intensity of 1.6 × 1012 protons per pulse are also presented.

Authors: Rogers A., Manwell J.F., Stein W.A., McGowan J.G.
Title: Experimental testing of variable speed diesels for wind/diesel system applications
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Solar Energy Division (Publication) SED
Affiliations: Univ of Massachusetts, Amherst, United States
Authors with affiliations: Rogers, A., Univ of Massachusetts, Amherst, United States; Manwell, J.F., Univ of Massachusetts, Amherst, United States; Stein, W.A., Univ of Massachusetts, Amherst, United States; McGowan, J.G., Univ of Massachusetts, Amherst, United States
Abstract: The diesel generator in most hybrid wind/diesel systems operate at synchronous speed in order to produce constant frequency electrical power. Under typical operation, dump loads or battery charging maintain minimum diesel loads to insure long term diesel operation until, with adequate wind power and energy storage level, the diesels are turned off. Such operation results in high average fuel consumption and significant diesel wear from frequent stops and starts. An initial investigation of the subject suggests that variable speed operation of the diesel/generator set with an inverter to convert variable frequency power to 60 Hz power would result in lower acceptable diesel loads, increased fuel efficiency, and decreased start/stop engine wear. This paper presents a summary of recent work at the University of Massachusetts on the development of variable speed diesel generators with applications for wind/diesel systems. The initial tests have been conducted on a 3 kW diesel/generator/inverter system to investigate limits on low speed, low power operation. Fuel consumption, generator and inverter efficiency, and lubrication system performance were used as indicators of system performance. As summarized in the paper, the results show a significant decrease in brake specific fuel consumption at low engine speed. Changes in performance indicators with speed and load indicate that low speed operation increases the acceptable load range of the diesel and that system fuel consumption is improved over typical synchronous speed operation.
Index Keywords: Electric inverters; Electric loads; Fuel consumption; Lubrication; Synchronous generators; Systems analysis; Variable speed drives; Variable speed diesel generators; Wind/diesel systems; Diesel engines

Authors: Meierhans R.A.
Title: Slab cooling and earth coupling
Affiliations: Meierhans and Partner AG, Zurich, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Meierhans, R.A., Meierhans and Partner AG, Zurich, Switzerland
Abstract: Radiant cooling has been used for several years to support HVAC systems in nonresidential buildings. Surfaces that are water cooled directly provide good thermal comfort at high cooling loads. The high thermal distribution efficiency of hydronic systems reduces the cost for energy transport, but, in reality, total energy consumption is insignificantly lower, as the high cooling power produces additional cooling demand. The slab cooling system installed in a Swiss office building combines the advantages of radiant cooling with the thermal storage of massive concrete ceilings. The concrete core is cooled by cold water during the night. The water circuit includes a water/air heat exchanger, which cools down the ceiling to 20° to 22 °C by means of heat exchange with the cool night air. During the day, the ceiling absorbs the room loads and keeps the air temperature in the comfort range. The heat exchange in the building occurs at a relatively high temperature level (20° to 26 °C), which allows the use of alternative cooling sources, e.g., earth coupling.
Index Keywords: Air conditioning; Buildings; Ceilings; Concrete slabs; Energy conservation; Energy utilization; Heat exchangers; Heat storage; Space heating; Temperature distribution; Ventilation; Earth coupling; Radiant cooling; Slab cooling; Thermal comfort; Water cooling systems

Authors: Finney S.J., Williams B.W., Green T.C.
Title: RCD snubber revisited
Source title: Conference Record - IAS Annual Meeting (IEEE Industry Applications Society)
Affiliations: Heriot-Watt Univ, Edinburgh, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Finney, S.J., Heriot-Watt Univ, Edinburgh, United Kingdom; Williams, B.W., Heriot-Watt Univ, Edinburgh, United Kingdom; Green, T.C., Heriot-Watt Univ, Edinburgh, United Kingdom
Abstract: The use of the polarised R-C-D turn-off snubber configuration across switching devices is popular because of its simplicity and use of only passive components. This configuration is limited by the fact that all capacitor stored energy is dissipated in the discharge resistor. In this paper it is shown that with the addition of a ferrite transformer to the standard R-C-D arrangement, in excess of 70% of the energy stored on the snubber capacitor may be passively recovered into the dc supply. Performance of this passive recovery snubber is supported by theoretical, simulated and practical results.

Abstract: The Solar Dynamic (SD) Ground Test Demonstration (GTD) program demonstrates the availability of SD technologies in a simulated space environment at the NASA Lewis Research Center (LeRC) vacuum facility. An aerospace industry/government team is working together to design, fabricate, build and test a complete SD system. This paper reviews the goals and status of the SD GTD program. Authors: Nanda A., Mossikov A., Prokhorskas R., Abou Shabanah M.H.
Title: Health in the central and eastern countries of the WHO European Region: An overview
Authors with affiliations: Nanda, A.; Mossikov, A.; Prokhorskas, R.; Abou Shabanah, M.H.
Abstract: The enormous social, political and economic changes that began in the CCEE/NIS in the late 1980s included the revelation and public discussion of a widening health gap between these countries and the other Member States of the European Region. The continuing economic problems and their effects on health increase the urgency of the need for assistance from the international community. Diverging trends in life expectancy became evident in the mid-1970s, and the gap continued to widen in the 1980s for all major causes of death, particularly cardiovascular diseases. The situation is worse in the NIS than in the CCEE, and worst in the central Asian countries. In 1990, the worst infant mortality rate in these countries was eight times the best rate elsewhere in the Region. Non-mortality data, while patchy, confirm the indications given by mortality data. There is no single reason for the health gap, but contributory factors include the increasing prevalence of major risk factors in lifestyles and the environment, and the low efficiency and effectiveness of health care systems. The current situation and short-term prospects are mixed, but the negative trends in mortality and morbidity patterns are likely to continue for some time. While the worst health problems of the transition period in the CCEE/NIS could largely have been avoided, there is no doubt that economizing on health today will exact large costs tomorrow.The socioeconomic conditions in eastern European countries are declining. Deterioration began during the mid-1960s. The mortality gap has continued to widen during the 1980s. The Central Asian Republics show mortality patterns similar to ones in developing countries; infant mortality is about 8 times higher than in western Europe. Infant mortality rates in eastern and central Europe are 2-3 times higher than in western Europe. Cardiovascular diseases are the leading cause of death. Another increasing mortality group is lung cancer, and the gap is widening in the West. The NIS (formerly republics of the Soviet Union) have high rates of communicable diseases preventable through immunization. The logistics of vaccine distribution and storage are inadequate. Abortion is the primary means of family planning. 70% of the population of the Russian Federation reported their health as less than good, and only 20% of Russian military personnel are fit based on international standards. Tobacco consumption and high alcohol consumption are the primary health risks. Poor nutrition, stress, and drug abuse add to the risks. The health gap is wide also due to poor housing conditions and environmental pollution. Health care systems, unhealthy lifestyles, and unhealthy environments all contribute to the widening gap in health. The rigid administrative health structures are not conducive to change. The quality of care is low. Decentralization and private sector involvement may produce needed changes in the quality of health services. CCEE countries spend 4.5-7.1% of gross national product on health, compared to 7.3% in the West. In the Czech Republic, Poland, Hungary, and Slovakia, health expenditures per person are 3-4 times less than in OECD countries. Prices are very high for drugs, food, and energy. Although the medical staff-patient ratio is high, there are shortages in particular specialties. Nurses are poorly trained and in low supply. Hospital equipment is very old and poorly maintained. There is overuse of secondary and tertiary hospitals and underuse of general hospitals.
Index Keywords: eastern europe; europe; health status; human; life expectancy; politics; risk factor; short survey; social status; world health organization; Asia; Biology; Critique; Developed Countries; Developing Countries; Europe; Health; Health Status Indexes; International Agencies; Obstacles; Organizations; Risk Factors; Un; Western Asia; Who; Europe; Europe, Eastern; Female; Health Status; Human; Infant; Infant Mortality; Infant, Newborn; Life Expectancy; Mortality; Primary Health Care; Quality of Health Care; Risk Factors; Socioeconomic Factors; Women's Health; World Health Organization

Authors: Ebeling Jerry A., Sundbom Todd A., Blanchard Steven K., Beaty Lawrence
Title: Inlet air cooling utilizing ice storage for multiple unit/combined cycle capacity enhancement
Source title: Proceedings of the American Power Conference
Affiliations: Burns & McDonnell Engineering, Company
Authors with affiliations: Ebeling, Jerry A., Burns & McDonnell Engineering, Company; Sundbom, Todd A., Burns & McDonnell Engineering, Company; Blanchard, Steven K., Burns & McDonnell Engineering, Company; Beaty, Lawrence, Burns & McDonnell Engineering, Company
Abstract: Hot, humid summer weather results in high electrical demand peaks. Combustion turbines have historically been used to meet these peaks. Combustion turbine capacity and heat rate are strongly affected by inlet air temperature, and performance degrades as the inlet air temperature rises. Inlet air cooling using thermal energy (ice) storage (TES) can be used to counteract this performance decline. An inlet air cooling system is being designed and constructed for eight 25MW G.E. 5001P combustion turbines, six of which are combined cycle units. The plant an intermediate load peak load shaving facility, is owned and operated by the Public Works Commission (PWC) of the City of Fayetteville, North Carolina. Burns & McDonnell Engineering Company has completed the detailed design for the project.
Index Keywords: Combustion; Cooling systems; Mass transfer; Turbines; Ice storage; Inlet air cooling; Peak load; Combined cycle power plants

Authors: Harris David W.
Title: Photovoltaic/regenerative fuel cell system performance for Mars surface
Source title: Conference Record of the IEEE Photovoltaic Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Rockwell Int Rocketdyne Div, Canoga Park, United States
Authors with affiliations: Harris, David W., Rockwell Int Rocketdyne Div, Canoga Park, United States
Abstract: It is suggested that the next step in space exploration is a mission to Mars. Due to the length of travel time to Mars the visit time will be on the order of days or months. A duration length that is not conductive to power systems such as primary fuel cells or batteries. Power systems for Mars will have to have an element of power generation. The candidate systems are photovoltaic with regenerative fuel cells (PV/RFC) and nuclear. This paper evaluates candidate PV array designs in conjunction with a candidate RFC storage system. The analysis is done in two steps. First several array designs (flat, tent, single axis tracked and two axis tracked) are analyzed to predict their performance on the Martian surface. Next these designs are coupled with RFC storage for a system model. The PV/RFC system designs are then optimized for minimum mass by trading off energy generation, PV, for energy storage, RFC. The optimization technique is based on methods used for optimizing terrestrial systems. This paper ties together several studies to provide a more detailed analysis of Mars PV system performance and Mars PV/RFC system mass. From the results of this analysis the performance benefit of several different array designs have been quantified and an optimum design approach identified. The next logical step would be to quantify the other characteristics (cost, operation, installation, maintenance) of array designs so that a Life Cycle Cost evaluation and selection can be made.
Index Keywords: Fuel cells; Nuclear energy; Performance; Spacecraft; Mars surface; Regenerative fuel cells; Photovoltaic cells

Authors: Perrone Antonio L., Basti Gianfranco
Title: 'Dynamic perceptron'
Source title: Proceedings of the International Joint Conference on Neural Networks
Affiliations: INFN, Rome, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Perrone, Antonio L., INFN, Rome, Italy; Basti, Gianfranco, INFN, Rome, Italy
Abstract: With respect to Rosenblatt linear perceptron, a classical limitation theorem demonstrated by M.Minsky and S.Papert is discussed. This theorem, 'ΨOne-in-a-box', ultimately concern the intrinsic 'mathematical' limitations of parallel calculations in pattern recognition problems. We demonstrate a possible solution of this limitation problem by substituting the static definition of characteristic functions and of their domains in the 'geometrical' perceptron, with their dynamic definition. This dynamics consists in the mutual redefinition of the characteristic function and of its domain depending on the matching with the input. We show an application of this 'dynamic' perceptron scheme in particle tracks recognition in high energy physics. Actually, this algorithm has been used for real time automatic triggering of ADONE e+ e- storage ring (Frascati, Rome) to evaluate the neutron time-like electromagnetic form factor in the context of 'Fenice' collaboration by Italian Institute of Nuclear Physics (INFN).
Index Keywords: Dynamics; High energy physics; Neural networks; Real time systems; Storage rings; Dynamic perceptrons; Electromagnetic form factors; Pattern recognition

Authors: Lehman Steven L., Lum Peter S.
Title: Fast movement exhibit spring-like braking
Source title: Proceedings of the Annual Conference on Engineering in Medicine and Biology
Affiliations: Univ of California, Berkeley, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lehman, Steven L., Univ of California, Berkeley, United States; Lum, Peter S., Univ of California, Berkeley, United States
Abstract: To test the hypothesis that elastic energy storage in the antagonist muscle is used to brake rapid models, we stopped voluntary wrist flexion movements at various angular positions at various angular positions and measured isometric torque production after the movement was stopped. For movements stopped between the intended final position and maximum overshoot, the peak torque was negative and proportional to the difference between the stopped position and the intended final position. After the peak, torque followed a pattern stereotyped for each subject, but offset by the peak torque. The results are consistent with braking by a spring-like antagonist muscle.

Authors: Stevens John, Kratochvil Jay, Harrington Steve
Title: Field investigation of the relationship between battery size and PV system performance
Source title: Conference Record of the IEEE Photovoltaic Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Sandia Natl Lab
Authors with affiliations: Stevens, John, Sandia Natl Lab; Kratochvil, Jay, Sandia Natl Lab; Harrington, Steve, Sandia Natl Lab
Abstract: Four photovoltaic-powered lighting systems were installed in a National Forest Service campground in June of 1991. These systems have identical arrays, loads and charge controllers. The only difference was in the rated capacity of the battery bank for each system. The battery banks all use the same basic battery as a building block with four systems utilizing either one battery, two batteries, three batteries or four batteries. The purpose of the experiment is to examine the effect of the various battery sizes on the ability of the system to charge the battery, energy available to the load, and battery lifetime. Results show an important trend in system performance concerning the impact of charge controllers on the relation between array size and battery size which results in an inability to achieve the days of battery storage originally designed for.

Authors: Wang Li, Lee Yuk-Tong, Lee Ching-Huei

Authors with affiliations: Wang, Li, National Cheng Kung Univ, Tainan, Taiwan; Lee, Yuk-Tong, National Cheng Kung Univ, Tainan, Taiwan; Lee, Ching-Huei, National Cheng Kung Univ, Tainan, Taiwan
Abstract: The paper presents the results of a comparative study of two damping controllers, i.e., the power system stabiliser (PSS) and the superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES) controller, on damping generator oscillations. The developed scheme employs a proportional-integral-derivative (PID) damping controller to enhance the dampings of both mechanical mode and exciter mode of the studied system. The parameters of the proposed controllers are determined by using a unified approach based on modal control theory. Frequency-domain approach based on root loci analysis and time-domain approach based on a linear model simulations are accomplished in order to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed schemes and to compare the different damping effects provided by two damping controllers.

Authors: Wolk Ronald H.
Title: New power plant cycles utilizing air humidification and turbomachinery
Source title: Proceedings of the American Power Conference
Affiliations: Electric Power Research Inst, Palo Alto, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wolk, Ronald H., Electric Power Research Inst, Palo Alto, United States
Abstract: EPRI has been supporting extensive analyses of new power plant cycles which utilize air humidification, and of the turbomachinery required for these cycles. These power plants are based on combustion-turbines, but include an air humidifier after the compressor energy input. Analyses have shown that in base load operation, the projected Humid Air Turbine (HAT) cycle fired with natural gas has a 300-400 Btu/kWh lower heat rate compared with combined cycles with a similar cooling technology level. When integrated with coal gasification (IG/HAT), cost calculations indicate a 10-15% savings in overall plant cost. For the intermediate load operation market the Compressed Air Storage with Humidification (CASH) cycle is being developed for integration with coal gasification. The results of the extensive work EPRI has done on these power plant cycles, and EPRI's current and planned projects are outlined and discussed.
Index Keywords: Compressed air motors; Turbomachinery; HAT cycle; Heat cycle simplified flow diagram; Humid air turbine (HAT); Power plant cycles; Power plants

Authors: Brandstetter A.
Title: Energy conservation, storage and management in buildings. Part 1
Source title: Australian refrigeration, Air conditioning and heating
Authors with affiliations: Brandstetter, A.
Abstract: Energy efficiency features of buildings are addressed. These features include building orientation, window emplacement, size and structure (single or double glazing, coated/uncoated, etc), wall and roof insulation, air change modes, thermal mass, and possibly day-lighting. The sum total of these measures can add up to most significant energy savings, perhaps over 50 per cent, even without additional recourse to active means such as solar collectors.
Index Keywords: Energy conservation; Energy management; Heat storage; Renewable energy resources; Energy-efficient buildings; Solar buildings

Authors: Kokoyama Hiroshi, Tokoi Hiromi, Yokoi Kazuaki

Affiliations: Hitachi. Ltd, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kokoyama, Hiroshi, Hitachi. Ltd, Japan; Tokoi, Hiromi, Hitachi. Ltd, Japan; Yokoi, Kazuaki, Hitachi. Ltd, Japan
Abstract: The disparate demand for power between daytime and nighttime has been increasing in recent years. If the increased amount could be supplied by load leveling technology, new power plants would not be needed as frequently. Hitachi is promoting a joint project on large-scale secondary battery system development with the Ministry of International Trade and Industry (MITI) and power utility companies. Hitachi has successfully developed a 10-kW sodium sulfur battery module in a joint project with the Tokyo Electric Power Co., Inc. for centralized use. A new 10-year R&D project with a budget of approximately $ 140 million was started in fiscal 1992 and called the New Sun Shine Project of the Agency of Industrial Science and Technology of MITI and the New Energy and Industrial Technology Development Organization (NEDO). The Lithium Battery Energy Storage Technology Research Association (LIBES) was organized by eleven companies and appointed to carry out the project. As a member of LIBES, Hitachi is challenging the de development of a composite negative electrode type battery using lithium-lead alloy and carbon.
Index Keywords: Electric batteries; Electric power systems; Electrolysis; Lithium batteries; Secondary batteries; Hitachi; Load leveling; Power utility; Electric power plants

Authors: Henderson Charles R., Ebeling Jerry A., Smith Richard C.
Title: Union electric company's combustion turbine inlet air cooling study
Affiliations: Union Electric Co, St. Louis, United States
Authors with affiliations: Henderson, Charles R., Union Electric Co, St. Louis, United States; Ebeling, Jerry A., Union Electric Co, St. Louis, United States; Smith, Richard C., Union Electric Co, St. Louis, United States
Abstract: Union Electric Company is a summer peaking utility, experiencing peak electrical load demands during the hot summer months. Combustion turbine generators are often used to meet the summer peak demands. However, the generating capability of a combustion turbine decreases as the ambient air temperature increases. When system peak demands are at their levels on the hottest days of the year, the generating capacity of the combustion turbines are at their lowest values. This lost generating capacity can be recovered by cooling the air entering the combustion turbines. Various combustion turbine inlet air cooling technologies were investigated for a General Electric Model 7B combustion turbine. The cooling technologies evaluated in the study were evaporative cooling, thermal energy storage (ice), on-line mechanical chiller, direct absorption chiller, steam absorption chiller with heat recovery steam generator (HRSG), and once-through cooling using well water. Conceptual designs, performance estimates, installation and operating costs were developed for each alternative.
Index Keywords: Combustion equipment; Costs; Evaporative cooling systems; Heat storage; Installation; Performance; Steam generators; Thermal effects; Water cooling systems; Combustion turbine; Direct absorption chiller; Equipment design; Heat recovery steam generator; Inlet air cooling; Online mechanical chiller; Thermal energy storage; Turbogenerators

Affiliations: ISE Research Ltd, Fort Coquitlam, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Butler, Bruce, ISE Research Ltd, Fort Coquitlam, Canada; Hertog, Vince den, ISE Research Ltd, Fort Coquitlam, Canada
Abstract: ISE Research is currently developing Theseus, a long-range AUV specifically designed to investigate technologies and techniques for deploying fiber optic cable on the seafloor in ice-covered waters. Previous sea trials with a testbed AUV have demonstrated the feasibility of this type of mission. Prior to the operational deployment of Theseus, development is required in several key areas of sub-sea technology: vehicle design, energy storage, navigation, control, cable deployment, logistics and communications. Currently, system-level design of Theseus has been completed, and detailed design is underway. This paper gives an overview of the Theseus AUV, outlines its specifications, and describes key technical problems related to cable laying.
Index Keywords: Control systems; Fiber optics; Optical cables; Vehicles; Cable laying; Theseus; Ocean engineering

Authors: Gaul G.W., Cornell J.M., Nakhamkan M., Paprotna H.

Abstract: This paper covers the development of Compressed Air Energy Storage (CAES) Systems and the methods used to increase performance and efficiency. It shows the evolution from the original non-recuperated cycle to the current designs, and examines the future possibilities of such cycles as CAES at 2500°C (1370°C), CAES with humidification, CAES integrated with coal gasification, and CAES with chemical recuperation.

Abstract: This paper describes the use of a superconducting magnetic energy storage device (SSDTM) to improve power quality at a large industrial facility by providing short term back-up power during utility system voltage sags and interruptions. This facility has critical electronic loads that are very sensitive to voltage variations. An explanation of why the SSD was chosen instead of other technologies will be presented along with a brief overview of the SSD technology as well as SSD performance to date. Finally some of the important lessons learned will be shared along with conclusions and future improvements.

Authors: Frenduto F.S., Klosek J., Osterstock E.R.

Abstract: Gasification Combined-Cycle (GCC) power generation is recognized as a truly advanced Clean Coal Technology because of its superior environmental performance and efficiency. GCC is fundamentally a baseload technology. However, GCC can also be economically deployed for load-following by incorporating energy storage in the flowsheet. The Liquid Phase Methanol (LPMEOH) process has been developed for this application. Clean burning methanol is produced from coal-derived synthesis gas off-peak, and withdrawn from storage and fired on-peak. This paper will describe the application of LPMEOH technology to convert a 500 MW GCC baseload reference plant into a flexible, load-following unit with a peak/valley capacity ratio of 3:1. The economics and comparative emissions performance of this dispatchable GCC energy storage plant are presented. It is hoped that this description will be helpful in expanding the range of requirements to be served by GCC.

Three major changes were implanted just prior to and during construction, which involved a redesign of some cavern ancillary equipment, and the dewatering method. These changes included the addition of an instrumentation well intersection the storage cavern, and the dewatering method.

Authors: Wolf S.M.M., Enslin J.H.R.

Authors with affiliations: Wolf, S.M.M., Univ of Stellenbosch, Stellenbosch, South Africa; Enslin, J.H.R., Univ of Stellenbosch, Stellenbosch, South Africa
Abstract: A 30% cost reduction of photovoltaic generation can be brought about, by the investment in a novel, highly efficient maximum power point tracker (MPPT). Such a converter is currently under development, implementing a feedforward output current controller as tracking algorithm. The dc-to-dc converter, typical of a MPPT, exploits the efficient high-frequency operation, associated with zero-transition switching. Thus the output filter only consists of the combination of a storage battery and its cabling. The resulting converter is suitable for integration into standard PV panels during manufacturing. The efficiency of the MPPT is 96% for a range of output powers at a low battery voltage of 12,5V and a component cost of US$21,00.
Index Keywords: Costs; Efficiency; Electric variables control; Energy conversion; Solar cells; Switching circuits; Feedforward output current controller; Power point tracking regulators; Simplistic controllers; Zero transition switching; Photovoltaic cells

Authors: Chen Weichang, Chen Zhiyi, Yin Gangda
Title: Information storage mechanism of the biological neural network
Source title: Proceedings of the International Joint Conference on Neural Networks
Affiliations: China Japan Friendship Inst of, Medical Sciences, Beijing, China
Authors with affiliations: Chen, Weichang, China Japan Friendship Inst of, Medical Sciences, Beijing, China; Chen, Zhiyi, China Japan Friendship Inst of, Medical Sciences, Beijing, China; Yin, Gangda, China Japan Friendship Inst of, Medical Sciences, Beijing, China
Abstract: The information storage mechanism of the biological-neural network is the most important problem in neuroscience. Our observations showed that the structure of the hippocampus, the core memory of the brain, is very similar to the Hopfield's neural network. An electronic neuronic model was constructed to simulate the dynamic process of the hippocampal LTP process. The kinetic process of the post synaptic potentials and the synaptic - synaptic interaction equations were also discussed. We proposed a dual coding theory of biological neural information and assumed that the mossy fiber synaptic glomerulus may be the chief storage medium of the neural information. A geometrical mapping of N dimensional unitron was constructed to analyse the distribution of the computation energy and to trace the dynamic loci in memory retrieve process.

Abstract: We have studied the change of expected performance of the Advanced Light Source storage ring at LBL for the (design) nominal and maximum energy of 1.5 and 1.9 GeV respectively. Furthermore, we have also studied a possible increase to 2.3 GeV by modeling the change of dynamical aperture caused by saturation of the magnets. In, we have also modeled the beam's trajectory at injection. Comparison with bpm data from early storage ring commissioning led to the diagnosis of a major lattice error due to a short in a quadrupole, which was rectified leading to stored beam of 60 turns.

Authors with affiliations: Krejcik, P., Stanford Univ, Stanford, United States; Bane, K., Stanford Univ, Stanford, United States; Corredoura, P., Stanford Univ, Stanford, United States; Decker, F.J., Stanford Univ, Stanford, United States; Judkins, J., Stanford Univ, Stanford, United States; Limberg, T., Stanford Univ, Stanford, United States; Minty, M., Stanford Univ, Stanford, United States; Siemann, R.H., Stanford Univ, Stanford, United States; Pedersen, F., Stanford Univ, Stanford, United States
Abstract: The SLC damping rings function to provide low emittance, short bunches for injection into the linac. The authors observe a threshold above which beam jitter would occur in the linac. The paper presents an interim solution to the instability problem which is to exercise control over the bunch length via the RF voltage. The peak current is kept below instability threshold by ramping the voltage during the store cycle. The blowup in the bunch length as the threshold of peak current is crossed is the result of short range wake fields. The main contributors to the vacuum chamber impedance are step discontinuities in transition pieces, radiation masks and pump slots. Also discussed is the transient bunch lengthening phenomena and its numerical simulations.

Abstract: The Advanced Light Source (ALS) accelerator is now completed. The numerous conventional magnets required for the booster ring, the storage ring and the low and high energy transfer lines were installed during the last two years. This paper summarizes the various costs associated with the quantity fabrication of selected magnet families. These costs include the costs of prototypes, tooling, coil and core fabrication, assembly and magnetic measurements. Brief descriptions of the magnets and specialized requirements for magnetic measurements are included in order to associate the costs with the relative complexities of the various magnet systems.

Abstract: We examine the properties of an elliptically polarized wiggler that will generate circularly polarized photons with energy spectrum of 3-12 KeV. The vertical wiggler magnetic field is produced by permanent magnets while the horizontal wiggler field is generated by electric coils capable of AC excitation. The radiation parameters of the wiggler are presented. Numerical values are calculated for radiation from the wiggler. A conceptual design for such a wiggler is discussed. We consider AC excitation of the wiggler to produce the time modulation of the elliptic polarization. The power dissipated in the vacuum chamber due to the eddy current is considered.

Abstract: Superconducting cavities have been chosen as the best approach to meet the rf requirements of the proposed Cornell B-Factory. These requirements involve high beam power, low Q for higher order modes, short beamline space and low cost. The next procedure in the development program of these cavities, following the successful tests of the prototype cavity in a vertical dewar, is to place it in a horizontal cryostat in the Cornell Electron Storage Ring and test under operational conditions with circulating beams. A later step in the upgrade of CESR before the switchover to a B-Factory will be to place four such cavities in the ring as the accelerating cavities for circulating beams of 2 × 500 mA. The B-Factory will require twelve cavities in the high energy ring (IA) and four in the low energy ring (2A).

Abstract: A novel three-phase power converter which is suitable for high voltage, high power applications is proposed. This converter consists of a neutral-point-clamped (NPC) converter with a switching frequency at a power line frequency as the main power circuit and an additional single-phase converter with a switching frequency at triple the power line frequency.
