Authors: Adebiyi George A., Nsofor Emmanuel C., Steele W.Glenn, Jalalzadeh-Azar Ali A.
Title: Parametric study on the operating efficiencies of a packed bed for high-temperature sensible heat storage
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Advanced Energy Systems Division (Publication) AES
Affiliations: Mississippi State Univ, Mississippi State, United States
Authors with affiliations: Adebiyi, George A., Mississippi State Univ, Mississippi State, United States; Nsofor, Emmanuel C., Mississippi State Univ, Mississippi State, United States; Steele, W.Glenn, Mississippi State Univ, Mississippi State, United States; Jalalzadeh-Azar, Ali A., Mississippi State Univ, Mississippi State, United States
Abstract: A comprehensive computer model of a packed bed thermal energy storage system was developed for storage media employing either sensible heat storage (SHS) materials or phase change material (PCM). The model is for high-temperature storage and incorporates several features including (a) allowance for media property variations with temperature, (b) provisions for arbitrary initial conditions and time-dependent varying fluid inlet temperature to be set, (c) formulation for axial thermal dispersion effects in the bed, (d) modeling for intraparticle transient conduction in the storage medium, (e) provision for energy storage (or accumulation) in the fluid medium, (f) modelling for the transient conduction in the containment vessel wall, (g) energy recovery in two modes, one with flow direction parallel with that in the storage mode (co-current) and the other with flow in the opposite direction (counter-current), and (h) computation of the first- and second-law efficiencies. Subsequently, the model was validated for the sensible heat storage media using a rather extensive set of data obtained with a custom-made experimental facility for high-temperature energy storage. Parametric studies of the sensible heat storage system were carried out using the validated model to determine the effects of several of the design and operating parameters on the first- and second-law efficiencies of the packed bed. Decisions on the thermodynamic optimum system design and operating parameters for the packed bed are based on the second-law evaluations made.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Dispersions; Heat conduction; Heat storage; High temperature applications; Optimal systems; Parameter estimation; Systems analysis; Thermal effects; Thermodynamics; Time varying systems; Axial thermal dispersion effects; High temperature sensible heat storage (SHS) system; Intraparticle transient conduction; Time dependent varying fluid inlet temperature; Packed beds

Authors: Reistad D.
Title: Recent developments in the Gustaf Werner cyclotron and CELCIUS
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference

Abstract: The Gustaf Werner cyclotron, which usually operates in isochronous mode, is used as a synchrocyclotron for high energy protons. In addition to its internal PIG ion source, it has been equipped with two external ion sources, an ECR source for heavy ions and a source for polarized protons and deuterons. The CELCIUS ring is used for intermediate-energy physics with thin internal targets. A major concern is to keep the experimental background small. The electron cooling system is helping this task, but is not yet very useful at the injection energy. The reasons behind this are becoming clear. A long shutdown in the fall of 1993 will bring further enhancement to both accelerators.

Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference

Abstract: Battery electric vehicles (EV) presents a challenge to the development of a more efficient and effective heating and cooling systems for automotive applications. This paper's scope is limited to identifying and evaluating the alternative solutions to HVAC battery electric vehicles. These include: basis for determining HVAC boundary design assumptions and showing mathematical methods for estimating the HVAC load and energy requirements; evaluation of the new European and Japanese approaches to wintertime heating.

Abstract: This paper investigates the optimal capacity of the battery energy storage system in a power system. Taiwan Power Company System is used as the example system to test this algorithm. Results show that the maximum economic benefit of the battery energy storage in a power system can be achieved by this algorithm.
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Dynamic programming; Electric batteries; Electric power systems; Optimal systems; Polynomials; Battery energy storage (BES) system; Optimal battery capacity; Taiwan Power Company System; Electric energy storage

Authors: Mei V.C., Chen F.C., Yang K.H., Hwang R.L.
Title: Analysis of a thermal energy storage air-conditioning system using eutectic salt. Part 1. System design and simulation results
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Advanced Energy Systems Division (Publication) AES
Affiliations: Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, United States
Authors with affiliations: Mei, V.C., Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, United States; Chen, F.C., Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, United States; Yang, K.H., Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, United States; Hwang, R.L., Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, United States
Abstract: Most residential and mobile air conditioning and refrigeration systems are direct expansion units. This type of system usually uses only about 85 percent of the evaporator capacity for cooling; the other 15 percent is used to superheat the refrigerant to protect the compressor from liquid slugging. This practice results in excessive evaporator volume. Full use of the evaporator is important in mobile air conditioning systems where the space available for the evaporator is very limited. In addition, full use of the evaporator provides higher cooling capacity and better dehumidification in residential applications. Current designs do not reflect those advantages. This study reports on a recuperative cycle (RC) air conditioning system that can use 100 percent of the evaporator effectively. At the same time, the design increases the compressor volumetric efficiency, resulting in an increase in refrigerant mass flow rate and a reduction in compressor power consumption. The test results indicated an improvement in system coefficient of performance (COP) of more than 20 percent over the entire compressor test range. The RC concept can also be used on heat pumps to improve system performance. conditioning system using Eutectic Salt was discussed and analyzed in this paper. The simulation result warrented the system design was successful, with a system payback period of 5.4 years. The simulation methodology presented in this paper is an efficient analytical tool in TES system design.
Index Keywords: Analysis; Compressors; Cooling; Design; Energy storage; Eutectics; Heat pump systems; Performance; Refrigerants; Simulation; Testing; Coefficient of performance (COP); Dehumidification; Direct expansion units; Eutectic salt; Evaporator capacity; Excessive evaporator volume; Liquid slugging; Mobile air conditioning; Recuperative cycle (RC) air conditioning system; Residential air conditioning; Thermal energy storage (TES) air conditioning; Air conditioning

Authors: Celata C.M., Abbott S., Bennett M., Bordua M., Calvert J., Dwinell R., Howard D., Hunt D., Feinberg B., Force R., Frias R., Halliwell J., Kalnins J., Lewis S., Nyman M., et. al.

Abstract: The Bevalac extraction time was increased from 1 to a maximum of 9.5 seconds, thus increasing the synchrotron duty factor and the data rate for experiments by a factor of 2-3, depending on the magnetic field. This slow rate of extraction required improved control of beam time structure, since magnet ripple remained approximately constant while the spill rate was decreased. Measurements of spill structure for the long spill are presented. Changes made to the accelerator systems are described, as well as tuning procedures found to be necessary, and the ultimate hardware limits found for the spill length.
Index Keywords: Accelerator magnets; Electric motor generator sets; Energy storage; Hardware; Magnetic fields; Particle accelerators; Particle beams; Synchronization; Synchrotrons; Tuning; Accelerator system; Beam time structure; Bevalac extraction time; Circulating beam intensity; Duty factor; Main magnet; Motor generator synchronization; Pulse cycle time; Spill structure; Wind tunnel fan cooling tower system; Particle beam extraction

Authors: Tang Le, Zavadil Robert M.
Title: Simulation of operational and control characteristics of hybrid wind/diesel energy systems using the electromagnetic transients program
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Solar Energy Division (Publication) SED
Affiliations: Electrotek Concepts, Inc, Knoxville, United States
Authors with affiliations: Tang, Le, Electrotek Concepts, Inc, Knoxville, United States; Zavadil, Robert M., Electrotek Concepts, Inc, Knoxville, United States
Abstract: This paper describes a short-term simulation of a hybrid wind/diesel generation system. The operation and control characteristics of the system, effects of combining battery energy storage, and the issue of harmonic injection to a connected AC network were investigated. When the system is isolated from a connected utility grid, the steady-state operation of the system is established dynamically between the synchronous diesel generation, the induction wind generation, and the load demand. Any change in wind or load conditions can cause system disturbances. Factors which significantly affect system voltage and frequency stability following disturbances are wind turbine dynamics, diesel engine governing response, and synchronous generator voltage regulation capability. With all these important factors included, system responses to several characterized input/output variation conditions were evaluated using the well-known Electromagnetic Transients Program (EMTP).
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Control systems; Diesel engines; Dynamic response; Frequency stability; Mathematical models; Power generation; Synchronous generators; Systems analysis; Voltage control; Wind effects; Electromagnetic transients program (EMTP); Hybrid wind/diesel energy systems; Wind power

Authors: Watson Scott A.
Title: Real-time spot size measurement for pulsed high-energy radiographic machines
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States
Authors with affiliations: Watson, Scott A., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States
Abstract: The focal spot size of an x-ray source is a critical parameter which degrades resolution in a flash radiograph. For best results, a small round focal spot is required. Therefore, a fast and accurate measurement of the spot size is highly desirable to facilitate machine tuning. This paper describes two systems developed for Los Alamos National Laboratory's Pulsed High-Energy Radiographic Machine Emitting X-rays (PHERMEX) facility. The first uses a CCD cameras combined with high-brightness fluors, while the second utilizes phosphor storage screens. Other techniques typically record only the line spread function on radiographic film, while systems in this paper measure the more general two-dimensional point-spread function and associated modulation transfer function in real time for shot-to-shot comparison.

Abstract: The MIT-Bates SHR, a 190m long race track shaped electron storage ring with a 9.144m bending radius, is designed for nuclear physics experiments using two modes; the STORAGE mode with internal targets or the PULSE STRETCHER mode, which uses the 1/2 integer resonance and 2 ramped quadrupole magnets and 3 octupole magnets to (smoothly) extract the stored electrons of up to 1.0 GeV energy and 80 mA intensity over a period as short as 1 millisecond into the extraction line.

Authors: Aceves-Saborio Salvador, Hernandez-Guerrero Abel, Nakamura Hajime
Title: Heat transfer and exergy analysis of the charge process of a heat storage cell
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Advanced Energy Systems Division (Publication) AES
Affiliations: Universidad de Guanajuato, Salamanca, Mexico
Authors with affiliations: Aceves-Saborio, Salvador, Universidad de Guanajuato, Salamanca, Mexico; Hernandez-Guerrero, Abel, Universidad de Guanajuato, Salamanca, Mexico; Nakamura, Hajime, Universidad de Guanajuato, Salamanca, Mexico
Abstract: This paper presents an analysis of the charge process of a latent heat storage cell. The analysis includes all the details of the melting process that takes place during the charging of the cell. While it is recognized that an overall latent heat storage system (LHSS) analysis is necessary to fully evaluate the effect of melting heat transfer on performance, it is considered that a single cell analysis can be used to give a qualitative indication of how the overall LHSS charging process takes place. The paper presents heat transfer and exergy analysis results for the cell charge process. Heat transfer results include interface positions and energy stored as a function of time. Heat transfer results are also compared with those obtained for melting with a constant wall temperature, to evaluate the effect of the interaction between the charge fluid and the cell. The results of the comparison indicate that this interaction has a great effect on heat transfer, resulting in asymmetric interface profiles and slower charge processes. Exergy analysis results include exergetic efficiency as a function of time; maximum exergetic efficiency as a function of phase change temperature; and optimum phase change temperature as a function of charge temperature. The optimum phase change temperatures are compared to the results obtained from previous simplified analyses that assume a small Stefan number, and the results are observed to agree closely in the range of Stefan numbers considered in this analysis.
Index Keywords: Heat transfer; Melting; Phase interfaces; Systems analysis; Thermal effects; Thermodynamics; Time varying systems; Cell charge process; Latent heat storage systems (LHSS); Maximum exergetic efficiency; Phase change temperature; Stefan number; Heat storage

Authors: Bauman F.S., Borgers T., LaBerge P., Gadgil A.J.
Title: Cold air distribution in office buildings: Technology assessment for California
Affiliations: Univ of California, Berkeley, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bauman, F.S., Univ of California, Berkeley, United States; Borgers, T., Univ of California, Berkeley, United States; LaBerge, P., Univ of California, Berkeley, United States; Gadgil, A.J., Univ of California, Berkeley, United States
Abstract: This paper presents the results of a study to assess the current state of practice and the energy and operating cost implications of cold air distribution in California and to identify the key research needs for the continued development of this technology in new commercial buildings in the state. Whole-building energy simulations were made to compare the energy performance of a prototypical office building in three California climates using conventional and cold air distribution, with and without ice storage, to show the impacts of load shifting, energy use, and utility costs for three typical utility rate structures. The merits of economizers and fan-powered mixing boxes were also studied when used in conjunction with cold air delivery. A survey was conducted to assess the perceived strengths and limitations of this technology, perceived barriers to its widespread use, and user experience. The survey was based on interviews with consulting engineers, equipment manufacturers, researchers, utility representatives, and other users of cold air distribution technology. Selected findings from the industry survey are also discussed. Cold air distribution (CoAD) is found to always reduce fan energy use in comparison to conventional 55 °F (13 °C) air distribution systems when conditioned air is delivered directly to the space (no fan-powered mixing boxes). Total building energy use for ice storage/CoAD systems was always higher than a well-designed conventional system but significantly lower than a commonly installed packaged system. When a favorable utility rate structure was applied, the load-shifting benefits of ice storage/CoAD systems produced the lowest annual operating costs of all system-plant configurations studied.
Index Keywords: Buildings; Cost accounting; Electric rates; Energy storage; Energy utilization; Surveys; Technology; Cold air distribution (CoAD); Fan energy use; Ice storage; Thermal energy storage (TES); Air conditioning

Authors: Kandarpa Vic, Semerie Jean-Pierre

Abstract: In 1988, General Dynamics Space Systems Division (GD/SSD) and SAFT started the development and qualification of a 250 Ah Lithium Thionyl Chloride battery for space launch application. This paper presents and summarizes the results of this successful development program. Results show that the battery designed delivers more than 250Ah at an energy density of better than 250 Wh/Kg while operated in a wide range of discharge currents, temperatures and environmental conditions. By controlling storage temperature, it doesn't show voltage delay phenomena. The battery also demonstrated safe operation under any operating condition plus it is suitable for any unmanned space application.

Abstract: A concentrated difference energy (CDE) scooter equipped with a LiBr solution tank and steam engines was constructed and tested. The scooter is heated by a 4 meter diameter solar dish with 57 small mirrors, and runs solely on the accumulated solar energy. Although the running duration was short and the efficiency was low, it has proved the possibility of power generation by solar CDE system.

Authors: Hiramatsu Masayoshi, Yoshida Hiroshi, Inoue Toshio, Kawada Akihiro, Kabune Hiroo, Ando Yoshimasa
Title: Test results of pilot plant and application study of thermal storage systems based on chemical concentration difference energy
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Chubu Electric Power Co, Inc
Authors with affiliations: Hiramatsu, Masayoshi, Chubu Electric Power Co, Inc; Yoshida, Hiroshi, Chubu Electric Power Co, Inc; Inoue, Toshio, Chubu Electric Power Co, Inc; Kawada, Akihiro, Chubu Electric Power Co, Inc; Kabune, Hiroo, Chubu Electric Power Co, Inc; Ando, Yoshimasa, Chubu Electric Power Co, Inc
Abstract: Thermal storage system based on a chemical concentration difference energy (CCDE) in new one. A thermal storage material is an aqueous solution of LiBr. The characteristic is that thermal storage density is large, and thermal energy for both cooing and heating can be stored in a unit. Moreover, this system can reduce the electricity cost by recovering the waste heat. We manufactured the pilot plant using electricity at night and carried out air-cooling/heating test under the actual field condition for about a year. It turned out that thermal storage density of this system was larger than that of ice storage system. We propose the combined system that the aqueous solution of CCDE is concentrated by the waste heat of phosphoric acid fuel cell (PAFC) for the thermal storaging. This system has a characteristic of lower electrical energy due to use the waste heat and relatively higher cool storage density 77Mcal/m3. As a result of the application study, the yearly electricity cost of this system is lower and the storage tank volume is smaller than those of other thermal storage systems.

Abstract: Presently (Dec. 1992) three RF systems power the electron beam at the NSLS X-Ray storage ring to 250 mA at 2.58 GeV. A fourth RF cavity and system is being installed to increase the machine reliability over pre-shutdown operational conditions (3 cavities). It also permits new levels of beam intensities of 500 mA at 2.5 GeV as well as 250 mA at 2.8 GeV are anticipated. A description of the hardware, the installation and the modes of operation will be outlined in this paper. X-ray ring operations are scheduled to resume January 1993. Injection performance and high energy reliability will also be discussed.

Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Pohang Accelerator Lab, Pohang, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Kang, H., Pohang Accelerator Lab, Pohang, South Korea; Ko, I., Pohang Accelerator Lab, Pohang, South Korea; Cho, M., Pohang Accelerator Lab, Pohang, South Korea; Namkung, W., Pohang Accelerator Lab, Pohang, South Korea
Abstract: Pohang Accelerator Laboratory (PAL) is constructing the 2-GeV Pohang Light Source (PLS), a dedicated synchrotron radiation source. The injector of the storage ring is a 2-GeV linear accelerator. The construction of the linac will be completed by the end of 1993. We plan to construct a test linac using some spare components after the linac construction. The design of the test linac is based on two accelerating columns and a matching girder, a klystron, and a modulator after upgrading current 60-MeV preinjector. The energy of the test linac will be 50-MeV, and the peak current be 30 A. The radiation wavelength is expected to be from 3 to 30 microns. A thermionic RF-gun is considered as an electron beam source. The whole test linac can be installed by sharing present 2-GeV linac tunnel and the gallery.

Authors: Ruggiero Alessandro G.
Title: Nuclear fusion of protons with ions of boron
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ruggiero, Alessandro G., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States
Abstract: This paper describes a method of extracting energy from the fusion events occurring between the collision of a beam of protons with a beam of ions of Boron 11. The two beams are circulating in separated and intersecting storage rings where they collide head-on in a common long-straight section. Requirements on the luminosity of the low-energy collider are shown. Limitations due to space-charge and intrabeam scattering are described. Very fast electron cooling is needed to compensate these effects.

Authors: Meisl Claus J.
Title: Parametric cost model for solar space power and DIPS systems
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Rockwell Intl Corp, Canoga Park, United States
Authors with affiliations: Meisl, Claus J., Rockwell Intl Corp, Canoga Park, United States
Abstract: A detailed cost model has been developed to parametrically determine the program development and production cost of (1) photovoltaic, (2) solar dynamic and (3) dynamic isotope (DIPS) space power systems. The model is applicable in the net electrical power range of 3 to 300 kWe for solar power, and 0.5 to 10kWe for DIPS. Application of the cost model allows spacecraft or space-based power system architecture and design trade studies or budgetary forecasting and cost benefit analyses. The cost model considers all major power subsystems (i. e., power generation, power conversion, energy storage, thermal management, and power management/distribution/ control). It also considers system cost effects such as integration, testing, management, etc.

Authors: Wu Y., Litvinenko V.N., Madey J.M.J.

Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Duke Univ, Durham, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wu, Y., Duke Univ, Durham, United States; Litvinenko, V.N., Duke Univ, Durham, United States; Madey, J.M.J., Duke Univ, Durham, United States
Abstract: A low emittance lattice of the Duke FEL (Free Electron Laser) storage ring dedicated to drive UV-VUV FELs is presented. The second order geometrical aberration is compensated to increase the dynamic aperture. The 6-D dynamic aperture study has been performed on this lattice using symplectic tracking codes, which demonstrates a large energy aperture. The influences of higher-order multipoles (HMs), RMS errors and 6.8-m OK-4 undulator on dynamic aperture are studied. The transverse dynamic aperture is mainly limited by HMs in the straight section quadrupoles. For future FEL operations, we have designed a new straight section lattice for a 26-m long FEL undulator. The dynamic aperture for this lattice is discussed.
Index Keywords: Free electron lasers; Klystrons; Particle beam dynamics; Particle beam tracking; Duke free electron laser (FEL) storage ring; Dynamic aperture; Higher order multipoles; Low emittance lattice; Symplectic tracking codes; Storage rings

Authors: Badin Joseph S., Eaton III Russell
Title: Hydrogen energy pathways: a federal plan for a sustainable energy economy
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Energetics, Inc, Columbia, United States
Authors with affiliations: Badin, Joseph S., Energetics, Inc, Columbia, United States; Eaton III, Russell, Energetics, Inc, Columbia, United States
Abstract: The use of hydrogen in the national energy infrastructure is discussed. The US Department of Energy has developed a multiyear plan to provide overall guidance and leadership for Federal investment in hydrogen R & D. The plan addresses numerous hurdles to be overcome before hydrogen use would be attractive in large end-use markets. It provides a realistic framework for deciding where the use of hydrogen can result in beneficial payoffs. It also suggests critical research programs that can make significant contributions to the development of competitive hydrogen energy systems. Factors such as primary energy input, methods of hydrogen production and technologies for conversion storage and utilization are considered in the energy pathway analyses. These analyses will form the foundation to identify technically sound, economically viable and environmentally beneficial options for a sustainable, nonfossil-based energy economy.

Authors: Furman Miguel A., Eden Jennifer R.
Title: Beam-beam effects for the PEB-II B factory
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, United States
Authors with affiliations: Furman, Miguel A., Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, United States; Eden, Jennifer R., Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, United States
Abstract: We present a summary of a fairly extensive study of beam-beam issues that arise in the design of PEP-II. Most of these studies are carried out with 'strong-strong' multiparticle tracking simulations. We focus on: choice of nominal beam-beam parameter, strength of the parasitic collisions, injection issues, performance and tradeoffs with unequal beam-beam parameters. We comment only briefly on beam lifetime. We conclude that: the beams are sufficiently well separated so that the parasitic collisions are effectively weak; that small inequalities in the beam-beam parameters may imply more comfortable performance margins; and that vertical injection with vertical beam separation is more comfortable than horizontal.

Authors with affiliations: Tommasini, D., Sincrotrone Trieste, Trieste, Italy
Abstract: The Elettra storage ring will be filled with a 2 GeV electron beam from its full energy linear accelerator. Two pulsed septum magnets will be housed in a vacuum tank and four identical fast kicker magnets in air, with an internal ceramic vacuum chamber, will be symmetrically placed around the mid-point of a single straight section. The layout of the injection section, the design of the main individual components, their manufacture and the results of the relevant test are presented and discussed.
Index Keywords: Ceramic materials; Electron beams; Linear accelerators; Magnets; Elettra; Injection; Kicker magnets; Pulsed septum magnets; Storage rings

Authors: Jackson Alan
Title: Commissioning and performance of the advanced light source
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Univ of California, Berkeley, United States
Authors with affiliations: Jackson, Alan, Univ of California, Berkeley, United States
Abstract: The Advanced Light Source (ALS) at the Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory is the first of the lower energy (1- to 2- GeV) third-generation synchrotron radiation facilities to come into operation. Designed with very small electron beam emittances, to operate with long insertion devices to produce very high brightness beams of synchrotron radiation in the VUV and soft x-ray regions of the spectrum, these facilities are complementary to the higher energy (6- to 9-GeV) facilities [1] designed for harder x-radiation. From the earliest periods of their design it was recognized that the performance of the required low-emittance lattices would be dominated by non-linear particle dynamics caused by the strong lattice sextu-poles required for chromatic correction, the effects of undulators and wigglers, and the requirement for very narrow-gap vacuum vessels. Commissioning of the ALS storage ring began early in 1993. In this paper we will briefly review the main characteristics of the storage ring design, describe our commissioning experiences, and review the present performance and performance limitations of the facility.
Index Keywords: Electron beams; Particle beam dynamics; Storage rings; X rays; Advanced Light Source (ALS); Insertion devices; X radiation; Synchrotron radiation

Authors: Shaheed M.Reaz, Maziar C.M.
Title: Plasma-induced bandgap renormalization model for accurate simulation of advanced bipolar transistors
Source title: Proceedings of the 1993 Bipolar/Bicoms Circuits and Technology
Affiliations: Univ of Texas at Austin, Austin, United States
Authors with affiliations: Shaheed, M.Reaz, Univ of Texas at Austin, Austin, United States; Maziar, C.M., Univ of Texas at Austin, Austin, United States
Abstract: We propose a model to describe plasma-induced bandgap narrowing in Si bipolar transistors. We present the simulation results of an advanced Si bipolar transistor structure and compare these results with experimental data. Our results show that inclusion of plasma-induced bandgap narrowing model provides a more accurate estimate of the current gain characteristics. We also found that this effect becomes more important for simulation at low temperatures.

Authors: Newton M.A., Cravey W.R., Hawkins S.A., Kirbie H.C., Ollis C.W.
Title: Development of FET-switched induction accelerator cells for heavy-ion fusion recirculators
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab, Livermore, United States
Authors with affiliations: Newton, M.A., Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab, Livermore, United States; Cravey, W.R., Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab, Livermore, United States; Hawkins, S.A., Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab, Livermore, United States; Kirbie, H.C., Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab, Livermore, United States; Ollis, C.W., Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab, Livermore, United States
Abstract: The `recirculator', a recirculating heavy-ion induction accelerator, has been identified as a promising approach for an inertial fusion driver. One of the technical challenges to building a recirculator is the requirement for a modulator that can drive the induction accelerator cells at repetition rates ≥100 kHz with variable pulse width and pulse repetition rate capability. A high repetition rate modulator and cell is presently being developed for use on a proposed heavy-ion recirculator. The goal is to develop an array of field-effect transistors to switch 5 kV, 1 μs pulses onto a Metglas induction core at pulse rates exceeding 100 kHz. Each transistor in the array is driven by a fiber-optic isolated gate signal that is powered by a dc/dc converter. The circuit architecture provides for core reset between pulses and produces bursts of pulses that are variable in pulse width and prf. The transistor switching array, energy storage capacitors, reset circuit and cell core are all combined into a single compact, low-impedance package. Progress of this development work will be presented with supporting data.
Index Keywords: Electric converters; Field effect transistors; Fusion reactions; Ion beams; Light modulators; Particle accelerator accessories; Waveguide circulators; Accelerator cells; Fusion driver; Particle accelerators

Abstract: A resonance correction system for the High Energy Booster (HEB) of the Superconducting Super Collider (SSCL) was investigated by means of dynamic multiparticle tracking. In the simulation the operating tune is scanned as a function of time so that the bunch goes through a resonance. The performance of the half integer and third integer resonance correction system is demonstrated.

Authors: Davis Gregory W., Hodges Gary L., Madeka Frank C.
Title: Development of a series hybrid electric vehicle for near-term applications

Abstract: A series Hybrid Electric Vehicle (HEV) is currently under development for use in the Hybrid Electric Vehicle Challenge which is scheduled to take place during June of 1993. This competition, involving 30 universities from North America, is jointly sponsored by Ford Motor Company, SAE International and the U.S. Department of Energy. The U.S. Naval Academy's entry is a 5 door Ford Escort Wagon which have been converted to a series drive hybrid vehicle. The HEV entry is designed to be a feasible alternative to gasoline powered vehicles. This vehicle was designed to retain the basic driving characteristics of a conventional gasoline powered vehicle. This paper shows that continued testing and evaluation will reveal the reliability and durability of the various system components. Costs of conversion is quite high but the potential reduction of smog in urban areas will continue to dictate the use of these vehicles.

Abstract: During this phase of study, the system was actually constructed and found to perform successfully. The system outperformed the conventional system by shifting almost 80 percent of the peak cooling load to off-peak hours in typical September weather. The success of the system performance was discussed in detail during this phase of study, and shows a bright future for cool storage applications nationwide.

Authors: Mathewson A.G.
Title: Vacuum technology for superconducting colliders
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Mathewson, A.G., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Abstract: In high energy proton-proton colliders such as the CERN Large Hadron Collider (LHC) project with a centre of mass collision energy of over 14 TeV and the American Superconducting Super Collider (SSC) where the centre of mass collision energy reaches 40 TeV the relativistic protons lose energy in the form of synchrotron radiation. For adequate beam-residual gas lifetimes in these machines the pressure should typically be in the 10-10 Torr range. However the synchrotron radiation impinging on the walls of the vacuum chamber desorbs gas and may result in large pressure increases detrimental to the operation of the collider. To achieve the required strong bending in these machines it is necessary, in the case of the LHC, to employ dipole fields up to 9.0 T which need superconducting magnets operating at 1.9 K. The vacuum chamber is therefore at cryogenic temperature and functions as a cryopump. At first sight this free cryopumping may appear beneficial but in practice introduces several liabilities-for example, only a few monolayers of cryopumped H2 already has a vapour pressure at 5 K in excess of 10-6 Torr. These and other effects and constraints on the design of the cold vacuum system will be described in detail.
Index Keywords: Desorption; Energy dissipation; Low temperature operations; Magnetic fields; Protons; Storage rings; Superconducting magnets; Synchrotron radiation; Vacuum pumps; Vacuum technology; Vapor pressure; Beam residual gas lifetimes; Centre of mass collision energy; Cold vacuum systems; Cryogenic temperature; Cryopumps; High energy proton-proton colliders; Large hadron collider; Molecular density; Superconducting colliders; Vacuum chamber; Colliding beam accelerators

Authors: Yimer Bedru
Title: Radiative interaction in multi-dimensional phase change energy storage systems
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Advanced Energy Systems Division (Publication) AES
Affiliations: Univ of Kansas, Lawrence, United States
Authors with affiliations: Yimer, Bedru, Univ of Kansas, Lawrence, United States
Abstract: This paper presents the result of a numerical investigation of the effects of internal radiation on the heat transfer process of latent heat energy storage systems. The effects of internal radiation on the solidification/melting of an absorbing, emitting, and isotropically scattering, finite, and semi-transparent gray phase change medium bounded between two concentric cylinders was studied. In this two-dimensional transient system, heat at the inner surface was extracted/added at a constant rate and also by a secondary fluid passing through the inner tube. In developing the describing equations a method that uses enthalpy along with temperature as dependent variables was employed. In this approach the energy equation is applied once over the complete domain covering both phases. The location of the solid/liquid interface is eliminated from the formulation and is obtained as one of the results of the solution after the temperature distribution is found. Applying the law of conservation of energy to a control volume, the net rate of energy increase of a control volume was equated to the net rate of heat conducted and radiated into the control volume through its surfaces. The radiative heat flux term in the energy equation was obtained from the differential form of the equation of transfer. The pn differential approximation to the equation of radiative transfer was utilized to derive the necessary moment equations. Marshak type boundary conditions were used to solve the differential equation describing the radiative transfer. The moment equations were then conveniently coupled with the other terms in the energy equation. The resulting describing equations which include the radiative flux, along with the appropriate boundary and semi-transparent moving interfacial conditions were written in finite difference form. The Gauss-Seidel iterative method with successive over-relaxation was used to solve the non-linear simultaneous equations. The transient temperature distribution, solid/liquid interface location, radiative heat flux and energy storage capacity of the semi-transparent phase change medium were then determined using the numerical scheme. Using the transient multi-dimensional model, the effects of parameters such as optical and thermophysical properties of the medium, conduction-radiation interaction parameter on the rate of solidification/melting and energy storage capacity were studied. The results show that radiative heat transfer significantly affects the dynamics of solidification/melting as conduction-radiation interaction parameter decreases. The results of this study will lead to a better design and optimization of phase change thermal energy storage systems particularly for space applications.
Index Keywords: Approximation theory; Describing functions; Differential equations; Finite difference method; Heat radiation; Iterative methods; Melting; Nonlinear equations; Phase interfaces; Solidification; Temperature distribution; Thermodynamics; Enthalpy; Gauss Seidel iterative method; Internal radiation; Marshak type boundary conditions; Phase change thermal energy storage (TES) systems; Energy storage

Abstract: LURE is designing a new storage ring of energy 2.15 GeV which will provide radiation in the intermediate energy range, 20 eV-1.5 keV, from undulators and 5 keV critical energy photons from dipole bends. On the basis of what was learned from Super-ACO experience, a number of criteria were retained for the new machine: large number of insertion sections (13), 3 and 5 m long, for a comparatively short circumference (216 m), moderate emittance (3.7 10-8m.rad) to secure good Touschek lifetime for the operation with a few intense bunches and for a realistic energy acceptance. Particular attention is paid to all aspects leading to the stability of the photon beam. A decision is looked for 1993-94. The construction time should be 4 years.

Abstract: In this paper the design of a accumulating storage ring for the electron beam with ultra-fast automatic cooling is given. The electron beam can be continuously injected and accumulated in more than 1 MA at the enough high energy. It can contain deuterium and tritium about one per cent and confine them to realize the fusion. The choice of the cooling magnet and the lattice design are introduced.

Authors: Stewart Jr. W.E., Kaupang R.L., Tharp C.G., Wendland R.D., Stickler L.A.
Title: Approximate numerical model of falling-film ice crystal growth for cool thermal energy storage
Affiliations: Univ of Missouri-Kansas City, Independence, United States
Authors with affiliations: Stewart Jr., W.E., Univ of Missouri-Kansas City, Independence, United States; Kaupang, R.L., Univ of Missouri-Kansas City, Independence, United States; Tharp, C.G., Univ of Missouri-Kansas City, Independence, United States; Wendland, R.D., Univ of Missouri-Kansas City, Independence, United States; Stickler, L.A., Univ of Missouri-Kansas City, Independence, United States
Abstract: A numerical model has been developed to numerically approximate the rate of ice crystal growth in a falling film flowing down a cooled vertical plate for assumed laminar flow. The governing energy equation contains the phase-change energy as a source term. Enhancement of heat transfer due to ice crystal and fluid interactions is accounted for in the use of effective values (thermal conductivity, viscosity, thermal diffusivity, and specific heat), as functions of volumetric concentration of ice in the falling film. Nusselt numbers and overall heat transfer coefficients between the film and cooled plate and ice crystal growth rates were calculated for different film thicknesses, initial ice crystal diameters, and Stefan numbers. Nusselt number and ice crystal growth rate were found to be dependent upon film thickness (flow rate), initial ice number concentration, and Stefan number. Quantitative comparisons of calculated heat transfer coefficients to some previous experimental data show reasonable agreement.
Index Keywords: Approximation theory; Evaporators; Growth (materials); Heat transfer; Ice; Laminar flow; Mathematical models; Phase transitions; Specific heat of liquids; Thermal conductivity; Thermal diffusion in liquids; Viscosity of liquids; Cool thermal energy storage; Energy equations; Falling film ice crystal growth; Nusselt number; Phase change materials; Heat storage

Authors: Suzuki Atsuyuki
Title: Japanese nuclear policy in a changing world
Source title: Uranium and Nuclear Energy, Proceedings of the International Symposium held by the Uranium Institute
Authors with affiliations: Suzuki, Atsuyuki
Abstract: In Japan, nuclear power reactors and oil-fired plants are the largest sources of energy for electricity generation. Nearly 30% of all electricity is now provided by more than 40 nuclear power plants, totalling about 35 000 MWe of generating capacity. While about 10 plants are still under construction, to bring the total capacity to about 45 000 MWe by 2000, the number of additional reactors being planned is limited, mainly because of the difficulty in procuring new sites. It is anticipated that plans to build some additional plants will be made in the near future. The planned reprocessing plant of Japan Nuclear Fuel Ltd (JNFL) at Rokkasho-mura has passed a two-phase safety review by the Science and Technology Agency and the Nuclear Safety Commission, and construction has already commenced on the related high-level radioactive waste storage facility, with completion slated for late 1994.
Index Keywords: Energy policy; Laws and legislation; Nuclear energy; Nuclear fuels; Radioactive wastes; Japan; Nuclear Safety Commission; Oil fired plants; Nuclear power plants

Authors: Blasche K., Franczak B., Langenbeck B., Moritz G., Riedel C.
Title: Heavy ion synchrotron SIS - a progress report
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: GSI, Darmstadt, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Blasche, K., GSI, Darmstadt, Germany; Franczak, B., GSI, Darmstadt, Germany; Langenbeck, B., GSI, Darmstadt, Germany; Moritz, G., GSI, Darmstadt, Germany; Riedel, C., GSI, Darmstadt, Germany
Abstract: A brief description is given of the Heavy Ion Synchrotron SIS, which is part of the new SIS/ESR facility at GSI. A survey of the ions that were accelerated in 1992 is presented showing the respective beam energies and intensities. Plans to increase the available beam intensities are shortly discussed. Progress in the supercycle operation for a time-shared use of up to 16 machine settings and commissioning of the beam line from the ESR back to the SIS with storage and future postacceleration of cold ESR beams are summarized. In addition, the results of recent machine experiments are presented: they include new data on Q-values for the dynamic change-over from triplet focusing at injection to doublet focusing at extraction and on machine chromaticity as well as beam profile measurements for the circulating SIS beam, which yield information on the transverse beam emittances. Finally some aspects of the present and future experimental program are discussed.

Abstract: Lengthening of a single bunch has been investigated in the VEPP-3 storage ring at different energies for beam current up to 100 mA. The bunch length was measured using optical diagnostic system. The current dependences of the transverse beam size, synchronous phase shift, coherent and incoherent synchrotron tune shift have been measured. The experimental data are in agreement with the model of longitudinal potential well distortion. The real and imaginary parts of the longitudinal coupling impedance are deduced from measured data.

Abstract: For Metal Finishing and Aluminum industries the EPA best available technology and cost effective industrial waste water treatment facility is the 300-M area Effluent Treatment Facility (LETF) of the Savannah River Site that employs precipitation and filtration. The LETF has three close-coupled treatment facilities namely, the Delute Effluent Treatment Facility (FETF), the Chemical Treatment Facility, and the Interim Treatment Storage Facility. To conform with the agreement set by the Department of Energy and Environmental Protection Agency, the F006 mixed (hazardous and radioactive) should be treated for disposal and clean closed IT/SF tanks. The key to cost-effective treatment of the supernate is water minimization and filtration efficiency because the filter cake produced is returned to the IT/SF. For maximum efficiency and minimum waste generation, the DETF has been successfully optimized. Presented in the paper is the DETF process of treatment and optimization of the supernate. At present, the F006 mixed water reductions total $1,900,000. Saving will be increasing us more optimization and supernate treatment continue.

Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: National Lab for High Energy physics, (KEK), Tsukuba, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Fukuda, S., National Lab for High Energy physics, (KEK), Tsukuba, Japan; Anami, S., National Lab for High Energy physics, (KEK), Tsukuba, Japan; Saito, Y., National Lab for High Energy physics, (KEK), Tsukuba, Japan; Michizono, S., National Lab for High Energy physics, (KEK), Tsukuba, Japan; Nakao, K., National Lab for High Energy physics, (KEK), Tsukuba, Japan; Sato, I., National Lab for High Energy physics, (KEK), Tsukuba, Japan
Abstract: The B-Factory project is a future plan at KEK requiring an energy upgrade of the KEK linac from 2.5 GeV to 8.0 GeV. This paper describes an upgrade plan and recent progress concerning the rf source. A test to increase the rf power using the existing 30-MW klystron is being carried out and an output power of 51.5 MW has been obtained by increasing the beam voltage up to 310 kV while optimizing the focusing magnetic field. Tests using a 60-MW klystron are also planned. The choice between upgrading of the present klystron and the use of a 60-MW klystron depends on the pulse-compression system to be adopted. The most efficient way regarding costs is being surveyed in order to use the existing components, such as the focusing magnet and the pulse transformer with only slight changes.

Authors: Despe O.D, Saunders C., McGhee D.G.
Title: Control units for APS power supplies
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States
Authors with affiliations: Despe, O.D, Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States; Saunders, C., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States; McGhee, D.G., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States
Abstract: The Advanced Photon Source (APS) accelerator facility is made up of five major subsystems in addition to the linac: the positron accumulator ring (PAR), low energy transport (LET), booster synchrotron (SYNCH), high energy transport (HET), and the storage ring (SR). Each subsystem has multiple magnet and power supply combinations, some requiring multiple modes of operation. These magnet and power supply combinations are computer controlled and monitored. The power supply control unit (PSCU) is the first layer of hardware and software directly above the power supply itself and is described in this paper. The description includes the basic philosophy for each mode of operation and how it influences the topology and means of implementing control. The design of the analog reference blocks (ARBs) influenced the design of other custom functions as well as the feedback controls for vibration and other dynamic corrections. The command set supported by the PSCU is discussed.

Abstract: A new quick-look method of sample analysis and a new equipment to carry out it, was developed by the authors. It's intended to use for special tasks occurring in the geology and in environmental protection. The layers in the ground are directly shot by a high energy pulse of a Nd:YAG laser and the picture of the excited plasma is observed trough a fibre optical system. The atomic emission spectra detected by the surface unit are stored in data files of special format. The spectrum files are analysed by the SAMPO 90 programme on an NB386 computer just at the site. The first methodological experiments were performed in the laser laboratories of Pecs University. The new equipment consists of a sonde (measuring head) connected to the surface unit trough a fibre optical system. The surface unit contains the supply unit, the polychromator and a RAM. The measuring and the data acquisition is controlled by a 386 Note Book Computer. The whole system seems to be a portable laboratory to determine the components of rock samples or the contamination in the soil.

Authors: Marsh Daniel R., Siegmund Oswald H., Stock Joseph M.
Title: Progress on high-efficiency photocathodes for soft x-ray, EUV, and FUV photon detection
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering

Abstract: We report on progress in the development of high quantum detection efficiency photocathodes for microchannel plate based photon detectors to increase soft X-ray, EUV and FUV response. Initial investigations of NaBr, KI and CsBr opaque photocathodes are discussed. All show QDE's of approximately 40% in the 300 - 1000 angstroms regime, and QDE > 60% at approximately 100 angstroms. KI also shows high QDE, approximately 60%, for soft X-rays (approximately 11 angstroms). Photoelectron energy and number distributions are also presented. Lifetest measurements on KBr and CsBr photocathodes show good long term stability for storage in dry nitrogen. A co-evaporated photocathode is also evaluated.

Authors: Yokoyama Ryohei, Ito Koichi
Title: Optimal operational planning of cogeneration systems with thermal storage by the decomposition method

Authors with affiliations: Yokoyama, Ryohei, Osaka Metropolitan Univ, Osaka, Japan; Ito, Koichi, Osaka Metropolitan Univ, Osaka, Japan
Abstract: An optimal operational planning method is proposed for cogeneration systems with thermal storage. The daily operational strategy of constituent equipment is determined so as to minimize the daily operational cost subject to the energy demand requirement. This optimization problem is formulated as a large-scale mixed-integer linear programming one, and it is solved by means of the decomposition method. Effects of thermal storage on the operation of cogeneration systems are examined through a numerical study on a gas engine-driven cogeneration system installed in a hotel. This method is a useful tool for evaluating the economic and energy saving properties of cogeneration systems with thermal storage.

Authors: Kander Ronald G., Namboodri Shannon L.
Title: Processing and characterization of ceramic superconductor/polymer composites
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Advanced Composite Materials
Affiliations: Virginia Polytechnic Inst &, State Univ, Blacksburg, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kander, Ronald G., Virginia Polytechnic Inst &, State Univ, Blacksburg, United States; Namboodri, Shannon L., Virginia Polytechnic Inst &, State Univ, Blacksburg, United States
Abstract: One way to more easily process a brittle high-temperature ceramic superconductor into a useful structure is to combine it with a polymer to form a composite material. Processing of polymer-based composites into complex shapes is well established and relatively easy when compared with traditional ceramic processing unit operations. In addition, incorporating a ceramic superconductor into a polymer matrix can improve mechanical performance as compared with a monolithic ceramic. Finally, because ceramic superconductors are susceptible to attack by moisture, a polymer-based composite structure can also provide protection from deleterious environmental effects. This paper focuses on the processing and subsequent characterization of ceramic superconductor/polymer composites designed primarily for electromagnetic shielding and diamagnetic applications. YBa2Cu3O7-x[YBCO] ceramic superconductor is combined with poly(methyl methacrylate) [PMMA] to form novel composite structures. Composite structures have been molded with both a discontinuous superconducting phase (i.e., ceramic particulate reinforced polymers) and with a continuous superconducting phase (i.e., polymer infiltrated porous ceramics). Characterization of these composite structures includes the determination of diamagnetic strength, electromagnetic shielding effectiveness, mechanical performance, and environmental resistance. The goal of this program is to produce a composite structure with increased mechanical integrity and environmental resistance at liquid nitrogen temperatures without compromising the electromagnetic shielding and diamagnetic properties of the superconducting phase. Composites structures of this type are potentially useful in numerous magnetic applications including electromagnetic shielding, magnetic sensors, energy storage, magnetic levitation, and motor windings.
Index Keywords: Ceramic materials; Characterization; Composite structures; Copper oxides; Electromagnetic shielding; High temperature superconductors; Mechanical properties; Phase transitions; Polymers; Polymethyl methacrylates; Processing; Structure (composition); Yttrium compounds; Ceramic superconductor/polymer composites; Nonmetallic matrix composites

Authors: Stabulnieks Y., Shinka Y.
Title: Estimation of energetic factors in power electronics supply systems
Affiliations: Latvian Acad of Sciences, Latvia
Authors with affiliations: Stabulnieks, Y., Latvian Acad of Sciences, Latvia; Shinka, Y., Latvian Acad of Sciences, Latvia
Abstract: Conventional calculation methods of electric power and its components as orthogonal, integral, symbolic, systems equivalence, etc., applied to nonsinusoidal system analysis bring to different and sometimes to inexplicable results. Obtained in such a way reactive and apparent power have no physical interpretation and have only an arbitrary mathematical implication. Therefore, currently accepted definitions of electric power components are reviewed and their limitations in systems with converters are analyzed. In terms of instantaneous power a number of energy flow and power components such as active, external, input, reverse, resonant, storage, oscillation, etc., have been determined. These components can be used to determine new energetic factors: the system energy utilization factor, consumer energy utilization factor, power oscillation factor, etc. They may be applied for the power system optimization, reactive and active compensation, harmonic suppression. The application of the theory developed is illustrated by a typical example. The proposed power and energy components can be directly measured by means of digital electronic instruments.
Index Keywords: Electric converters; Electric power measurement; Electric power systems; Mathematical models; Reactive power; Energetic factors; Electric power supplies to apparatus

Authors: Oman Henry
Title: Infrastructure for battery-powered electric bicycles
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Consulting Engineer, Seattle, United States
Authors with affiliations: Oman, Henry, Consulting Engineer, Seattle, United States
Abstract: With a 200 km range between charges, an electric bicycle powered by nickel-metal hydride batteries would be a practical vehicle for commuting to city centers. With the new polymer batteries a 300 km range will be feasible. An electric bicycle is a traditional bicycle on which have been installed a propulsion motor, its control, and its power supplying battery. Widespread use of battery-powered electric bicycles in downtowns of cities in industrialized nations would require designated bicycle routes and battery-recharging facilities in homes and workplaces.

Authors: Senf Friedmar, Menthel U., Peatman William B.
Title: Quantitative analysis of the effects of heat loading on an undulator beamline
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: BESSY GmbH, Berlin, Ger
Authors with affiliations: Senf, Friedmar, BESSY GmbH, Berlin, Ger; Menthel, U., BESSY GmbH, Berlin, Ger; Peatman, William B., BESSY GmbH, Berlin, Ger
Abstract: With the help of several computer codes especially developed or adapted for this application, the energy losses in the individual components of a high resolution undulator beamline for BESSY II were quantitatively calculated and their affect on the performance of the beamline determined. The critical portion of the beamline, a Kirkpatrick-Baez system in front of the entrance slit, can be designed so as to withstand the deleterious effects of the heat loading with essentially no loss of intrinsic brightness of the source. The absorbed heat load profile has been determined in a dense grid on the mirror surfaces by taking the variation of the spectral power distribution from the undulator and the reflectivity of the surfaces into account. The influence of the angle of incidence on the first horizontally deflecting mirror as well as of a vertical aperture in front of the beamline has also been studied.

Authors: Hagoort Jacques
Title: Simulation of production and injection performance of gas storage caverns in salt formations
Source title: Proceedings - SPE Annual Technical Conference and Exhibition
Affiliations: Hagoort & Assocs. Inc
Authors with affiliations: Hagoort, Jacques, Hagoort & Assocs. Inc
Abstract: We have developed a simple yet comprehensive mathematical model for the simulation of the injection and production performance of gas storage caverns in salt formations. The model predicts the pressure and temperature of the gas in the cavern and at the wellhead for an arbitrary sequence of production and injection cycles. The model incorporates non-ideal gas properties, thermodynamic heat effects associated with gas expansion and compression both in cavern and tubing, heat exchange with the surrounding salt formation and non-uniform initial temperatures. Not included are rock-mechanical effects. The model is based on a mass and energy balance for the gas filled cavern and on the Bernoulli equation and energy balance for flow in the wellbore. The cavern equations are solved iteratively at successive time steps. The wellbore equations are solved within an iteration cycle of the cavern equations. Gas properties are calculated internally using generally accepted correlations and basic thermodynamic relations. Example calculations show a strong effect of the initial temperature distribution on the production performance of a typical gas storage cavern. The main application of the model is in the design, planning and operation of gas storage projects. For example, the model may be used for deliverability forecasts and for the evaluation of gas hydrate formation.
Index Keywords: Caves; Correlation methods; Gas fuel storage; Injection (oil wells); Mathematical models; Natural gas; Natural gas well production; Numerical methods; Performance; Petroleum geology; Salts; Thermodynamics; Bernoulli equation; Energy balance; Gas expansion; Gas properties; Gas storage caverns; Heat exchange; Injection cycles; Production cycles; Salt formations; Wellhead; Geologic models

Abstract: The Storage - Accelerating Complex (SAC) of heavy ions is intended for the storage of ions up to Neon, their acceleration up to an energy of 300 MeV/n (A/Z=2), and physical experiment on an internal target with the electron cooling used at a high energy. The experiments can be performed both with narrow and wide beams on the targets. The stored current is about 109 - 1011 particles, the luminosity is expected to be 1029 - 1030cm-2 · sec-1, the ion beam life-time - several tens of seconds.

Affiliations: Cornell Univ, Ithaca, United States
Authors with affiliations: Greenwald, Z., Cornell Univ, Ithaca, United States; Tigner, M., Cornell Univ, Ithaca, United States
Abstract: The B factory bunch train in both beams is designed with a 250 nsec gap in order to minimize ion trapping. Possible differences in the synchronous phase between bunches due to this gap in the bunch train is studied and this unequal phase shift between bunches could lower the luminosity. The paper presents the calculations and deviations being made in the study of the synchronous phase changes in the bunch train gap and results show that a gap of 250 nsec does not cause a measurable change in the phase since the time constant of each cavity is larger than the gap in the bunch train meaning the cavity voltage does not discharge during the gap causing only a small change.

Abstract: The nominal beam storage time in the SSC Collider is 24 hours. During this period, there are many co-existing effects that have impacts on the luminosity - intrabeam scattering, synchrotron radiation, pp collisions, beam-gas scattering and beam collimation. A computer program has been written which takes these effects into account simultaneously, and calculates the emittances and luminosity as a function of time. These evolution curves are compared for different operation scenarios (i.e., different initial conditions of the beam current, emittances, and beam energies.)

Abstract: This paper is to illustrate that the transverse emittance of a beam with constant energy can be automatically shrinked in the particular static magnetic field, which can be used as an ultra-fast 'cooler' to accelerators or storage rings. The analytical solution for the nonlinear equation of motion is obtained. The exact proof of the problem is given by means of the precisely analytical representation of Jacobean determinant corresponding to the nonlinear transformation of emittance.

Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Osaka Univ, Osaka, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kato, Syohei, Osaka Univ, Osaka, Japan
Abstract: A beam cooling method which uses a stimulated emission of radiation by relativistic electrons in a magnetic field is proposed to apply to an electron beam in SR rings. A traveling RF electric field in a transmission line against the beam produces the stimulation. Averaging the emission power over electron energy distributions, the net emission from the beam takes place in a certain frequency region. The emission power is shown to be large enough to decrease horizontal emittance of the beam to a very small value in typical SR rings. Some conditions for the energy emission are discussed.

Authors: Meyer Alfred P.
Title: Development of proton exchange membrane fuel cells for underwater applications
Source title: Proceedings of the Conference on Oceans '93
Affiliations: Int Fuel Cells Corp, South Windsor, United States
Authors with affiliations: Meyer, Alfred P., Int Fuel Cells Corp, South Windsor, United States
Abstract: A 20-kW proton exchange membrane (PEM) fuel cell power plant developed for application in unmanned underwater vehicles (UUVs) is described. The power plant is based on a simple system concept requiring no circulation of gases for thermal and water management - enhancing reliability, durability and maximizing energy density and vehicle range. The power plant is part of an energy storage system designed to replace the silver-zinc battery system currently used to supply power in the 44-inch UUV developed by the United States Advanced Research Projects Agency. The power plant may be operated with hydrogen and oxygen supplied from a variety of alternative sources. Hydrogen generation from methanol by reforming is discussed. Specifically, a method demonstrated for reducing the carbon-monoxide content of reformate to levels compatible with the long endurance of the PEM fuel cell is presented. Data showing compatibility with hydrogen supplied from a regenerable metal hydride bed is also presented.

Title: Measurement of the orbit parameters at SOR-RING
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Univ of Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kudo, Hirofumi, Univ of Tokyo, Japan; Shinoe, Keniji, Univ of Tokyo, Japan; Takaki, Hiroyuki, Univ of Tokyo, Japan; Koseki, Tadashi, Univ of Tokyo, Japan; Ohkuma, Haruo, Univ of Tokyo, Japan; Kamiya, Yukihide, Univ of Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: In the 1992 summer shutdown, beam position monitors (BPM's)[1] [2] have been installed in SOR-RING as one of the R&D's for the future plan of a VUV high-brilliant source. They have been also aimed at measuring the closed orbit of the ring and correcting it by beam steerings that have been also installed at the same time as the BPM's. With these systems, we measured the closed orbit distortion (C.O.D.) at the first time since the ring had been constructed. Horizontal and vertical C.O.D.'s were then corrected within 1 mm by exciting the steerings and changing the RF frequency. We also measured the other orbit parameters such as betatron and dispersion functions, chromaticity and RF-cavity parameters. Moreover, it was proved in a recent machine study that SOR-RING is capable of accelerating the electron up to 450 MeV or more from the present energy of 380 MeV.
Index Keywords: Cavity resonators; Electron beams; Particle accelerators; Synchrotron radiation; Beam position monitors (BPM's); High brilliant source; Orbit parameters; Storage rings

Abstract: This volume of the proceedings contains 18 articles devoted to new developments in refrigeration, heat pump, and air conditioning systems. Particular emphasis is given to heat pump systems. Abstract: There are distinct physics advantages to using asymmetric φ factories to test and study CPT and CP violation. However, several beam dynamics issues remain to be addressed, especially for the effects of a high energy linac beam on a low energy target (most likely a storage ring or a recirculator structure), We present a preliminary discussion of collider concepts, especially with regard to the creation of high luminosities.

Abstract: The MIT-Bates South Hall Ring (SHR) is an electron storage ring used with the 1 GeV Bates electron accelerator to increase the effective duty factor and luminosity. A beam can be stored for use with an internal target, thus allowing for high duty factor high luminosity experiments. External beams with high duty factor can be obtained using resonant extraction. References describe some aspects of the SHR design features. A layout of the 190m circumference ring and associated new beam lines is shown. The new systems associated with the SHR include the Energy Compression System (ECS), the Injection line, and the Extraction line. We have commissioned the ECS, the new injection line and the SHR without Rf. This includes transporting beam, measuring beam phase space parameters, using critical injection elements including a high voltage electrostatic septum, and a fast beam kicker, a storing a beam in the SHR.
Index Keywords: Electron ring accelerators; Particle beam injection; Particle beams; Performance; Plant layout; Commissioning; Energy compression system; Extraction line; Injection line; Storage rings

Authors: Chubar O.V.
Title: Resolution improvement in beam profile measurements with synchrotron light
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Moscow Engineering Physics Inst, Moscow, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Chubar, O.V., Moscow Engineering Physics Inst, Moscow, Russian Federation
Abstract: Numerical method for improving optical resolution in electron beam profile measurements with visible synchrotron radiation (SR) is propose. Image formation of electron beam profile is described by integral convolution-type equation of the first kind - the diagnostic equation. Precise procedure of computing the equation kernel in terms of classical electrodynamics is presented. With this procedure special features of the SR emission and diffraction scheme peculiarities may be taken into account. Numerical regularized solution of the diagnostic equation is shown to lead to the resolution improvement. The technique is supposed to be beneficial in high-energy storage rings.
Index Keywords: Electrodynamics; Electron beams; High energy physics; Mathematical models; Numerical methods; Storage rings; Synchrotron radiation; Beam profile measurement; Diagnostic equation; Electron beam profile; Image formation; Radioactivity measurement

Affiliations: Georgia Inst of Technology, Atlanta, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sanderson, Terry M., Georgia Inst of Technology, Atlanta, United States; Cunningham, Glenn T., Georgia Inst of Technology, Atlanta, United States
Abstract: Designers of packed bed thermal storage heat exchangers may face the following question: given a packed bed thermal energy storage system, and holding all other system components constant, what is the impact of altering the equivalent sphere diameter DE of the packing material on system operation? Constant system components would include heating/cooling loads and equipment size, pump size, storage tank dimensions, etc. Experimental results presented in this paper show some of the effects of changing DE on the temperature distributions in the packing. An average driving temperature difference for packed beds is also proposed, and instantaneous heat transfer rates in the packing are discussed.

Authors: Cramer Gunther, Kleinkauf Werner, Schott Thomas
Title: Wind/diesel/battery systems - applications, experience, economy of different system configurations and sizes
Affiliations: SMA Regelsysteme GmbH, Niestetal, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Cramer, Gunther, SMA Regelsysteme GmbH, Niestetal, Germany; Kleinkauf, Werner, SMA Regelsysteme GmbH, Niestetal, Germany; Schott, Thomas, SMA Regelsysteme GmbH, Niestetal, Germany
Abstract: The wind/diesel/battery system which was installed on the Irish island of Cape Clear in 1987 has been delivering information and experience for more than 3 years of operation. The autonomous energy supply system consists of 2 wind energy converters of type AEROMAN (2×33 kW) a diesel engine coupled with a synchronous generator (working as phase shifter when the diesel is shut down), and a battery storage with a capacity of 100 kWh (connected with the AC-bus via a line commutated converter). The measured results of the first one year's operation period revealed the technical as well as the economical advantages of the advanced wind/diesel/battery system. The experience derived from the Cape Clear project brought a variety of improvements which have been incorporated into second generation wind/diesel/battery systems. The supervisory control as well as the operation control were improved allowing minimization of the battery storage. In the case of very good wind conditions and low demands, the output of the wind energy converter may now be utilized far better by the use of a consumer control. The improvements have been incorporated into 2 small wind/diesel/battery systems (1×AEROMAN, diesel engine 25 kW, battery storage 30 kWh) located in Inner Mongolia. Within the frame of the EC demonstration projects, another improvement shall be applied regarding a medium-sized wind/diesel/battery system (165 kW wind energy converter, diesel engines with 75 kW and 20 kW, resp., and a battery storage with a capacity of 75 kWh) located in Spain: the diesel operation will be economized by installing 2 disconnectable diesel engines having a basically different output. Therefore, in the case of good wind conditions and fuel costs of about DM 0,60/ltr, the costs for electric energy generated by these hybrid systems are approximately 20% to 35% lower than those arising from the use of diesel power stations of comparable output.
Index Keywords: Control systems; Costs; Diesel engines; Electric power generation; Secondary batteries; Synchronous generators; Systems analysis; Wind turbines; Wind/diesel/battery systems; Wind power; Engines-Diesel; Power Generation; Wind Turbines

Authors: Ruddell A.J., Bleijs J.A.M., Freris L.L., Infield D.G., Smith G.A.
Title: A wind/diesel system with variable speed flywheel storage
Affiliations: Imperial Coll, London, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Ruddell, A.J., Imperial Coll, London, United Kingdom; Bleijs, J.A.M., Imperial Coll, London, United Kingdom; Freris, L.L., Imperial Coll, London, United Kingdom; Infield, D.G., Imperial Coll, London, United Kingdom; Smith, G.A., Imperial Coll, London, United Kingdom
Abstract: The economic application of autonomous wind/diesel generating systems in remote areas requires high wind power penetration. Energy storage is required to enable system operation for the maximum possible time with the diesel engine stopped. A 45 kW wind/diesel system with an energy store consisting of a variable speed flywheel and a power electronic drive has been improved. The integration of a high percentage of wind power into a weak electrical network, and the quality and stability of the electrical supply achieved, are discussed. Results of operating the prototype system in all modes have demonstrated the feasibility of the approach, and further design improvements to the energy store and the dynamic controller are proposed.

Authors: Kercan Vladimir, Djelic Vesko, Mocnik Zdravko, Sturm Mitja
Title: Hydro power plants on the Drava river in Slovenia. Two approaches for refurbishment
Source title: International Water Power and Dam Construction
Affiliations: Turboinstitut
Authors with affiliations: Kercan, Vladimir, Turboinstitut; Djelic, Vesko, Turboinstitut; Mocnik, Zdravko, Turboinstitut; Sturm, Mitja, Turboinstitut
Abstract: The exploitation of the Drava River began after World War I (1918) with the construction of the first hydro power plant, the Fala HPP. Twenty-two hydro power plants have been built up to the present, with a total installed power capacity of 1400 MW and a mean annual energy production of 6854 GWh. One HPP was built on the South Tyrolia (in Austria) as a derivation plant with a high head, while the remaining 21 hydro power plants were built in an uninterrupted chain. Ten hydro power plants are located in Austria (Osterreichische Draukraftwerke AG), eight in Slovenia (Dravske elektrarne Maribor-Drava Power Plant Utility), three in Croatia (Hrvatska elektro-privreda Croatian Power Authority). Owing to the fact that in Slovenia the Drava River is a lowland river, partly running through the narrow river valley, the hydro power plants were built as barrage plants with relatively small storage reservoirs. The plants operate as run-of-river type plants, partly using head storage reservoir.
Index Keywords: Electric power generation; Modernization; Operations research; Reservoirs (water); Retrofitting; Rivers; Water power; Drava River, Slovenia; Plant refurbishment; Hydroelectric power plants; Power Stations-Hydroelectric; Refurbishment; Slovenia

Authors: Kaino Koji
Title: Similarity curve in solidification process of latent-heat energy storage unit with longitudinally straight fins. Part 1. Effect of Stefan number on applicability of similarity rule
Affiliations: Toyota Technological Inst
Authors with affiliations: Kaino, Koji, Toyota Technological Inst
Abstract: Similarity curves for different Biot numbers are known to become indistinguishable with decreasing Stefan number; in other words, the similarity rule becomes more applicable for smaller Stefan number. In such a finned-tube-type storage unit as treated in this study, it has been found that the effect of Stefan number on the similarity curve varies with the number of fins. Sensible heat liberated during the solidification process has been calculated individually in a phase-change material with a heat-transfer tube and fins, and represented as a function of the frozen fraction for two specified values of Biot number, 0.1 and 1000, under specified conditions of Stefan number and the number on fins. The latent-heat contribution to heat flow out of the storage unit has been examined in comparison with the sensible-heat contribution. The latent- and sensible-heat contributions are almost inversely related. This inverse relationship reduces the effect of the Stefan number on the applicability of the similarity rule.
