Authors: Linford Gary J., Driemeyer Daniel E., Fornaca Steven W., Maschke Alfred W.
Title: Design of 7.8 MJ 4 GeV Pb++ heavy ion inertial fusion energy driver
Affiliations: TRW Inc, Redondo Beach, United States
Authors with affiliations: Linford, Gary J., TRW Inc, Redondo Beach, United States; Driemeyer, Daniel E., TRW Inc, Redondo Beach, United States; Fornaca, Steven W., TRW Inc, Redondo Beach, United States; Maschke, Alfred W., TRW Inc, Redondo Beach, United States
Abstract: A 7.8 MJ 4 GeV Pb++ heavy ion (HI) inertial fusion energy (IFE) driver operating at 3.5 Hz has been designed for a prototype 1000 MW thermonuclear power plant planned early in the next century. The HI driver design is based upon a short, ramped gradient (5 MeV) LINAC followed by a longer (approx. 2 km) constant gradient, single beam LINAC operated in a 50 kHz burst mode to generate sequentially eighteen 4 GeV beamlets. A 2-sided irradiation geometry is provided for indirect-drive HI targets. Six beamlets generate the 30 ns precursor HI pulses and are accumulated in 2 superconducting storage rings (SCSRs). Twelve SCSRs accumulate 12 main beamlets with a final buncher generating 8 ns pulses. Ballistic foci of triplet focusing magnets pass through a Pb-vapor neutralization cell onto two Pb stripping jets permit 2-sided, self-pinched propagation through two small openings in the HI TC blanket. HI beam foci approx. 0.6 cm diameter were estimated, including the effects of beam emittance and residual space charge. Self-pinched HI beam transport in preformed channels greatly simplifies target chamber (TC) shielding and increases blanket coverage.

Authors: Ancher C.R., Tureikas S.
Title: TFTR ECS safety ground switch soft close modification
Affiliations: Princeton Plasma Physics Lab, Princeton, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ancher, C.R., Princeton Plasma Physics Lab, Princeton, United States; Tureikas, S., Princeton Plasma Physics Lab, Princeton, United States
Abstract: The Safety Disconnect and Grounding Switches represent a major group of components used to support the Tokamak Fusion Test Reactor. There are fifteen such switches in the TFTR power conversion TF and PF coil system. These switches are metal enclosed DC equipment, rated at 15 kV (2500 amperes continuous). They contain gapless zinc oxide arrestors, a stored-energy-operated, double-pole, single-throw grounding switch (capable of closing in on an 80 kA load current), a double-pole, single-throw disconnect switch (to isolate the load from the power supplies), and polarity reversal bus links. In addition to circuit protection the switches provide a level of electrical isolation when it is necessary to access the DC side of the machinery. The operation of the stored energy grounding switches are the subject of this paper. The ground switch is opened by a pneumatic cylinder and is closed with the energy stored, in two heavy springs, during the opening stroke. Whenever the ground switch closes in the normal mode, it does so with a very high level of mechanical acceleration and, consequently, with a relatively high incidence of breakdown. Off line operating modes (i.e., access to Tokamak, hipot testing of the coils, power supply reconfiguration, maintenance and testing) generate a significant number of ground switch operations for non emergency purposes. To minimize downtime resulting from the mechanical trauma of frequent operation, a soft close operating mode was designed into the existing electrical and pneumatic system since there is no need for rapid switch closure during these conditions. Implementation of the soft close enhancement is accomplished pneumatically. Whenever the ground switch control logic detects that its associated interleaf power supplies are disarmed, air pressure from an accumulator tank (an integral component of each switch) is introduced into the backside of the piston of the main pneumatic cylinder. The energy stored in the closing springs is released upon receipt of a 'Close' command. This backfill pressure is vented to atmosphere through a small orifice. The ground switch will now close slowly due to the action of the large closing springs working against a pneumatic impedance. The design of the soft close system and its operational logic will be described in this paper.
Index Keywords: DC machinery; Design; Electric equipment protection; Electric grounding; Electric power systems; Energy storage; Pistons; Pneumatic control equipment; Security systems; Switches; Accumulator tank; Hipot testing; Poloidal field coil; Soft close system; Tokamak fusion test reactor; Toroidal field coil; Tokamak devices

Authors: Hasan Mohammad Z.
Title: Low cost and efficient energy storage concepts for powerplants using pulsed fusion reactors
Affiliations: Univ of California, Los Angeles, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hasan, Mohammad Z., Univ of California, Los Angeles, United States
Abstract: Three new energy storage concepts are introduced which are particularly suitable for delivering steady power from cyclic power sources, and specially from pulsed fusion reactors. These are: (1) PCM: Primary Coolant Mixing, (2) DCS: Diverted Coolant Storage, and (3) DCRS: Diverted Coolant Reversible Storage. The PCM concept is suitable for both compressible and incompressible primary coolants. The DCS and DCRS concepts are suitable for incompressible and compressible coolants, respectively. The PCM mixes the primary coolant over one cycle time or for a large multiple of the downtime. On the other hand, DCS and DCRS store only enough primary coolant at the exit temperature to supply the BOP during the downtime. In DCRS, large pumping power is avoided by making the storage chambers into large cylinders and charging and discharging them with the primary coolant reversibly against nearly equal back pressures of steam bled from the steam turbines. These energy storage concepts have close to 100% turnaround efficiency, and they are expected to be much cheaper compared with other options.
Index Keywords: Coolants; Electric power supplies to apparatus; Energy storage; Tokamak devices; Balance of plant (BOP); Diverted coolant reversible storage (DCRS); Diverted coolant storage (DCS); Primary coolant mixing (PCM); Pulsed fusion reactors; Nuclear power plants

Authors: Yamaguchi Akiyoshi, Chiba Hiroo
Title: Shirashima oil storage terminal as a national energy security project of Japan
Affiliations: Japan Natl Oil Corp, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Yamaguchi, Akiyoshi, Japan Natl Oil Corp, Japan; Chiba, Hiroo, Japan Natl Oil Corp, Japan
Abstract: As part of Japan's national program that calls for the construction of a national crude oil stockpile of 50 million kilo-liters(kl) by the mid-1990s, ten national oil storage terminals have already been completed or are under construction in the country. One of these ten, the Shirashima Oil Storage Terminal, which is scheduled for completion by 1996, is a floating barge type oil storage terminal being constructed southeast of an uninhabited island about 8 km offshore. Eight 700,000-kl-capacity oil storage barges are moored in a 60 ha basin protected by breakwaters to enable a capacity of 5,600,000 kl in total. This paper discusses the progress of the Shirashima Project and the marine construction technology used therein with particular emphasis on the main offshore structures comprising the oil storage terminal, such as breakwaters, mooring dolphins for oil storage barges, sea berth and pipe trestle.

Authors: Fairfax Stephen A., Daigle Joseph, Bertolino Vincent, Paranay Jeffrey, Zhong XiWer
Title: Operation of the alcator C-MOD power system
Affiliations: MIT Plasma Fusion Cent, Cambridge, United States
Authors with affiliations: Fairfax, Stephen A., MIT Plasma Fusion Cent, Cambridge, United States; Daigle, Joseph, MIT Plasma Fusion Cent, Cambridge, United States; Bertolino, Vincent, MIT Plasma Fusion Cent, Cambridge, United States; Paranay, Jeffrey, MIT Plasma Fusion Cent, Cambridge, United States; Zhong, XiWer, MIT Plasma Fusion Cent, Cambridge, United States
Abstract: The energy storage and power conversion system for Alcator C-MOD is designed to supply up to 500 MJ to the experiment at peak powers in excess of 300 MVA. The experiment requires flexibility in the control of magnet currents to achieve simultaneous shaping, ohmic drive, and position control with a small set of uncompensated PF magnets. The relatively modest budget and limited manpower make issues of maintenance and reliability extremely important to the eventual success of the experiment. These requirements resulted in a power system design with many unique features. A total of 11 conversion systems power the 14 magnets of the tokamak to provide nearly complete flexibility in plasma shaping and control. Five thyristor circuit breakers are used to initiate the plasma. Four of the PF converters utilize circulating current configurations to maintain plasma position control as the magnet currents pass through zero. The TF converter incorporates transformer tap-changing circuitry to reduce alternator loads during peak demand periods. Many converters have solid-state fuse loss and conduction monitor circuits that allow continued operation when only 1 device in a parallel bank fails. The same circuits detect commutation failures and protect the converters from these potentially destructive faults. Unique design features can sometimes lead to new and unforeseen problems in operation or maintenance. This report will discuss the initial operating experience of the Alcator C-MOD power system from preliminary acceptance testing through plasma operations. The performance of the thyristor circuit breakers, commutation and conduction monitor circuits, circulating current power supplies, and tap-changing TF supply will be presented and compared with expectations. The overall performance and reliability of the power system will be examined as well.
Index Keywords: Electric converters; Electric current control; Electromagnets; Energy conversion; Energy storage; Maintenance; Plasmas; Position control; Reliability; Systems analysis; Thyristors; Tokamak devices; Alcator; Detects commutation failure; Flexibility; Magnet currents; Peak powers; Poloidal field converters; Toroidal field converters; Electric power supplies to apparatus

Authors: da Cunha Mauricio Pereira, Adler Eric L.
Title: Scattering of SAW at discontinuities: Some numerical experiments
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Ultrasonics Symposium
Affiliations: McGill Univ, Montreal, Canada
Authors with affiliations: da Cunha, Mauricio Pereira, McGill Univ, Montreal, Canada; Adler, Eric L., McGill Univ, Montreal, Canada
Abstract: In developing models to characterize the metallic-finger step discontinuity in SAW devices on piezoelectric substrates it is important to estimate the SAW reflection coefficients and the effect of other modes at step discontinuities. In the literature perturbation approximations, finite element methods and various phenomenological parameter-fitting using experimental data are among the techniques which have been exploited. In this paper, a non-perturbation approximation method, which attempts to parallel some well-established techniques used in solving electromagnetic waveguide-discontinuity problems, is developed as an alternate numerical procedure for calculating SAW reflections. Implementing such method requires that the full solution to SAW propagation in the free and in the layered regions be obtained. Thus, for a free-to-metallized discontinuity, the two SAW phase velocities, the total SAW power flow in the free region and in the layered region, and the electroacoustic fields, must be calculated. In this paper the reflection problem is formulated as an optimization problem subject to the necessary scattering parameter constraints. Numerical experiments are described, and the results of calculations for reflectivity are compared to perturbation approximations, non-perturbation approximations and the available experimental data for the effects of energy storage.
Index Keywords: Acoustic wave reflection; Acoustic wave scattering; Approximation theory; Energy storage; Finite element method; Mathematical models; Perturbation techniques; Piezoelectric materials; Substrates; Waveguides; Metallic finger step discontinuity; Mode matching method (MMM); Reciprocity relation method (RRM); Acoustic surface wave devices

Authors: Waganer Lester M.
Title: Industry cooperates to advance IFE reactor design - the results of prometheus
Affiliations: McDonnell Douglas Aerospace, St. Louis, United States
Authors with affiliations: Waganer, Lester M., McDonnell Douglas Aerospace, St. Louis, United States
Abstract: An industry team, led by McDonnell Douglas Aerospace, has developed two inertial fusion energy reactor plant designs that are predicted to compete favorably with other energy sources. Symmetrically illuminated, direct drive targets were chosen for the KrF laser driver for better gain at a lower cost. The 4 MJ pulse energy to the target is provided by 960 medium-sized (6 kJ) electric discharge lasers. This provides redundancy, system reliability, and stringent illumination requirements. Innovative non-linear optics (NLO) design for beam combination and pulse compression converts the beams into temporally-shaped, high quality beams. The 60 beamlines are shielded to minimize the radiation to the reactor and driver buildings. Long-lived, aluminum-coated, grazing incidence metal mirrors (GIMM), supported by SiC structure, are located within 20 meters of the center of the reactor cavity. These GIMMs and the final focusing mirrors are high-speed, adaptable structures that help steer the beams to the position of the tracked target. The second reactor design uses an innovative, lower-cost, pulsed, single beamline LINAC to deliver heavy ion beams into 14 storage rings. Tailoring of the beam storage, compression, and extraction from the storage rings provides the required temporal and energy shaping. The sets of beams are divided to illuminate the indirectly-driven target from two sides with 7 MJ of energy. The beams are focused to a point on the backside of the blanket where the beams are stripped to a high charge state. This enables formation of a small diameter transport channel through the blanket and across the cavity to the target. The first wall system for both designs uses a SiC structure cooled internally and on the surface with liquid lead. The lead is evaporated and recondensed on the surface to protect and cool the first wall from the 3 to 5 Hz target explosions. The blanket is a Li2O solid breeder, cooled with low pressure helium. The two Prometheus IFE reactor designs show that IFE has the potential to be economically competitive with very attractive safety and environmental features while maintaining a high degree of technical credibility.
Index Keywords: Codes (symbols); Computer simulation; Excimer lasers; Ion beams; Laser beams; Lighting; Linear accelerators; Mirrors; Nonlinear optics; Plant layout; Radiation shielding; Silicon carbide; Balance of plant; Direct drive target; First wall system; Grazing incidence metal mirrors; Heavy ion beam driver; Inertial fusion energy reactor; Fusion reactors

Authors: Schutz Y.
Title: The adjustment of energy expenditure and oxidation to energy intake: The role of carbohydrate and fat balance
Affiliations: Institute of Physiology, Faculty of Medicine, University of Lausanne, CH-1005 Lausanne, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Schutz, Y., Institute of Physiology, Faculty of Medicine, University of Lausanne, CH-1005 Lausanne, Switzerland
Abstract: Evidence is accumulating that total body mass and its relative composition influence the rate of fat utilization in man. This effect can be explained by two factors operating in concert: (i) the effect of the size of the tissue mass and (ii) the nature of the fuel mix oxidized, i.e. the proportion of energy derived from fat vs. carbohydrate. In a cross-sectional study of 307 women with increasing degrees of obesity, we observed that the respiratory quotient (RQ) in post-absorptive conditions became progressively lower with increased body fatness, indicating a shift in substrate utilization. However, the RQ is known to be also influenced by the diet commonly ingested by the subjects. A short-term mixed diet overfeeding in lean and obese women has also demonstrated the high sensitivity of RQ to changes in energy balance. Following a one-day overfeeding (2500 kcal/day in excess of the previous 24 h energy expenditure), the magnitude of increase in RQ was identical in lean and obese subjects and the net efficiency of substrate utilization and storage was not influenced by the state of obesity.

Authors: Kurosaki Yasuo, Satoh Isao, Ohira Akiyoshi
Title: Freezing of supercooled liquid droplets agitated by alternating electric fields
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Heat Transfer Division, (Publication) HTD
Affiliations: Tokyo Inst of Technology, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kurosaki, Yasuo, Tokyo Inst of Technology, Tokyo, Japan; Satoh, Isao, Tokyo Inst of Technology, Tokyo, Japan; Ohira, Akiyoshi, Tokyo Inst of Technology, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: This paper deals with the supercooling phenomena occurring on a pure water droplet, which is agitated by an alternating electric field. The supercooling of liquids is a metastable state of the phase change process, and it reduces the efficiency of thermal storage system which utilizes the latent heat of fusion (or freezing) of a Phase Change Material. The supercooling of the liquid can be reduced by adding some activation factors, such as shock, flow, impurities, and so on, but the mechanisms of freezing of supercooled liquid under the activation conditions have not been made clear. In this study, therefore, effects of agitation due to alternating electric fields on the freezing of supercooled liquid droplet were experimentally investigated. The results clearly showed that the alternating electric fields reduce the degree of supercooling of the droplets, and that the freezing in the agitated droplets is initiated by the phenomena occurring on the droplet ″surface.″ One of the phenomena was considered to be the change of surface energy due to droplet ″deformation″, because the degree of supercooling is affected not only by the existence of agitation but also by the frequency of alternating electric fields.
Index Keywords: Electric field effects; Freezing; Heat transfer; Phase transitions; Activation factors; Alternating electric fields; Metastable state; Supercooled liquid droplets; Liquids

Authors: Butner D.N., Meyer W.H.
Title: Storing data from fusion experiments at the National Storage Laboratory
Affiliations: Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab, Livermore, United States
Authors with affiliations: Butner, D.N., Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab, Livermore, United States; Meyer, W.H., Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab, Livermore, United States
Abstract: The National Storage Laboratory (NSL) at the National Energy Research Supercomputer Center (NERSC) is a prototype facility which is developing data storage and retrieval techniques using hardware that includes a hierarchy of storage devices. The ultimate goal is to store terabytes of data and achieve rapid retrieval times compatible with the type of media where the data is stored. Files stored in the NSL are accessed directly using the Network File System (NFS); in the future, the Andrew File System (AFS) is expected to be used. System level control of files is available using the File Transfer Protocol (FTP) or a set of program-callable routines. We have experimented with storing and retrieving data from fusion experiments at LLNL and at General Atomics in San Diego, California, using computers running UNIX and VMS operating systems. We discuss some issues associated with accessing files whose names are known, but which are not immediately available, the time required for retrieval, and other pertinent parameters.

Authors: Cavaco C., Schurtenberger P.
Title: Viscoelastic lecithin reverse micelles: a simple model system for equilibrium polymers?
Affiliations: ETH Zentrum, Zurich, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Cavaco, C., ETH Zentrum, Zurich, Switzerland; Schurtenberger, P., ETH Zentrum, Zurich, Switzerland
Abstract: We report on a detailed study of lecithin reverse micellar solutions with novel polymer-like properties using dynamic (QLS) and static (SLS) light scattering and rheological measurements. The QLS and SLS experiments show a pronounced water-induced micellar growth from small and almost spherical reverse micelles at ω-0$/ = 2.0 to giant polymer-like reverse micelles at ω-0$/ ≥ 8.0 for lecithin/cyclohexane w/o-microemulsions. An excellent agreement between polymer theory for dilute and semidilute solutions and the light scattering results was found. At volume fractions φ ≪ φ*, where φ* is the overlap threshold, the scattering data is in good agreement with the work-like chain model. At φ > φ* a viscoelastic network is formed, and properties such as the static (ζs) and hydrodynamic (ζh) correlation length or the osmotic compressibility exhibit universal behavior which is in agreement with scaling theory and experimental results from polymer literature. While the dependence of the zero shear viscosity ηs on φ can be explained by the `living polymer' model, the frequency-dependent measurements of storage and loss moduli G' and G″ are in clear disagreement with the single exponential stress relaxation predicted by this model. The frequency-dependent measurements could indicate the formation of crosslinks between the entangled micelles, a hypotheses further supported by the very large values for the `scission energy' found in a preliminary study of the temperature dependence of the micellar size distribution at low values of φ.
Index Keywords: Colloid chemistry; Light scattering; Mathematical models; Physical chemistry; Polymers; Rheology; Correlation strength; Equilibrium polymers; Lecithin reverse micelles; Micellar size distribution; Osmotic compressibility; Scission energy; Sphere to coil transition; Micelles

Authors: Villagra F., Cooke C.B., McDonagh M.J.N.
Title: Metabolic cost and efficiency in two forms of squatting exercise in children and adults
Source title: European Journal of Applied Physiology and Occupational Physiology
Affiliations: School of Sport and Exercise Sciences, University of Birmingham, P.O. Box 363, Birmingham, B15 2TT, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Villagra, F., School of Sport and Exercise Sciences, University of Birmingham, P.O. Box 363, Birmingham, B15 2TT, United Kingdom; Cooke, C.B., School of Sport and Exercise Sciences, University of Birmingham, P.O. Box 363, Birmingham, B15 2TT, United Kingdom; McDonagh, M.J.N., School of Sport and Exercise Sciences, University of Birmingham, P.O. Box 363, Birmingham, B15 2TT, United Kingdom
Abstract: These experiments investigated the oxygen consumption and work efficiency of adults and children performing identical movement patterns. Adult men (mean age 24) and male children (mean age 12) performed squatting exercises with and without a pause at the lowest point of the squat. The former were termed no rebound squats and the latter were termed rebound squats. Subjects performed the exercises without load and with loads equal to 5%, 10% and 15% of body mass. The results showed that the children consumed 10% more oxygen per unit total body mass than the adults. The gross efficiency of the adults was significantly greater than that of the children. Net and apparent efficiencies were not significantly different between the age groups. Gross and net efficiencies declined with load. Rebound squats required 13% less oxygen than no rebound squats. The gross, net and apparent efficiency of rebound squats was significantly greater than that of no rebound squats. It is suggested that the greater gross efficiencies of adults is related to their lower basal metabolic rate and that the greater efficiency of rebound exercise is related to the storage of energy in elastic tissues. © 1993 Springer-Verlag.

Authors: Byrne Eamonn
Title: Alternator control system for the Alcator C-MOD tokamak
Affiliations: Massachusetts Inst of Technology, Cambridge, United States
Authors with affiliations: Byrne, Eamonn, Massachusetts Inst of Technology, Cambridge, United States
Abstract: The Alcator C-MOD tokamak can expend over 500MJ in a single pulse. The primary power source for this experiment is the upgraded Alcator C alternator. Over the years the alternator has undergone several modifications to make it more suited for pulsed operation and in the near future the energy storage of this 40 year old alternator will be increased from 500MJ to 2000MJ with the addition of a 75-ton flywheel. After 25 years of utility service and 8 years of pulsed operation the alternator is still in good condition. However, in order to insure many more years of reliable service every effort must be made to reduce electrical, thermal and mechanical stresses. This means the alternator must be interlocked with the power supplies (7 in all) so that it can protect itself from excessive armature current should any one fail. It also necessitates monitoring many of the critical temperatures, pressures and safety backup systems so that either operator intervention or an orderly shut-down can prevent serious problems. This report will describe how the Alternator control system has been modernized with the addition of a Programmable Logic Controller (PLC) in conjunction with a networked, PC based Supervisory Control And Data Acquisition (SCADA) package. The report will discuss the design, commissioning and operational experiences of the new control system.

Authors: Sager G.T., Wong C.P.C., Kapich D.D., McDonald C.F., Schleicher R.W.
Title: Limitations of power conversion systems under transient loads and impact on the pulsed tokamak power reactor
Affiliations: General Atomics, San Diego, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sager, G.T., General Atomics, San Diego, United States; Wong, C.P.C., General Atomics, San Diego, United States; Kapich, D.D., General Atomics, San Diego, United States; McDonald, C.F., General Atomics, San Diego, United States; Schleicher, R.W., General Atomics, San Diego, United States
Abstract: The impact of cyclic loading of the power conversion system of a helium-cooled, pulsed tokamak power plant is assessed. Design limits of key components of heat transport systems employing Rankine and Brayton thermodynamic cycles are quantified based on experience in gas-cooled fission reactor design and operation. Cyclic loads due to pulsed tokamak operation are estimated. Expected performance of the steam generator is shown to be incompatible with pulsed tokamak operation without load leveling thermal energy storage. The closed cycle gas turbine is evaluated qualitatively based on performance of existing industrial and aeroderivative gas turbines. Advances in key technologies which significantly improve prospects for operation with tokamak fusion plants are reviewed.

Authors: Polizzotto Leonard
Title: Hard-copy imaging options
Source title: Proceedings - Annual Meeting, Microscopy Society of America
Affiliations: Polaroid Corp, Cambridge, United States
Authors with affiliations: Polizzotto, Leonard, Polaroid Corp, Cambridge, United States
Abstract: The use of photographic hard copy in microscopy can be advantageous in imaging microscopic images. A black and white imaging system and color imaging system is developed that are activated by diode lasers. The systems employ the laser power to print directly on new media by making phase transitions within it. Black and white process uses carbon particles and is exposed to high power GaAs solid state laser diodes. The carbon particle size, and laser energy must be controlled to produce a high quality image. The color imaging system is under development at Polaroid, it uses laser energy to activate color dyes within the medium. The applications of these systems is expected to be varied focusing especially in microscopy and scientific imaging.
Index Keywords: Carbon; Costs; Digital image storage; Image quality; Image recording; Laser beams; Microscopic examination; Particles (particulate matter); Phase transitions; Photographic films; Photography; Semiconductor lasers; Digital gray scale rendering technique; Hard copy imaging; Laser imaging system; Permanence; Pixel; Imaging systems

Authors: Yoshino R., Neyatani Y., Hosogane N., Wolfe S.W., Matsukawa M., Ninomiya H.
Title: The softening of current quenches in JT-60U
Affiliations: Naka Fusion Res. Establ., JAERI, Ibaraki, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Yoshino, R., Naka Fusion Res. Establ., JAERI, Ibaraki, Japan; Neyatani, Y., Naka Fusion Res. Establ., JAERI, Ibaraki, Japan; Hosogane, N., Naka Fusion Res. Establ., JAERI, Ibaraki, Japan; Wolfe, S.W., Naka Fusion Res. Establ., JAERI, Ibaraki, Japan; Matsukawa, M., Naka Fusion Res. Establ., JAERI, Ibaraki, Japan; Ninomiya, H., Naka Fusion Res. Establ., JAERI, Ibaraki, Japan
Abstract: Current quenches caused by density limit disruptions have been investigated in JT-60U divertor plasmas in order to develop general methods of reducing the current decay rate and of suppressing the generation of runaway electrons. The reduction of the impurity influxes at an energy quench and the direct neutral beam (NB) heating of the plasma core during a current quench were beneficial for reducing the speed of the current quench. The low stored energy just before the energy quench and the high safety factor at the plasma edge had the advantage of decreasing the impurity influxes at the energy quench. The detached plasma state was useful for degrading the energy confinement for both joule and NB heated plasmas within a short time period. Runaway electrons were not generated at plasma densities of more than 5*1019 m-3 measured just before the energy quench. Fast controlled plasma shutdown with energy quenches but without a current quench was demonstrated successfully from 2 MA to zero, with a value of dIp/dt of -6 MA/s. This shutdown was obtained by lowering the stored energy within a short time period of 20 ms, actively using the detached plasma state produced by intense helium gas puffing.
Index Keywords: Beryllium; Carbon; Electric currents; Electrons; Energy storage; Impurities; Plasma density; Plasma heating; Plasma interactions; Quenching; Current decay rate; Current quenches; Density limit disruption; Fast plasma shutdown; Helium gas puffing; Neutral beam; Plasma currents; Runaway electrons; Softening; Tokamak devices

Authors: Constant W.D., Thibodeaux L.J.
Title: Integrated waste management via the Natural Laws
Affiliations: Hazardous Waste Research Center, Louisiana State University, 3418 CEBA Building, Baton Rouge, 70803, Louisiana, United States
Authors with affiliations: Constant, W.D., Hazardous Waste Research Center, Louisiana State University, 3418 CEBA Building, Baton Rouge, 70803, Louisiana, United States; Thibodeaux, L.J., Hazardous Waste Research Center, Louisiana State University, 3418 CEBA Building, Baton Rouge, 70803, Louisiana, United States
Abstract: The basic tools of engineering, energy and material balances and rate expressions, provide a pathway to apply the Natural Laws of Hazardous Waste for proper waste management. Overall, one must focus on nature's limits, which are discussed, using open minded engineering practices for proper waste management. By expansion of balance concepts beyond 'end-of-pipe' and integrating concepts beyond basic life-cycles, as discussed in this paper, the true impact ofwaste management practices may be established. These cradle-to-grave balances are connected to nature's limits via results of recent work by others on risk assessment. The combination of approaches for evaluating concentration limits of chemicals in the environment allows the facility for an engineering solution for proper waste management. The method is presented by making example comparisons of choices of technology for recycling, storage, and site remediation. © 1993 Science and Technology Letters.
Index Keywords: hazardous waste; methodological approach; natural law; technological choice; waste management

Authors: Blanz M., Rayner T.J., Smith J.A.S.
Title: A fast field-cycling NMR/NQR spectrometer
Affiliations: Dept. of Chem., Kings Coll., London, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Blanz, M., Dept. of Chem., Kings Coll., London, United Kingdom; Rayner, T.J., Dept. of Chem., Kings Coll., London, United Kingdom; Smith, J.A.S., Dept. of Chem., Kings Coll., London, United Kingdom
Abstract: The authors describe a fast field-cycling NMR/NQR spectrometer with a switching time of only 0.7 ms between zero field and maximum field (1 T) which uses a novel air-cored magnet design in which the magnet is cut out of a solid copper tube by means of electric spark erosion. The pitch and cross section of the windings vary and have been optimized for small inhomogeneity of the field (6 parts in 105) and the highest field for the available power (20 kW). The design of the power supply, which uses one capacitor as energy storage, and considerations concerning the safety of the instrument are also described as well as the probe and the more conventional parts of the NMR spectrometer. The authors conclude with examples of the performance and the main applications: field-dependent spin-lattice relaxation time measurement (T1 dispersion), cross relaxation and nuclear quadrupole double resonance (NQDR).
Index Keywords: Air cored magnet; Electric spark erosion; Fast field cycling NMR/NQR spectrometer; Spin lattice relaxation time measurement; Capacitors; Electric power supplies to apparatus; Electric windings; Magnetic resonance spectrometers; Magnets; Performance; Probes; Relaxation processes; Spectrometers

Authors: Tubbing B.J.D.
Title: On the operation cycle of tokamak fusion reactors
Affiliations: JET, Abingdon, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Tubbing, B.J.D., JET, Abingdon, United Kingdom
Abstract: Regimes of tokamak operation more favourable to either inductive or non-inductive current drive are discussed. Steady-state operation, while desirable, appears to be limited to 'advanced' operation regimes. Non-inductive and inductive current drive are shown for 'conventional', high current, and 'advanced', low current, concepts. Thermal energy storage and augmentation systems suitable for pulsed systems are shown, and the issues of stress and thermal cycling are introduced. The advances in physics that may lead to attractive steady-state concepts are shown also to lead to attractive pulsed concepts.

Authors: Asghar M., Zafar Iqbal M., Zafar N.
Title: Characterization of deep levels introduced by alpha radiation in n-type silicon
Affiliations: Semiconductor Physics Laboratory, Department of Physics, Quaid-i-Azam University, Islamabad, Pakistan
Authors with affiliations: Asghar, M., Semiconductor Physics Laboratory, Department of Physics, Quaid-i-Azam University, Islamabad, Pakistan; Zafar Iqbal, M., Semiconductor Physics Laboratory, Department of Physics, Quaid-i-Azam University, Islamabad, Pakistan; Zafar, N., Semiconductor Physics Laboratory, Department of Physics, Quaid-i-Azam University, Islamabad, Pakistan
Abstract: A detailed deep-level transient spectroscopy study of the characteristics of deep-level defects introduced by 5.48 MeV alpha particles in low-doped n-Si is reported. The deep-level characteristics studied include emission rate signatures, activation energies, capture cross sections and their temperature dependence, and defect concentrations and their spatial profiles. At least five deep levels in the upper-half band gap and two levels in the lower-half gap have been observed as a result of irradiation and characterized in detail. A systematic study of their generation rates up to a dose of about 3×10 10 alpha particles/cm2 has been performed providing insights into the dose dependence of their formation mechanisms. Interesting room temperature transformation phenomena have been observed in our deep-level spectra during room temperature storage of the irradiated samples. Extensive isochronal thermal annealing measurements have been carried out to obtain data on the anneal-out characteristics of the radiation-induced deep levels and to identify these with the known defects wherever possible. A number of new annealed-in levels have been observed during this investigation. A detailed comparison with the published results is presented.

Authors: Bélanger R., Paquette A., N'soukpoé-Kossi C.N., Leblanc R.M.
Title: New portable photoacoustic and fluorescence photometer for field measurement of photosynthesis
Affiliations: Centre de Recherche en Photobiophysique, Université du Québec à Trois-Rivières, 3351, Boul. des Forges, Trois-Rivières, Que. G9A 5H7, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Bélanger, R., Centre de Recherche en Photobiophysique, Université du Québec à Trois-Rivières, 3351, Boul. des Forges, Trois-Rivières, Que. G9A 5H7, Canada; Paquette, A., Centre de Recherche en Photobiophysique, Université du Québec à Trois-Rivières, 3351, Boul. des Forges, Trois-Rivières, Que. G9A 5H7, Canada; N'soukpoé-Kossi, C.N., Centre de Recherche en Photobiophysique, Université du Québec à Trois-Rivières, 3351, Boul. des Forges, Trois-Rivières, Que. G9A 5H7, Canada; Leblanc, R.M., Centre de Recherche en Photobiophysique, Université du Québec à Trois-Rivières, 3351, Boul. des Forges, Trois-Rivières, Que. G9A 5H7, Canada
Abstract: A new portable photoacoustic and fluorescence photometer has been built. The instrument is especially made for field measurements but can also be used indoors. This new instrument has many advantages. It can measure the photosynthetic O2 evolution and energy storage, and the vitality index in the same sample. The system is very compact, which makes it easy to transport. A small electrical generator satisfies the 110 V power requirement for field applications. All manipulations are computer controlled including the data acquisition and treatment. The photoacoustic signal-to-noise ratio for carbon black is the same under field conditions as in the laboratory (∼2×104) at 130 Hz. Results obtained on declining sugar maple trees in the field are presented. The combination of photoacoustic and fluorescence measurements in one instrument represents a very powerful tool in photosynthesis research.

Authors: Kielar P., Nyvlt M., Parizek V., Prosser V., Visnovsky S., Krishnan R., Tessier M.
Title: Magneto-optical Kerr spectroscopy in Pt-Ni multilayers
Affiliations: Institute of Physics, Charles University, CS-12116 Prague 2, Czechoslovakia; Laboratoire de Magnetisme et Materiaux Magnetiques, CNRS, F-92195 Meudon, France
Authors with affiliations: Kielar, P., Institute of Physics, Charles University, CS-12116 Prague 2, Czechoslovakia; Nyvlt, M., Institute of Physics, Charles University, CS-12116 Prague 2, Czechoslovakia; Parizek, V., Institute of Physics, Charles University, CS-12116 Prague 2, Czechoslovakia; Prosser, V., Institute of Physics, Charles University, CS-12116 Prague 2, Czechoslovakia; Visnovsky, S., Institute of Physics, Charles University, CS-12116 Prague 2, Czechoslovakia; Krishnan, R., Laboratoire de Magnetisme et Materiaux Magnetiques, CNRS, F-92195 Meudon, France; Tessier, M., Laboratoire de Magnetisme et Materiaux Magnetiques, CNRS, F-92195 Meudon, France
Abstract: The magnetic multilayers consisting of ultrathin 3d-transition metal and Pt or Pd layers are considered for the magneto-optical storage media with increased information density. This paper reports on the magneto-optical polar Kerr rotation and ellipticity spectra in Pt-Ni multilayers at photon energies from 1.5 to 5.2 eV prepared by evaporation onto glass substrates. The thickness of individual Pt layers was kept constant at 2 nm in all samples studied while that of Ni layers varied between 0.9 and 3.9 nm. The prominent feature of the Kerr rotation spectra is a broad negative peak the amplitude of which increases with the individual Ni-layer thickness. The multilayer spectra show less structure than that of pure Ni. Nevertheless the trends in multilayer spectra when the thickness of individual Ni layers changes can be reasonably simulated using the electromagnetic wave theory and permittivity spectra in bulk (or thick film) Ni and Pt.

Authors: Yamamoto S., Zhang X., Kitamura H., Shioya T., Mochizuki T., Sugiyama H., Ando M., Yoda Y., Kikuta S., Takei H.
Title: In-vacuum undulator installed in a 6.5 GeV storage ring for producing brilliant 14.4 keV Mössbauer photons
Affiliations: Photon Factory, National Laboratory for High Energy Physics, Oho, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Department of Applied Physics, Faculty of Engineering, University of Tokyo, Hongo, Bunkyo, Tokyo 113, Japan; Institute for Solid State Physics, University of Tokyo, Roppongi, Minato, Tokyo 106, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Yamamoto, S., Photon Factory, National Laboratory for High Energy Physics, Oho, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Zhang, X., Photon Factory, National Laboratory for High Energy Physics, Oho, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Kitamura, H., Photon Factory, National Laboratory for High Energy Physics, Oho, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Shioya, T., Photon Factory, National Laboratory for High Energy Physics, Oho, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Mochizuki, T., Photon Factory, National Laboratory for High Energy Physics, Oho, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Sugiyama, H., Photon Factory, National Laboratory for High Energy Physics, Oho, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Ando, M., Photon Factory, National Laboratory for High Energy Physics, Oho, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Yoda, Y., Department of Applied Physics, Faculty of Engineering, University of Tokyo, Hongo, Bunkyo, Tokyo 113, Japan; Kikuta, S., Department of Applied Physics, Faculty of Engineering, University of Tokyo, Hongo, Bunkyo, Tokyo 113, Japan; Takei, H., Institute for Solid State Physics, University of Tokyo, Roppongi, Minato, Tokyo 106, Japan
Abstract: Using a newly developed in-vacuum type undulator installed in the 6.5 GeV TRISTAN Accumulation Ring at the National Laboratory for High Energy Physics, a beam comprising of more than 2.4×104 Mössbauer photons/s at 14.4 keV has been achieved from an enriched α-57Fe 2O3 single crystal. The spectrum in terms of brilliance in the region from 5 to 25 keV agrees well with the calculation.

Authors: Wang L., Wilson M.T., Haegel N.M.
Title: Interpretation of photoluminescence excitation spectroscopy of porous Si layers
Affiliations: Department of Materials Science and Engineering, University of California, Los Angeles, Los Angeles, CA 90024, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wang, L., Department of Materials Science and Engineering, University of California, Los Angeles, Los Angeles, CA 90024, United States; Wilson, M.T., Department of Materials Science and Engineering, University of California, Los Angeles, Los Angeles, CA 90024, United States; Haegel, N.M., Department of Materials Science and Engineering, University of California, Los Angeles, Los Angeles, CA 90024, United States
Abstract: Photoluminescence excitation (PLE) measurements allow one to obtain direct information on the absorption processes in porous Si leading to the strong visible luminescence which has recently been reported. This technique does not need a free-standing porous Si sample, but the effect of layer thickness should be included in the interpretation of PLE data. In our PLE spectra, two separate absorption edges are observed and the initial one shifts to higher energies with storage time. The trends of these changes are consistent with the quantum wire model.

Authors: Yang M., Thompson M.
Title: Perturbation of the Electrified Interface and the Response of the Thickness-Shear Mode Acoustic Wave Sensor under Conductive Liquid Loading
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry, University of Toronto, 80 St. George Street, Toronto, Ontario, M5S 1A1, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Yang, M., Department of Chemistry, University of Toronto, 80 St. George Street, Toronto, Ontario, M5S 1A1, Canada; Thompson, M., Department of Chemistry, University of Toronto, 80 St. George Street, Toronto, Ontario, M5S 1A1, Canada
Abstract: The behavior of the thickness-shear mode (TSM) acoustic wave sensor under conductive liquid loading has been examined by acoustic network analysis. The response of the TSM sensor arises from the perturbation of the electrified interface, including the acoustoelectric coupling of the surface potential with ionic species and the formation of the electrical double layer. In dilute solutions, dissipation of acoustic energy resulting from acoustoelectric coupling dominates the complete energy-transfer process, which leads to a rapid decrease of the series resonant frequency and an increase in the motional resistance. In concentrated solutions, energy transfer from the quartz dielectric to the interface becomes more important due to increasing energy storage of the double layer, as shown by the continuing increase of the static capacitance and steady decrease of the parallel resonant frequency. In addition, the overall energetics of the dissipation and transfer processes at the interface are reflected in the measurement of the quality factor. © 1993, American Chemical Society. All rights reserved.

Authors: Belsick J.R., Krupanidhi S.B.
Title: Electron-cyclotron-resonance plasma-assisted radio-frequency-sputtered strontium titanate thin films
Affiliations: Materials Research Laboratory, Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA 16802, United States
Authors with affiliations: Belsick, J.R., Materials Research Laboratory, Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA 16802, United States; Krupanidhi, S.B., Materials Research Laboratory, Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA 16802, United States
Abstract: Strontium titanate thin films were deposited by electron-cyclotron- resonance plasma-assisted radio-frequency magnetron sputtering. Electron-cyclotron-resonance plasma assistance was employed because of its ability to be used as a source of low-energy bombardment by a high density of species that are highly activated. It was found that both the structure and composition improve with the application of microwave plasma during the deposition. Analysis of the capacitance-voltage characteristics of metal-insulator-semiconductor devices revealed that the quality of the film/substrate interface is dependent on the pressure, atmosphere, and temperature of the deposition. Interfacial traps which give rise to charged surface states and silicon oxide formation have detrimental effects on films deposited on bare silicon substrates. Films on platinum-coated silicon substrates show good dielectric properties. The small-signal dielectric constant and dissipation factor at a frequency of 100 kHz were 170 and 0.033, respectively. For a 0.37-μm-thick film a charge storage density of 28 fC/μm2 and a unit area capacitance of 3.7 fF/μm2 were obtained at an applied electric field of 200 kV/cm.

Authors: Carr R., Lidia S.
Title: The adjustable phase planar helical undulator
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory, P.O. Box 4349, bin 69, Stanford, CA  94309, United States; Advanced Light Source and Center for Beam Physics, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, CA  94720, United States
Authors with affiliations: Carr, R., Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory, P.O. Box 4349, bin 69, Stanford, CA  94309, United States; Lidia, S., Advanced Light Source and Center for Beam Physics, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, CA  94720, United States
Abstract: The study of magnetic and biological materials which exhibit magnetic circular dichroism has created a demand for circularly polarized x-rays whose helicity may be switched between the right and left hand senses. At present, circularly polarized x-rays are obtained from storage ring bending magnets by accepting radiation from above and below the axis, but insertion device sources are desired for greater intensity. Planar helical undulators are magnetic insertion devices that generate helical magnetic fields. The charged particle beam executes a helical trajectory in the device, and produces elliptically polarized x-rays. The special case of circularly polarized x-rays is most in demand. We present here the design description of a new type of planar helical undulator, which we are constructing for the SPEAR storage ring at the Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory (SSRL). It comprises four rows of pure permanent magnet blocks, one row in each quadrant about the axis defined by the electron beam. Rows may be translated longitudinally with respect to each other to change the helicity of the magnetic field they create at the position of the beam. They may also be translated longitudinally to vary the energy of the x-rays emitted, unlike designs where this function is performed by varying the gap between the rows. This work includes numerical calculations of the fields, electron trajectories, x-ray spectra, offaxis effects, and mechanical design considerations. © 1993 SPIE. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Biological materials; Circular polarization; Dichroism; Electron beams; Electrons; Luminance; Magnetic anisotropy; Magnetic fields; Permanent magnets; Storage rings; Synchrotron radiation; Wigglers; Circularly polarized x-rays; Electron trajectories; Helical trajectory; Helical undulators; Magnetic circular dichroisms; Mechanical design; Numerical calculation; Permanent magnet blocks; X rays

Authors: Zotti G., Schiavon G., Berlin A., Pagani G.
Title: Electrochemistry of end-capped oligothienyls. New insights into the polymerization mechanism and the charge storage, conduction and capacitive properties of polythiophene
Affiliations: Istituto di Polarografia ed Elettrochimica Preparativa, Consiglio Nazionale delle Ricerche, 35020 Padua, Italy; Dipartimento di Chimica Organica, Industriale dell'Università, Centro CNR, 20133 Milan, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Zotti, G., Istituto di Polarografia ed Elettrochimica Preparativa, Consiglio Nazionale delle Ricerche, 35020 Padua, Italy; Schiavon, G., Istituto di Polarografia ed Elettrochimica Preparativa, Consiglio Nazionale delle Ricerche, 35020 Padua, Italy; Berlin, A., Dipartimento di Chimica Organica, Industriale dell'Università, Centro CNR, 20133 Milan, Italy; Pagani, G., Dipartimento di Chimica Organica, Industriale dell'Università, Centro CNR, 20133 Milan, Italy
Abstract: The kinetics of anodic coupling to dimers of thiophene oligomers (n = 3-5), methyl protected at one α-terminal position, is second order in oligomer concentration and evidences high activation enthalpies and negative activation entropies. Activation free energies are linearly related to the inverse of the oligomer length n (the dimerization rate decreases as n is increased). Thin films of methyl end-capped thiophene oligomers (n = 4, 6, 8 and 10) display reversible oxidations from a single one-electron step (tetramer) to a single two-electron step (octamer and decamer) through two separate one-electron steps (hexamer). ESR indicates strong magnetic dimerization for the one-electron-oxidized hexamer. The close resemblance of the electrochemical and ESR behaviour of the hexamer with that of polythiophene suggests that oxidation of the latter occurs via hexameric spin-dimerized polarons. The conductive and capacitive properties of the end-capped oligomers (n = 6, 8 and 10) were investigated by in situ conductivity and chronopotentiometry. While conductivity of octamer and decamer is displayed at the two-electron (bipolaron) state, the hexamer, insulating at this state, is conducting at the mixed-valence polaron-bipolaron state; capacitive responses are evidenced at the bipolaron state for the octamer and decamer only. The difference of conductive and capacitive behaviour between the hexamer and the higher oligomers is explained by charge localization in hexameric segments. © 1993.
Index Keywords: Aromatic compounds; Capacitance; Chemical activation; Electric conductivity; Electrochemistry; Microwave spectroscopy; Oligomers; Oxidation; Polymerization; Reaction kinetics; Sulfur compounds; Thin films; Electron spin resonance (ESR); End capped oligothienyls; Thiophene oligomers; Conductive materials

Authors: Bashforth M., Koppenjan S.
Title: Ground Penetrating Radar applications for hazardous waste detection
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Special Technologies Laboratory, 5520 Ekwill Street, Santa Barbara, CA  93111, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bashforth, M., Special Technologies Laboratory, 5520 Ekwill Street, Santa Barbara, CA  93111, United States; Koppenjan, S., Special Technologies Laboratory, 5520 Ekwill Street, Santa Barbara, CA  93111, United States
Abstract: The detection of buried hazardous waste storage containers and unexploded ordnance has gained significant interest in the Unites States in the 1990's. The desire to remediate the thousands of sites has become an increasing concern. In many cases, a lack of knowledge regarding the exact location and depth of these objects can greatly escalate the time requirements and costs of a cleanup. Currently, the estimated cost for cleanup is approximately $100 billion with site characterization costs in the range of $25-30 billion. The United States Department of Energy's Special Technologies Laboratory (STL) staff has been involved with subsurface technologies and imaging since 1968. STL has developed a stepped FM-CW Ground Penetrating Radar (GPR) that operates from 196 MHz to 708 MHz. Included is a brief technical description on this fully self-contained unit. Several sample data sets also are described for familiarization with the unique data format of this GPR. Field tests were conducted at old toxic waste disposal sites at Idaho National Engineering Laboratory (INEL) and Los Alamos National Laboratory (LANL) in New Mexico. Soil composition was mainly clay at the INEL location and a rocky limestone/sand mixture at the LANL location. The primary targets of interest were 55 gallon barrels (metallic), but larger concrete storage containers also were examined. Field tests for buried ordnance were conducted at Twenty Nine Palms Magnetic Test Range in California and at Fort Polk in Louisiana. The soil was mainly sand at the Twenty Nine Palms location and a loam composition at the Fort Polk location. The primary targets of interest varied from 60 mm projectiles to 500 pound bombs. Test surveys were conducted to determine the feasibility of GPR under these specific conditions. Detection of both known and unknown targets were made to varying degrees. Estimations of lateral location and depth of these targets were accomplished. This paper describes how ground penetrating radar can be applied to site characterization, its limitations and some case study results. © 1993 SPIE. All rights reserved.

Authors: Rózyczka M., Spruit H.C.
Title: Numerical simulations of shock-driven accretion
Affiliations: Warsaw University Observatory, Al. Ujazdowskie 4, 00-478 Warsaw, Poland; Max-Planck-Inst. F. Astrophysik, Karl-Schwarzschildstrasse 1, W-8046 Garching, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Rózyczka, M., Warsaw University Observatory, Al. Ujazdowskie 4, 00-478 Warsaw, Poland; Spruit, H.C., Max-Planck-Inst. F. Astrophysik, Karl-Schwarzschildstrasse 1, W-8046 Garching, Germany
Abstract: We calculate how accretion in a mass transferring binary system takes place if shock waves are the only means of angular momentum transport and energy dissipation. Cooling by radiation from the disk is included. In the absence of a mass transferring stream, with shocks excited by the tidal force only, the disk quickly settles into a quasi-stationary shock pattern. The presence of a stream impacting on the disk has a profound effect by keeping the flow very nonsteady. From simulations covering several hundred binary orbits, we find the following sequence of events. After an initial transient (which lasts on the order of 20 orbits) most of the mass transferred accumulates in a ring while a lower level accretion takes place from the ring onto the central object. For disk temperatures of a few percent of the local virial temperature, the effective α-viscosity, as measured by the accretion rate, during this phase is of the order 10-3. The size of the disk and the shape of the brightness distribution across it agree well with observations of quiescent CV disks. The rotation profile in the ring approaches a constant angular momentum distribution and then becomes violently unstable by a process observed earlier by Blaes and Hawley. During the instability, the accretion rate onto the central object is enhanced. Storage of mass in a ring alternating with accreting phases due to instability of the torus is expected to take place in general at low disk viscosity, whatever the process responsible for the viscosity. This provides a new mechanism for soft X-ray transients and the superoutburst cycle in cataclysmic variables.
Author Keywords: Accretion, accretion disks; Binaries: close; Methods: numerical; Shock waves; Videotapes

Authors: Müller R.W.
Title: Interaction of the RF system of storage rings and linacs with longitudinal bunch oscillations
Affiliations: GSI, Darmstadt, D-64220, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Müller, R.W., GSI, Darmstadt, D-64220, Germany
Abstract: The RF amplifier feeding a synchrotron, a storage ring or a linac is the source not only of the beam energy, but also of the energy of mismatch oscillations, which lead to emittance growth if they are not damped. The steering mechanism for the energy flow is a first of all particle dynamics and resistivity of the beam environment. Also the properties of the amplifier play a role; the Robinson criterion is an example. Longitudinal mismatch can be excited as well by cavity as by amplifier properties. The mechanism can be very easily demonstrated and understood in case of a storage ring with a one-gap RF cavity. In case of a linac of finite length, the effect is evaluated statistically. Excitation of mismatch occurs already below the «Robinson threshold». At the Robinson threshold it becomes catastrophic: the beam vibrates. We discuss measures to suppress the growth of mismatch. © 1993 Società Italiana di Fisica.
Author Keywords: Amplifiers; Beam dynamics, collective effects and instabilities; PACS 29.27.Bd; PACS 84.30.Le

Authors: Barnard J.J., Bangerter R.O., Deadrick F., Faltens A., Friedman A., Fong C.G., Godlove T.F., Grote D.P., Judd D.L., Griffith L.V., Kirbie H.C., Lee E.P., Neil V.K., Newton M.A., Paul A.C., Reginato L.L., Sharp W.M., Shay H.D., Yu S.S.
Title: Recirculating induction accelerators for heavy-ion fusion
Affiliations: Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, Livermore, 94550, CA, United States; Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, 94720, CA, United States; FM Technologies, Inc., 10529-B Braddock Road, Fairfax, 22302, VA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Barnard, J.J., Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, Livermore, 94550, CA, United States; Bangerter, R.O., Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, 94720, CA, United States; Deadrick, F., Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, Livermore, 94550, CA, United States; Faltens, A., Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, 94720, CA, United States; Friedman, A., Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, Livermore, 94550, CA, United States; Fong, C.G., Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, 94720, CA, United States; Godlove, T.F., FM Technologies, Inc., 10529-B Braddock Road, Fairfax, 22302, VA, United States; Grote, D.P., Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, Livermore, 94550, CA, United States; Judd, D.L., Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, 94720, CA, United States; Griffith, L.V., Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, Livermore, 94550, CA, United States; Kirbie, H.C., Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, Livermore, 94550, CA, United States; Lee, E.P., Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, 94720, CA, United States; Neil, V.K., Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, Livermore, 94550, CA, United States; Newton, M.A., Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, Livermore, 94550, CA, United States; Paul, A.C., Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, Livermore, 94550, CA, United States; Reginato, L.L., Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, 94720, CA, United States; Sharp, W.M., Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, Livermore, 94550, CA, United States; Shay, H.D., Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, Livermore, 94550, CA, United States; Yu, S.S., Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, 94720, CA, United States
Abstract: A two-year study of recirculating induction heavy-ion accelerators (recirculators) as low-cost drivers for inertial-fusion energy power plants has recently been completed. A summary of that study and other recent work on recirculators is presented. © 1993 Società Italiana di Fisica.

Authors: Sagdeev I.R., Drukier A.K., Welsh D.J.
Title: Data acquisition system for dark matter detectors
Affiliations: Department of Physics, University of South Carolina, Columbia, 29208, SC, United States; also, BioTraces Inc., 7986 Lakecrest Dr., Greenbelt, 20770, MD, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sagdeev, I.R., Department of Physics, University of South Carolina, Columbia, 29208, SC, United States; Drukier, A.K., Department of Physics, University of South Carolina, Columbia, 29208, SC, United States, also, BioTraces Inc., 7986 Lakecrest Dr., Greenbelt, 20770, MD, United States; Welsh, D.J., Department of Physics, University of South Carolina, Columbia, 29208, SC, United States
Abstract: Progress in Ge detector technology has resulted in ultralow backgrounds of less than 0.3 counts keV-1 kg-1 d-1 at energies between 5 and 12 keV, and less than 1.0 counts kev-1 kg-1 d-1 for energies between 3 and 5 keV. Coupled with good energy resolution, 0.4 keV FWHM at 10 keV, this allows searches for DM particles with m ≥8 GeV/c2. Electromagnetic interference and acoustical pick-up are the main sources of background in the best Ge detectors. These problems are even more important in cryogenic WIMP detectors under development. A PC-based on line pulse shape analysis system is presented which permits rejection of about 95% percent of the EMI/ acoustical background. The hardware uses a low cost, commercially available digital storage oscilloscope. The software consists of about 20,000 lines of code in Pascal and assembly language. We tested this system using a low radioactive background Ge-system on the Earth's surface. For low energy events (27 keV photons) this system permits improvement in the background from 0.1 cpm to 2 cpd. © 1993 Plenum Publishing Corporation.

Authors: Kröll S., Elman U.
Title: Photon-echo-based logical processing
Affiliations: Department of Physics, Lund Institute of Technology, Box 118, Lund, S-221 00, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Kröll, S., Department of Physics, Lund Institute of Technology, Box 118, Lund, S-221 00, Sweden; Elman, U., Department of Physics, Lund Institute of Technology, Box 118, Lund, S-221 00, Sweden
Abstract: Word-by-word logical and and or operation with photon-echo processing is demonstrated for what is to our knowledge the first time. The photon-echo process can store sequences of optical data before processing. The present logical operations on 8- and 4-bit words are performed by using single-shot frequency-chirped photon echoes. Data rates of approximately 1 MHz, input energies of 1–10 nJ/bit, and output energies in the picojoule-per-bit range are demonstrated by using a transition with a transition probability of only 20 s−1. © 1993 Optical Society of America.
Index Keywords: Logic devices; Optical data processing; Optical data storage; Optical devices; Photons; And and Or processing; Frequency chirped photon echoes; Logical processing; Photon echo based processing; Data processing

Authors: Einfeld D., Plesko M.
Title: A modified QBA optics for low emittance storage rings
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Research Center Rossendorf Inc., P.O. Box 510119, D-01314 Dresden, Germany; Sincrotrone Trieste, Padriciano 99, I-34012 Trieste, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Einfeld, D., Research Center Rossendorf Inc., P.O. Box 510119, D-01314 Dresden, Germany; Plesko, M., Sincrotrone Trieste, Padriciano 99, I-34012 Trieste, Italy
Abstract: A modified quadruple bend achromat (QBA) optics as a lattice for a low emittance storage ring is presented. The novel feature of this lattice is the use of horizontally defocusing bending magnets with different bending angles to keep the radiation integrals low. A realistic storage ring with six achromats, non-dispersive straight sections of 4.6 m each and a total circumference of 124.8 m is studied. At an energy of 2.5 GeV the emittance yields only 20π nm rad. The chromaticities and the sextupole strengths are moderate, the dynamic aperture is large and the momentum acceptance is more than ± 9% relative. A similar 3 GeV storage ring with 12 achromats and a circumference of 300 m yields an emittance of 3π nm rad. Possible applications and extensions of the QBA structure for diffraction limited storage rings are discussed. © 1993.
Index Keywords: Betatrons; Electromagnetic wave diffraction; Electromagnetic wave emission; Magnets; Particle beams; Particle optics; Synchrotron radiation; Bending magnets; Low emittance storage rings; Modified quadruple bend achromat (QBA) optics; Storage rings

Authors: Koca R.W., Hellickson M.L.
Title: Energy savings in evaporator fan-cycled apple storages
Affiliations: Pacific Science and Technology Co., Bend, United States
Authors with affiliations: Koca, R.W., Pacific Science and Technology Co., Bend, United States; Hellickson, M.L., Pacific Science and Technology Co., Bend, United States
Abstract: A two-year experiment was devised to demonstrate electrical energy savings through evaporator fan cycling in part of a full-sized refrigerated controlled atmosphere apple storage facility in Yakima, Washington. Room cooling demand and evaporator fan operation was controlled by the bulk fruit temperature. Evaporator fans remained off 60 to 65% of the time during periods of fan cycling operation. Seasonal average fan energy savings approached 50 to 55% when the product remained in storage for a typical length of time. Less fan motor heat input in the fruit storage space also results in compressor energy savings, Total electrical energy savings were projected to an 18-room fruit storage facility implementing computer-controlled evaporator fan cycling. Projected electrical energy savings achievable through evaporator fan cycling for the state of Washington were made based on reported controlled-atmosphere fruit storage capacity.
Index Keywords: Electrical engineering; Evaporators; Fans; Orchards; Refrigeration; Apple storages; Controlled atmosphere (CA); Energy savings; Fan-cycling; Energy conservation

Authors: Rosenberg Robert R.
Title: Technology to meet the challenge of change
Affiliations: Gas Research Inst, Chicago, United States
Authors with affiliations: Rosenberg, Robert R., Gas Research Inst, Chicago, United States
Abstract: It's something of a paradox, but major challenges for the U.S. natural gas industry in 1993 are coming from opposite directions: deregulation and regulation. On the marketing and sales side of the business, the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission Order 636 will have profound effects on the structure of the U.S. gas industry and the way it does business. On the operations side, numerous environmental regulations will have a marked impact on industry activities. The good news, however, is that technology can help meet the challenge on both fronts. The challenge is for individual companies to adopt the new technologies and apply them to their special circumstances.
Index Keywords: Corrosion prevention; Economic and social effects; Economics; Environmental protection; Gas fuel storage; Laws and legislation; Nondestructive examination; Environmental regulations; Marketing and sales deregulation; Operational sector regulation; Pipeline corrosion prevention; U.S. natural gas industry; Gas industry

Authors: Leong Julie L., Gross Randy S.
Title: Synergistic process for performing instrument setpoint calculations
Affiliations: GE Nuclear Energy
Authors with affiliations: Leong, Julie L., GE Nuclear Energy; Gross, Randy S., GE Nuclear Energy
Abstract: An area of increasing importance in nuclear plant operation is the determination of instrument setpoints. The NRC-accepted setpoint calculational methodology developed by GE Nuclear Energy produces optimum instrument setpoints that are fully supported by a well-documented design basis. Also, tremendous advances have been made in data retrieval and, most recently, data gathering techniques developed by Black & Veatch advance the state-of-the-art considerably. An overview of a synergistic process for performing instrument setpoint calculations, including several of the software tools used, is presented. Data collection, verification, conversion of hard copy data to electronic format through optical scanning, and processing through search tools are explained. A result of the search tool processing is the compilation of the data required to perform the setpoint calculation and the identification of conflicting input data. The storage of the setpoint calculation input data into the database is explained. This article describes both the actual implementation of the setpoint calculation methodology by the program and the techniques used to find the data, store it in a database, and retrieve the input data previously found and stored in the database. The program operates in the Windows environment, interfaces directly with the database, and uses NRC-accepted instrument setpoint calculation methodology.
Index Keywords: Calculations; Computer software; Data processing; Database systems; Information retrieval; Interfaces (computer); Optical scanning; Scanning; Brute force technique; Data collection; Data gathering; Instrument setpoints; Software tools; Synergistic process; Nuclear power plants

Authors: Fortune Lamont
Title: Achieving a robust UPS system
Authors with affiliations: Fortune, Lamont
Abstract: Total power trauma management for critical equipment loads requires more than just installing an uninterruptible power supply (UPS) unit. This article constitutes a full-dress review toward achieving a robust UPS system, including a guiding definition of robustness. Starting with a sound knowledge of UPS basics and moving through accurate sizing, correction application, life cycle cost evaluation and redundancy issues to operation requirements, this article spans the entire range of topics that must be considered. Transitioning into UPS use can happen gradually, especially if starting with a PC or LAN application. However, effective UPS use demands time, capital and concentrated effort to realize the robustness necessary to meet real-life conditions.
Index Keywords: Electric batteries; Electric inverters; Electric rectifiers; Electric switches; Energy storage; Power supply circuits; Redundancy; Standby power systems; Energy storage devices; Life cycle cost evaluation; Power system redundancy; Rapid disconnect devices; Robust UPS systems; Standby power systems; Static switches; Uninterruptible power supplies (UPSs); Electric power supplies to apparatus

Authors: Lynch Terrence
Title: Cold war spins off cleaner power
Authors with affiliations: Lynch, Terrence
Abstract: Technologies long considered impractical for commercial application are emerging from the hot-house atmosphere of cold-war R&D. They could challenge the internal combustion engine in power transmission roles. Critics argue that the military's unique cost/benefit criteria make technology transfer to the civilian market difficult. Yet, promoters of the reborn devices -- solar-powered Stirling engines and flywheel batteries with magnetic bearings -- counter that the military's demand for ruggedness makes the life cycle costs of their products competitive. They add that design-for-manufacturing practices, as well as civilian economies of scale, should quickly bring down the purchase price. Another factor in their favor: the devices offer more environmentally friendly power than conventional IC engines.
Index Keywords: Electric automobiles; Energy storage; Flywheels; Heat engines; Magnetic bearings; Military engineering; Solar power plants; Stirling cycle; Technology transfer; Cold-war R&D; Electric car batteries; Electromechanical batteries; Flywheel batteries; Military technology spinoff; Power-transmission innovations; Solar-powered Stirling engines; Power transmission

Authors: Chen C.S., Sheen J.N.
Title: Cost benefit analysis of a cooling energy storage system
Affiliations: National Sun Yat-Sen Univ, Kaohsiung, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Chen, C.S., National Sun Yat-Sen Univ, Kaohsiung, Taiwan; Sheen, J.N., National Sun Yat-Sen Univ, Kaohsiung, Taiwan
Abstract: In this paper, an A/C system with 1800 RT-HR eutectic salt energy storage tank was built on the campus of National Sun Yat-Sen University (NSYSU) for the demonstration of the cooling energy storage(CES) system. By computer simulation, it is found that 41.1% of the electric peak demand has been reduced and 56% of the energy consumption has been shifted from peak hours to off-peak hours by the CES-system. In this paper, the mathematical model of an eutectic salt CES-system has been developed for the computer simulation of the energy storage system. It is found that the optimal capacity of the storage tank is determined by the off-peak time period and the largest annual electricity charge saving could be obtained by applying the smallest nominal chiller size under the optimal operating conditions. According to the results of the computer simulations and the field test, the payback period of the test system is estimated to be 3.6 years by considering the additional investment cost and the electricity charge saving of the CES-system.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Cooling systems; Economics; Electric load management; Eutectics; Cooling energy storage (CES) systems; Cost benefit analysis; Payback period; Peak demand reduction; Tank priority; Electric energy storage

Authors: Valenti Michael
Title: Taming Hanford's most troublesome nuclear waste tank
Authors with affiliations: Valenti, Michael
Abstract: An industrial mixer pump, augmented by cameras, sensors, and a computerized data acquisition system, is being used to prevent the buildup of hydrogen gases in Tank 101-SY at the Department of Energy's Hanford nuclear waste storage site at Richland, WA. The mixer pump selected for 101-SY is a submersible pump that takes in lighter wastes from the top of the tank and discharges them through the sludge at the bottom. An advantage of this operation is that no new liquid is added to the vessel. A sensitive real-time gas monitoring system was developed to identify the type and concentration of gases being continually released by agitation inside 101-SY. The new system augments existing, but less sensitive, gas chromatographs that still monitor the tank.

Authors: Vaccari A., Saba P., Gessa G.
Title: Potent, extra-channel influence of several calcium-channel modulators on striatal binding of [3H]tyramine
Affiliations: Department of Neuroscience 'B. Brodie', Via Porcell 4, Cagliari, 09124, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Vaccari, A., Department of Neuroscience 'B. Brodie', Via Porcell 4, Cagliari, 09124, Italy; Saba, P., Department of Neuroscience 'B. Brodie', Via Porcell 4, Cagliari, 09124, Italy; Gessa, G., Department of Neuroscience 'B. Brodie', Via Porcell 4, Cagliari, 09124, Italy
Abstract: A number of Ca2+-, K+-, and Na+-channel modulators has been tested with respect to their effects on [3H]tyramine (TY) binding, as a putative marker for the vesicular dopamine (DA) transporter in striatal membrane preparations containing vesicle ghosts. Among organic Ca2+-channel modulators, the diphenylalkylamines tested consistently inhibited TY binding: the order of potency was prenylamine>lidoflazine>flunarizine>cinnarizine, with Ki values of 0.1, 0.2, 0.5 and 1.2 μM, respectively. Low (up to 100 nM) concentrations of prenylamine did competitively inhibit TY binding, and higher concentrations provoked a mixed-type inhibition. Furthermore, LIGAND-analysis of competition curves revealed a high- and a low-affinity binding site for prenylamine and flunarizine. The TY binding process was also sensitive to selected K+- and Na+-channel modulators. Since several Ca2+-antagonists are known to affect H+-ATPase and the bioenergetics of catecholamine storage vesicles in chromaffin granules, thus affecting monoamine storage, the energy requirements for the formation of the TY/carrier complex were here assessed, assuming similarity between chromaffin granules and synaptic vesicles. TY binding, though not reflecting endovesicle-sequestered TY, was indeed strongly sensitive (with Ki coefficients in the fM or low nM range) to the dissipation of the vesicular transmembrane proton concentration (Δ pH), electrical (Δ Ψ), and proton electrochemical (Δ μH+) gradients, provoked by a number of specifically targeted agents. It is concluded that Ca2+-channel agents of the diphenylalkylamine group may directly affect striatal TY binding due to an extrachannel-regulated competition with TY for the vesicular carrier of DA, as well indirectly, by disruption of the transmembrane energization of the reserpine-sensitive carrier. © 1993 Plenum Publishing Corporation.
Author Keywords: [3H]Tyramine binding; Ca2+-channel modulators; dopamine carrier; K+-channel antagonists; Na+-channel agents; vesicle membrane energetics; vesicular markers
