Authors: Ciureanu M., Ryan D.H., Ström-Olsen J.O., Trudeau M.L.
Title: Electrochemical Studies of Hydrogen Storage in Amorphous Ni64 Zr36 Alloy
Affiliations: Centre for the Physics of Materials, McGill University, Montreal, Quebec, Canada; Hydro Quebec Research Institute, Varennes, Quebec, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Ciureanu, M., Centre for the Physics of Materials, McGill University, Montreal, Quebec, Canada; Ryan, D.H., Centre for the Physics of Materials, McGill University, Montreal, Quebec, Canada; Ström-Olsen, J.O., Centre for the Physics of Materials, McGill University, Montreal, Quebec, Canada; Trudeau, M.L., Hydro Quebec Research Institute, Varennes, Quebec, Canada
Abstract: The characteristic features of the electrochemical behavior of the amorphous Ni64Zr36 alloy in alkaline media have been investigated. Changesoccurring in both the physical state and the composition of the surface layer during chemical etching and electrochemical activation were studied by scanning electron microscopy, Auger electron spectroscopy, x-ray diffraction, and cyclic voltammetry. Severalnew anodic maxima were observed in cyclic voltammograms after long-term cycling and were attributed to the oxidation of hydrogen atoms stored in low-energy fourfold coordinated interstitial sites, Zr4 and NiZr3. The kinetics of the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) on the alloy under investigation was studied in terms of the cathodic polarization curves. The Tafel plots contain two different ranges: (i) a low-overpotential range, in which the slope of the linear η vs. log i is characteristic for charge transfer controlled processes; (ii) a high-overvoltage range, in which a combined mechanism, charge transfer and hydrogen diffusion into the bulk, is operative. To get information about the parameters influencing the hydrogen charging and discharging processes, chronopotentiometric experiments were performed. The changes of anodic overvoltage with time during constant current discharge were used to determine the electrochemical parameters io and p, as well as the diffusion coefficients (D) of the H atoms in the bulk of the alloy. Both io and D increased with hydrogen concentration, an observation which is consistent with a broad distribution of interstitial sites in the amorphous alloy. © 1993, The Electrochemical Society, Inc. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: amorphous magnetic materials; amorphous state; electrochemical analysis; nickel alloys; storage

Authors: Komarek P.
Title: Superconductivity for energy technology
Affiliations: Institute for Technical Physics, Karlsruhe Nuclear Research Centre (KfK), Germany
Authors with affiliations: Komarek, P., Institute for Technical Physics, Karlsruhe Nuclear Research Centre (KfK), Germany
Abstract: Investigations of applications of the attractive properties of superconductors in energy technology started in principle with the discovery of practical conductors about 25 years ago. The Karlsruhe Nuclear Research Centre has been active in parts of this area for about 15 years. As this paper describes, the potential applicability covers most of the well known fields of electrical power engineering, such as motors, power transmission cables and transformers, and novel devices such as superconducting energy storage systems and fault current limiters also become feasible. However, the complexity of superconductivity technology sets technical and economic limits to the use of this technology in all these areas. A major component is the superconductor itself, which has to meet stringent operating conditions. There is no doubt that the potential for superconductor applications in energy technology will greatly increase when, besides the already well developed classical superconductors with liquid helium cooling, high temperature superconductors for use at liquid nitrogen temperature become available with the necessary properties for these applications. As shown, for some applications, power transmission cables for example, only with cooling temperatures ≥77 K will the use of superconductors have the possibility of becoming economic. Another critical design area is high voltage components in cryogenic environments, where specific techniques are needed. In spite of advanced experimental results for several applications such as generators and energy storage systems, commercial implementation will take another decade at least. © 1993 The Institute of Materials.

Authors: Thomson B.J.
Title: Explosives and energetic chemicals: Problems, uses, hazards and control
Affiliations: Explosion and Flame Laboratory, Health and Safety Executive, Harpur Hill, Buxton, Buxton, Derby, SK17 9JN, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Thomson, B.J., Explosion and Flame Laboratory, Health and Safety Executive, Harpur Hill, Buxton, Buxton, Derby, SK17 9JN, United Kingdom
Abstract: Energy releasing (energetic) materials find many uses in society today and range from those that are very fast reacting, such as explosives, to more slowly reacting ones, such as sponge blowing agents used to foam plastics. Their energetic (exothermic) nature means that the hazards involved must be determined for the different circumstances that apply in their manufacture, transport, storage and use. This examines what constitutes an energetic material, accidents that have occurred involving such chemicals, systems to establish and control the hazards encountered and some areas of research being undertaken to resolve problems that still exist. © 1993 The Institute of Materials. All Rights Reserved.

Authors: Tang Q., McCarthy O.J., Munro P.A.
Title: Oscillatory rheological study of the gelation mechanism of whey protein concentrate solutions: Effects of physicochemical variables on gel formation
Affiliations: Department of Food Technology, Massey University, Palmerston North, New Zealand
Authors with affiliations: Tang, Q., Department of Food Technology, Massey University, Palmerston North, New Zealand; McCarthy, O.J., Department of Food Technology, Massey University, Palmerston North, New Zealand; Munro, P.A., Department of Food Technology, Massey University, Palmerston North, New Zealand
Abstract: The thermal gelation of a commercially available whey protein concentrate was studied by oscillatory rheometry using a Bohlin rheometer. Gelation time increased with decreasing protein concentration with a critical protein concentration (at infinite gelation time) of 6.6%. The effect of temperature in the range 65–90 °C on gelation time was described by an Arrhenius equation with an activation energy of 154kJ/mol. Gelation time was a minimum at pH 4–6, the isoelectric region of the whey proteins. Small additions of NaCl or CaCl2 dramatically decreased gelation time. Higher protein concentrations always produced higher storage modulus (G‘) values after any heating time. Loss modulus (G“) v. time curves exhibited maxima at relatively short times for protein concentrations of 30 and 35 %. G’ values for 10% protein concentration increased with temperature for heating times up to 59•5 min. G’ values at 59.5 min for 25% protein concentration were higher at 78 °C than at either 85 or 90 °C. The results are discussed in terms of current theories for biopolymer gelation. © 1993, Proprietors of Journal of Dairy Research. All rights reserved.

Authors: Chandra D., Day C.S., Barrett C.S.
Title: Low- and high-temperature structures of neopentylglycol plastic crystal
Affiliations: Department of Chemical and Metallurgical Engineering, Mackay School of Mines, University of Nevada, Reno, Nevada 89557, United States; Crystalytics Company, 82286, Lincoln, Nebraska 68501, United States; Department of Engineering, University of Denver, Denver, Colorado 80210, United States
Authors with affiliations: Chandra, D., Department of Chemical and Metallurgical Engineering, Mackay School of Mines, University of Nevada, Reno, Nevada 89557, United States; Day, C.S., Crystalytics Company, 82286, Lincoln, Nebraska 68501, United States; Barrett, C.S., Department of Engineering, University of Denver, Denver, Colorado 80210, United States
Abstract: Plastic crystals, such as neopentylglycol, 2, 2-dimethyl-l,3-propanediol, that exhibit polymorphic behavior are emerging materials for thermal energy storage. The energy is stored isothermally in the y phase, FCC, during solid-state phase transformations. This y phase of NPG has been determined as an orientational disordered phase. The low temperature a phase structure, which is of great significance in the evaluation of lattice expansions and other parameters, was first determined in 1961. However, the reported unit cell dimensions and the intensities of the reflections led to erroneous indexing of the powder patterns in binary systems. The a phase structure is redetermined here as monoclinic, M= 104.15 amu, space group P2/n (an alternate setting of P21/c— C2h, space group No. 14) a= 5.979(1) Å, b= 10.876(2)Å, c=10.099(2)Å, β=99.78(1)°, F=647.2(2)Å3at 20°(± 1)C, 2x= 1.069 g cm s 3 for Z=4. In this paper the redetermined structure of the a phase of NPG is presented in projections of the atomic positions, in tables, and in calculated powder pattern and these results are compared with those reported by others. The powder patterns obtained from the Bragg—Brentano diffractometer are compared with our calculated pattern from the single crystal data. The structural parameters of the high temperature phase of NPG as determined by a Guinier diffraction system are also reported. © 1993, Cambridge University Press. All rights reserved.

Authors: Ling S.-K.R., Steinberg L., Jaluria Y.
Title: MSG: A computer system for automated modeling of heat transfer
Source title: Artificial Intelligence for Engineering, Design, Analysis and Manufacturing
Affiliations: Department of Computer Science, United States; Department of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, Rutgers University, New Brunswick, NJ 08903, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ling, S.-K.R., Department of Computer Science, United States; Steinberg, L., Department of Computer Science, United States; Jaluria, Y., Department of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, Rutgers University, New Brunswick, NJ 08903, United States
Abstract: The task of modeling, i.e., of creating a set of equations that can be used to predict the behavior of a physical object, is a key step in engineering analysis. This paper describes a computer system, MSG, for generating mathematical models to analyze physical systems involving heat transfer behavior. MSG is motivated by the need for modeling in an automated design process. The models are sets of equations which may include algebraic equations, ordinary differential equations and partial differential equations. MSG uses the strong domain theory to guide model construction in three sequential tasks: identify regions of interests on an object, determine relevant heat transfer and energy storage processes, and transform these processes into equations. The decisions in these tasks are guided by estimates of variation in temperature and material property, and the relative strengths of heat transfer processes. © 1993, Cambridge University Press. All rights reserved.

Authors: Tahat M.A., Babus'Haq R.F., O'Callaghan P.W.
Title: Thermal energy storage
Affiliations: Department of Applied Energy, Cranfield Institute of Technology, Bedford MK4 OAL, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Tahat, M.A., Department of Applied Energy, Cranfield Institute of Technology, Bedford MK4 OAL, United Kingdom; Babus'Haq, R.F., Department of Applied Energy, Cranfield Institute of Technology, Bedford MK4 OAL, United Kingdom; O'Callaghan, P.W., Department of Applied Energy, Cranfield Institute of Technology, Bedford MK4 OAL, United Kingdom
Abstract: Energy storage not only plays an important role in conserving energy but also improves the performance and reliability of a wide range of energy systems. It can be expected to continue as a cost-saving technology as utility companies struggle to meet consumer energy needs without constructing new power plants. An up-to-date comprehensive overview of the role of thermal energy storage is presented in the context of achieving a more rational use of energy and in particular its contribution towards satisfying the future requirement. A summary of thermal energy storage theory is given and its concepts are discussed. The energy density and the economic viability for several storage media are also presented. © 1993, Sage Publications. All rights reserved.

Authors: Golembiewski J., Bourtsos N.
Title: Cardioplegia Solution
Affiliations: Operating Room Pharmacy Satellite, Department of Pharmacy, Bergan Mercy Medical Center, Omaha, NE, United States
Authors with affiliations: Golembiewski, J., Operating Room Pharmacy Satellite, Department of Pharmacy, Bergan Mercy Medical Center, Omaha, NE, United States; Bourtsos, N., Operating Room Pharmacy Satellite, Department of Pharmacy, Bergan Mercy Medical Center, Omaha, NE, United States
Abstract: The mechanisms of the metabolic and ultrastructural changes that occur as a result of myocardial ischemia during cross-clamping of the aorta and the secondary injury that can occur during reperfusion after removal of the cross-clamp are important determinants of the composition and method of administration of cardioplegia solution (CS). Traditionally, basic principles of myocardial protection included hypothermia, potassium-induced diastolic cardiac arrest, buffering, membrane stabilization, and control of osmolarity and osmotic pressure. As the mechanisms of myocardial ischemia and reperfusion are further shown, methods of providing myocardial protection continue to expand. Current trends favor blood cardioplegia administration via a more complex approach to protect as much of the myocardium as possible; exogenous metabolic substrate enhancement in the presence of oxygen to allow aerobic metabolism to continue, with an end result of additional available myocardial energy; and warm (37°C) blood CS to optimize the metabolic rate for cellular repair. Thus, today the cardiothoracic surgeon can offer patients with energy-depleted hearts and those requiring more complex surgery improved myocardial protection with active myocardial resuscitation before and after the aortic cross-clamp is placed and removed. To this end, the pharmacist, ideally an operating room (OR) pharmacist, has a vital role in ensuring proper preparation, composition, storage, and quality control/assurance of CS. The basic principles of myocardial ischemic and reperfusion injury and how they relate to myocardial protection, CS composition, and methods of administration are described. By understanding these principles, in addition to surgeon and institution-specific factors, the pharmacist can build the foundation needed to maximize the role of pharmacy in ensuring optimal myocardial protection during open-heart surgery. © 1993, SAGE Publications. All rights reserved.

Authors: Jortner J., Bixon M.
Title: Electron transfer in supermolecules
Source title: Molecular Crystals and Liquid Crystals Science and Technology. Section A. Molecular Crystals and Liquid Crystals
Affiliations: School of Chemistry, Tel Aviv University Ramat Aviv, Tel-Aviv 69978, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Jortner, J., School of Chemistry, Tel Aviv University Ramat Aviv, Tel-Aviv 69978, Israel; Bixon, M., School of Chemistry, Tel Aviv University Ramat Aviv, Tel-Aviv 69978, Israel
Abstract: Energy storage and disposal by electron transfer in molecular and supermolecular systems may provide a conceptual and technical basis for the construction of molecular electronic devices, e.g., molecular wires and switches. We consider structural, intramolecular, medium energetic and medium dynamic control of electron transfer in synthetic and neutral supermolecules. Optimization principles are formulated for ultrafast, highly efficient and stable charge separation. © 1993, Taylor & Francis Group, LLC. All rights reserved.

Authors: Haarer D.
Title: Hole-burning memories: A frequency selective mesoscopic approach to molecular storage
Source title: Molecular Crystals and Liquid Crystals Science and Technology. Section A. Molecular Crystals and Liquid Crystals
Affiliations: Physics Institute, University of Bayreuth and BIMF, P.O. Box 101251, 8580, Bayreuth, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Haarer, D., Physics Institute, University of Bayreuth and BIMF, P.O. Box 101251, 8580, Bayreuth, Germany
Abstract: Due to the long wavelength of visible light, most straight forward optical methods, like absorption or emission spectroscopy, are not well suited for spectroscopy on a 'molecular level'. The hole-burning method is a selective spectroscopy scheme based on energy selection. This method yields, at low temperatures, very high spectral resolution and, hence, can be used to investigate molecular environments and molecular potentials. With the simultaneous application of external fields the hole-burning technique is a true two-dimensional spectroscopy method. Hole-burning can also be used for enhancing the schemes of presently used optical memories by many orders of magnitude. In this context new developments based on the use of semiconductor laser diodes are reported. The question of the requirement of low temperatures is also critically reviewed and, finally, a comparison between mesoscopic storage schemes and molecular schemes is given. © 1993, Taylor & Francis Group, LLC. All rights reserved.

Authors: Bryant C., Miller A., Bakaysa D.L., Brems D.N.
Title: Acid stabilization of insulin
Affiliations: Lilly Research Labs, Eli Lilly and Company, Indianapolis, IN, 46285, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bryant, C., Lilly Research Labs, Eli Lilly and Company, Indianapolis, IN, 46285, United States; Miller, A., Lilly Research Labs, Eli Lilly and Company, Indianapolis, IN, 46285, United States; Bakaysa, D.L., Lilly Research Labs, Eli Lilly and Company, Indianapolis, IN, 46285, United States; Brems, D.N., Lilly Research Labs, Eli Lilly and Company, Indianapolis, IN, 46285, United States
Abstract: The effect of pH on the conformational stability of insulin was studied. Surpnslngly, the Gibbs free energy of unfolding increased 40% by acidification. pH titration of the conformational stability of insulin is described by a transition involving a Single proton With an apparent pKa of 7.0. The acid stabilization of insulin's conformation was attributed to the protonation of HB5 as determined by selective amino acid alteration, and enthalpies of ionization. Further acidification (at least to pH 2) does not decrease the free energy of unfolding. We propose that the acid stabilization of ins∼lin is physiologically important in maintaining insulin stability in the acid environment of the secretory/storage granules of the B-cell of the pancreatic islets of Langerhans. © 1993 Oxford University Press.

Authors: De Lucia M., Bronconi R., Carnevale E.
Title: Performance and economic enhancement of cogeneration gas turbines through compressor inlet air cooling
Source title: ASME 1993 International Gas Turbine and Aeroengine Congress and Exposition, GT 1993
Affiliations: Dipartimento di Energetica, Università di Firenze, Firenze, Italy
Authors with affiliations: De Lucia, M., Dipartimento di Energetica, Università di Firenze, Firenze, Italy; Bronconi, R., Dipartimento di Energetica, Università di Firenze, Firenze, Italy; Carnevale, E., Dipartimento di Energetica, Università di Firenze, Firenze, Italy
Abstract: Gas turbine air cooling systems serve to raise performance to peak power levels during the hot months when high atmospheric temperatures cause reductions in net power output. This work describes the technical and economic advantages of providing a compressor inlet air cooling system to increase the gas turbine's power rating and reduce its heat rate. The pros and cons of state-of-the-art cooling technologies, i.e., absorption and compression refrigeration, with and without thermal energy storage, were examined in order to select the most suitable cooling solution. Heavy-duty gas turbine cogeneration systems with and without absorption units were modeled, as well as various industrial sectors, i.e., paper and pulp, pharmaceuticals, food processing, textiles, tanning, and building materials. The ambient temperature variations were modeled so the effects of climate could be accounted for in the simulation. The results validated the advantages of gas turbine cogeneration with absorption air cooling as compared to other systems without air cooling. © 1993 by ASME.

Authors: Goulon J., Brookes N.B., Vettier C.
Title: Sensitivity of spectrometers and optical components to floor instability and vibrations
Affiliations: European Synchrotron Radiation Facility, BJ. 220, Grenoble, F-38043, France
Authors with affiliations: Goulon, J., European Synchrotron Radiation Facility, BJ. 220, Grenoble, F-38043, France; Brookes, N.B., European Synchrotron Radiation Facility, BJ. 220, Grenoble, F-38043, France; Vettier, C., European Synchrotron Radiation Facility, BJ. 220, Grenoble, F-38043, France
Abstract: For the third generation of low emittance storage rings and high brilliance sources, one should not underestimate the troubles that can be caused by short (or long) term instrumental instabilities, mechanical resonances, ground vibrations and local excitation of unwanted noise of any type. It is shown that the "Dragon " type spectrometer which we plan to install on the low energy side-branch of the ESRF BL#6 is critically sensitive to differential and angular instabilities which may cause a significant deterioration of the energy resolution unless the rms amplitude of vertical displacements is kept below: o$z (rms) < 0.12S im. Intensity fluctuations could also prevent us from detecting minute circular dichroism effects. In this perspective, we comment briefly the results of low frequency vibration test measurements carried out on repaired slabs in the ESRF Experimental Hall. Although the site stability is not quite as good as expected on the basis of the most optimistic reports, vibration noise should not have any dramatic consequence on the operation of the Spectroscopy BL#6, unless the slab repair deteriorates with time. © 1993 The Japan Society of Applied Physics.

Authors: Peczak P., Luton M.J.
Title: The effect of nucleation models on dynamic recrystallization: I. Homogeneous stored energy distribution
Source title: Philosophical Magazine B: Physics of Condensed Matter; Statistical Mechanics, Electronic, Optical and Magnetic Properties
Affiliations: Exxon Research and Engineering Company, Corporate Research Laboratories, Annandale, NJ, 08801-0998, United States
Authors with affiliations: Peczak, P., Exxon Research and Engineering Company, Corporate Research Laboratories, Annandale, NJ, 08801-0998, United States; Luton, M.J., Exxon Research and Engineering Company, Corporate Research Laboratories, Annandale, NJ, 08801-0998, United States
Abstract: A Monte Carlo simulation technique, in which the microstructure is mapped onto a discrete, two-dimensional lattice with the use of the g-state Potts model, is applied to the problem of dynamic recrystallization in a polycrystalline matrix. The response of the material to hot deformation is simulated by adding recrystallization nuclei and stored energy continuously with time. The simulations use an energy storage rate schedule that models both work hardening and dynamic recovery of metals by way of a parabolic work hardening law. Recrystallization nuclei, having zero stored energy, were added at a rate which is related to the level of work hardening. Departing from a previously applied scheme, the nucleation rate is chosen to be proportional to the strain rate. Also considered is a more intuitive, local model in which the creation of a nucleus occurs with a probability proportional to exp(−δE), where δE is the energy change associated with the introduction of an embryo into the matrix. The evolution of the stress and the mean grain size is similar to those obtained with use of the constant nucleation rate. It was found, however, that the relations between steady-state parameters are different from the results obtained earlier but are more consistent with the experimental literature. Careful numerical analysis of data obtained for the exponential nucleation model yield new power-law relations between steady-state parameters and nucleation attempt rate. The kinetics of dynamic recrystallization are analysed with use of the Johnson-Mehl-Avrami-Kolmogorov (JMAK) equation which is shown to be sensitive to the rate of deformation. Higher than expected values of the JMAK kinetic exponent were obtained that are attributed to the use of the parabolic work hardening model in the simulations. © 1993 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Authors: Lippert J.R.
Title: Battery power supply for the navy electromagnetic torpedo launcher
Affiliations: Computer Science and Applications, Inc., Shalimar, FL 32579, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lippert, J.R., Computer Science and Applications, Inc., Shalimar, FL 32579, United States
Abstract: Chemical energy storage in the form of batteries is now being considered to satisfy the high power and high energy requirements for electromagnetic launchers. This paper will describe the design concept and rationale for one such battery power supply delivered to the Naval Underwater Systems Center, Newport, RI, for electromagnetic launcher laboratory research. This power supply takes advantage of new developments in lead/acid battery manufacturing to utilize a quasi-hi-polar battery called the PULSAR by GNB. The inherent advantages of the PULSAR technology greatly increase the power and energy density over conventional lead/acid design, allowing total volume (always a critical factor for Naval applications) to be reduced. These features also make the battery well suited for high power pulse mode operation as required by the EM launchers. Since the PULSAR is mass produced for commercial applications, its cost and short lead time advantage overwhelms other custom battery and potential non-battery power source options. The feasibility of shipboard installation will be discussed. © 1993 IEEE

Authors: Unshaw J.L., Zowarka R.C., Aanstoos T.A.
Title: Design of a dissipation circuit for a 560 MJ inductive storage supply
Affiliations: The University of Texas at Austin, Center for Electromechanics, 10100 Burnet Rd., Bldg., 133 Austin, TX 78712, United States
Authors with affiliations: Unshaw, J.L., The University of Texas at Austin, Center for Electromechanics, 10100 Burnet Rd., Bldg., 133 Austin, TX 78712, United States; Zowarka, R.C., The University of Texas at Austin, Center for Electromechanics, 10100 Burnet Rd., Bldg., 133 Austin, TX 78712, United States; Aanstoos, T.A., The University of Texas at Austin, Center for Electromechanics, 10100 Burnet Rd., Bldg., 133 Austin, TX 78712, United States
Abstract: This paper reports on the design, and component testing of a dissipation circuit for a 560 MJ inductive storage supply. This storage supply is charged by a 5 MA battery power supply where both are part of a large pulse power test facility being upgraded under a U.S. Air Force contract This battery upgraded supply (BUS) requires energy management at either the end of a test or as a means of aborting a test in the event of a fault. Energy management is accomplished by diverting the supply current into large dump resistors capable of dissipating the inductively stored energy through resistive heating. After the most of the energy has been resistively dissipated, a low residual current exists in the resistor circuit due to the applied battery voltage of the battery power supply. This current is interrupted with final interrupter switches in series with the dump resistors. Both the divert and final interrupt switches are explosive opening switches. Details of BUS (a 5 MA battery power supply charging of pair of inductors to 560 MJ) are presented in companion papers. This paper reports on the details of the energy management components which include the high current divert switches, the energy dump resistors, the final interrupt switches, the switch containment vessels, and the robust buswork and clamping required to construct the high energy circuits. Special design features of these components include low cost extruded aluminum switch elements for use in both the divert and final interrupt positions that have the designed in capability to open thermally in the event of an explosive switch failure. Other special design features include nonferrous containment vessels and compact stainless steel dump resistors whose geometry provides the required circuit resistance and also helps control the separation forces acting on the resistor plates. © 1993 IEEE

Authors: Ford R.D., Johnson N.E., Christopher F., Klug R., Matyac M., Lucas N., Barber J.
Title: Evolutionary development of the multi-function “RAP” Explosive operated switching cartridge
Affiliations: Science Applications International Corporation, Shalimar, Florida 32579, United States; USAF Wright Laboratory Armament Directorate, Eglin AFB, Florida 32542, United States; IAP Research, Inc., 2673 Culver Ave., Dayton, Ohio 45429, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ford, R.D., Science Applications International Corporation, Shalimar, Florida 32579, United States; Johnson, N.E., Science Applications International Corporation, Shalimar, Florida 32579, United States; Christopher, F., USAF Wright Laboratory Armament Directorate, Eglin AFB, Florida 32542, United States; Klug, R., USAF Wright Laboratory Armament Directorate, Eglin AFB, Florida 32542, United States; Matyac, M., USAF Wright Laboratory Armament Directorate, Eglin AFB, Florida 32542, United States; Lucas, N., USAF Wright Laboratory Armament Directorate, Eglin AFB, Florida 32542, United States; Barber, J., IAP Research, Inc., 2673 Culver Ave., Dayton, Ohio 45429, United States
Abstract: The Rapidly Actuating Pyrotechnic (RAP) Switch was conceived and developed as an explosive operated switching array utilizing replaceable cartridges to switch very high energy (tens of megajoules) inductive storage power supplies for railgun research. The first generation switch was designed to commutate 1.5 MA peak current into a 50 nH railgun breech. By the time the switch cartridge became operational, the state of the art in guns required a switch capable of commutating 2 MA into a 200 nH breech. Novel switch design requirements include the need for a cartridge array where each cartridge presents an almost identically low inductance between the switch and load, each cartridge to contain both closing and opening circuit functions with individual firing controls, explosive debris to be self contained within the cartridge, and cartridges to be quickly reloaded into the array. Operating experience at up to 2.2 MA current has expanded the design data base to assist in scaling results from low energy experiments. This paper describes design evolution and switch performance results. © 1993 IEEE

Authors: Miao Zhenjiang, Yuan Baozong
Title: New analytical method for AM neural networks and its application to pattern recognition
Source title: 1993 IEEE International Conference on Neural Networks
Affiliations: Northern Jiaotong Univ, Beijing, China
Authors with affiliations: Miao, Zhenjiang, Northern Jiaotong Univ, Beijing, China; Yuan, Baozong, Northern Jiaotong Univ, Beijing, China
Abstract: In this paper, the problems of asymptotic stability and associative memory for Hopfield type neural networks are analyzed. First, we introduce a new kind of energy function which is different from Hopfield's definition. Then, the networks' asymptotic stability is analyzed by means of the new energy function. Two theorems are obtained. By comparing these two theorems with the existing conclusions, it can be found that in some cases they are consistent and in other cases they are not equivalent but complement each other. Finally, by using these theorems, we design one associative memory neural network and demonstrate their applications to pattern recognition.

Authors: Schlechtriemen U.F.T., Heinrichs W., Puente-Gonzalez I., Halmagyi M.
Title: The Measurement of Enzyme Activities in the Resting Human Polymorphonuclear Leukocyte — Critical Estimate of a Method
Affiliations: Klinik für Anäthesiologie der Johannes Gutenberg-Universität Mainz, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Schlechtriemen, U.F.T., Klinik für Anäthesiologie der Johannes Gutenberg-Universität Mainz, Germany; Heinrichs, W., Klinik für Anäthesiologie der Johannes Gutenberg-Universität Mainz, Germany; Puente-Gonzalez, I., Klinik für Anäthesiologie der Johannes Gutenberg-Universität Mainz, Germany; Halmagyi, M., Klinik für Anäthesiologie der Johannes Gutenberg-Universität Mainz, Germany
Abstract: As a system for study, the isolated human polymorphonuclear leukocyte combines the advantages of a quasi-non-invasive preparation with a nearly complete complement of enzymes of carbohydrate and energy metabolism. However, small sample volumes and, in some cases, very low enzyme activities make high demands on sample processing, storage, and performance of continuous measurements, if the enzyme activities are to be measured with acceptable reproducibility. In the presented study several aspects of homogenization, storage, and continuous measurement were scrutinized, to identify critical steps and consider ways of optimizing the method. Polymorphonuclear leukocytes were separated from the blood of healthy subjects by sedimentation and density gradient centrifugation. After ultrasonic homogenization, 13 enzymes of glycolysis and gluconeogenesis, the tricarboxylic acid cycle, and glycogen metabolism were determined photometrically. The variation of several conditions showed: 1. The duration of exposure to ultrasound for the homogenization of polymorphonuclear leukocytes has no influence over a wide range of time. 2. Addition of the detergents Triton X-100 and deoxycholic acid, as well as the SH-group protector dithio-threitol, to the homogenizing medium increased the measured activities of only a few enzymes. 3. Considerable inaccuracy was encountered-when the suspension was divided into parts for homogenization with different additives; such splitting of the suspension should therefore be performed only when necessary, as in the determination of reference values (e. g. protein or DNA content of the cell suspension). 4. Twenty four-fold determination of enzyme activities from one homogenate resulted in precisions between 4.5% (citrate synthase) and 14.4% (transketolase), which is satisfactory for the low activities (as low as 1 U/l) in the homogenate. 5. The reproducibility of enzyme activities, measured in homogenates of polymorphonuclear leukocytes from different blood samples drawn simultaneously, was only slightly worse than that of the continuous measurement method itself. Thus, the precision of the measurement of enzyme activity seems to be the main determinant of the overall method. In conclusion, the described procedure of separation, homogenization, and enzyme measurement in human polymorphonuclear leukocyte meets the requirements of biochemical or clinical trials and can be recommended for clinical metabolic studies. © 1993, Walter de Gruyter. All rights reserved.

Authors: Kim Q., Schwartz H., Mccarty K., Coss J., Barnes C.
Title: Single event effects on space radiation hardened 64K SRAMs at room temperature
Affiliations: Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, CA  91109-8099, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kim, Q., Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, CA  91109-8099, United States; Schwartz, H., Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, CA  91109-8099, United States; Mccarty, K., Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, CA  91109-8099, United States; Coss, J., Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, CA  91109-8099, United States; Barnes, C., Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, CA  91109-8099, United States
Abstract: The single event upset (SEU) linear energy transfer threshold (LETth) of radiation hardened 64K Static Random Access Memories (SRAMs) has been measured with a picosecond pulsed dye laser system. These results were compared with standard heavy ion accelerator (Brookhaven National Laboratory (BNL)) measurements of the same SRAMs. With heavy ions, the LETth of the Honeywell HC6364 was 27 MeV-cm2/mg at 125°C compared with a value of 24 MeV-cm2/mg obtained with the laser. In the case of the second type of 64K SRAM, the IBM6401CRH, no upsets were observed at 125°C with the highest LET ions used at BNL. In contrast, the pulsed dye laser tests indicated a value of 90 MEV-cm2/mg at 25°C for the SEU-hardened IBM SRAM. No latchups or multiple SEUs were observed on any of the SRAMs even under worst case conditions. The results of this study suggest that the laser can be used as an inexpensive laboratory SEU prescreen tool in certain cases. © 1994IEEE.

Authors: Gaiewski W.R., Dunleavy L.P., Geis L.A.
Title: Hybrid Inductor Modeling at L-Band using 1-Port Fixtured S-Parameter Measurements
Affiliations: University of South Florida, Dept. of Elecrtical Engineering, 4202 E. Fowler Ave. ENG118, Tampa, FL  33620-5350, United States; Honeywell Inc., Space and Strategic Systems Operations, 13350 US Hwy 19 No., Clearwater, FL  34624-7290, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gaiewski, W.R., University of South Florida, Dept. of Elecrtical Engineering, 4202 E. Fowler Ave. ENG118, Tampa, FL  33620-5350, United States; Dunleavy, L.P., University of South Florida, Dept. of Elecrtical Engineering, 4202 E. Fowler Ave. ENG118, Tampa, FL  33620-5350, United States; Geis, L.A., Honeywell Inc., Space and Strategic Systems Operations, 13350 US Hwy 19 No., Clearwater, FL  34624-7290, United States
Abstract: Methods for deriving accurate L-band inductor models using 1-port fixtured S-parameter measurements are presented, along with examples of modeled inductor data. The modeled inductors include both surface mount " chip" inductors with nominal values ranging from 4.7nH to 330nH, and wire-wound " leaded" inductors with nominal values from 7.5nH to 470nH. The test fixture for the surface mount inductors consists of a CoilCraft 1-port coaxial fixture, whereas a modified SMA connector was used as a test fixture for the leaded inductors. In both cases, the measurements were taken using an HP8510B network analyzer, to allow for careful modeling of the fixture. The fixture models were used to de-embed the time-delay and energy storage effects of the fixtures from the coaxially calibrated HP8510 measurements of the fixtured inductors. Using EESof's Libra CAD package and de-embedded 1-port S-parameter data, models were developed for 33 samples of 21 inductance values of chip inductors, and 22 samples of leaded inductors. The models are seen to fit the measured data over a broad band, from low RF through resonance. Models for devices which self-resonate above 1 GHz maintain close tracking to measured data over the L-band (1-2 GHz). TRL calibrated 2-port microstrip measurements of the inductors were performed to verify the models obtained from the 1-port measured data. The 2-port measurement data is seen to track the 1-port measurements well, with some uncertainty caused by the effect of the microstrip mounting gap. Simple lumped/distributed filter circuits employing the inductors also were fabricated and tested. © 1993 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Computer aided design; Digital storage; Fixtures (tooling); Parameter estimation; Scattering parameters; Surface mount technology; Uncertainty analysis; Inductance values; Inductor modeling; Inductor models; Measurement data; Measurements of; S-parameter data; S-Parameter measurements; Surface mount inductors; Electric inductors

Authors: Fish S., Cherry J.
Title: Dynamic simulation of capacitor-based electric gun systems for naval applications
Affiliations: Naval Surface Warfare Center, Annapolis Detachment, David Taylor Research Center, Annapolis, MD 21402-5067, United States
Authors with affiliations: Fish, S., Naval Surface Warfare Center, Annapolis Detachment, David Taylor Research Center, Annapolis, MD 21402-5067, United States; Cherry, J., Naval Surface Warfare Center, Annapolis Detachment, David Taylor Research Center, Annapolis, MD 21402-5067, United States
Abstract: The shipboard application of electric gun systems technology, specifically electromagnetic (EM) or electro-thermal chemical (ETC), poses unique constraints on the required prime power supplies and power conditioning components. In some cases, a dedicated and properly sized power supply may be feasible to provide adequate electric gun system performance. However, in many cases the prime power source must be shared with the ship’s propulsion system due to limits in available ship space, allowable weight, and cost. In both of these instances, the dynamics of the propulsion power supply may have significant effect on the performance of the EM or ETC gun. This paper examines the dynamic simulation of an ETC gun system utilizing capacitor based energy storage and gas turbine prime power. A comparison of system response for both dedicated and shared prime power source configurations confirms that both modes are feasible. © 1993 IEEE

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Proceedings of the ASME Turbo Expo
Source title: Proceedings of the ASME Turbo Expo
Abstract: The proceedings contain 8 papers. The topics discussed include: biomass gasification hot gas cleanup for power generation; compressed air energy storage thermal performance improvements; evaluation of repowering cycles; development of an online electrochemical corrosion monitoring system; performance improvement in industrial gas turbines; union electric company's combustion turbine inlet air cooling study; second law approach to the analysis of blade cooling effects on gas turbine performance; and impact of ISO 9000 quality program on power generating industry.

Authors: Wyczalek F.A.
Title: Heating and Cooling Battery Electric Vehicles—The Final Barrier
Source title: IEEE Aerospace and Electronic Systems Magazine
Affiliations: HSST NA Engineering, FWLilly Inc., Bloomfield Hills MI 48301, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wyczalek, F.A., HSST NA Engineering, FWLilly Inc., Bloomfield Hills MI 48301, United States
Abstract: Battery electric vehicles (EV) present a particular challenge to the development of more efficient and effective heating and cooling systems for automotive applications. Because heating-ventilating-air conditioning (HVAC) systems are electrically powered, vehicle range is reduced when the HVAC system is operating. Consequently, it is necessary to devise new approaches which significantly reduce the HVAC energy requirements. Specifically, the summertime interior heat load must be reduced by limiting infrared (IR) energy transmission into the passenger compartment, and, heat pump coefficient of performance (COP) needs substantial improvement. Furthermore, wintertime heating and defrosting requirements may consume half the electrical energy stored in the battery if based on electrical heaters. The scope of this paper is limited to identifying and evaluating the alternative solutions to HVAC battery electric vehicles. These include: basis for determining HVAC boundary design assumptions and showing mathematical methods for estimating the HVAC load and energy requirements; evaluation of the new European and Japanese approaches to wintertime heating, such as: NaS battery, motor and component waste heat recovery, electric seat warmer, radiant foot warmer, electric windshield and backlight defrost, molten salt latent heat storage, metal hydride hydrogen storage and catalytic heater, and, liquid fueled heater. © 1993 IEEE

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Hydrology, hydraulics, and geomorphology of the Bonneville flood
Source title: Special Paper of the Geological Society of America
Abstract: Approximately 14,500 yr ago, Pleistocene Lake Bonneville discharged 4,750 km3 of water over the divide between the closed Bonneville basin and the watershed of the Snake River. The resulting flood, released near Red Rock Pass, Idaho, followed the present courses of Marsh Creek, the Portneuf River, and the Snake and Columbia Rivers before reaching the Pacific Ocean. For 1,100 km between Red Rock Pass and Lewiston, Idaho, the Bonneville Flood left a spectacular array of flood features that have allowed for geologic reconstruction and quantitative evaluation of many aspects of the flood hydrology, hydraulics, erosion, and sediment transport. Geologic evidence of maximum flood stages in conjunction with step-backwater flow modeling has furnished estimates of peak discharge and local hydraulic flow conditions for 10 separate reaches along the flood route. Peak discharge was approximately 1.0 million m3-sec-1 at the Lake Bonneville outlet near Red Rock Pass. Downstream, near Lewiston, Idaho, the maximum discharge attenuated to 0.57 to 0.62 million m3-sec-1. In part, attenuation of the peak discharge was probably the result of flow storage in the wide alluvial valleys of the western Snake River Plain. Diverse geologic and geomorphic environments along the flood route resulted in large spatial variations in the channel geometry as the flood moved downstream. Consequently, the local hydraulic conditions (flow depth, velocity, boundary shear stress) of the Bonneville Flood varied substantially within and between the study reaches. The rate of energy expenditure was also highly varied; local calculated stream power magnitudes ranged from less than 10 watts-m-2 in ponded reaches to more than 100,000 watts m-2 in major constrictions. More than 50% of the total energy loss at peak discharge was expended over a distance that encompassed less than 6% of the flood route. These spatial variations in local hydraulic conditions were profoundly important in controlling the distribution of flood processes and the resulting flood features. The deposition of tractively transported cobbles and boulders (measured clast diameters ranged from less than 10 cm to more than 10 m) were deposited in reaches of decreasing flow competence within quantitatively definable limits. The hydraulic conditions at areas of erosion were more difficult to precisely evaluate; however, erosion of basalt bedrock was primarily in reaches that had stream power magnitudes that exceeded 20,000 watts m-2. Cavitation was probably an important erosional process in areas of most intense flow conditions.
Index Keywords: Energy dissipation; Erosion; Hydraulics; Lakes; Rivers; Sediment transport; Shear flow; Shear stress; Boundary shear stress; Channel geometry; Erosional process; Hydraulic conditions; Quantitative evaluation; Snake river plains; Spatial variations; Total energy loss; Floods; basalt; bedrock; depositional environment; flow modeling; fluvial geomorphology; hydraulic property; hydrological regime; peak discharge; Pleistocene; reconstruction; shear stress; watershed; Columbia [Missouri]; Great Salt Lake; Idaho; Lewiston [Idaho]; Marsh Creek; Missouri; Portneuf River; Snake River Plain; United States; Utah

Authors: Gully J.H., Pratap S.B., Headifen R.N., Marinos C., Dick W., Goodel B.
Title: Investigation of an Alternator Charged Pulse Forming Network with Flywheel Energy Storage
Affiliations: The University of Texas at Austin, Center for Electromechanics, 10100 Burnet Rd., Bldg. 133, Austin, TX 78712, United States; FMC Corporation, 4800 East River Road, Minnesota, MN 55421, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gully, J.H., The University of Texas at Austin, Center for Electromechanics, 10100 Burnet Rd., Bldg. 133, Austin, TX 78712, United States; Pratap, S.B., The University of Texas at Austin, Center for Electromechanics, 10100 Burnet Rd., Bldg. 133, Austin, TX 78712, United States; Headifen, R.N., The University of Texas at Austin, Center for Electromechanics, 10100 Burnet Rd., Bldg. 133, Austin, TX 78712, United States; Marinos, C., FMC Corporation, 4800 East River Road, Minnesota, MN 55421, United States; Dick, W., FMC Corporation, 4800 East River Road, Minnesota, MN 55421, United States; Goodel, B., FMC Corporation, 4800 East River Road, Minnesota, MN 55421, United States
Abstract: One of the more promising electric gun system configurations utilizes a capacitor based pulse forming network to power the launcher, a limited duty, high power alternator to charge the capacitors and a composite flywheel for energy storage. This configuration combines the flexibility of a pulse forming network (PFN) with the high average power of an alternator and the high energy density of a flywheel. The alternator can be designed to directly charge the capacitors without the inverter/transformer typical of battery charged capacitor systems. Optimization will require trade-offs between energy density, voltage and efficiency. System integration is facilitated by direct coupling of the flywheel/alternator to a turbine or motor and modularity of the components. This paper presents the conceptual design of a system to power an 18 shot, salvo fire 30-mm railgun. The performance of components was selected to be slightly beyond the state of the art but achievable in the near term. For instance, the baseline PFN utilizes a 935 kJ capacitor bank made up of Aerovox 1.3 J/g, 2.5 A/J, 80% efficient capacitor technology. It was sized assuming a 33% efficiency from capacitor to launch package. These capacitors would require some development and are based on the 1.5 J/g technology developed under the BTI/Army Pulse Power Module program. The 1.5 J/g technology is based upon high voltage (24 kV), low current capacitors. 1.3 J/g is estimated for lower voltage (8 kV) higher current devices. The alternator has a power density of about 12 kW/kg. This power density is beyond the state of the art (≈ 9 kW/kg) [1] but is considered reasonable because the system does not require continuous power providing opportunities between charging cycles for cooling. Compulsators have demonstrated peak powers of 100 kW/kg [2] and are being designed to produce 500 kW/kg [3]. The energy storage flywheel design is based on the minimization of overall system mass. It is mounted integrally with the alternator rotor and is enclosed in a containment vessel. Consideration of both the flywheel and containment yields a specific geometry that has minimum mass. © 1993 IEEE

Authors: Headifen G.R., Pappas J.A., Weldon J.M., Wright J.C., Price J.H., Gully J.H., Brunson G.
Title: Preliminary Design of a 1 Gigajoule Homopolar Generator
Affiliations: Parker Kinetic Designs, Inc., 8303 MoPac, Suite C240, Austin, TX 78759, United States; Center for Electromechanics, The University of Texas at Austin, Austin, TX 78712, United States
Authors with affiliations: Headifen, G.R., Parker Kinetic Designs, Inc., 8303 MoPac, Suite C240, Austin, TX 78759, United States; Pappas, J.A., Parker Kinetic Designs, Inc., 8303 MoPac, Suite C240, Austin, TX 78759, United States; Weldon, J.M., Parker Kinetic Designs, Inc., 8303 MoPac, Suite C240, Austin, TX 78759, United States; Wright, J.C., Parker Kinetic Designs, Inc., 8303 MoPac, Suite C240, Austin, TX 78759, United States; Price, J.H., Center for Electromechanics, The University of Texas at Austin, Austin, TX 78712, United States; Gully, J.H., Center for Electromechanics, The University of Texas at Austin, Austin, TX 78712, United States; Brunson, G., Center for Electromechanics, The University of Texas at Austin, Austin, TX 78712, United States
Abstract: A high-energy, high-voltage homopolar generator has been designed. The HPG will have composite flywheels to maximize energy storage density and a multi-pass armature to achieve high output voltage. The homopolar generator is designed to discharge a constant 895 kA into a 460 V load for several seconds and recharge in less than a minute. The designed energy density is in excess of 15 J/g. Output current control will be achieved by increasing the field coil current proportionally to the decrease in rotational speed. © 1993 IEEE

Authors: Andrieu X., Fauvarque J.F.
Title: Supercapacitors for telecommunication applications
Affiliations: Alcatel Alsthm Recherche, Route de Nozay, Marcoussis, 91460, France; CNAM, 2 rue Conte, Paris, 75003, France
Authors with affiliations: Andrieu, X., Alcatel Alsthm Recherche, Route de Nozay, Marcoussis, 91460, France; Fauvarque, J.F., CNAM, 2 rue Conte, Paris, 75003, France
Abstract: Supercapacitors are electrochemical energy storage devices that can find several applications in the power systems for telecommunications. The principle of these components is explained and their relative characteristics are described. Different applications are envisioned in the stationary and portable areas. Their use would allow the realization of more reliable uninterruptible power supplies and higher performance power sources for portable telecommunications. © 1993 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Supercapacitor; Electrochemical energy storage devices; Power sources; Telecommunication applications; Telecommunication equipment

Authors: Dethlefser R., McNab I., Dobbie C., Bernhardt T., Puterbaugh R., LeVine F., Coradeschi T., Rinaldi V.
Title: Pulse Power Applications of Silicon Diodes in EML Capacitive Pulsers
Affiliations: Maxwell Laboratories, Inc., 8888 Balboa Avenue, San Diego, California 92123, United States; US Army Armament Research Development and Engineering Center (ARDEC), Picatinny, New Jersey 07806-5000, United States; International Rectifier Canada Ltd., 101 Bentley Street Markham, Ontario L3R3L1, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Dethlefser, R., Maxwell Laboratories, Inc., 8888 Balboa Avenue, San Diego, California 92123, United States; McNab, I., Maxwell Laboratories, Inc., 8888 Balboa Avenue, San Diego, California 92123, United States; Dobbie, C., Maxwell Laboratories, Inc., 8888 Balboa Avenue, San Diego, California 92123, United States; Bernhardt, T., Maxwell Laboratories, Inc., 8888 Balboa Avenue, San Diego, California 92123, United States; Puterbaugh, R., Maxwell Laboratories, Inc., 8888 Balboa Avenue, San Diego, California 92123, United States; LeVine, F., Maxwell Laboratories, Inc., 8888 Balboa Avenue, San Diego, California 92123, United States; Coradeschi, T., US Army Armament Research Development and Engineering Center (ARDEC), Picatinny, New Jersey 07806-5000, United States; Rinaldi, V., International Rectifier Canada Ltd., 101 Bentley Street Markham, Ontario L3R3L1, Canada
Abstract: Crowbar diodes are used for increasing the energy transfer from capacitive pulse forming networks. They also prevent voltage reversal on the energy storage capacitors. 52 mm diameter diodes with a 5 kV reverse blocking voltage, rated 40 kA were successfully used for the 32 MJ SSG rail gun. An uprated diode with increased current capability and a 15 kV reverse blocking voltage has been developed. Transient thermal analysis has predicted the current ratings for different pulse length. Analysis verification is obtained from destructive testing. © 1993 IEEE

Authors: Bell P.M., Kilkenny J.D., Landen O., Ress D.B., Wiedwald J.D., Bradley D.K., Oertel J., Watt R.
Title: High speed x-ray gating cameras for ICF imaging applications
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, P.O. Box 808, Livermore, CA  94550, United States; Laboratory for Laser Energetics, University of Rochester, United States; Los Alamos National Laboratory, Los Alamos, NM, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bell, P.M., Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, P.O. Box 808, Livermore, CA  94550, United States; Kilkenny, J.D., Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, P.O. Box 808, Livermore, CA  94550, United States; Landen, O., Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, P.O. Box 808, Livermore, CA  94550, United States; Ress, D.B., Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, P.O. Box 808, Livermore, CA  94550, United States; Wiedwald, J.D., Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, P.O. Box 808, Livermore, CA  94550, United States; Bradley, D.K., Laboratory for Laser Energetics, University of Rochester, United States; Oertel, J., Los Alamos National Laboratory, Los Alamos, NM, United States; Watt, R., Los Alamos National Laboratory, Los Alamos, NM, United States
Abstract: High speed, high x-ray energy imaging of implosions is a key diagnostic technique in the glass laser implosion program in the USA. With the correct x-ray energy, time gated images can measure the symmetry and mix of the imploding shell into the stagnated fuel if the spatial resolution of 10 or 5 μm matched by a temporal resolution of 100 or 50 psec. Several 100 psec microchannelplate (MCP) x-ray pin hole cameras have been installed and run on large laser systems with improving reliability. To increase the sensitivity of the imaging system a ring aperture microscope has been coupled to a gated MCP detector allowing imaging at up to 8 keV. To achieve 40 psec resolution, thinner MCP's are required. On line tests with a thin low gain, but high speed MCP, followed by a d.c. MCP for higher gain have demonstrated 40 psec gating, but the second plate may lead to an unacceptable sensitivity of the camera to hard x-rays. Off line tests have extensively investigated the properties of thinner MCP's and good agreement is seen with modeling. © 1993 SPIE. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Cameras; Explosions; Image storage tubes; Program diagnostics; Speed; X rays; Diagnostic techniques; Imaging applications; Laser implosions; Laser systems; On-line tests; Spatial resolution; Temporal resolution; X-ray energies; High speed photography

Authors: Budicin D., Hofmann I., Conte M., Schulze R., Melchert F., Salzborn E.
Title: Beam loss in heavy-ion fusion accelerators due to charge exchange scattering
Affiliations: GSI Darmstadt, P.O.B. 110552, Darmstadt 11, D-6100, Germany; Dipartimento di Fisica dell'Università, INFN, Sezione di Genova, Via Dodecaneso 33, Genova, I-16146, Italy; Institut für Kernphysik, Strahlenzentrum, Universität Giessen, Giessen, D-6300, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Budicin, D., GSI Darmstadt, P.O.B. 110552, Darmstadt 11, D-6100, Germany; Hofmann, I., GSI Darmstadt, P.O.B. 110552, Darmstadt 11, D-6100, Germany; Conte, M., Dipartimento di Fisica dell'Università, INFN, Sezione di Genova, Via Dodecaneso 33, Genova, I-16146, Italy; Schulze, R., Institut für Kernphysik, Strahlenzentrum, Universität Giessen, Giessen, D-6300, Germany; Melchert, F., Institut für Kernphysik, Strahlenzentrum, Universität Giessen, Giessen, D-6300, Germany; Salzborn, E., Institut für Kernphysik, Strahlenzentrum, Universität Giessen, Giessen, D-6300, Germany
Abstract: Beam loss due to charge exchange scattering leads to a fundamental limit for the acceptable storage time. Recently measured cross-sections for Bi1+ and Au1- are evaluated in a computer program, which takes into account the variation of beam temperature and density in the storage ring due to strong focusing. In particular we have found that in case of Bi1+ the loss is increasing with emittance, whereas for Au1- the behaviour is the opposite due to a different dependence of the ion cross-sections on collision energy. Examples are presented for driver storage rings. Several examples of synchrotrons for an experimental facility leading beyond the threshold of radiation conversion physics have been studied. © 1993 Società Italiana di Fisica.
Author Keywords: Heavy-ion-induced reactions and scattering; PACS 25.70; PACS 29.20.Dh; Storage rings

Authors: Hehu Z., Chuanzhen W.
Title: Design of YCF-1 mobile γ irradiator
Affiliations: Beijing Institute of Nuclear Engineering, Beijing, 100840, China
Authors with affiliations: Hehu, Z., Beijing Institute of Nuclear Engineering, Beijing, 100840, China; Chuanzhen, W., Beijing Institute of Nuclear Engineering, Beijing, 100840, China
Abstract: YCF-1 Mobile irradiator is designed by BINE of China. It has been put into running in YanJi city of Jilin province. It is able to be moved to border and distance places and area lumped and spreading out of agricultural products to service. It can play a important role in demonstration and extending irradiation technology in food irradiation, disinfestation, sterilization and quarantine, etc. This paper describes the features and design considerations of mobile irradiator. This irradiator adopted Cesium-137 source. The design capacity of loading source is 9.25PBq (250kCi), A half-time of Cs- 137 is 30.2 years long, exchanging source is not needed utilization rate of energy is higher, and the shielding is thinner, The Weight is lighter, The dose rate on the surface of it is 0.0025mSv/h in accordance with national standard. The internal size of irradiation room is 1800×1800×900mm (L×W×H), The sheilding of irradiation room is a steel shell filled with lead. The thickness of lead is 18cm. The irradiator is installed on a special flat truck. The size of the truck is 7000×3400×4200mm (L×W×H). The weight of irradiator is more than 80 150kw. The main components and parts of irradiator are: source, source racks and hoist, irradiation chamber, storage source chamber, the product's transport system, dose monitoring system, ventilation system and safety interlock system, etc. © 1993.

Authors: Malesani L., Rossetto L., Tenti P., Tomasin P., Zuccato A.
Title: Performance optimization of quasi-direct converters
Source title: Proceedings of Power Conversion Conference - Yokohama 1993
Affiliations: Department of Electrid Engineering, University of Padova, Via Gradenigo 6A, Padova, 35131, Italy; Department of Electronics and Informatics, University of Padova, Via Gdenigo 6/a, Padova, 35131, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Malesani, L., Department of Electrid Engineering, University of Padova, Via Gradenigo 6A, Padova, 35131, Italy; Rossetto, L., Department of Electrid Engineering, University of Padova, Via Gradenigo 6A, Padova, 35131, Italy; Tenti, P., Department of Electronics and Informatics, University of Padova, Via Gdenigo 6/a, Padova, 35131, Italy; Tomasin, P., Department of Electrid Engineering, University of Padova, Via Gradenigo 6A, Padova, 35131, Italy; Zuccato, A., Department of Electrid Engineering, University of Padova, Via Gradenigo 6A, Padova, 35131, Italy
Abstract: The paper describes a three-phase to three-phase quasi-direct power converter, i.e. a forced commutated AC/DC/AC power converter with small energy storage devices in the DC link. Since energy storage minimization calls for instantaneous input/output power balance, a proper control strategy is needed. In the paper, an effective digital control of the line current waveforms capable to work with unbalanced line and/or load voltages and providing also high power factor, is presented. After a discussion of the general properties of quasi-direct power converters, design criteria of both power and control sections are given, and experimental results of a 2 kVa prototype are reported. © 1993 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Digital control systems; Energy storage; Control sections; Control strategies; Design criteria; Digital control; Direct converter; Direct power converter; High power factor; Performance optimizations; AC-AC power converters

Authors: Sugimoto S.
Title: Power system control experiments using 1 MJ SMES
Affiliations: Chubu Electric Power Co. Inc., Electric Power Research and Development Center, 20-1, Kitasekiyama, Ohdaka-cho, Midori-ku, Nagoya, 459, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Sugimoto, S., Chubu Electric Power Co. Inc., Electric Power Research and Development Center, 20-1, Kitasekiyama, Ohdaka-cho, Midori-ku, Nagoya, 459, Japan
Abstract: Chubu Electric Power Co. Inc., developed a 1 MJ Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storage (SMES) system composed of a pulsive superconducting magnet (1000 A, 2 H) and experimental researches connecting this system to a simulated power system composed of four generators, fluctuating load and some transmission lines were carried out in the laboratory of Chubu Electric Power Co. Inc., since 1989. The purpose of this experimental researches are to investigate the effects of SMES adapting in power system control use. This paper describes the results and confirmed effects of four kinds of experiments as the following, cut-off peak demand, load leveling effect for fluctuating load, improvement of dynamic stability and frequency control effect in isolated power system. © 1993.

Authors: Tiwari G.N., Singh A.K.
Title: Thermal efficiency of collection-cum-storage solar water heater
Affiliations: Centre for Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, Hauz Khas, New Delhi, 110 016, India
Authors with affiliations: Tiwari, G.N., Centre for Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, Hauz Khas, New Delhi, 110 016, India; Singh, A.K., Centre for Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, Hauz Khas, New Delhi, 110 016, India
Abstract: In this Technical Note, an analytical expression for the thermal efficiency of a collection-cum-storage water heater, in terms of design and climatical parameters, has been derived. The effects of the design and climatical parameters on the efficiency have been discussed analytically which are in accordance with the results obtained by earlier workers. A good agreement between experimental and theoretical results was obtained. © 1992.
Author Keywords: Solar energy; Thermal efficiency; Water heater

Authors: Keilin V.
Title: Research on forced-flow cooling of large superconducting magnets in the Russian Federation
Affiliations: Kurchatov Atomic Energy Institute, Moscow, 123182, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Keilin, V., Kurchatov Atomic Energy Institute, Moscow, 123182, Russian Federation
Abstract: The benefits and drawbacks of forced-cooled superconducting magnets (FCSM) compared with pool-type magnets are well known for a long time. Several relatively large FCSM have been successfully built and tested, some to them are in continuous operation. Even more of the very large FCSM are in developmental stages for energy storage and fusion. Nevertheless many scientific and technological problems connected with FCSM are not solved yet. The cheap and reliable manufacturing processes of forced-cooled conductors are not finally developed. The same relates to the design of dielectric tube connectors. All the above-mentioned problems are discussed in the paper, which is dedicated to the late Mario Morpurgo. © 1993.

Authors: Takeo M., Sato S., Funaki K., Okada H., Ezaki T., Sumiyoshi F., Irie F., Ichiki A., Tokunaga T., Kanetaka H.
Title: Plans on developments of a SMES system in Kyushu
Affiliations: Research Institute for Superconducting Magnets, Faculty of Engineering, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Oita University, Japan; Kagoshima University, Japan; Kinki University, Japan; Kyushu Electric Power Co. Inc., Japan

Abstract: We have continued an investigation on superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES) systems. Here, we review recent progresses in the Kyushu community, in relation with a national project of SMES by the Agency of National Resources and Energy in MITI of Japan. © 1993.

Authors: Banerjee S., Banerjee P.
Title: A new performance index for parameter selection under random load changes
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur, 721 302, India; Theoretical Statistics and Mathematics Division, Indian Statistical Institute, Calcutta, 700 035, India
Authors with affiliations: Banerjee, S., Department of Electrical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur, 721 302, India; Banerjee, P., Theoretical Statistics and Mathematics Division, Indian Statistical Institute, Calcutta, 700 035, India
Abstract: Power systems experience continuous and random load changes. With the present analytical tools it is very difficult to assess the overall performance of a power system under such loading, especially if the system contains non-linear elements. As the quality of performance of the system under random disturbance is not easily quantifiable, it becomes very difficult for a designer to check the optimality of a certain parameter under all possible loading patterns. This paper attempts to overcome this difficulty by suggesting a new performance index that quantifies the quality of any power system (or any other control system) under random disturbance. © 1993.
Author Keywords: load frequency control; parameter selection; performance index; power system statistics; superconducting magnetic energy storage

Authors: Wu S.T., Weng F.S.
Title: Numerical modeling of the energy storage and release in solar flares
Source title: Journal of Atmospheric and Terrestrial Physics
Affiliations: Center for Space Plasma and Aeronomic Research, Department of Mechanical Engineering, The University of Alabama in Huntsville, Huntsville, AL 35899, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wu, S.T., Center for Space Plasma and Aeronomic Research, Department of Mechanical Engineering, The University of Alabama in Huntsville, Huntsville, AL 35899, United States; Weng, F.S., Center for Space Plasma and Aeronomic Research, Department of Mechanical Engineering, The University of Alabama in Huntsville, Huntsville, AL 35899, United States
Abstract: This paper reports on investigation of the photospheric magnetic fieldline footpoint motion (usually referred to as shear motion) and magnetic flux emerging from below the surface in relation to energy storage in a solar flare. These causality relationships are demonstrated by using numerical magnetohydrodynamic simulations. From these results, one may conclude that the energy stored in solar flares is in the form of currents. The dynamic process through which these currents reach a critical value is discussed as well as how these currents lead to energy release, such as the explosive events of solar flares. © 1993.

Authors: van den Oord G.H.J.
Title: The role of current sheets in the flare development
Affiliations: Astronomical Institute, Postbox 80.000, 3508 TA Utrecht, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: van den Oord, G.H.J., Astronomical Institute, Postbox 80.000, 3508 TA Utrecht, Netherlands
Abstract: A review is presented on the physics of energy release in current sheets during flares. The process of energy storage is discussed and it is shown how the evolution of the magnetic field may give rise to the presence of current sheets. The presently known types of magnetic energy release are discussed and attention is paid to the results of analytical/numerical models and laboratory experiments. Recent results on three-dimensional reconnection are summarized. The observational evidence that flare energy release is a highly time-dependent process puts severe constraints on the models and indicates that nonlinear processes are important. The large scale magnetic structure in which sheets are embedded is discussed for both compact and two-ribbon flares. Apart from the MHD-picture of current sheets some plasma physical aspects are discussed together with the energy partitioning in sheets (acceleration/heating). © 1993.

Authors: Kottick D., Blau M.
Title: Operational and economic benefits of battery energy storage plants
Source title: International Journal of Electrical Power and Energy Systems
Affiliations: Israel Electric Corporation, Research and Development Division, PO Box 10, Haifa, 31000, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Kottick, D., Israel Electric Corporation, Research and Development Division, PO Box 10, Haifa, 31000, Israel; Blau, M., Israel Electric Corporation, Research and Development Division, PO Box 10, Haifa, 31000, Israel
Abstract: Battery Energy Storage Plants (BESP) may provide significant dynamic operational and economic benefits to electric utilities. BESPs are composed only of static elements, hence their response to changing conditions in the power system is very fast. This paper analyses both the operational and the economic benefits of a BESP designed to supply spinning reserve and to reduce the extent of the under frequency load shedding that follows forced outages of large generating units. The analysis of the operational benefits was performed on a single area model representing the whole power system. The economic benefits were calculated with the aid of a long term generation expansion computer program and a daily operation simulation program. © 1993.
Author Keywords: battery; spinning-reserve; storage

Authors: Stöhlker Th., Mokler P.H., Beckert K., Bosch F., Eickhoff H., Franzke B., Jung M., Kandler Y., Klepper O., Kozhuharov C., Moshammer R., Nolden F., Reich H., Rymuza P., Spädtke P., Steck M.
Title: Ground-state Lamb shift for hydrogenlike uranium measured at the ESR storage ring
Affiliations: Gesellschaft für Schwerionenforschung, 6100 Darmstadt, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Stöhlker, Th., Gesellschaft für Schwerionenforschung, 6100 Darmstadt, Germany; Mokler, P.H., Gesellschaft für Schwerionenforschung, 6100 Darmstadt, Germany; Beckert, K., Gesellschaft für Schwerionenforschung, 6100 Darmstadt, Germany; Bosch, F., Gesellschaft für Schwerionenforschung, 6100 Darmstadt, Germany; Eickhoff, H., Gesellschaft für Schwerionenforschung, 6100 Darmstadt, Germany; Franzke, B., Gesellschaft für Schwerionenforschung, 6100 Darmstadt, Germany; Jung, M., Gesellschaft für Schwerionenforschung, 6100 Darmstadt, Germany; Kandler, Y., Gesellschaft für Schwerionenforschung, 6100 Darmstadt, Germany; Klepper, O., Gesellschaft für Schwerionenforschung, 6100 Darmstadt, Germany; Kozhuharov, C., Gesellschaft für Schwerionenforschung, 6100 Darmstadt, Germany; Moshammer, R., Gesellschaft für Schwerionenforschung, 6100 Darmstadt, Germany; Nolden, F., Gesellschaft für Schwerionenforschung, 6100 Darmstadt, Germany; Reich, H., Gesellschaft für Schwerionenforschung, 6100 Darmstadt, Germany; Rymuza, P., Gesellschaft für Schwerionenforschung, 6100 Darmstadt, Germany; Spädtke, P., Gesellschaft für Schwerionenforschung, 6100 Darmstadt, Germany; Steck, M., Gesellschaft für Schwerionenforschung, 6100 Darmstadt, Germany
Abstract: The Lyman α transitions of hydrogenlike uranium associated with electron capture were measured in collisions of stored bare U92+ ions with gaseous targets at the storage ring ESR. By applying x-ray-particle coincidence techniques the ground-state transition energies in the rest frame could be determined with a precision of about 600 ppm. The experimental result is in excellent agreement with the theroretical prediction for the ground-state Lamb shift in hydrogenlike uranium and is already sensitive to the 2s Lamb shift. © 1993 The American Physical Society.

Authors: Andersen L.H., Posthumus J.H., Vahtras O., Agren H., Elander N., Nunez A., Scrinzi A., Natiello M., Larsson M.
